The Chana was barely warm and tasted worse than a Tasty Bites vacuum sealed meal. The chicken tikka was bland, also barely warm, and simply didn't live up to expectations. I've had excellent tikka masala here before along with great specials and vegi korma. But this most recent meal was just bad tasting, poor conditions in the restaurant, and not worth it. They still allow you to BYOB though so at least they've got that going for them still. I'll be going to Alhamra next time though.
author: Abe G.

description:
My fiance and I were sticking to one dollar sign restaurants in the mission, and when we saw this place was BYO we were sold. Food is so good and so cheap for this area. 

We got Karahi Chicken, Bhuna, Garlic Naan, Keema Naan (with beef), rice and raita. Everything was excellent! I especially loved the Karahi chicken which had a nice kick to it. I've never had naan with beef in it and I thought the beef would be sparse, but this thing was STUFFED with beef. It was almost like a manakeesh, which is one of my favorite things. So good! 

They did have a corskscrew at the cash register (which we weren't sure about and ended up getting a twist off because we were afraid they wouldn't.) The busser was nice and super helpful in helping us find a place to sit. As others have said, you get everything yourself from the area near the cash register. 

Good, cheap food and BYOB. Really can't ask for much  more!
author: Christine U.

description: This is not a fancy place. But when all your Indian friends pick this one, you know it's good. We were fans of the Nihari and garlic naan. The mango lasso was pretty on point. It's pay at the counter when you order and sit wherever, Bollywood video going in the background and focus on the food, not the setting.
author: Joy Y.

description:
I used to come here all the time when I lived a couple blocks away.  I still dream about dipping my naan into my chicken masala sauce. Yum. I would eat before a night out on the town or I would pick up and watch a game at the house.  Either way tastes great.  I always get the same thing. 
 Chicken masala, rice, and garlic naan.  I usually end up with a big dinner and small lunch the next day.  Can't wait to go back and bring my boys!
author: Albert A.

description: I was blown away by how good their dishes were! And that's coming from someone who usually is not a huge fan of Pakistani/Indian food. All the dishes were incredibly flavorful, full of spices and depth. And their garlic naan was delicious. If you get the tea, you get unlimited refills. Ambiance maybe leaves something to be desired, but it's simplistic decor possibly adds to the authenticity of the Pakistani food experience. Definitely worth checking out!
author: Brian B.

description: Tried this place today. It was bland and the "garlic" naan was okay at best. I wouldn't eat here again. No flavor in their butter chicken or chicken tikka masala and both dishes tasted identical - like tomato sauce. Food was not even mildly spicy. I really don't understand the hype. I'll take Shalimar and its questionable public health practices  any day of the week for some of their delicious and flavorful food
author: c c.

description:
Their lamb biryani is awesome! However, be warned that the portions are huge! I didn't realize portion size and we ordered two lam biryani. We ended up packing half of it. Next time, I would order another dish since the biryani is kind of like ordering fried rice at a Chinese restaurant. 

Self serve sit down restaurant.
author: Hana A.

description:
love pakwan!

boneless chicken biryani!!!!! loveeeee!
author: Rabika S.

description: This was the closest pakistani restaurant. So i went there and it looked authentic pakistani food and food was really good no doubt. But the restrooms is so dirty. No mirror. Smells bad. The toilet seat had poop stains. That was a big turn off. Please work on that.
author: Pragya G.

description: Our go to for Indian/Pakistani pick up food in the Mission!  Our go-to items are the Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Biryani, Saag Paneer, Garlic Nan, & Raita.  Everything is consistently delicious, and it's enough food for 2 full meals for two people.  The staff is always nice, they even have our phone number/usual order in their system, so ordering is quick and easy.  Love Pakwan!
author: Bud L.

description: I love the food here. Very well cooked and flavorful. 5 stars only for food. This is a small dhabha in a middle of an amazing city. Definitely worth if you love indo pak food.
author: Monika B.

description: Iam too disappointed with the tasty of food.naans and chickens curry's was good but I ordered chicken and lamb biryani it was too worst quality and no tasty.it seems like chicken and lamb fried rice .
author: Sreedhar A.

description:
It's been awhile since I've had a poor food experience but this place takes the cake. Not only was the food subpar (this is really a compliment), but the service was absolutely horrendous. 

Service -
My girlfriend and I weren't even greeted. Instead we were thrown a menu as the man at the counter was clearly impatient waiting for us to decide. He was standing there with a scowling face, fiddling with a pile of receipts as if he was playing with a deck of cards. We ended up ordering the chicken tikka masala, bengan bhartha, and 2 servings of rice. The total should have come to roughly $18 after tax, but we were charged $24 and weren't even handed a receipt. SCAMMERS!!!! I didn't think about the total till it was too late...

Food -
At the time, it wasn't that bad but after discovering that I was over charged for some unknown reason I rather have drank sewage water from the street. At least I know what to expect. The curry's spices were complicated. I wasn't sure what I was eating. The chicken was very tough and dry and the bengan bhartha, which claimed to contain eggplant, didn't have any eggplant at all. What in the f were we paying for!?!?!? On top of that, we were responsible to grab our own drinks, utensils, and plates.

Overall - 
Hate is a pretty strong word so I'm gonna use "despise" instead, because hate is not expressive enough to describe how much this place infuriates me. Piss poor food, lousy customer service, and most likely a front for scamming customers for their money. TRY AT YOUR OWN RISK AND QUESTION THEIR PRICING!!!!!!!!!
author: Julian T.

description:
I like this place for some filling takeout.

My boyfriend and I always get the chicken tikka masala, chicken or lamb biryani, and garlic naan. Definitely recommend this combo! All of the three dishes are flavorful on their own, but they really compliment each other well when eaten together. 

The biryani is your best bet for portion size. We usually end up getting another meal out of it unless one of us is really hungry.

I also love that both the chicken tikka masala and the chicken or lamb biryani always have a generous amount of meat chunks. Even the lamb biryani! Which is pleasantly surprising to me, since the lamb biryani is only $1 more than the chicken from what I remember. 

Overall, affordable and tasty Indian food!
author: Sara L.

description:
Be smart, DON'T get any of the curries, ghoshts, kadai, whatever. Just get some grilled chunks of meat on a stick and you'll be fine. Typical of most Pakistani places, the aforementioned curries are absolutely dripping with oil. you can tilt your bowl and see the slick of oil creeping across it. The kabobs are where it's at for this place (and these types of places in general). 
One of the cool things is that you can bring your own booze and they don't really care. Seating is a little limited, probably not great for groups.
author: Samir K.

description:
Good prices and delicious indian food. However if you are into feeding your eyes with delightful cultural impressions you should consider going somewhere else - its self service and the environment is not very authentic, but I don't mind that. 

I liked the fact that you can bring your own beer - great for a beer enthusiast who's fed up with the regular beer assortments. 

Worth a try!
author: Johannes E.

description:
Solid Indian option where you can bring your own booze. This place has never let me down. 

Pros:
- reasonable prices, no tipping 
- garlic naan bread 
- byob
- lots of veg options
- friendly staff

Cons:
- none at this time
author: Sam H.

description:
Pakwan is Indian food done fast. Think Curry Up Now, but much more authentic.

The tikka masala is kind of a small portion for what you get, but it is fresh nonetheless. The garlic naan is pretty solid too, though a little burnt. Order some rice and you're good to go.
author: Casey S.

description:
Service - 7/10
Food - 9/10
Atmosphere - 9/10
Instaworthy - 7/10 

The vibe here is like a typical Indian Dhaba (street stop restaurant/stall), it's all self service and BYOB. Finding a place to sit sometimes can be difficult but the crowd comes and goes frequently so the wait time isn't too bad. 

The food is delicious, has some fairly authentic taste and the Naan and Paneer quality is perfect! The Aloo Nan was definitely my favorite. The raita is a little too bitter though.

Tip: tell them to take it easy on the spices if you're sensitive.
author: Meher G.

description:
Holy cow! Best Indian food I have ever had in my life!

I was on work trip with friends and needed a hearty lunch after flying in. We ordered lamb curry, tikka masala, tandoori chicken (amazing), garlic naan and rice. 

All of the flavors were rich and savory. The use of garlic in the cooking was amazing. There is nothing of this caliber in my hometown. I highly recommend this place.
author: Joshua J.

description:
Cash only. Order at the front. Huge portion of a "side of rice" and small portion for my actual meal of chicken tikka masala. I very easily was able to count out about 7 pieces of cubed chicken.

Delicious food but meh, something was off.
author: Kelly G.

description:
2/5 strictly for the experience. The food is actually 4.5/5!

The ambience is nasty. Unclean, and self service. 
I'd never bring my family or guests here. 

That being said, the food is actually tasty. I had the chicken masala and lamb biryani. Both were exceptional. 

Free chai also available but he cups and cutlery is visibly dirty and puts you off. 

This place is best for takeout. But then, the biryani might get cold. Sigh. 

Apparently they also let you bring in your own drinks (like beer from he store across)

Tip- get a table before you get in line to order food.
author: Arjan N.

description:
We went here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. It was almost empty. The ambiance is in tone with the neighborhood, kinda run down, very smelly and kinda broken. The place it self service so make sure you order before you sit down for the long wait.

We ordered samosas and chicken tikka kebabs for appetizers. Unfortunately they came out almost 45 minutes later, just after our entrées. The samosas were very average. The chicken tikka was very tender and flavorful and probably the only thing I liked about the meal.

We ordered a bunch of entrées:

Saag Paneer : Not bad but the spinach was overcooked till it was black and had no vibrant green colors that spinach should have.

Butter Paneer/Chicken: We ordered both of these. They were both terrible. The gravy was clearly frozen and reheated from an old batch and had no flavor whatsoever. The chicken and paneer were both overcooked and dry, again, frozen.

Daal: Tasted ok but was undercooked

Naans: Plain and Garlic naans were all undercooked and too fluffy. They lacked those slight crisp burnt bits that bring out the tandoori flavor. The Onion naan on the over hand was burnt completely black.

Veg/Lamb Biryani: Ordered both. They were very greasy but tasted ok. There was a generous portion of lamb(you guessed it, frozen) and veggies in the respective biryanis and they held the flavor from the whole spices pretty well.

Overall the food was barely average, the service was extremely slow and the ambiance is not one you would want to frequent. The one good thing though was the large portion sizes for the price. It's rare to find that in the bay area. 

I probably won't go back here or recommend it to anyone after this experience.
author: Rohan K.

description: The chicken tiki marsala was good. The wait after ordering was a bit long, but it was during lunch time. Recommend to show up before lunch time.
author: Jackson T.

description: The best food from India is here! Authentic and nothing like it! A good friend recommended us to this place and thankful that we found this jewel in the Nile of San Fran.  Must haves are:  nan (garlic), chicken (spicy with rice), and the lamb (tandoori) of course with their basmati rice (so yummy)!  Don't forget the mango lassi drink (mango pulp with yogurt).  Delectable is a word that comes to my mind when I remember Pakwan! I just wish the area was better which caused one less star.
author: Josie T.

description:
I love spices and I love curry!  Mix them all together well, then you will get a full of spices' enrichment!

Their lamb curry was nicely tender and flavored.  Their chicken masala was creamily delicious.  Order up garlic naan, dip that into the curry, then it will be perfection!

Sizable dining area!  Curry on!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Stopped in for a quick lunch while in town. Food was decent - I'd give at least 3 stars for the food. Although the chicken in the Tikka Masala was really dry (no amount of curry can correct that).  Service however was just terrible. The man handling orders mumbled and just seemed annoyed at us for being there. This place seems to be doing the fast casual thing, where you place your order, get a number, they call your number and you pick up your food. You're also expected to set your own table and serve your own water from carafes in the fridge. I don't have a problem with any of that. What I do have a problem with is unfriendly staff who are more interested in watching their TV program than helping customers. A smile would have gone a long way. 

There are so many better places in SF - skip this one.
author: Nikki R.

description: I forgot my wife name after I ate that spicy lamb biryani, coming back today and order two...
author: Tony U.

description:
I came here for dinner with a few friends and was not impressed.

We ordered the chicken tikka masala, the goat biryani, and the tandoori chicken leg. All of the meats were very dry and the curries were not that flavorful. We also ordered a few naans to try, but none really stood out.

The place felt very dirty - tables and bathrooms were not clean.
author: Alvin W.

description:
It's cheap, no frills, and you can grab mango lassi from the fridge, or grab chai from the counter.

The food is for sure oily, and sometimes I wish it had more vegetables and meat in it than just sauce, but that doesn't mean the sauce isn't delicious. By which I mean the food was delicious. Come here if you want a quick meal and don't want to talk to that many people. It's okay--I've been there, too.
author: Rosy H.

description: This is a down home cooking sub continent cuisine. It's goooooood. Self service, friendly guy at the register.!quickly cooked in an open kitchen.
author: Sanaa H.

description:
Food: We ordered a lamb biriyani, chicken tikka masala, and garlic naan  (those seem to be popular choices on Yelp). I rarely have Indian/Pakistani cuisines so I can't comment on the food authenticity, but I enjoyed the flavors very much! The chicken and parts of the lamb were kind of dry though. The prices were decent; the whole meal came out to be $26. You don't have to tip because it's self service. You go up and order at the counter and get your food when your number is called. You also need to go get water and utensils yourself, which is fine with me. 

Atmosphere: I was there on a weekday so there wasn't much of a big crowd but the place was still popular. Lots of post grad aged people for some reason, probably because it's BYOB and the prices are good for dinner. The restaurant is definitely a good place for a casual group get together.
author: Vio C.

description:
This food is delicious! I've taken the food to-go and dine in.  The guys at the register are pleasant and sometimes funny. The food comes out pretty quick. 

When dining in I'll come with several bottles of beer. IPA goes really well with the tiki masala and lab biryani. The garlic naan is my favorite, made fresh the traditional way. Give this place a try for easy, tasty and casually Indian dining.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Pakwan fills a couple niches that are highly valuable in any neighborhood--it's both the restaurant you can walk into with a big group and no reservation on a weekend night, and the place you can have a cheap, tasty meal with alcohol. I went with a large party for a Saturday dinner, and it required no planning. There was even a liquor store across the street, which someone ran off to while we waited to order, to B the B in the BYOB.

The space was very casual, with plain decor and self-seating. We ordered from a cashier and grabbed the first big table that opened up, with some help collecting chairs from the staff. There was no table service, but everyone we interacted with was friendly and competent.

We had dinner family style, ordering a nice spread that set us back something like $11 a person (though I spent a little extra to split a $3 mango lassi for dessert). The food was great. I loved the goat curry, which came with fall-off-the-bone tender goat meat in a flavorful, stewy, tomato-tinged curry. The butter chicken was lovely, with a thick, velvety sauce that was took well to a garlic nan sop. Everything else was vegetarian, and all quite good. The vegetable curry was loaded with a nice mix of vegetables--cauliflower, potato, green beans, carrots--cooked to just the right texture. The saag paneer was a decent version of the standard, and I liked the fluffy vegetable biryani. The only thing I was kind of meh on was the channa masala. I found it vaguely bland and mushy. The mango lassi was delicious, not too sweet and definitely made with some fresh, wonderful mango.

I wouldn't say Pakwan is the best Indian restaurant I've ever been to or anything, but it's pretty great and its convenience and BYOB policy make it even better. I'd come all the time if I lived in the Mission.
author: Steph C.

description: I picked up my meal and it was just rice and meat, no sauce. Didn't realize until I got back to my hotel
author: Katie C.

description: A real hole in the wall. You go up, look at the menu and order. Then you get the plates yourself as well as the water and glasses and sit a table. When your number is called , you pick up the food. And obviously the best part. EAT. The goat biryani was amazing. And so was the veggie biryani. Didn't really enjoy the Tandoori.
author: Chad P.

description:
I thought Pakwan was pretty good overall. The place is fairly casual and is self-service. You may need to wait 10-15 minutes if you go on a busy day, but generally there isn't too much of a wait. 

Below is what we got between two people (ended up being ~$20pp)

- Chicken Tikka Masala: The classic go-to dish at Indian restaurants. Had good flavours.
- Seekh Kabab: A beef kabab - it was very tender and made for a good appetizer.
- Naan (3): They were pretty good but nothing special
- Achar Ghost: A spicy lamb curry. There's a less spicy one too if you prefer that. It was good, though I thought the chicken was better.

We were stuffed by the end of the meal and couldn't even finish the third Naan.

They also have unlimited masala chai for $1. I didn't try it but my friend did and he said it was good.

Tip: Ask one person in your group to go grab a table while another goes to order for the group.
author: Tanay J.

description: I've only tried their samosas but I loved it! Definitely would like to go back to try their other items.
author: Judy K.

description:
Only 2 reasons I'll draft a review at the table. If it's bad. Or really bad.. Guess which one it was ? Yah, it was bad.

After a day of shenanigans at delores park, we wanted some cheap good eats. Is that too much to ask for ? Yelp led us here, although some friends on yelp expressed un satisfaction here, we decided to take the plunge anyways.

This place is cash only, you pour your own water, basically self service. Expect no frills or thrills here. 

I really hoped for the food to make up for the ambiance or lack there of. A disappointment it was . Bite after bite, dish after dish ... Sigh. Butter chicken, buttery it was not. Creamy it was not. Good it was not. Sour and tomatoey , yes it was. Was that what I hoped for ? Heck the eck no!!! Spicy goat , well what can I say? It tasted like goat, but buffet was still better. Iced water no ice. The bathroom door, wouldn't shut, and once it did I couldn't get back out. I was close to panic and clawing my way out, but I put some back Into it and the dungeon door swung open.. Was there one perk to this place you say? There was one dish I was pleased with was the beef kebab.. Oh mr.beef kebab, you saved this place from getting one star from me. Was the a fluke ? I will never know because I will never go back. Nevaaarrrrrr!!!!
author: Sharon N.

description: We were once seriously addicted to this place. Despite parking impossibility and nightmare, we insisted on coming here. Their dishes are the real deal, authentic and flavor explosion after another--the lamb dishes never disappoint and chicken tikka masala a winner. When their bhindi is in season, we always get it, and their bengan bhartha is another must. I'd go here so much more often were it not for my colitis, which is a nightmare situation for Indian food, because even if they leave out the chilis, which they're really good about doing, the spices will do me in. You don't go here for the ambience or decor, only for the kicking ass food. The prices seriously could not get any lower--how do they even make a profit? Did I mention their tandoori stuff? The chicken is making me salivate--super moist and tender, flavored well. Could not love this place more than  I do.
author: Ranjan P.

description: This place was quite a disappointment. The Biryani was sweet which was very odd. The Chicken Tikka Masala was missing salt and flavor. The naan however was good. But overall I do not think that we would be going back to this place any time soon.
author: Mariam C.

description: Best food of all time I am a huge fan. Great flavors and good size servings at an affordable price. They do not serve alcohol hee but will allow you to bring your own or go to the liquor store across the street.
author: Nora S.

description:
I am not sure why this place has such great reviews. This is an average Pakistani/Indian place. I had paneer makhani and garlic naan. The paneer makhani was not that great. Very mild and paneer was not fresh. The garlic naan was big and fluffy but there was too much salt in the dough which wasn't mixed properly as you can taste extremely salty naan while eating. 
Hubby's chicken tandoori was good according to him. 
The chai was welcome after walking in the cold outside. 
Overall it is cheap and fast eat if you are in area. Cash only and self service.
author: Priya A.

description: Love this place but they were out of chicken seekh kebabs the three times I have come to the 16th street location to buy them. All three times I was told they ran out earlier in the afternoon. So odd. Attention owner: How about better supplies and inventory management? Otherwise the place is superb.
author: Milana T.

description:
Totally rad how customers can BYOB!

My first time here with a friend- ordered the lamb curry, ribs, and naan. DELICIOUS! The lamb and the ribs were tender and seasoned so well. The naan is probably the best naan I've ever tasted- very fluffy, fresh, and not overly chewy or dry. The portions were more than enough for two people. 

This is definitely a MUST TRY place. I will keep coming back for more!
author: Carol D.

description:
We ordered butter chicken and chicken tikka masala. I thought they were different but turns out the only difference is that one has cilantro and the other doesnt. Same flavor. Plus they made us wait 25min. 

Mediocre Indian food. Not authentic.
author: Thanh P.

description: This place is awesome. Been going here for a few years and it's always on point with the food. The people are nice and the to go stuff is already laying out by the kitchen in case you can finish it all. The portions have always been more than generous for the price and I've never had a bad experience here.
author: East Oakland Roy ..

description: I see why my friend comes to buy lamb biyani to-go.  It is so fragrant with chunks of lamb.  That was really good and I, too, will dream about it the next time I come.  We ate and was able to doggie box a good portion for the next day's lunch.  The garlic naan was cold, but the second one was nice and hot with more garlic flavor.  The only thing is that you have to eat fast or else it will get cold fast.  No one likes cold naan.  It's $1.00 to drink the chai tea with free refills.  My favorite of the meal is .....the complimentary sauce you get-it-yourself near the cash register, inside the refrigerator.  I can drink the two sauces, especially the one with the cilantro!  It really complimented our meal and with the naan.  I wish I can come with at least 4 more people to try out all their dishes!
author: Helen L.

description:
One of my favorite comfort food places in the mission. Probably come here every other week. Quality food, always delicious and hot.
You can bring your own drinks from elsewhere, even alcohol. 
Low key atmosphere, no hipsters vibes here.
For $15 I usually get the eggplant dish (Pakwan Style), a naan, and side of rice. It easily stuffs two (small) people. 
Although not a fan of the dish myself, the biryani plates are GIGANTIC.
author: Danielle C.

description: Amazing food. Everything was delicious, and we were so glad this was open on Thanksgiving. We tried lamb curry, baigan bharta, and daily special chicken haleem. I was too full, but ordered one more chicken haleem since it was freaking awesome. The portions are good to share for 2-3 people. Garlic naan was fresh soft and delicious as well. Samosas served with chole were fantastic and so was the tandoori chicken boti. Basically seems like you cannot go wrong with the meat here. They also let you bring your own beer and wine in store.  No hard liquor though since they do not have a license for that.
author: Pancham P.

description:
My go-to spot for Indian/Pakistani food. I have nothing but good things to say about this spot. It's fresh, quick, and affordable. I highly recommend ordering the Chicken Tikka Masala, and the Lamb Biryani - it's a little spicy but very manageable with a side of their fluffy garlic naan. These dishes complement each other very well and are good size portions. 

Make sure you also try their sauces, their sweet & spicy sauce is my favorite. Order at the register, and wait for your number to be called and grab water from the fridge, cups, plates/utensils.
author: Karen C.

description:
Best Indian food in the Bay!! Yes, really!!

Wow. I can still taste the food. Where have you been all my life, Pakwan??!!! You're magic. Everything from the curry, biryani and kabobs to BYOB liquor rule. You simply rock!!

Came to this buzzy busy crowded place on a Saturday night after a full day of wine tasting/ drinking. My stomach was screaming for carbs & spice!! Every single table was filled. My gf and I waited/scouted for about 10 minutes for a table and jumped at the first one. Did I mention this place is self-serve?? It is kind of overwhelming walking in but getting the table first was a much smarter move. Let me explain.

Ambiance- 
Self-serve place with massive kitchen, cooks busting out dishes left and right. They call your number, you go get your food. So you definitely need to have a table especially if you want to order many dishes like me. It is a chill yet a super crowded  with lots of hipsters and few older people in between. The menus are at the counter- it's cash only! And you get to bring whatever liquor you want to drink. How cool is this???!!

Food-
Let's move on to the food. Hmmm Mmmm.There may or may not have been a vegetarian section on the menu but seriously? Who'd look at it when you have so many amazing meat choices. 
They have kebobs, chicken /beef/lamb curries, biryanis (chicken, mutton) and $1 chai!! Zomg. So many to choose. It is also a mixture of North Indian and South Indian food. Talk about the best of both world. Luckily, I came with indian peeps! And we all have similar taste. We got
1. Seekh Kabobs
2. Nihari with lamb
3. Spicy chicken curry ( forgot the name)
4. Mutton biryani
5. Lamb biryani
6. Naans , chai and loads of peppers on the side!

And we patiently waited for our food for a whole 7 minutes?? We went and got ourselves plates, silverware and water.And the our food was ready. Let the feast begin...Zomg zomg!

1. Biryani - it was so well spiced! So tasty and spicy!! Two non indians including me tolerated that spice really well, if not loved it. So gooooood!

2. Kabobs- nicely spiced. Tasty with loads of fresh onions and jalapenos.
3. Chicken curry  - with jalapenos and fresh ginger slices on top. This was probably the spiciest dish we had on the table.
4. Nihari with lamb shank- yummmm! This one came with a huge lamb shank. Again, so well spiced that curry is. Nice, thick, tasty with a kick. 

The four of us happily devoured our food! Various spices in their food opened our sinuses, taste buds and it hit about 6 if not all 7 taste profile. Turns out, 5 dishes were way too much for us. The portions were nice and big. And the best part- they were all around $9-$11 per entree. Did I mention how tasty each one of those dishes were??  I mean, wow! I'd probably skip the super spicy chicken next time. Or try a dish chicken dish but the rest were totally point on and mind blowing. That biryani man...Mmmm. Totally soaked up my countless glasses of wine consumption!

Did I mention that they give you a pile of peppers with every dish? It's like an added bonus heat to already nicely spiced dishes. Yes, SF has so many Indian restaurants and yes, you can find amazing biryani else where.  But this place offers a combination of dishes you wouldn't normally find in one place. The ambiance was totally relax and fun. Food was fantastic. What else can you ask for? Well except for more food!!  I wish they would fed-ex me some right now. It's like crack and I am totally hooked. 6 stars in my book!
author: Latifa S.

description: this place is amazing, honestly. my family and i go here at least twice every month for the last 18 years, and i have never not enjoyed my experience here. we order the chicken biryani and the chicken achari, both are absolutely amazing. the wait time can be a little long, but it's well worth it.
author: Rachel C.

description:
It is wonderful that they support local farms. You know that delicious Bengan Bhartha? They use eggplants from Salinas! Specifically, from Rigoyen Farms! Woohoo! How do i know? Well, after encountering multiple bits of charcoal in my take out and losing my appetite bit by bit, I decided to just scour the dish and remove all the charcoal I could find. But wait! What is this? I see something shiny amongst the eggplant. It's a... It's a... Fruit label! Yay!! Now anytime I want an eggplant, I'll know the produce code is 4081.

So, the next time you dine, you can dine in peace knowing that your carbon footprint is not that big. This only applies if you order the Bengan Bhartha (eggplant curry).

Of course, the severity of getting a produce label and bits of charcoal in my food was lost on the lady who answered the phone. I think she forgot the English language judging by how often she said "I don't understand you."
author: Gene L.

description: I got the beef boti and my wife got bone in chicken. The beef was too salty, and the chicken was pink.
author: Amir A B.

description: Delicious and authentic Pakistani food. They even have dishes like Nihari, and Chicken Haleem and multiple daily special. Fast, convenient, and so delicious!
author: Javaid K.

description: This place is a super popular place, and you usually have to wait until you can actually sit. They let you bring your own drinks from outside, so you'll see a lot of people bringing in their own six packs and what not. Their tikka masala is amazing, and the garlic naan is super bomb as well. The seating is a little informal, though, so if you're not good at hunting down tables/seats, this place may stress you out a little.
author: Do P.

description: So I tried both Shalimar and Pakwan in the same night to get an instant review and the winner hands down is Pakwan. The Chk+beef were excellent, good spice and char, the tandoori leg was on point and the Bihari kebob was good but should have been seasoned better along with a bit more tenderness, the Nan needs some flavor/salt help.....Would try next time in SF.
author: N And N K.

description: Love their chicken tiki Masala and garlic Naan. Self serve kind of place. The flavors are very authentic and my go to place if I am craving some Indian food. The only downside it's hard to find parking here.
author: Karla R.

description: I must say the food is 5 star delicious. The ambience, not so much. But then again they don't advertise their setting, do they?
author: strfrm y.

description:
Food here is delicious. 

Fair warning: It is ALWAYS crowded. Come here early! It is also BYOB so either bring some with you or go across the street to the liquor mart. 

Tip: They give more food when you order out. Do it!

Food: So much flavor! Get the the Kebabs, Chicken Biriyani, and Kheer (in the fridge). Naan should be common sense. Mango lassi is also delicious!

Bathrooms: Only one stall and messy, this needs to be fixed.
author: Chhaya N.

description:
The lamb biryani is out of this world, packed smock full of flavor! Based on this alone, I would come here again and again. I highly recommend this dish.

However, the chicken tikki masala was really disappointing. It was too acidic and tasted very tomato-y, unlike other better quality tikki masalas I've had. Thankfully, the garlic naan we got on the side to dip into was fresh and made the tikki masala edible. The mango lassi is good / average. Not the most amazing lassi I've had, but definitely passable.

Overall, Pakwan is a fast food type Indian restaurant that fulfills my Indian food cravings. It's not as cheap as I'd imagine it to be at ~$17 per person, but definitely cheaper than restaurant dining since it's a no frills type of business.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Chicken tikka (poured over) + chicken biryani = Mission takeout heaven when you inevitably begin to tire of burritos/tacos.

The chicken tikka masala was nice and creamy with tender pieces of chicken. The chicken biryani, while loaded up with rice, was fragrant and very generously portioned (note: I had to wait about 10-15 minutes for this after we got our chicken tikka).

Pretty busy spot, but the buzz is well-earned!
author: Kelly R.

description:
Chicken Tikka Boti was fresh, tender, and full of flavor. Pairs perfectly with the warm fluffy naan and Raita yogurt dip. 

Lentil Daal was very flavorful and tasty as well!

Garlic naan was good, but I prefer the plain.

Fresh, fast, and delicious! I will return and I will bring friends!

BTW - it's BYOB!
author: Kimia M.

description: Went for dinner on Saturday with a bunch of friends, we had ordered a lot of food, everything and I mean it everything was just amazing starting from the lamb, to the chicken preparation the biryani. Must try this place if you are in this area.
author: Apurv B.

description: Always a fave. Celebrated Eid here. delicious gravies and naans. Will come back many times.
author: Esther D.

description: Super solid, affordable food, especially for vegetarians. Thumbs up on the mattar paneer, dals, and saag paneer. I'd stay away from the chana masala, though.
author: Marianna M.

description:
In a city/region with really good and authentic Indian or Pakistani food, Pakwan doesn't stand out. Having heard great things about this place, I was excited to try it but left disappointed with the vegetarian options. 

I ordered the paneer makhani with garlic naan and neither stood out as anything exceptional. The paneer makhani was extremely oily to the point that there was a visible layer on top. To me, it seems it wasn't made fresh or else they wouldn't have separated. The garlic naan was stale and tough to chew. The one good thing is that this place is BYOB. 

It can be difficult to find a place to sit so you may have to wait for a while. Also, they don't care too much about customer service. 

If you're a vegetarian, I'd recommend not coming here because you can get better curries at other places. If you eat meat then you may enjoy this place.
author: Krishna S.

description: Pretty good Indian food. You order at the counter, they give you a number, they shout out your number, and you grab your food.  Nothing fancy, and you need to grab your own water, silverware, and plates.  The food was pretty delicious (I got the saag paneer and the naan), but FYI the entrees don't come with rice or naan, so you have to pay extra for that.  When we got there at 7:30, it was fairly empty.  However, by 8:30, there were people stalking our table as there were no more empty tables.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Despite all the good reviews on Yelp, I just didn't like the place at all. I just moved to San Francisco from Seattle and was craving some Indian food. 

The reviews I read said they had "fluffy" naan but the garlic naan I ordered was just crispy and dry. I love those chewy naan that can absorb all the good flavorings in the curry but this one was a disappointment. 

It's true that the restaurant has a very relaxed and chill environment, but to me there is really not much attention given to the customer. I don't think I will be back again.
author: Crystal W.

description:
Wow!
What an amazing find...in the Mission area.

great food, great prices, great staff.

The Daal was great and the chicken saag was outstanding. Throw in the garlic naan and our dinner was complete.

Cash only, and byob seems to be accepted.

A must try!!
author: Larry N.

description:
Cash only goodness, any time of day

Tough for groups over 4 otherwise you wait
Hop in line and order delicious food, grab a number and hang for just a bit before "amazing" arrives. 

LOUD. What? I can't hear anything you just said about this delicious food. At least we have BYOB so I can get bombed and pretend I hear and agree with everything you're saying. So basically, a perfect date spot.

Here's what $28 bucks buys you
Tikka masala
Pakora
Sag paner
Regular and garlic Nan

The food was fantastic for the price, I love it's BYOB so there's no hidden costs there. The service was quick and the team was very friendly and patient fto guests before us, not knowing what they wanted when they reached the front of the line. Come on kids. Peruse the menu before you reach the front. I bet you don't have change out when you arrive at a toll booth either. 

Go, stay and come back. Pakwan will be waiting for you. 
Any maybe I will too.
author: Mark F.

description: Pakwan has two branches and this is the best one amongst this two. I would not suggest the Pakwan at  O'farell because once they served me rotten fungus filled Daal. So I tried chicken biriyani, beef boti and naan here. Their biriyani is just amazing and delicious and I like the fact that they put potatoes in there as it is very similar to Bangladeshi kacchi (biriyani). If you tell them to make it spicy they will do that for you. The naan was good too but the boti was a little overcooked and burned which I didn't like. Their kitchen is way cleaner than the the other one and stuffs are nicer too.
author: Nujhat Nashia R.

description: Pakwan is a good choice for a quick lunch if you are in the vicinity and fancy some North Indian/Pakistani cuisine. This is a no frills place, you order your food, get a number and seat yourself, and pick up your food when your number is called. Food is freshly prepared and tasty. Some minor quibbles- the chicken kebab could have done better with a bit less salt, and the paneer makhani gravy was a bit sweet for our taste. Overall we were happy with our meal. Expect to pay $10-$12 per person for an entree and Nan/Rice. They also have masala chai at $1 per cup with free refills.
author: P D.

description: Great food! I just wish the portion was bigger! I enjoy every bite and the wait time is very short if you're in a rush
author: Eleazar D.

description:
Pakwan is awesome.This is one of my favorite local spots to both grab take out from and also to stop in for a casual dinner. The nicest people in the world work there and all of the food is delicious.

I've tried a lot of different dishes and they are all amazing, however I do have some favorite. My go to's are Saag Paneer, the Chicken Tikka Masala (to die for!), and the Bengan Bhartha. The Saag Paneer is fresh, full of flavor and big tender pieces of paneer. The Chicken Tikka Masala is one of the most delicious dishes I've had in SF. The sauce is delicious and perfectly thick and the chicken is very juicy. My boyfriend and I literally fight over the dish so sometimes I just get two. The Bengan Bhartha is a delicious dish of creamy eggplant. My boyfriend jokingly calls it baby food but I absolutely love it.  

One off the best things about Pakwan is also that it's BYOB. In a city full of delicious restaurants with $25 plates and $12 cocktails it's refreshing every once in awhile to go to spot where you can get a huge, delicious dinner for two for $25 and bring your own favorite beverages without even having to pay a corkage fee. There is a store right across the street where you can pick up your favorite drinks. 


Pakwan also has bottle openers, a bit of outdoor seating, and a TV. In summary, grab your favorite booze and run to Pakwan to have a delicious, fun dinner!!
author: Juliet S.

description:
Pakwan is undoubtedly one of my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the city. Although it's usually packed on most nights (particularly on Friday and Saturday nights), the food is reasonably priced and definitely worth whatever wait you might have. I'm a big fan of the fluffy naan here (get the garlic naan!!), and my standard dishes of choice are always the chicken tikka masala, chana masala, and aloo palak. I would highly recommend the samosas as well since they provide an amazing way to start off your meal. 

Pakwan has the uncanny ability to pack so much flavor into each dish. Even more, this place is BYOB...say whaaaat?! 5/5 for sure.
author: Aaron W.

description: One of the best restaurants we found while visiting San Francisco. Their food is delicious as well as less expensive. I loved the ambiance and experience. A must place to try tandoori and naan.
author: Asif A.

description:
Pakwan is an incredible restaurant; my boyfriend and I make it a point to go there if we're in the Mission or order take-out from there if we aren't. (You'll notice upon coming inside that a majority of customers are Indian which is a sure giveaway about the authenticity of the food.)

We order garlic naan (one is a huge enough serving, but when we carboload we each get our own), saag paneer, and chicken tikka masala. We're always surprised how incredible the dishes are here for the price that we're paying. The "bad service" that people might be referencing is having to get up and get your own food from the bar which is a small price to pay for such authentic food. There also might be a bit of a wait for your food, but use this time wisely and go to K+D across the street to buy some wine and beer for your meal. They do not serve alcohol in this restaurant but have a great BYOB policy and will provide you with cups/wine glasses if you ask for them.

Lovely place. No complaints. Feels like I take a little vacation to India whenever I go here!
author: Cassandra L.

description:
was super excited to try this place given all the great reviews! and i mean, the mission just has great ethnic food right?! hmmmm, maybe if you want indian, stick to the tenderloin..?

we ordered - lamb briyani, paneer tikka masala, a mixed veggie dish, garlic naan, and naan with potato.  naturally my favorite thing was the lamb dish...always goes well with tikka sauce. but the sad thing is that the paneer was so tough! not used to that texture for paneer. and the briyani and veggie dish had so many large chunks of potato! not a fan per se. WAH! 

everything is self serve, from water to plates to utensils to to-go boxes. interesting. but they do clear out your table when you leave. probably will stick to tenderloin for indian....
author: Christina L.

description: always great IndoPak food at Pakwan.  You certainly don't go for the ambiance, but if you want well-priced food that's delicious, then head on over to the Mission.  We had butter chicken (my friend had never had butter chicken before and loved it), a lamb & spinach dish, and lots of naan.  As always, it was delicious and just the right amount of spicy -- all washed down by an Allagash Triple, but for that you have to go across the street; Pakwan is BYOB.  Definitely one of my favorites for Indian food in the city
author: Scott L.

description:
Horrible service.
You walk up and pay and sit down. Drinks are self serve as well.
The food was average but the service! I think we waited like 30 minutes + for the food.
When I asked around the 20 minute mark, the guy said, oh tandoori takes extra time. Well he should have told us that when we ordered. I've had tandoori at other places before and I did not have to wait extra long for it.
The mango lassi was ok but I think it could have been colder. It was lukewarm.
The lamb curry was not bad. The flavors were good. The chicken tikka masala was decent.
The onion naan was ok but the alloo naan was better. But they were very burnt on one side which was not enjoyable at all.
author: Heejin L.

description:
The worst customer service that I have ever seen at any restaurants in San Francisco. I was expecting a lot from the restaurant but after being through such unfriendly experience, no amount of tasty food could compensate.  You pick the plates yourself. You get yourself the glasses and all the cutlery, water, tissues, essentially everything! Self service is not uncommon around the world, but this place was a next level. It makes you feel like a restaurant server, serving yourself and then paying the restaurant for being served by yourself. All the time I wondered if they would also have me wash the dishes after I am done with my meal.
I regret not asking the cashier if I could get a discount for doing everything my self. So basically, the amount you pay to the restaurant is not the "price" of the food but a "fee" for using the restaurant's place! 
Never recommending this place to anyone!
author: Sahil K.

description: Everything is very good. I had the best mango lassi and masala chai every in my live. The people who working here are also very nice.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Why does this place average four stars? The food is alright (there are so many better places in San Francisco) and everything is dirty - the plates, the cups, there's sediment in the water, the bathroom is gross. 

I did not enjoy my experience here.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
Great food! especially the Biryani, Bhuna
Chicken tikka masala sauce
author: Janaye A.

description: Omg the women's bathroom is a disaster. Sticky wet dirty I'm afraid to touch anything! And I'm being polite here....
author: Diana D.

description: Hands down some of the best food you'll have. The chicken tandoori was cooked fresh and nicely grilled, not dry at all. The chicken biryani was also fantastic. Overall a great experience for the price.
author: Arvind G.

description:
It sucks that I found out about Pakwan so late. I spent years going to Naan n Curry or other barely decent Indian food restaurants just looking for the best kinds of Indian food. Luckily i found it in Pakwan on Guerrero street. Pakwan has the best versions of Indian foods that I've had. All the flavors combine well with the spices (which very depending on how you like it) and all the different ingredients pack a punch. 

When you walk-in you're always greeted with a pleasant hello from the staff working the register, and that's also where you order you're food from. They finally added the ability to pay with debit/ credit card which makes things so much easier because it used to be a cash only establishment. After ordering, you're utensils, dishes and water are all self serve and are located by the soda machine. The portions are always plentiful so you will never leave hungry. 

Some of my favorite choices here are the: chicken tikka Masala, biryanies rices, kebabs and desserts. 

First, the chicken tikka masala it has the perfect balance of creamy sauce and tender chicken.

The chicken or lamb Biryanies (you can't go wrong) served with basmati rice and tons of other ingredients that would take to long to remember. But it's oh so good.

The tandoori BBQ kebabs come in beef or chicken varieties. Generally great just cooked right (might find some burnt ends so be aware) but very addicting. 

Finally the Mango lassi is another. All I can say is simply try it and you'll love it. Might be a bit sweet for some but that's where sharing is caring comes to mind.

You honestly can't go wrong with anything off the menu from the varieties of Nan and biryanies to the tasty desert options. Even writing this review makes me wanna go there right now and grab a bite. With this good food you can't go wrong.
author: Donald W.

description: I've been here a few times before & had the tikka masala, dash paneer and vegetable curry, which were all good, but tonight I tried the Chicken Byriani which is delicious! And huge portion on this dish - it could probably have fed 3 people. I'm always happy with leftovers. I will be back!
author: Shawna G.

description: The nicest people work at this location. They are patient in answering questions about the menu...which is delicious. It can be a quick meal or a sit and enjoy for hours. I love the food! Every time the food has been reliable and consistent. After I began going there I found out two separate households of my family have been enjoying it for years. It is very reasonably priced so I can afford to dine there and not worry about cost. I do appreciate that orders are taken at the counter and picked up so there is no actual server. This eliminates the need to tip and therefore affordable.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Awesome! Friendly Indian guys in plad flannels. The pakora was so so. This is a good spot for late night grub.
I would say this place is a 6/10 on the spice wrack.
Service with a smile for suuuuuuure.
I feel like a lot of Indian food issued no corn starch as India doesn't have a big corn thing going on..
Just because you use corn starch doesn't mean it's not Indian food.
A chef will use readily available ingredients to produce great food. Just because this may not be available where you chef reins from does not mean we shouldn't use it in cooking here.
A lot of people would call something of the sort a "fusion" however; it is not -.-
A dish with avocado at an Indian restaurant does not make it California fusion, simply using what is available.
I think this place is awesome and shall return.
Always a great time in the mission..
author: Nathan B.

description:
This is one of my go to restaurants in the city. Food is solid, consistent, and reasonably priced. I think they are cash only, so be prepared. One order of rice is usually enough for two to three people, but I would recommend getting an extra nan (those are pretty delicious and might go fast.) Their food never seems greasy or calorie laden, but if calories are a concern, the tandoori chicken is a safe choice.

Tip: Their restrooms are in the little hall in the rear of the restaurant.
author: Shoole S.

description:
I would move to San Francisco just to be closer to this! 
Just for the record- it is actually that good.

First off- quality of food is something short of amazing. 
Secondly: quantities are  generous! And you can get it to go too. So win-win. 

The way it works is, you come in, order, decide if it's to go or for the restaurant, and your food order is called out. Tables are not hard to come by, and someone is always assisting with seating arrangements. 

Nan here? Delicious!! And cheap!! Alloo Nan (Nan stuffed with potatoes) is only $3!
The Lamb Biryani (Spicy lamb with rice) was amazing, as was the Saag Paneer (Spinach & cheese) is definitely worth trying. 

Goal is to come back and try everything on this menu! 

Absolutely great.
author: Danae K.

description: Ordered tandoori chicken leg, chicken achar, garlic naan and chicken biryani. The tandoori is perfect. Chicken achar is good and flavorful. Chicken biryani is ok - not great, not bad either (don't expect hyderabadi/ dum biryani). The naan is a bit cold. It could have been served hot. Ambience isn't that great but I would definitely come back for the food.
author: Ravi Teja P.

description: Great, authentic food! Great ambiance. BYOB. What more could you ask for?!
author: Holly J.

description:
CASH ONLY!

Amazing food, fun ambiance and BYOB :)

This place rocks !

If your looking to have dinner with some friends or a loved on and grub on some delicious Indian food - this is the place to be.

I have been going to Pakwan for so many years with my family around the Bay Area. 16th and Valencia spot is where I go with my friends to enjoy the ambiance.

Weekends are busy - but still great experience.

What I recommend : lamb chops, naan, nihari, chicken leg, butter chicken or chicken tikka masala and a mango lassi on the side :)
author: Kirpa W.

description: As many others here mention, this is a self serve place. What that means is that if you want to eat in, you will have to pick up the menu yourself, order the food at the counter, find a table, wait for them to call your number, and pick up the food and cutlery yourself. There were a good number of tables for dine in and it was very loud. The knife I picked up was not properly washed and contained some leftover substance. I ordered the chicken biryani and the aloo palak. The plate of chicken biryani was a mountain of rice, enough to properly feed one hungry person. Surprisingly, the rice buried a lot of tender chicken. All the spices were still intact. The food was also very spicy which I liked. The spinach in the aloo palak was very buttery. Overall, the prices here are very reasonable and the food is delicious. Come here for the food, not for the service.
author: James S.

description:
* (SPECIAL) GOBI ALOO - 5 STARS:
Cauliflower curry with potatoes, so delicious! 

* (SPECIAL) LAMB SHANK CURRY - 5 STARS: 
Fork tender fall off the bone lamb; VERY spicy, and delicious. This was probably one of the smallest lamb shank's I've had though, I probably had about 1 big bite (shared this 3 ways).

* KEEMA NAAN ($2.99) - 3 STARS:
Beef stuffed Naan - Sounds better than it tastes. I prefer the plain naan over the garlic and stuffed. Plain ($1.00) and Garlic ($1.99) are nice and fluffy, recommend 1 per person.

* SEEKH KABAB ($2.99) - 2 STARS:
Big chunks of lean beef on a skewer, pretty dry and tough.

* TANDOORI CHICKEN BREAST / THIGH ($4.49 - $3.99) - 1 STAR:
All of it generally very dry, especially the tandoori chicken (even the dark meat chicken leg and chicken tikka masala which is essentially all cream).

* CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA ($7.99) - 1 STAR:
Very creamy, mostly sauce and just a bit of very dry boneless chicken. 

* BIRAYANIES ($6.99 - $7.99) - 4 STARS:
Huge portions of rice, my favorite is the lamb but it's not bad even with chicken.

* MIXED VEGETABLE CURRY ($5.99) - 4 STARS:
Standard but delicious mixed vegetables. They sometimes have okra (bhindi masal) but on certain days. Check out their daily vegetarian and meat specials listed on the board.

* ACHAR GOSHT ($8.99) - 4 STARS:
Love all their lamb curries. Tender, savory and full of spices.

* TANDOORI FISH ($8.99)  - 5 STARS:
One of my favorites, grilled tandoori tilapia which comes with 2 pretty large filets, vs. 4-5 small fillets at Lahore Kahare.
author: Jess C.

description: My tastes are definitely different since I don't see the 4 or 5 star appeal. The rice is dry, the naan needs to be more crisp and less dough and raw and the saag tastes so plain. I don't need a lot of cream but a little cream to cut out the bitterness and dryness would have been good. The chicken was also dry. Which is what most of the dishes tastes like....dry and lacking flavors and spices.
author: Jackie H.

description: I love this place , I always order the vegetable curry and vegetable biryani - don't forget that green sauce ! And naan bread duh . But don't even bother ordering over the phone , it's hard to understand them and you basically have to yell into your phone so they can hear you if they're busy , but other than that this place is pretty good and do offer vegetarian dishes . I never see any reviews talk about prices ( idk why)  so if you're a broke ass like me , the biryani and curry are about $8-$9 each and I never pay more than 25-30$ unless I order something else to go because besides being a broke ass , I'm also a fat ass ‍
author: Mirella A.

description:
I was never a fan of Indian/Pakistani food until
My buddy brought me here.  Everything was good.  The butter chicken was bomb.  The tandoori chicken was tasty.  They also had this bread that had beef inside it... That was Amazing too.  Great prices too.
author: David S.

description: One of the best Pakistani restaurants in the Bay Area. I have tried most of the dishes and everything is so delicious and tasty ...... the curries, biriyanis, tandooris, nans etc. Reasonable prices and fast service too!
author: Anwar I.

description: I wanted to eat something delicious for lunch since it was Friday. I took out the car from parking lot and started driving and thought of going to Pakwan and remembered their Lamb Biryani that's it I went and ordered 3 Biryani's to go he gave me big portions and surprised my wife she loved it. I have tried lots of other dishes like chicken tikka masala etc Pakwan is the place to eat and price is very reasonable and place is nice and clean excellent service
author: Gul M.

description:
F****** awesome!
Bring your own beer and order some lamb.
We'll be back!!!
author: Ole T.

description:
I used to go to naan n curry all the time in undergrad. Why didn't I know about Pakwan?! This should be everyone's staple for fast casual Indian food. You order at the register and then find yourself a table. The silverware, plates, and water are self serve. If you pay for the Chai tea it has free refills (just as naan n curry does). I like that the portions match the price. This is no buffet, but you will be happily full. I mean, sometimes you want to eat garlic naan until you are sweating garlic, but sometimes you just want satisfying Indian food. Pakwan fulfills the latter. 

A few of the dishes I've tried:
Chicken tikka masala-- my go to dish. Lived up to my tikka masala taste buds. I love the balance of buttery creaminess and acid and spice in a good tikka masala that is different to other curries. 

Spicy goat special-- Spice warning! This was one of those dishes you keep eating and then keep complaining your mouth is on fire. Goat was cooked just right. Next time I'll ask if they can knock the spice level down a touch. 

Bengan Bhartha (eggplant)-- this dish wasn't my favorite. The texture was a bit mushy and the flavors lost. Not for my taste. 

Garlic naan--I want one all to myself. Why is naan so good? Obviously essential for dipping into your main dishes.

Chai tea-- For $1, worth it. This is not that starbucks chai stuff, this is the good stuff.

Mango lassi-- I'm not a big mango lassi fan because I think it is served too sweet and the same holds true here. But the bf liked it. 

Yes, parking sucks because it is in the mission. As for a wait, both times I came for lunch and there were plenty of tables open. I can't speak to the dinner rush. And Cash only!
author: Danielle G.

description:
I've walked by for the past 2+ years and never ventured in until now! What a gem! 
This place has a sit-down atmosphere but with a grab-and-go feel.  Great place to grab something fast before heading to BART. 
They bus tables and serve food hard and fast here! Impressed with the work ethic.  They deserve every tip!  They should have a dish return bin.  I felt so bad seeing them not being able to catch their breath as they cleared one table to another.  

Everything is self-served in terms of utensils, plates  sauces, and even drinks! They have a fridge and it's on a honor system! Wow!

Mango lassi was delicious and refreshing! Yummy!
Rice is $2 extra on top of the Tikka Chicken Masala.  They don't give itemized receipts here....and I felt pinned to a corner when the cook accused me of not paying for it.  He still gave it to me to avoid the hassle but that made for a sour note on such a great experience. -1 star 

Potato naan was really nasty.  I thought it was going to be potato chunks but it was actually potato PASTE!  The naan flour was also too thick and chewy.  I don't think it was cooked all the way.
Still, I saw literally EVERY table order Garlic Naan.  Must get that next time!

PS 
The cashier is eye candy!
author: David W.

description: The best byob restaurant in all of SF. The food is delicious, the atmosphere is laid back. The only disappointment is that my stomach isn't big enough to eat more food!!
author: Kaila H.

description: Beef seekh kabab was excellent; very moist. Chicken biryani was amazing! White  b meat chicken pieces were very moist. The chicken masala didn't taste right and the chicken wasn't cooked all  the way nor was it tandoori. Rather go to Chutney or Shalimar.
author: R K.

description:
It's been a while since we've visited.   We still like the spicy lamb, eggplant dishes,  but it's not quite as good as it used to be. ..and the place has gotten way dirty especially the bathrooms and the hallway leading to it... So I may not go back there again. 

Cleanliness... 1 star

Food.... 4 stars

Service... don't expect any service :)
author: Paul K.

description: Super cheap food, a bit cramped seating and a not very attentive staff just about sums it up. It's a great spot to hit up after a drink, their naan is insanely good. Every else is about what you'd expect for the price point.
author: Kristen T.

description:
BYOB without any charges. 
Everything is self service but all the things you need is easily accessible. 
No need to wait for a server. 
Probably why the cost is low. 
Food is inexpensive but really good and flavorful. 
Relaxed atmosphere. Chillax.
author: Mai G.

description:
Being Indian and having eaten in most of the South Bay Area Indian restaurants, I was expecting a lot from Pakwan. More so, because of the glowing reviews. This place did not disappoint me one bit. Came here with a friend on Friday evening and luckily got a table. I ordered four types of naan: garlic, plain, aloo and Kheema along with my personal favorite of Mirch Salan and Aloo Palak. All four were delicious and portions were huge. 

Beware of the crowds especially on weekends.
author: Pranav B.

description:
Pakwan is unreal! The entire experience here, from the very beginning to the end, is wonderful. 

I went with my boyfriend and we took two bottles of sake, since this place is BYOB. I love restaurants like Pakwan, where you can place your order and pay before you even sit down at a table it was very casual and fun. The ambiance is intimate and loud; my boyfriend and I chatted for a while with the couple sitting next to us and had a great time. 

As for the food... Some of the best Pakistani food we have ever had. Not only was it incredibly inexpensive, the vegetarian selection was endless and mouthwatering. 

Definitely recommend Pakwan for non-meat eaters and meat-eaters alike! Top notch.
author: Alejandra L.

description:
I'll tell you what, you ever heard of those stories where people completely stumble across a place and only to find it a true gem??? Welp, that's what happened tonight. I was trying to go to San ting, closed, uber driver pulled over to help find another Chinese spot on yelp. Came up with big lantern next door. Hopped out the uber and big lantern looked like it needed some lantern oil, but Pakwan was popping! We walked in and ordered chicken biryani and nan. Ran across the street to grab a six pack because it's a byob event and boy! Pakwan is fire! Great place to come across!!! Definitely recommend!!!!
4 stars, no silverware and had to eat with plastic forks after he told me he'd get me some silverware and my yogurt mango drink never showed up. I'm about to get up and get my refund. Either way, when I come back to SF I'm hitting Pakwan.
author: Danny M.

description:
Pakwan is my favorite Pakistani/Indian restaurant. The food is fantastic, and the meat dishes are particularly good. The tandoori chicken leg is nice and juicy, and makes for a perfect side dish to one of the lamb curries -- especially the achar gosht..  The naans are freshly baked for each order, and are great for mopping up the curry sauce. 

Although I'm far from being a vegetarian, the saag paneer is probably the best I've had. 

The only downside is that it can get very hectic during dinner, and sometimes the orders can get messed up. It's a good idea to keep a close eye on the pickup counter and to make sure that they didn't lose your order.  The last time I was there, they lost my order and I was wondering why everyone who ordered after me were getting their food.

Pakwan is BYOB so bring your favorite beverage to enjoy with your meal.
author: Allen T.

description:
Came here with the bf after craving some Indian for dinner.

We ordered the chicken tikka masala and lamb shank (special of the day), along with two orders of garlic naan. The tikka masala was delicious with chunks of chicken and spiced to perfection. I soaked up the curry with the amazing naan. This is probably my new favorite spot just because of the naan. It's light, airy, and fluffy -- none of that crispy, breaks into pieces business. Amazing. My bf's lamb shank was also tasty. It just melted in our mouths.

The smell is amazing in this place, which can be good and bad. Good because it's indicative of the food. Bad because you come out smelling like the food. Oh well, I guess it's worth the trade off!
author: Leana L.

description:
I don't really know what to say. I can't tell if this was good or not. 

I kind of enjoyed my food but my Indian friend looked miserable eating his. 

4 out of 5 for that reason alone.

Plus the naan bread was a little weird... good, but weird...
author: Kyle K.

description:
Great place and value in the Mission to grab some Indian/Pakistani food.

Food=4

Chicken Tikka Masala: Rich creamy goodness. Goes well with naan or rice. Chicken was still juicy too.

Lamb Special: They were offering this lamb curry special when we visited. The curry was aggressively seasoned and the lamb was super tender.

Eggplant: I can't recall what the dish was called, but it was this mushy eggplant dish that was phenomenal.

Saag paneer: Average well done.

Service=4

You order at register, they give you your number, and you grab your own drinks and utensils. Our food took about ~30 minutes to come out. I was sad they charged for their chai tea, cause other place like Naan and Curry have it complimentary and it tastes the same.

Ambience=4

Feels like a family business and the decor seems authentic.
author: Alex C.

description:
I was looking for a quick dinner, as I didn't want to cook. So I decided to come here. 
Food was ready in less than 5 minutes, and we only had to wait in line for other 5 minutes to order. So in less than 10 minutes, dinner was ready! Awesome.

Still...Not my favorite Indian place. It's cheap, yes. But it's really noisy, dirty and the food (the only important thing) is not very good.

I love Indian food, and I find it usually very tasty and rich which was not the case here. I liked the rice though!
author: Maggie J.

description:
We got take out from Pakwan twice so far and it's been pretty satisfying. Is it the absolute best? No, but you shouldn't write it off either. I haven't found any Indian food in SF proper that has blown me away (I've been to Lahore Kitchen, Shalimar, Chutney, and Pakwan) I've heard the East Bay has all the best places, but I have yet to try anything out there. 

The nice thing is that both times the food has been hot enough even when unraveling the deliciousness at home. Their chicken tikka masala is pretty good. Today we tried the chicken achar, which was actually surprisingly amazing. I had no idea what to expect with that one. It's quite spicy, so be aware. We'll definitely order the chicken achar again. 

The aloo palak (spinach and potato) had potential to be good, but it didn't quite make it. It wasn't too creamy, so it didn't feel excessively unhealthy, but the problem was it's over the top smoked flavor - like straight up burnt. Weird and kind of didn't jive with anything else. I'm not sure if that was a mistake or it's normally that way. Naan here is excellent - chewy, soft and delicious. For take out, I'd recommend heating it up in a pan really quick if it's gotten cold. Trust me, it makes all the difference. 

One order of samosa comes with three little pockets over a small bed of chana masala. It's kinda awesome. 

When your taste buds are craving that Indian flare, Pakwan will def get the job done. Also, it's super affordable. Usually less than $30 for 2.
author: Priti K.

description: The best thing about this place is that it's BYOB, which is pretty fun! The food is solid (but not amazing) and relatively cheap, even for Indian food. The low prices mean everything is self-serve (water, silverware, plates, even picking up your order off the counter which is weird since they give you a number for the table). If you think cleanliness is next to godliness or having to repeatedly ask your dining partner "what?" amongst the background noise is annoying, go elsewhere. But give it a try if you want a place where you can claim a table for awhile and not have a waiter keep asking if there's anything else they can get you (hint, hint).
author: Cristina S.

description:
Honestly, one of the better Indian spots I've had in the city, and that says a lot.  Pakwan is not only delicious, but it's also in a convenient location and more than affordable. 

We had an array of dishes from lentils and chickpeas to naan and vegetable curry.  Classics, yes, but this space is BYOB so wave goodbye to every other Indian spot you thought you ever loved. 

My favorite dishes were the yogurt-dipped garlic naan and spinach chicken dish.  Nourishing, but not too heavy.  The veg dishes were cleaner than one would expect, so order up on the greens and beans.

The atmosphere here is casual and very spacious.  Optimal location for hitting the bars afterwards or catching a show.
author: Rachel H.

description: Been going here for years and years. The clientele is definitely changing, and the food spice level is going down. Such is the middling nature of food in the mission trying to draw in culinarily-challenged transplants. (sigh). But still one of the better affordable Indian places in the area, still top of the heap chicken tikka, and the garlic naan is still delicious. Still, gotta love the BYOB and the place across the street has some exceptional beers and wines.
author: Mike V.

description: The State of California gave a rating of 71 of 100, food inspector.... that's "F**king NASTY! No! I don't want diarrhea!
author: D M.

description: Solid Pakistani restaurant, great for sharing or groups. The biryani dishes are great and the saucy meat dishes are good too. Perhaps a little too saucy at times but everything has a great flavor and the food is consistent. A step up from other similar restaurants.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: This is a great authentic Pakistani food place , I went to school in San Francisco and always use to go to Pakwan for dinner- loved it and miss it- great Place
author: Tahir K.

description:
Amazing food but the cashier was not very friendly. Crack a smile it will go along way. 


We got the butter chicken, savory and delicious. Seehk kabobs were DELISH oh my god so amazing and so juicy paired so well with chutney and the amazing garlic naan bread. 


We also got the CTM, it was soooo good such good chicken and the sauce was great. 


I would defiantly go again, very soon. 5 stars for the food 3 stars for the service.
author: Mercedes C.

description:
What a super and simple meal! Everything was tasty. Bought a six pack of beer across street to drink with dinner. They told us to do it..:-). The price is very very affordable when eating out is getting out of control expensive if SF. 

Oh, and the Nan Bread is like a cloud! 

Thanks For The Great Experience Pakwan.
author: Matthew F.

description:
Very happily surprised and satisfied with this indian place. 

It's a no nonsense seating area, good value and good food. I like my ethnic restaurants to focus on price and quality and generally short waits are a plus. Pakwan checks all those boxes. Most dishes seem to be around or under $10. 

In a neighborhood that is dominated by Mexican taquerias (not complaining), it's nice to have some variety in cuisine. It's great for takeout as well. 

Also, this may be biased but I feel like any restaurant that does BYOB should get an automatic 4 stars...
author: Leslie W.

description:
We confessed it was our first time there, & I feel the staff took extra measures to make us feel welcome. 

No table service. Place your order at the counter, pay, & grab your dishes when your number's called. Extra plates, napkins, utensils, & water is laid out for you to take as you need. 

After trying a few items, I understand why this clean, roomy 16th street joint is busy, busy. 

Foods: 
-- lamb shank: did not try, but he ate it up!
-- chicken tikka masala: white meat. Spicy, creamy sauce that I dipped everything but my fingers into (almost, though.)
-- chicken tandoori: chunks of white meat chicken breast. Quite salty, not too dry. 
-- basmati rice: more than enough for two & flavored nicely. 
-- papadum: delicious! 
-- garlic naan: Warm, fluffy, thicker than other naan I've tried. Garlicky enough. So necessary to sop up every bit of that tikka sauce!
-- coke in a bottle 
Total: $41 

I'm fairly certain this is the first Indian restaurant I've given 5 stars. Why? Everything tasted "right" (to both of us) & we agreed -- we'd definitely return. We'll try almost any restaurant once, but we rarely find one that we'll consider adding to our rotation. 

Cash only.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
The price is right! Delicious Indian food and BYOB! 
The two down parts are hard to find parking bc of location. The bathrooms are filthy too! :( 

Food is authentic!
author: Nicky C.

description: WOW, someone messaged me with a Yelp Compliment saying that this happened to her, too.  PLEASE, watch for this and post!  This is really unfair for the business to do this purposefully.
author: Cathy U.

description:
I love this joint.
Friendly service.
Great food.
Order everything and share with friends. It's solid!
author: B T.

description:
OK this place won me over. The first thing was the staff, so sweet and patient with us being indecisive. Plus food comes out so fast and BYOB! - there is a liquor store across the street (cash only).

Chicken tikka masala was lovely. Not too creamy, just right. The garlic naan YUM. Rice, perfect. The absolute winner was the saag paneer. Ohhhhhh that paneer. In general, one of those amazingly satisfying dinners. Totally worth the many minutes spent looking for parking :p
author: Lisa K.

description:
Ever since I "moved" (squatter rights at the boyfriends) into the mission, this has been my go-to for Indian food. You order at the cashier and wait for your number to be called. It gets pretty chaotic since it's fairly busy on most nights. 

Lamb Biryani -- 5 stars 
This is my favorite biryani in all of the Bay Area. Biryani is basically Indian fried rice. Pakwan's is so flavorful. It's loaded with spices and huge, tender lamb chunks. I could eat this everyday. In fact, I think I ate it for 3 dinners in a row last week. And yes, although the portions are huge, I ate a full portion each time... No judgment. 

Fish tandoori -- 5 stars 
Tender flaky fish! Very light and healthy tasting. The fish is marinated in a spice mixture (tandoori) and roasted in a clay oven. The fish quality seems pretty decent but the serving is not quite enough to fill me up. 

Garlic naan -- 5 stars 
So fluffy and chewy! I love that it's always piping hot.

Okra curry (special) -- 4 stars 
Maybe I'm just not into okra? It was flavorful but pieces of waxy dried pepper made the texture bizarre. I had to keep picking those pieces out.
author: Xinxin W.

description:
I don't really get how this place has so much hype. We came on a Friday night around 6, and I was very unimpressed with every single item that we ordered. Their seating system is a bit chaotic and we were asked to switch tables twice. 

Saag paneer: the best thing that we ordered but still lacking in flavor. 
Tandoor chicken leg: completely dry
Chicken tikka masala: also lacking in flavor
Nan: burnt and dry

I could have used a lot more spicy and heat in these dishes. All in all, I didn't really care for any of it. The one upside is that it was reasonably priced and it's BYOB.
author: Regina L.

description:
I've been here a few times, and I although I believe the food is good, it never stood out among its similar competitors.  However, I when I ordered a Lamb Vindaloo to go the other night, I have to say it is a notch higher than some of the other places.

Your typical Indian/Pakistani restaurant set up - order at the register, grab some silverware, water/chai, and get a table.  All the usual favorites are on their menu.

What made the Lamb Vindaloo stand out for me was the Lamb itself.  Good portions of good cuts of lamb. Where as other places I have been too usually have tougher cuts, the lamb here was cooked until it was perfectly tender.  And it wasn't that Gamey.    The Vindaloo itself could have been spicier (i did ask for it spicy).
author: Veasna H.

description:
I was going to say 3 stars till I checked a calculator at home.

This was my order, verbatim: "Can I get an onion nan and saag gosht?"

+ $1.99 Onion Nan
+ $8.99 Saag Gosht
+ $0.93 8.5% tax
= $11.91

Funny thing is, I saw the register saying $12-something, which then jumped to $15-something. I tipped on top of that and paid $18 flat. But the question is what the $15 - or even the $12 - was about in the first place. I was given no receipt, so there's no way for me to know.

Another curiosity is a kabab (my friend said it was a kabab) that appeared alongside the two things I ordered. The three items were put on the counter and the cook waved me over. I pointed to the two I recognized asking if only those were mine, but he said everything was for me. I acquiesced since I didn't feel like messing around with a perceived language barrier.
