So let's pretend the cashier heard "kebab" somewhere in my order and charged accordingly.

+ $1.99 Onion Nan
+ $8.99 Saag Gosht
+ $2.49 Seekh Kabab
+ $1.14 8.5% tax
= $14.61

That still doesn't explain $15-something. I just wish I'd had a receipt so the charge could be transparent. I suggest you ask for one, and / or I suggest you take the liberty to ask what your total represents instead of just going along with it.
author: Dan B.

description:
Very affordable and solid Indian food. I had the tandoori chicken, the garlic naan and the chicken tikka masala here. The tandoori chicken leg was huge (if you're not sharing) and so flavourful. The chicken was juicy and grilled just right with a tang of spiciness. The garlic naan was fluffy and more importantly, not too dry. The chicken tikka masala was more spicy than I expected but quite creamy and went very well with the naan. Flavour wasn't as rich as in other restaurants I've been to, but still very good.

The restaurant was quite crowded and can be difficult to grab seats but food came out relatively quickly, making this a quick no-frill place to grab food for a very reasonable (and cheap in SF standards) price.
author: Michelle Y.

description: Quite possibly one of the last bites in the city that pack this much bang for your buck. The tandoori grilled chicken thigh or breast is relatively cheap (5$) for the amount and quality you get. Self serve utensils, drinks, and food (when your number is called), but also BYOB! I've had a lot of this type of food, but man do some places have a gift for maximizing spice/flavor potential or what? I mean the grilled tandoori is like an initial charcoal smoke flavor but then it's finished with a natural gas grill. All of us ate the white onions that came with the chicken because the ratio of charcoal grilled to raw sweet and crunchy fresh was perfect and consistent every time I go. Lamb curry is a go to, garlic Naan is a huge portion and everything else I've tried here is simply a notch above other similar style restaurants. Last time I went the special of the day was goat curry :o)
author: Shaun C.

description: I've been here before- years ago when I was single and free. Food is still great, not a lot of wait-- ooh, that rhymed, GREAT! Came here to meet up with a couple of girlfriends and had a wonderful night of conversing and catching up over delicious Indian food. The tikka masala is always on hit as is their tandoori chicken, marinated in lime, you can tell as soon as you chew it. Everything was delish!
author: Sharon B.

description: My go to for quick, delicious Indian.  The only negative is that it's not the healthiest food but that's par for the territory.
author: Sean O.

description:
Cheap and super yummy indian food in San Francisco!!! 
Must get their Garlic Naan!!!!! Super super delicious!! 

Chicken Tikka Masala and Chicken Biryani as well! You won't regret!
author: Charlene T.

description:
I love Pakwan - Pakistani/Indian fusion. The food was delicious!

It is super busy and packed! So make sure you are ready to stand in line!

[+] All the plates we ordered were yummy! Decent prices too!
[+] Flavors do exist!
[+] Chicken Biryani was delicious!!
[+] Lamb chops were tender and flavorful!
[+] Naan


[-] Long line (not their fault)
[-] Self seating, self serve = watching every single table like a HAWK
[-] Tables could be cleaner

Since Pakwan doesn't serve alcohol, what most customers do is they go across the street to the corner store and buy a 6-pack, wine, champagne, etc and bring it in. Pakwan is super casual!

I will be back :)
author: Tammy F.

description:
Good and fast Indian food. It is a counter-order, self-seat type of place, so faster and less formal than a typical Indian food restaurant, but a cut above a "street cart" type place.

The food was good but not the best -- it would be the type of restaurant right at home next to a university where students could come for a quick, cheap meal. No complaints about it though -- if I want super-high-end Indian food I'll go to a super-high-end restaurant (and pay their prices!)
author: Andrew S.

description: My favorite place to go to for Indian food in the city. My staple dish, chicken tikka masala, is very well done here. Spicy and sweet flavors all mixing in beautiful harmony. It's BYOB if you're into that, but I usually call my order in to-go and it's never more than about at 15 minute wait to pick up your food. Prices and portions are just right.
author: Austin W.

description: Yummy spinach dishes and great chicken tikka masala. The nan is super here. Can't beat the price for the food and it's very convenient to BART. Just writing this is making me want to go there soon.
author: Jenny B.

description:
Why did it take so long to discover Pakwan?  The garlic naan bread with the sweetest gems of tikka chicken turned me away from cheap Indian for life!  No, I can't speak for the flavor adventurers, only my generic American palette, but my palette is a picky-bish palette at that!  

The rice, the paneer, spiced sauces---we silently devoured the tasty morsels, bit by bit.  

1 star for the flashbacks to my middle school cafeteria.  They could take it up a notch without departing from the Mission district 'careless hipster joint' disposition.
author: Ashley W.

description:
It's crazy that I've been eating at Pakwan for 15 years now.  I started visiting SF in 1999 and ever since then, I've had a bond with this place.  In fact, and this is honest truth, I had a decision matrix when picking out my first SF apartment and "proximity to Pakwan" was a factor.  For realzies.

And it's funny to still see it referred to as a divey restaurant because, child, you have no idea how far it's come.  This place was the epitome of squalor back in the day, with kitchen hygiene that could be as best regarded as "discretionary" and a bathroom that was literally outside the restaurant.  It was not for the faint of heart.

But the food..

Once that chicken tikka masala and naan hit your taste buds, all the surrounding depravity just disappeared.  It was just you and some of the most delicious (and cheap) Indian food served in SF.

Roll call on my favorites:

1) Chicken Tikka Masala - could eat it with a spoon (and have a couple of time).  Best of the best
2) Saag Paneer - Don't sleep on the cheese, it's legit
3) Samosas - amazing with the tamarind sauce
4) Lamb Chops - super savory and spicy, the smell will make your mouth water
5) Garlic Naan - amazing with any curry
author: Saminda W.

description:
Got take out from this location before driving back to LA. Food stayed fresh through the six hour drive back. Only issue was the service. Which is why i can't give this place a deserving 4 stars. Also, ther'es no ambiance. Go famished and in sweats. 

We asked for the seekh kababs to be wrapped in a naan with onions, in essence making it a roll wrapped in foil so we could easily eat it while driving etc. The guy at the counter, was uncooperative and kind of rude in a how dare we ask that kind of way. I' not sure why, i mean its a fast causal place that doesn't justify the haughtiness. And the guy refused to help us out in any way when ordering. Most of the times, since i"m South Asian, I will ask the fellow South Asian for recommendations/whats fresh etc in the language spoken behind the counter. I do it when i'm around Spanish and French folks, therefore, speaking in Urdu in a very Desi like place shouldn't be rebuffed. The cashier refused to speak to us in urdu, but was speaking to his co workers in it. Super strange. 

But back to the food. I put the food boxes on my suitcase in my trunk, making it like a table in the parking lot of some random McDonalds somewhere near Fresno, and had a phenomenal meal. Tailgaiting at 10pm and it really hit the spot. The naan and kababs were excellent. The biryani is this particualr kind of spice that's amazing. Should  have bought more and eaten it all week. 

loved the refillable Chai - nice and milky! 
loved this place and i will definitely be back!
author: Farwah N.

description: I know Indian food and this place has it down. The food is amazing, the staff is pretty nice, and the food is super affordable. I never go wrong when I come here and I keep on coming back. There is a good amount of seating, but it does get full quickly so when you first get in keep an eye if there are open tables!
author: Devika B.

description: I have no idea about SFO and I just drove and picked a order for my family. That was a fantastic biryani flavor I got. I still starve for this place but as on outsider I got no luck. A must go for a desi.
author: Dipika R.

description:
Pakwan never fails to hook it up. Personal faves are: daal, chana masala, saag paneer, and garlic naan. The tamarind sauce is the perfect finishing touch to any of their dishes. 

Prices are reasonable, no-frills-kinda-place, and you're guaranteed to walk out with a satisfied tummayyy. 

Do it.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
I can see why this place is bustling around the clock. 

That being said, its unfortunately very Americanized Indian food, for Non-Indian people...

Decided to check out this place for dinner, and was definitely not impressed.

Garlic naan: Theirs suppose to be garlic right?
Chicken tikka masala: Very bland. Not enough meat. No taste for my tongue.
Rice: Very good! Should have just eaten this by itself...
Chicken tikka: Blah. Skip. Not worth it. Didn't use the correct spices. 
Mango lassi: Actually pretty good. Considering its already pre-made, and you just have to grab it from the fridge.

The service is somewhat confusing. You order, grab your number, then wait for them to call your number. 

Except its so loud with music and people talking, you can't hear your number. Oh wait, they don't call it. They play some background chime music. So EVERYONE comes rushing to the pick up window thinking its their order. Uhhhh.... are you going to use the mic right next  to you to call the number?


Go if you want tasteless mediocre food. Pass for me. Still on the hunt for an authentic Indian restaurant... (sigh)
author: Nika K.

description:
I LOVE this place. It's my favorite spot to get Indian food. 

My Favorite dishes include Bangan Bartha (Pakwan Style is a must) Chicken Tikka masala, tandoori lamb champs and Garlic Naan. I usually treat it as a family style place although you can order your own dishes if you please. 

It's BYOB so you can bring your own bottle of wine or beer, glasses provided. 

They accept cards and you order first, receive a number and take a seat. 

You are also in charge of grabbing your silver ware, napkins, forks, water Etc. Anything in the fridge you are free to grab! Except for special drinks of course. 

I Highly recommend this place!
author: Heidi H.

description:
Came with a friend, and was a little surprised with my experience. 

We ordered Chicken Saag, Chicken Vindaloo, and of course, Chicken Tikka Masala with one garlic naan & one reg. naan. Maybe we should've ordered a dish that didn't have chicken (but we love chicken..!!) because the chicken in all three dishes were incredibly dry! We ended up avoiding all chicken by mid-meal and just dipping our naan in the dishes. 

CTM tasted like tomato soup to me, Chicken Vindaloo had these peppercorn-like herb that I didn't know of until I unknowingly chewed into one and it was blasting with...pepper. Is this normal or should they have.. I don't know.. used a grinder?!?? (Unless this is some Indian herb that I'm unaware of. But still. Uncomfortably disgusting!) Chicken Saag and garlic naan was nothing special... honestly the only thing I liked was the fluffy reg. naan. (What...my favorite was the bread....) 

However, there was something fearfully hard in the texture within the dishes I ate. I had to casually spit out what was in my mouth to see little black "things" that were pretty hard... kind of like a cardboard-texture. This happened at least twice for me! Towards the end of the meal, the same thing happened to my friend, and she had no hesitation in expressing her confusion with her lovely cuss words. She proceeded to use her fork to stab the black "things" multiple times to see what the hell it was. (FYI: Still don't know what it is)

We didn't even finish half of our meal and decided to not take the leftovers home. (That's seriously a big deal for me. I NEVER WALK AWAY FROM LEFTOVERS!) I've definitely had better Indian food elsewhere. I've only been here once, but coming here once is enough for me to never come back again.
author: Kris C.

description:
I only had the Lassi here, as I awaited Picaro to open at noon for a tapas brunch. But it was lovely, and mellow, and cool and creamy and delicious. I was tempted to stay here for lunch, but deferred to my friend's tapas craving and pre-existing reservation.

I'll be back to check out the food; it smelled awesome.
author: Sean B.

description:
First and foremost, this location does have a BYOB program in place. I came a couple weeks ago with my friend after looking for places we could bring our own beer. Pakwan popped up on Google and we were only a few blocks away, sounded perfect ! 

Cuisine is delicious, tasty, and authentic. The service was alright, but it is a take a number and pick up your own order type place so I can't really complain. Pricing was honestly not that bad, we ordered 6 items and paid $40 with tip, if you add in the beer we bought, our girls night out was $60 total for 2. 

Always get the onion naan and I made the mistake of ordering just 1 for the two of us - big mistake. they have delish extra sauce with every curry dish so please do yourself a favor and get your own naan. Hahaha
author: Lynette G.

description:
So imagine my surprise as I noticed that I've passed this place way too many times without stopping for a bite. I stopped in and ordered lamb vindaloo and garlic naan. The lamb was cooked to perfection with seasoning that made my taste buds dance. 
Indian food in the US is generally dialed down in the spice department; not the case here. I tasted the gram masala as well as the coriander and some saffron. It was spicy, but so very delicious. 
It was so  good in fact that took a butter chicken to go. The restaurant is no frills but delivers a fantastic menu.
author: Freeme P.

description:
Office catered lunch from here. Portion was generous. Food was tasty. I enjoyed the mixed vegetable curry a lot. The chicken tikka masala was great too, and I loved the spice kick. The kabab unfortunately, was too dry and tough :( Would give that a pass!

Definitely looking forward to more meals from here!
author: Christina N.

description: We came in for dinner one Saturday night before going clubbing. They do get packed so arrive earlier in the evening for guaranteed seating. We ordered chicken tikka, lamb biryani, garlic naans, samosas and channa curry. The channa curry was pretty good. Tastes just like the way we make at home. The chicken tikka actually looked more like chicken karahi, this dish was actually just ok. They could have put more meat in it too, we got only 3 good pieces of chicken. Ive had better at other places. The samosas were good. It had a different taste to it almost like they use extra ingredients for the potato filling, but it had good flavor and I liked it because it was different but still tasted good. Garlic naan was VERY good. It was soft, fresh, and baked just right. The Lamb biryani was my favorite dish of the night. The lamb was cooked perfectly, the meat was soft and flavorful. The rice was good too but it was mostly the lamb that made this biryani good. The rice could use a little more spices to give it its own flavor. We had a good experience here and they do have good food. Its definitely a spot I'd hit up again when im in the city. Im hoping next time all the food tastes as great as the biryani.
author: Vince N.

description: Samosas really hit the spot on a chilly Friday night when I was starving. While most other restaurants in the area had a 30-120 minute wait, I was able to acquire this piping hot deliciousness in less than 10 minutes from order to table (a little too hot though, and I burned the roof of my mouth in my eagerness). Plus free chai tea to boot and a nice side of chickpea curry to go with the samosas couldn't really be beat. After this little snack, I had a renewed vigor to brave any other ridiculously long waits for food.
author: Audrey L.

description:
If you're looking for cheap, quick and generous portion sizes of authentic Indian food- you've come to the right place. 

Not-so-hidden in the heart of the mission, it is really quite awful finding parking in the area so expect to go around the block a few times (came here on a Sat night) or take Bart (its quite close to the station). The place was bustling and its an order at the cashier and seat yourself establishment. 

Thankfully for yelp, we read it is BYOB. so the boy and I ran to Safeway and bought some Heinekens before dinner and brought a few bottles with us. Half the restaurant had the same idea. Convenient enough- there IS a liquor store right across the street so you don't need to look far if you're craving a cold one. 

Food: Delicious! Especially the chicken tikka. The sauce is not too spicy but has the right kick and its smokey and tangy at the same time. Order some of their garlic nann and dip it in the sauce- mmmm...heaven! We ordered the vegetable biryani too as well as their Bengan Bhartha. The vegetable Biryani was a heaping plate of rice with vegetables- flavor was good. The Bengan Bhartha was  alright but nothing knock your socks off amazing. The Chicken Tikka definitely hit it out of the park though. 

As others have said, do not expect customer service here. Just a bus boy to clear table and that's it. We had to wait a few minutes for fresh forks to come out of the dishwash. I made sure to wipe all my silverware down- I've been told this place is definitely not the cleanest. 

Definitely worth a try if you're in the area!
author: Sam L.

description:
As a Pakistani, I don't prefer eating at Indian/Pakistani restaurants since I get to eat the same food every day at home. Also, my experience of desi food restaurants in the Bay Area has been so-so as I've felt that the food at most places lack some authentic touch.

So far, Pakwan has been the only Indian/Pakistani food restaurant in San Francisco that, in terms of taste, comes close to the way we cook food back home. I would definitely recommend visiting this place once if one is looking for some authentic Indian/Pakistani food.
author: Ali F.

description:
After getting my car towed (you'd think I've have learned to read street signs after 3 years in the city), and then abandoning the cluster that was Yelp Literati, my friends and I settled on meeting up for food at Pakwan instead, so at least I didn't get towed for nothing at all.

I ordered the achar gosht (a supposedly spicy lamb curry) along with an alloo nan. And, I say supposedly because, while the curry certainly had a little kick to it, it was not nearly as spicy as the cashier seemed to be implying. Both the nan and curry had good flavor, but I found the latter a bit lacking in meat and, again, spice.

Cash only, and you order your food up front at the cashier. Grab your number, and get your food when they call it!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Open and spacious, so no real accessibility issues here.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description: Not coming back! Of the eight of us who came here for dinner, five were sick all night afterward. Even if we hadn't gotten sick, the food was okay, but not excellent (four of us were Indian/Pakistani and experienced in Indian cookery).  Shalimar is MUCH better.
author: Susan A.

description: This place, self serve. Food is ok, for the price, you get what you pay for. Be aware if you don't want your jacket or nice clothes to stink, this isn't the place to wear nor bring them in. It's a place you have to try at least once and decide on your own.
author: Dang D.

description:
The fact that this place has 4 stars shows the very sad state of Indian food in the city. 

Sikh kabob: not very flavorful, and overpriced. Just kind of tastes like spicy hamburger.  Saag paneer: tastes like burnt spinach with paneer. Yum. There was a lot of paneer, which was a nice change from some of the places that basically serve creamed spinach with a couple cubes of cheese. 

Chicken tikka masala: let's all agree, if you can't nail this dish, you probably shouldn't run an "Indian" restaurant in the US.  Well they can't, and they shouldn't.  Not the worst thing I've ever eaten, but it's just really subpar.  No depth to the flavor, nothing that makes you think "Hey, this is good."

An Indian buddy of mine once told me you can tell when Pakistanis are making Indian food because there's no finesse with the spices, and everything ends up tasting like a one-dimensional Xerox copy of an Indian dish. I don't know where these guys are from, but taste-wise, that's Pakwan.
author: jared c.

description: Loved the food here. Even being vegetarian, they had good choices. Less oil and fresh. Naan's are just amazing and so does biryani.
author: Shruti A.

description:
Good in terms of chicken breast, chicken leg and naan.

They do not have great Indian curries and there are lots of good restaurants in San Francisco where you can have great Indian food. You guys can check my reviews. 

Parking: street. This is not a clean place. You  might hate it even.
author: Pratik J.

description: The lamb biriyani was good. The chicken seesh Kebob taste better than beef seesh Kebob. The garlic naan was okay. The nihari was very thin and the meat wasn't soft like it should be. We couldn't eat the nihari, so I told the girl upfront, she apologized and offered another item from the menu instead. The food is more like 3.5, the only reason I'm giving a 4 is because of customer service.
author: S Z.

description:
I have been facing this multiple times, i order a Goat biryani and Pakwan providing me Lamb biryani instead and insisting that its Goat and not lamb.
Cmon you cannot argue with me, i've 20 years of experience knowing the difference between Goat and lamb.
Whats really annoying that management argues repeatedly that since it has bones its not Lamb - Guys what you gave me is Lamb with bones - just because your bone has meat doesnt make it goat.
It does't always happen but once in every 3 times that i order goat  - i ended up getting Lamb.
Usually i order it for delivery but this time Pakwan you really stepped on my nerves when it happened while i was eating in today on May 7th 2016 all of your staff insisted that its goat - no its not!
You guys charge more for Goat biryani , save even more money by providing me lamb , insist that its not lamb and do it once in every 3 times i order it. Definitely your staff is not trained to know the difference.
This has happened at both Ofarrell and 16th st location.
Since its Bayare and no one provides you objective feedback so you guys continue deceiving customers who end up overpaying for it and then you further saving that money by utilizing lamb meat.
WAKE UP
author: Syed S.

description: I order from here every week and I love that I can have consistently good authentic Indian food on the cheap. When I call in, they know my name and my order every time, I'm not saying that they'll know yours but I'm happy with them.
author: Winston S.

description:
I like this place---quality Indian food reasonably priced.

Came here for dinner with a friend. Don't expect any kind of service (because it's self-service). Simply, order your food, take a number,  and wait until your number is called. Then go get your food. I saw a good number of people come in for checkout which I'd totally do if I lived in the Mission.

They don't serve alcohol but there's a liquor store right across the street. And they have glasses so you can still keep it somewhat classy. 

We had the Chicken Tikka Masala (very well done here), Rice & Garlic & Regular Han. All of it was delicious & filling for only $25 dollars total for us both. 

Win.
author: Juan T. K.

description:
Super casual, cheap, BYOB!  Grab a table, serve yourselves and prepare for a non-pretentious experience!  

They even provide bottle openers and wine glasses.

Lamb Biryani was flavorful. Chicken Masala, sauce was great with naan but chicken was on the dry side.  The plain Naan was better than the Garlic Naan, fluffier!

Will definitely return.
author: Kea H.

description: Amazing food! We were a large family , and are very picky when it comes to Pakistani/ Indian cuisine. The food was very authentic and tasted like our home cooked meals! We ordered from this restaurant all three days during our stay in SF , and this was our FAVORITE place from all the Pakistani/ Indian restaurants we tried . We loved their chana masala, aaloo palak, nihari, and chicken biryani. If I ever go back to SF, definitely coming to eat at pakwan, and will be sending all my friends there too!!
author: Uzma A.

description:
Pros:
- None. 

Cons:
- Worse service ever! 
- CASH only and there's no sign specifying CASH only


~Food~ 2 stars
Mediocre chicken tikki masala, there were no hint of spices. I would not come back especially if I wanted authentic Indian food. The restaurant is owned by Pakistani people and they just cook Indian food. 

~Service~ 1/2 Star
This place is a self-service restaurant. Basically, you grab your own food, your own plates, your own drinks. And if I were you, grab your own dignity and do not eat here because the servers/workers are very rude. We arrived at 11:00am and was not greeted by anyone in the restaurant. When we asked if they were open, they said not yet, so we were going to wait outside but then the gentleman that was standing there then changed his mind and said we are open. I ordered a masala chai and was not told that it would take awhile to brew. 

~Ambiance~ 1 star
Felt like I was stuck in prison since it was gloomy and dark in the restaurant and the servers/workers treated us like non-human beings. We were unsure of what to do with the dishes, so my friend had asked the guy at the register. He told my friend that we needed to wash the dishes and he had a serious look on his face. He told my friend the reason why the food was so cheap is because it is a self-service restaurant. She laughed it off and walked back towards me and we just left a tip and the dishes on the table and stormed off, never wanting to come back.
author: Rena V.

description:
There was a time when Pakwan was possibly the best Pakistani restaurant in the U.S. Sadly, that time is long gone.

Back in 2004, I remember that in one of my visits, I finished lunch (Achar Gosht AND Chicken Breast with Garlic Naan - food enough for two people!) at 2:30 pm, and was still back for an early dinner at 5:30 pm (Bihari Beef Kabab and Seekh Kabab) before taking a 9 pm red eye flight back to NYC! Yup, 10 years back the metabolism was fast enough to relegate worries about BMI to deeper recesses of the mind!

I've been back many times since, hoping that the chef will live up to those expectations, but have been disappointed by the mute flavors each time. I'm surprised at the thousand odd reviews that still find considerable merit in the restaurant's food, but expect that the low price points, generous servings, BYOB, and the hipster central Mission location, have a lot to do with that. 

If the major problem diners have is with the confusing, token based ordering system (and more importantly when to pick up your food), then the restaurant can continue to rake in money. Is it too much to expect from the "aspiring artists" to complain about tables not getting cleaned between seatings? Or, does that not even register in their stream of consciousness???

Fans of Pakistani food can do better by making their way instead to Tenderloin and dining at the reliably consistent Shalimar, though it too follows the same ancient, Indus valley civilization era model for roadside dining: cheap food, generous servings - service, ambiance, and cleanliness be damned!!!
author: Atif I.

description: One of our most favourite places in the neighbourhood. Affordable and great food. We always order to go and the staff albeit always slammed, are very nice. Haven't eaten in yet but their atmosphere is pretty nice and not super fancy schmancy. Just good food and good people. Highly recommend the Sag Dal and Garlic Naan.
author: Valerie T.

description:
The first thing I see is vegetarians go crazy, I really don't see why, because the vegetarian dishes suck! Big time ... I took a vegetarian with me and I felt sooo bad..

The meat  the Meat selections are amazing... 4 stars if I was only rooting for the meat. I felt a little misguided by the vegetarian rave by Yelp!

The tables are not so clean seating is crappy, service is provided. I didn't see it. 

I am not sure on cleanliness. 

Bring your own silver ware to be sure ...
author: Nav K.

description:
Terrible service! Filthy restaurant and rude cashiers! 

Service: As soon as we walked in the cashier threw a menu at us. After we finished ordering and paying he rudely threw the table number against the counter making it fall to the ground. At this point I was very upset.  He did not greet us or smiled once. At least the bus boy is always friendly and smiles at us. 

Cleanliness: FILTHY, FILTHY, FILTHY! Please watch your step as the restrooms are always slippery! I've ate at this location several times and there is never any seat covers in the woman's restroom. I do not recommend dinning in since the plates, utensils and cups are in a counter that is always messy and slimy. Ugh! How can someone eat at this restaurant! 

Food was served fast since it wasn't too busy. Chicken tika masala was yummy. Everything else's was just too plain. 

MAJOR WARNING: After I finished my not so pleasant meal I witnessed how the same cashier who was extremely rude to us scratch his "private/manly part" without attempting to wash his hands after. Disgusting!
author: Citlali N.

description:
The 16th street Pakwan is legit Pakistani food, which for those who don't know is similar to North Indian food, but with more meats and breads. Mmm.

So why is this pakwan legit? They do a great job with the 4 basic pillars of Pakistani food: grill/tandoori eg tandoori chicken, rice dishes eg biryani, curries eg chicken tikka masala and breads eg garlic naan. For those more adventurous I would say try more authentic dishes beyond the chicken tikka masala, chicken vindaloo and you will be surprised.

If I were to wish in a wishing well, I wished they had puri bread, Pakistani breakfast items like halwa poori , rare dishes like bone marrow soup called paya and the national dish called pulao rice. A few downsides: lines can be long, the bathroom might leave you less hygienic than before you entered it, but it's all part of the experience.
author: Haris I.

description:
wow soooo freaking delicious. Plate licking delicious, and you can bring your own booooooozzzzz, seriously!!! No charge!!!

The food was perfectly cooked, and the curry's were amazing. Oh and the Biryani...
author: yana Z.

description: I had to rescind my previous review which could have been a one-time fluke.  Or was this time the fluke?  Anyways, the paneer makhani and saag paneer were absolutely delicious.  Some of the best in the city.  The garlic naan was perfect.
author: Sanket K.

description: Tasty food reasonably priced. Outdoor sitting is perfect for those rare warm SF days.
author: Alena L.

description:
I've been coming here for a long time, and it's always really great. I love their chicken biryani. I think there's caramelized onions in there (actual ingredient may be wrong, haha) which's sweet flavor mixes incredibly well with the otherwise bolder flavors of the rice.

I also always just randomly select two curry dishes. I think I might have found a new favorite in the chicken makhanwala which has a great creamy, tomato-y taste. And my old favorite, lamb achar gosht, is good for those who like something a little spicy.

And the naan. You guys already know. Garlic or potato naan for daaaayysss.
author: Vincent C.

description: Their biryani was the best that i have ever eaten..it was very flavorful but not so spicy that you dont even taste the flavors . The palak paneer was awesome . And naan were freshly made right in front of us . The ambience is OK. Go for the food not the ambience .
author: Foodie H.

description:
Pakwan! I've always been a fan of this spot. Good food and great proportions. They really show love, two people can eat off of most of the dishes. It's really simple as far as the decor and all around aesthetic of the restaurant goes. Most Indian/Pakistan spots have the same formula, as far as the way the food is served. You usually just go up to pay and sit back down, there's no waiter. 

One of my favorites here is the Chicken Biryani, good stuff. And again the plate is huge, and only around 12 bucks.
author: Black Frankenstien ..

description: Used to be a place worth driving up from East Bay to have good grilled (tikka) meats--no more. It is usually filthy, and there are many better spots all around to make it worth our while to trek down to mission district for this one.
author: Sam M.

description: Love the food here. I always get the lamb biryani and aloo palak. The tandoori chicken is good. The sheek kebab is so so. I've had way better.
author: N B.

description: Ordered nan, chiken tandoori, chiken tika ma sala, panir, veggies in light curry, samosa. All was sooo tasty . Also you can bring your own alco. The place is so good!
author: Julia S.

description:
Terrible service, cold naan, nasty chai, frozen kheer (rice pudding).

I told both guys up front that the kheer was frozen. They denied it was and when I actually brought it to them to show them they just microwaved it--in the flimsy plastic container--which left it hot on the outside still frozen in the middle. No offer of a refund or follow-up from them to make sure it was OK.

I will never come back after this experience. I don't mind paying a couple dollars more for a better experience in this neighborhood (e.g., Aslam's Rasoi, Udupi Palace, Alhambra, or even Dosa).
author: Wendy J.

description: If you like tandoori chicken , this is the place.  It's not a fancy place, but the food quality is so great! Their naan and butter chicken are also great.
author: Ahmad A.

description: This place is good not great. I've had better biryanis. Quantity and price is golden, taste middle of the road. If you want to feed your stomach come here, if it's your ego you want served stay the hell out of here. They treat clients with total indifference. You'd fell more loved at a thrift shop!
author: Don V.

description: Love Love Love their chicken tikka masala. The saag paneer was not greasy and the naan was super fluffy and scrumptious. The only reason I'd take off a star here is for the cleanliness of the place. But really, the food is delicious. I'd definitely come back.
author: Marlene T.

description: This place is pretty good, not amazing. I used to get take-out here pretty often when I lived in the Mission, because it was so convenient. Their food is fine but not super spicy or flavorful. Good garlic naan and decent chana masala. Mostly I liked them because they're quick and convenient, but this isn't the best Indian food I've ever had.
author: Lee A.

description: Ordered the chicken tiki masala, nothing special here. I think naan and curry is even better. Also no shrimp curry dishes .
author: anthony j.

description:
Came here with my parents when we were in the area. It's pretty darn awesome. Recommendations: chicken tikka masala and garlic naan!

Doubt I'll come here again since we just happened to hear about this place when we passed through San Francisco........good place for curry though! 

4/5 stars instead of 5/5 because: The locality isn't the best. There's a tobacco store next door....be wary if you're taking kids. Also, service isn't that great.
author: Anne S.

description:
Yes--  The food is constantly tasty & layered w/ flavor. (4 stars)

Why this place only has 1 "$" sign...??

Last night I ordered  1 lamb in spice sauce , 1 tandoori chicken breast, & 1 naan.
$ 20 bucks!!!  (**(they should eliminate the inch of excess oil floating on the top of the lamb dish--I ordered take-out and had to pour it out when I got home)


All was delicious but $20 bucks for a somewhat incomplete meal (no rice, drink or additional side dish) is a lil TOO  steep for what I'm used to.

Sucks--'cause I could eat here everyday!  (...actually I mean take-out 'cause the hipsters are annoyingly loud & it's always crowded here)
author: Chapstiq G.

description:
Like my boyfriend said, people rarely say "I'm craving Indian food" but once you try Pakwan, you'll crave Indian food every day. I've never been a huge fan of Indian food, so I was a bit skeptical when my boyfriend said that Pakwan was the best Indian food he's ever had. One Tuesday afternoon at around 4pm, we decided to eat at Pakwan and since it was my first time, I was more than excited! We ordered the Saag Paneer, Chicken Boti Kabab, and Garlic Nan. Pakwan was so good that I decided to visit the next day with my sister and mom! 

Saag Paneer (Spinach Curry with cheese) - If you're Filipino or familiar with Filipino food, Saag Paneer's texture is very similar to laeng. Anyways, the Saag Paneer goes perfectly with the delicious Garlic Nan and is a very good veggie to accompany your meal. So good!

Chicken Boti Kabab - Grilled to perfection! Ah I love the smoky charcoal taste it gives off when you first bite into a piece of this delicious chicken. The lemon that accompanies it is so refreshing and gives the Chicken Boti a little bit of a tangy kick. I highly recommend this dish!

Garlic Nan - The Garlic Nan is always piping hot! There's a very subtle garlic flavor, so don't expect garlic breath after you eat this meal. 

Chicken Tikka Masala - I love chicken tikka masala and Pakwan has one of the best Chicken Tikka Masala's I've ever had! Again, it's goes perfectly with the Garlic Nan and is very flavorful.

Mango Lassi - I wish they had bigger cups! The mango lassi I had was sweet, creamy, and very good. My only gripe is that the mango lassi was not cold enough.

Both of the times I've been here, the total exceeded more than $20 which is honestly not that bad. All the items listed were enough to feed 3-4 people. Pakwan is self serve and cash only which sort of takes away from the dining experience. I heard that you can BYOB, which is cool if you have a large party. Overall, I highly recommend!
author: Joyce E.

description:
This place is so good! We found it by accident and wandered in, but by the time we left, we couldn't have been more pleased!

The portions are generous, the food is flavorful, and the prices are so fair. The only downside is that you have to get your own utensils and pick up the food yourself when your number is called. Small inconvenience for an otherwise great place.

Recommend: Chicken Tikka Masla/Garlic Naan/Samosas (pretty spicy but the Chana Masala it comes with is amazing!)
author: Yanni L.

description:
I've never been to a Indian restaurant and I didn't really know if I like this kind of food but when I was introduced to this restaurant, then it became my favorite.. It's like one of those hole in the wall kinda place, always busy. This has been our go to restaurant when it comes to Indian food.. been coming here for years and we love it.. Only downside and we really dread it every time we come here is the OIL, OIL, OIL! We hated it, we normally skim the oil out specially when we order carry out, just not to feel bad after eating the food... but I think too much oil is like a NORM for this kind of cuisine.. The price has changed over the years too.. Love it that you can bring your own "special drinks" though just keep it discreet. Parking is a headache around this area since it has alot of stuff going on in this part of the Mission, so my advice is to find parking couple blocks away, saves more time than driving around in circles trying to find a spot closer to the restaurant..
Overall, we are happy with this place, got nothing to say about the service, since its more like a pay as you order self service kinda restaurant..
author: Sarah B.

description:
Bottom line at the top: basically trader joes kinda Indian food- I think the high ratings are just because they're BYOB? Skip?
--
Why does this place have so much hype, so confused. Wanted to pick between the chicken tikka masala and the butter chicken and asked the cashier for his opinion and he told me they're the same thing. I'm not Indian so I'm not totalllyyy sure on this but I'm pretty sure it's not supposed to be that way. 

Told him to give us whatever was easier then and also got garlic naan. They have a lot TVs and will totally put on whatever game you want to see which is cool, but it's super crowded and too loud.
author: Dahlia S.

description:
Yummy food, but by no means cheap. Everything is a la carte, even the rice. So if you get tikka masala, basmati rice, 1 naan and a drink, you're looking at about almost 16. Pretty expensive for indian and everything DIY(grabbing your own plates/utensils, condiments, drinks). 
Good place to come every once in awhile.

and CASH only even though it's already 2015.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Had heard really good reviews from friends/family but thought it was just ok. we had their paneer makhani and baigan bharta (only reason i'd probably go back!). there was barely any paneer in the dish. Cousin's who are from the area love the chicken tikka masala.

Free chai!
author: Sadhna C.

description:
this place used to be great up until i guess a few weeks ago. Seems there has been some kind of sea change in the restaurant. Unfortunately the food quality took a huge hit. The chicken achar used to be spicey and delicious, now it tastes like it came out of a can. The garlic naan used to be crispy and garlicy, now its kind of soggy and bland...

pretty tragic.
author: vivace K.

description: Visiting from San Antonio and we love Indian food. We went to this place on a whim and it's amazing! Best Indian food I've ever had. Recommend the chicken tikka masala! Great customer service as well and very clean.
author: Katya C.

description:
After a fun Elite event in the Mission, as well as some excellent shopping at Idol Vintage next door, our little group needed some dinner to power back up so we sauntered into the crowded Pakwan for some Indian/Pakistani grub. I was in a good mood after a great blazer buy and wanted to treat my pals to a great meal.

We ordered chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, and the vegetable curry, as well as rice and naan. My favorites were definitely the chicken tikka and paneer, but the naan kind of disappoints. It's not chewy at all, and was mostly dried out and burned. The rice was good however.

Prices are great and the whole meal came out to just over $28. We could have easily fed a fourth person too. Service was kind of slow but that might have had something to do with the large table next to us. However, it definitely wasn't that friendly especially if you try to give them a credit card. Cash only! At least they've got some tables outside so your dog can join you for dinner. They've got to stay outside the whole time so I'd recommend bringing a few friends to make sure nobody runs off with your dog!

Food: 8/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Good food and decently priced. I ordered the chicken that was supposedly the spiciest on the menu. I wasn't too impressed with the spice level, but the taste it self was up to par.

I would just suggest wearing clothes you don't really care about since you carry the smell of the restaurant all the way home afterwards. Sit by the open windows! That helps. Also, be prepared to wait, if you're unlucky, you'll hit the crowd and be waiting a while.
author: Angela L.

description: Great and inexpensive Indian food. My adult children and their families live in San Francisco and love this place. Every time we do take out there for six adults, ordering lots of food, we pay only $60 and we still have leftovers for the next day. Be aware that authentic Indian food is very spicy. I would say hotter than standard Mexican food.
author: Patricia B.

description: My friend Grace invited a few of us to have dinner at this amazing Pakistani restaurant.  I loved it.  The vegetarian dishes were great.  The chicken curry was awesome.  Nan was chewy and delicious.  It is also a BYOB restaurant.  I'll definitely come back!
author: Wing W.

description:
Gleaming.

Not good this way: http://www.yelp.com/biz/pakwan-restaurant-san-francisco-4?hrid=-1ClDvCsXZ9Uj2CsOt2eCQ

Really good this way: Chicken Boti Wrap with marinated grilled chicken, onions and a rich but surprisingly not oily tomato sauce in naan. Felt like an oversized burrito.

Staff was on point, order delivered quick, reasonable $8 exchanged hands. Very full afterwards and very pleased. 

Expectations were low. Stars deserved are high.
author: Jason B.

description:
Pakwan offers up large portions of flavorful, cheap, Indian food!

You cant go wrong with an order of lamb biryani, chicken tikka masala, and a side of garlic naan! 

Be aware that this is completely self serve. Silverware, water cups, napkins, and extra plates, are in the door to the immediate left, and grab the to-go boxes by the pick-up area!
author: Alex H.

description:
I love good indian food and pakwan is one of the best for me!

I usually get the garlic naan, samosas, chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, and aloo ghobi. 

Everything they have here is delicious. If you are eating in or take out, the food comes out quick and is delicious everytime. 

Bonus! if you are dining in, you can help yourself to the chai tea drink yum!
author: Christine W.

description: Good Indian, you can BYOB. It's casual and light atmosphere. It's nothing to spicy and manageable menu for a group.
author: Tina W.

description:
Deliciouso... We enjoyed the tastes of the food here.. I would have given 5 stars, but we had to fight for a seat and they ran out of clean glasses and plates. If I wanted to serve myself I would stay at home ;)

So, 4 stars is for food taste which is a really great score. No customer service here, but on the positive side I saved on tipping - No tip given..
author: C L.

description:
This is definitely my favorite casual Indian restaurant because 1. the food is great (for the price your pay) 2. service is awesome and super welcoming 3. BYOB-- which is amazing for SF residents who are on a budget (which is almost everyone).

My go-tos are chicken tika masala, garlic naan, aloo palak, and rice. Sometimes the chicken can be a hit or miss-- being too dry-- but for the most part, the chicken is usually moist and flavorful.

The price is definitely right and the ambiance is great for groups-- loud and filled with laughter.

Parking around here is a bit difficult-- so try to BART or be prepared to drive around a bit. There are other great options for food around the area too: i.e. Lers Ros, Cream, and Ramen Izakaya Goku are some of my favorites.
author: Julie H.

description: First time here and I want to thank all you Yelper's on behalf of my taste buds and tummy I'm very pleased with the selection and will definitely be back! My craving has been met and I still have enough leftover for dinner! Chicken Tikka, tandoori chicken leg, garlic naan, veggie pakora and rice...all deelishis.
author: Misha P.

description:
Still a decent Indian place within walking distance from Dolores and spitting distance from the Roxie, so no complaints here, but I also realized how inconsistent the food here is sometimes. 

Pakwan definitely turns out speedy food, which is great for slamming it in your ganja'd face or when you're rushing to a show, but sometimes things are underspiced or just plain bland!
author: Kevin L.

description:
The food was quite good , we took the butter chicken and the tikka masala chicken.  Good thing its a BYOB, and its cheap. The Naan bread was fluffy and tasty. Too bad we didnt get aloo peas also :)

The fact is also that we got turned off by the place. The washrooms were awful, but when I say awful, I mean it. Not worse than an old gas station in the middle of nowhere. The difference being, people are eat to eat, so attention should be drawn to this ASAP. I even saw the pregnant lady sitting next to us going to the bathroom and returning with a ghostly face, telling her husband they had to leave NOW. so they take their order and left.

Also, you need to know there is no service. You call out the order at the counter, you pay (cash only), you have to take your own dishes to your table, grab glasses and utensils  (I guess bringing beer would be better since you get to drink wine in water glasses, not too fancy.) and you got to run after the openers. Once your order is ready, they call out your number and you gotta go to the counter and bring back the dishes to your table. Attention, we went on a tuesday and it was SO full and SO loud, we couldnt even hear ourselves. So if you like tranquillity, it is not a place for you. 

I guess in that case, since the food was good, id simply order a take out.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I came here not expecting much, just needing a place to grab a quick dinner before returning home with my friend. The food was cheap (dishes under $10), but not very well-made. Runny, watery curries for those that are supposed to be rich and creamy, and tough, low-quality goat and lamb that didn't taste all that fresh even under all those spices. But the biggest indicator of bad food? Food poisoning. I escaped relatively unscathed, but my friend was in torturous pain. 

Don't come here.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Yes, Hindi is banned in Tamil Nadu state. Telugu people are from state called Andhra Pradesh. Where, Hyderabad was a capital city. People from this city actually speak more Hindi than Telugu. It's referred to as Hyderabadi Hindi with a different accent/slang. Hindi is not banned in Andhra Pradesh. We actually love our national language. We don't know what south and north part mean because we still respect our Indian motto "Unity in Diversity".

First off all, I don't know which states come on South Indian category because, it is not an official one. This category is created by North Indians and I don't know what that means either because, I love to live in harmony. USA is great example of harmony. Best country in the world. 

Only one state i.e., Tamilnadu state in India banned Hindi because of rivalry in the past for choosing Hindi as national language over Tamil. It wasn't selected as national language even after it is being spoken by many other countries. Ex. Srilanka :)

Please write helpful reviews on food taste, customer service and hygiene.

I loved the food esp. Chicken Biryani.

Its affordable and love their customer service. I just talk to them in English. Really, don't care if they knew other languages which are of no use here in USA

Finally, I didn't mean to write Indian History in my review but, I don't want people to believe in something that isn't right and completely useless also a bit racy comments. :)
author: Tulc K.

description:
3.5 stars. I ordered the chicken tikka (dry, not masala) and my husband ordered the chicken biryani. The chicken tikka was delicious and the price was very reasonable.

The biryani was lacking spices and could not be enjoyed on its own. This was disappointing. 

The ambiance is similar to a fast food restaurant and let's just say go to the bathroom before you go. That chicken tikka makes up for it, though, so we will be coming back!
author: H K.

description:
Excuse me while my mouth starts watering.  Or shall I say salivating?  I had a to go container here of the Chicken Tikka Masala for dinner one night and I didn't have it until 2 days later when I brought it to work for some microwaveable lunch.  

While most Indian places are great, I think I have found my favorite thus far for Chicken Tikka Masala.. It was the right amount of sauce, chicken and spice and I have no hesitation recommending this place to anyone who either hasn't tried it or who craves it on the regular.. (the latter being me.)

Did I mention that it's pretty cheap too?  Awesome.
author: Lorie N.

description: I've eaten at several Pakwans around the Bay Area but 1st time at this location. The quality of food wasn't as great as the others and neither was the taste. The beef boti kabab was tough and smelled of lighter fuel. The special squash curry of the day was tasteless n oily. Biriyani was excellent and the goat meat very soft! Had to buy separate raita for it though. Don't expect great hygiene standards esp in the restroom.
author: Pompy B.

description: Pakwan is by far my favorite Indian-Pakistani restaurant in town! First off I love the casual vibe Pakwan offers, great food, great price and it's casual! My go to at Pakwan is the Bengan-Bertha Pakwan style. It's this delicious eggplant curry with just the perfect amount of spice. I always will get the garlic naan to go with this curry. Other curries I love are the Chana Masala and Saag. Anytime I have friends visiting me, I always take them to Pakwan for good food and a good price!
author: Chelsea S.

description: This place used to be so good a few years back. Was here just to have brain masala which they didn't have, and no gulaab jamun as well, whatever else we tried was no good. I miss my old Pakwan :(
author: S C.

description:
One of the best indian restaurant in SF.

Really worth going, prices are great and food -just super delicious!

I have never been disappointed so far.
author: TS P.

description:
Pakwan is a bastion of casual, cheap, in delicious in a neighborhood/city where all of those things are scarce commodities. It's become a default for ultra-casual meetups with groups of friends. I've had several birthdays and one going away party here. Everyone loves the food, loves the BYOB, and appreciates that the price point is friendly for teachers and tech millionaires alike.

Come one, come all, to Pakwan.
author: Ben P.

description:
Yup, I'm a fan. No frills place, works for my budget, really like the food. 
Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Paneer, rice, the garbanzo bean thing (channa something... I forget.) Get the naan, because you need bread to soak up sauce, but it's only ok.
Parking is an issue.
author: El B.

description:
I think I have officially grown out of this place.  It's probably exactly the same as it was in 2007.  But ya, it's 1) not that cheap (like $15 if you want a dish + rice + naan), 2) it's pretty dirty, and 3) you gotta do all the work yourself.  And there's no alcohol.

There's at least 3 Indian restaurants within 5 blocks that I'd rather go here than here.  First, you got Udupi Palace.  Amazing south Indian food, a ton of food too, and it's totally affordable.  Unfortunately, vegetarian.  But that's why you got Gajalee.  Gajalee is absolutely delicious.  Try the fish cooked in banana leaf - Amazing!  Lastly, there's Dosa, which is super nice, but definitely a different price point than the rest.  Still, worth it.

Anyway, that's my update.  I still like Pakwan, but it's not the go-to it once was.
author: Jon E.

description: This is a complete self service place. You get your own plates, cups, water, drinks, food, etc. However, it's so gooooood. I had the butter chicken from here and it was so goood. The mango lassi wasn't the best I've had, but was decent. Came here for a late dinner for the first time and was surprised how self service it was. That wasn't a problem though. It was a super casual place to just grab a bite to eat. Totally would come back here. I want to be able to try everything on the menu especially the biryani, paneer, and chicken tikka masala. I need to come back here actually. So happy to find this place. Also, it looks like this place is a BYOB and that just makes it even better.
author: Julie L.

description:
My dad used to take me here when I was 8 years old

The five stars are for my childhood nostalgia
author: Anastasia D.

description:
What else to say other than 4 stars!!!!!

1. Quick service
2. Authentic taste
3. Consistent in taste and flavor
4. Fresh and Hot
5. Flavor yeah that is important
6. Price very reasonable
author: Momo G.

description: Overly salty kebab and burnt naan left a bad taste in my mouth. Such a let down.
author: Jon T.

description: The best Indian food I have eaten in the US till date. Very authentic and filled with flavour. I loved the Chicken seekh kebab and Achari chicken. Flavorful and delicious. Must try the chicken biryani.
author: Salonee R.

description:
love their naan here, the tikki masala and the chicken w/ spinach is delicious

CASH ONLY
author: Long C.

description:
Arrived at Pakwan famished after downing some Belgian beers across the street at Gestalt. I started to rattle off a list of dishes to order: pakoras (delicious and not greasy), butter chicken (rich and delicious, eggplant, saag paneer, garlic naan and basmati rice.

Everything came out quickly, piping hot and full of flavour. I love the casualness of this place, it's super cheap and definitely hit the spot.
author: Colene C.

description: Great Pakistani dive restaurant in the Mission. Food is very good, inexpensive, quick service, great for take-out. Would prefer if the food was less greasy.
author: Sonia V.

description:
Best indian food in town if you forget the ambience. Also, don't use the restroom. Trust me on this :)

Good with Kids - Excellent
Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Excellent
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Hole in the wall.
author: Vibhor C.

description: Really enjoyed tandoori chicken, naan, and riata today...samosas too. Friendly service, great prices, yummy food.
author: Leticia G.

description: Love Pakwan - 5 stars for fast service and good food that is priced right - nothing fancy just good Pakistani food.
author: Paul B.

description: Food was good. It's not as good as shalimar but it was the closest to me so I went.  I ordered chicken tikka and Naan. I also got tandoori chicken that was great.
author: Moawia E.

description:
This restaurant is overhyped. Self served. They ran out of tandoori chicken. Best indian restaurant I like the most in Bay is Naan & Masala in Milpitas.
Dishes we had: 
1. chicken tikka masala: curry is too sour. There are many indian restaurants that have better dish than this one.
2. Biryani lamb curry: just ok, not flavorful
3. Seekh Kabab: this one is very delicious. One of the dis I will recommend.
4. Samosa: not bad but not impressive
5. Garlic Naan: one of the disappointed dishes here. It has no taste and texture is not right. 
If you wanna try authentic indian foods, I would recommend to have it in East bay or South bay, not in SF.
author: Bill W.

description:
Came for a Tuesday night dinner and the place was pretty packed, though getting a table wasn't too difficult. But it is a popular joint. We secured a table, and then some one went to order.

I'm a vegetarian, so we got one of the eggplant dishes and the palak paneer. Both were very good. We also ordered the lamb biryani and I just avoided the lamb. This dish was EXTREMELY delicious. My previous experience with biryani is that it's seasoned rice with whatever is supposed to come in it and frozen peas and carrots. This biryani was awesome because it featured caramelized onions. Soooo goood!! It was very well seasoned and the crispy caramelized onions were divine. I don't much remember the naan.

Dishes were about $7-10 each. A delicious meal at a great price, though it is "cafeteria-style" in its ambiance.
author: Christina K.

description: The flavor and spices of this delicious food makes up for any lack of atmosphere. Really well done!
author: Jason R.

description: Food was good for the price but most certainly not the best I have ever had in the city as far as Indian and Pakistani go.  Self serve is the best way to describe our family brunch outing. No one comes to the table or calls your number when drinks and food are ready. It just shows up on the counter.  We sat outside and failed to hear our number (if it was even called). I loved the tandoori taste of the beef we ordered but my husband went into a coughing fit from the smoke inside, hence our outside dining choice.  Wish the service had been friendlier and explained how the restaurant operates to us. Staff didn't look very happy.
author: Eva G.

description:
This place is great if you're in the Mission, craving Indian food, and don't want to dish out a lot of cash. We got a lot of food for under $20. It was good, filling, quick. Drinks are "get it from the cooler yourself" so make note of that, or you won't get it when they put your food out. It's also self-service, so grab a seat and wait for it to pop up on the counter, then go get it!

Between two entrees, rice, naan and drinks, it came to under $20. Not bad at all!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Food tasted good too bad I got food poisoning. As well as the group I went with. 

Was very hard to find a seat to sit.  There were a lot of fruit flies and was hard to eat our food without moving our hands to get rid of them.
author: Ree G.

description:
For indian food in the area, there are two excellent places on 16th street within a block of each other, Pakwan and al Hamra. I've tried them both, and each is a little different. Pakwan has a little bit more of an upscale fast food sort of feel while al Hamra has a more divey sit down feel. Both have excellent food, and I don't think you could go wrong with either.

I had the lamb shank special with some naan, which was nice. The lamb was well cooked and came in a flavorful curry which was delicious when soaked up with the naan. Additionally, the lamb was super tender, which is not always the case. Overall flavors were good and the price was right. I'll be back.
author: Brent W.

description:
Reliable, inexpensive, no-frills Indian-Pakistani food. Huge serving sizes, so great for family-style sharing, but not so much for dining alone - unless you're an NFL linebacker, be prepared to take at least half of your food home.

I have a serious weakness for the veggie biryani, garnished with fresh mint. The saag paneer was a bit disappointing, but the other vegetarian entrees are pretty good. 

The self-serve mango lassi is a lifesaver if you show up famished and can't even wait the (short) time it takes for your order to arrive - it's instant gratification to grab it from the fridge right after you've paid. :)

It's hard to find a seat on weekends, especially for dinner, but come in on a weekday for lunch and you nearly have the place to yourself.
author: Cat C.

description:
I heart SF food. I heart Pakwan. My friends use to bring me to this place and relax with a cup of Chai. I absolutely LOVE Northern Indian food. This is definitely Pakistan/Indian food. The flavor, the aroma, the personality of the servers. 

Note: Cash Only and BYOB. It feels like a place where everyone mingles. 
So you order at the counter, get a number, and snatch a seat. The place is really clean and the price is extremely reasonable. Under $10 can fill you up.

What I love here is:
the Mirch Salan, very very flavourful.
Chana masala
Samosas
Chicken Tikka Masala.
Garlic Naan
Lamb Biryani

This place is just YUMMY!
author: Sandra W.

description:
How does this place have such good reviews? Surely you guys must've tried out the better indian places just down the road?

I ordered butter chicken and tea and both were distinctly below par. I've had better, way better. 

Only reason I am giving it 2stars instead of 1 is because it's cheap. But then you get the quality you pay for. 

Do yourself a favor and don't jude indian/Pakistani cuisine on the basis of this place and try the other places around the block.
author: Sahil B.

description:
Great Pakistani food. It's rare that a restaurant can do good BBQ and good "curry" but this one does a decent job - although a little oily. 

Guy at register was cool and helpful. Recommended to go for a wet dish (cheaper) than having the lamb tandoori plus the other BBQ items we were getting.

Under $30 for 2, not complaining.
author: S M.

description:
Just had Pakwan yesterday with co-workers. It was delicious. We had naan, biryani rice, garbanzo bean curry, bengan bhartha, saag paneer, achar chicken, another curry chicken...I especially liked the achar chicken, it is spicy.

Friendly staff :-)
author: Elizabeth I.

description: Came here based on the 4 star average review only to find the worst chicken tikka masala I've ever had
author: Aakash D.

description:
The smell of spices beckons as you approach the door. A friend and I met here at 7pm on a Thursday and were able to get a table indoors (there are also a couple of places outdoors) before going to the counter to order. I had the saag paneer, which was good, and an order of veg samosa - they came with a side of amazing chana masala that melted in my mouth. My friend had the chicken tikka, which she said was good, and the keema (beef) nan, which was stuffed with a generous amount of ground beef. 

Great place for a casual dinner. Counter service, help yourself to water and other beverages (pay at the counter). There is an ever-present queue, because the food is THAT good. 

You can help make the queue go faster by figuring out your order before you get to the front; let others go ahead of you if you're not ready, to expedite the experience for everyone.
author: A N.

description: Great food, good choices on menu, the pudding dessert is to die for. Staff ok but could be freindlier, parking can be hard.
author: Vanessa G.

description:
I was a little lost when I walked in because I didnt realize it was self-service. The guy at the counter was nice enough to guide me towards him after realizing that I looked like a completely lost child.

We ordered the chicken tiki marsala, lamb curry, garlic naan, some type of beef sausage thing on a stick and the mango/yogurt drink. The beef sausage on a stick wasnt really my thing, but I loved everything else that we ordered. Hot, fresh and quickly made!

I thought it was cool how other patrons brought in a case of beer to have with their meals. Most establishments wont allow that, but not Pakwan!
author: M W.

description:
I love the food here.  Tandoori is great.  I appreciate how they stagger the food with dishes that take longer to make (i.e. Tandoori).

Vibrant location, attentive staff (table was wiped for me immediately by very polite busser), and don't forget to try the tea.
author: F N.

description:
Best Pakistani/Indian food in all of the bay area. Period. I used to think Shah in Sunnyvale was the best one until now, but now I'm completely sold on Pakwan.

We tried only the white meat dishes this time, but will try the lamb/beef next time. I would recommend the chicken biryani, chicken tikka masala, and the kadhai chicken (this was fairly oily though). The garlic naan was the softest naan I've had in a long time.

It does get crowded by around 8 pm even on a weeknight and they don't take reservations. We reached at 7.30 pm, which was probably the best time - barely a line to order and a table to sit immediately. Don't go there for the ambiance - it gets pretty noisy, they have simple tables and you have to self serve. Go there for the food though. Highly recommend.
author: Sahil S.

description:
Ordered the lamb biryani to go. The rice was pre-cooked plain (without spices,) some inadequate sprinkling of spices were unevenly stirred in, and lukewarm over-cooked lamb (cooked in another sauce) was added. Not how you make biryani at all. 

Reminded me of Chipotle. It has some authentic flavors, but then mashed together in a bland, inauthentic way. 

They may do well in the curries (acc to the reviews,) but they definitely failed on the biryani front. Very disappointed. I don't plan to go back with all the other options in the city.
author: Sneha P.

description: Briyani was good, other stuffs were pretty ordinary. It would be a sin if I dont mention the poor customer service. Guy at the  reception was least bothered about customers.
author: Gopal Krishnan R.

description: I would go back to SF and eat here again and eat the leftovers for breakfast with a fried egg on top again.  Thanks Pakwan!
author: Chelsea L.

description: Though the food was decent, poor customer service literally spoiled the evening for us. Just avoid this place
author: Babu S.

description: I got buttered paneer and my husband got saag paneer.. we opted out rice and got nan and wow they were huge! We also got samosas which were good not greasy. We got free refills chai for a dollar . Good deal!
author: Asha R.

description: love the tandori chicken. so flavorful, slightly charred. have it with some crispy fuffly nann with some sweet curry to seal the deal.
author: Jason C.

description: The food here is so delicious! No fuss self seating type of place. The portions are huge for the price you pay. I tried their lamb biryani, saag paneer, garlic naan, beef kabab, chicken tikka masala, vegetarian biryani and it's all really good. Their kheer is AMAZING!!!! I would eat a bucket full if I could. I saw people bringing in their own alcohol which I thought was a great idea. I will definitely come back again if I'm in the area.
author: Rebecca T.

description: Three words; cheap, ghetto and tasty. Its BYOB, order at the counter and doesn't take long for food to come out. The place was really busy and seems like the place to go on a Friday night.
author: Hannah K.

description: I had lunch here last Tuesday with my son and brother.  the tea is very good, the food is very tasty, we wanted another bowl of daal and the server just brought it to us.  thanks Pakwan we dill definitely be back.
author: pochini m.

description:
This place reminds me of Naan and Curry, but I think N&C is a little better. 

Prices are cheap, and portions are extremely generous, but basically you get what you pay for. Not a ton of flavor, but good Indian/Pakistani food. Neighborhood is a little rough on the edges though.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
My co-worker was telling me about how great this place was and how affordable it was so we decided to come here for dinner yesterday. It was amazing! Especially for the price that we paid for it! It's always pretty packed in here from what my friend said. You order your food at the counter and then they bring it to your table. They are cash only so hit up the atm before going in! The food was amazing!

We ordered:
-Vegetarian Samosas, comes with 2 ($2.99)
-Daal Chana ($5.99)
-Mixed vegetable curry ($5.99)
-Aloo Palak ($5.99)
-Vegetable Biryani ($6.99)
-2 orders of naan ($1 each)

Our food could barely fit on our table because we ordered so much. For real, check my yelp photo! Two people definitely did not need this much food but we knowingly went overboard because wanted to order everything! All the dishes were delicious and we were stuffed to a point where we could barely breathe. It was so good that even though we were full we still wanted to eat more! lol. FYI this is also coming from somebody that is half Indian and grew up with his grandma cooking amazing Indian food all the time!  We got boxes to go and we had plenty of leftovers for today! I will definitely go back again soon!
author: Anthony H.

description:
I didn't mind the kind of extreme divey-ness of the place, but the saag paneer was bland and the naan had a strangely plastic quality to it.  Like I was eating plastic.  But if you need FOOD NOW and don't have a lot of money on you, you can get lots of food here for very little money.  

It's cash only.
author: Amy M.

description:
This Indian restaurant is one of my favorites! Their foods are so delicious, and chai tea too! 

It is a self-serve restaurant (you take your own plates, utensils, water, glasses etc from the restaurant and put them on your table) and you can bring your own beer or other drinks because they don't serve alcohol. 

It is good for close friends or family or coworkers sharing foods together or someone you know pretty well and don't mind doing all the work because you go upfront near the cashier to bring foods to your table, too.  Ambiance wasn't nice at all, so I won't recommend this restaurant if you are looking for a romantic sitting for a special event. 

My all time favorites are their chicken tikka masala, spicy chicken rice (Biryani) seekh kabab (beef sausage), eggplant, and naan! Love these dishes each time! 

Good Indian foods, no table services, cash only. I will bring friends and family here for a good Indian meal because I do not mind waiting myself :)
author: Lena H.

description:
My friend loves Pakwan. There is another location in the Tenderloin on Jones st. 

We arrived around 2pm and there was about 3 other parties here. We ordered a chicken tikki masala with two naan and a mango lassi for me. I LOVE mango lassi! Total came out to be 13ish. CASH ONLY!

You can grab the lassi and a pitcher of water yourself along with the utensils, cups, straws, etc. Just like most Indian restaurants I have been to. 

You get a number and when they call your number you have to get up and pick it up. 

My friend loves the chicken tikki masala. That is like the only thing she ever gets at an Indian restaurant. I thought it was good but I really can't tell the difference. My friend though thought it was absolutely amazing. Having eaten a big breakfast and with the mango lassi I was not able to finish my naan. My friend finished hers but we couldn't finish the dish. Can probably feed 3 girls or 2 guys. A lot of food!

The mango lassi was delicious! 

The workers here aren't super friendly and there are two bathrooms in the back, one for men and one for women.
author: Sarah C.

description: Biryani here is a specialty and different from what you'll get elsewhere. It has northern indian style flavors and definitely enough for two hungry people. The lamb is tasty, curries with great spices, and the naan is freshly made. Clean tables, no frills seating, and often not packed during lunch hours makes this a great place for a simple tasty meal. Coworkers come here regularly for lunch.
author: Thomas L.

description:
We couldn't believe our eyes when we saw the menu. The kababs were delicious and one skewer of Beef/Lamb/Chicken Seekh Kabab for $2.99 was a stupendous bargain anywhere in the world. The boti kababs and Chicken Kababs were immaculate as well. The Goat Biriyani was also incredibly tasty. The person taking our order was kind enough to help us control our excitement while ordering. We were on the verge of going overboard and ordering food enough to feed 4-5 people while we were just two. 
Word of caution - The food can be a bit on the spicier side for those who cannot handle North Indian spices. Also this is a CASH only and order at the counter establishment.
author: Sourav D.

description: If only Pakwan was located in LA... I swear I would be here weekly if not bi-weekly. After hearing my NorCal friend rave about this place, I had to try it for myself and I'm glad it met and surpassed my expectations. It was the first on my SF food destination list and I made sure it would hold its spot. My sister and I ordered the garlic naan, lamb biryani, and chicken tikka. I wish the naan had more flavor but as far as texture goes, it was super fluffy, dense and warm. It paired greatly with the chicken tikka which was an explosion of delicious flavor. The chicken could've been a bit more tender but the dish was still good overall. The lamb biryani came out on a huge plate and could've served 4-5 people. The lamb was super tender and flavorful. Gotta love crazy big portions for reasonable prices! I love that Pakwan is a casual, seat-yourself get-yourself type of place. It definitely makes the place more home-y, in my opinion. I hope we meet again in the near future but until then, I will be on the hunt for another Indian restaurant that matches the quality, taste, and price.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Everytime I'm in the City and I have an Indian Food craving ( which is almost always), I make a stop at this place. I can't say it's the best indian food I've had, but it is up there with the best! 

This place is like a lot of the Indian places I've been to, self-service. Order at the counter, get your number, get your table, and wait.

The usual always works for me, and one thing that always draws me back here is the food consistency.  

I recommend  :
Appetizers : Pakora , or Samosas
Veggie dish: Saag Paneer or Aloo Palak 
and of course, you can NEVER EVER go here without ordering the Chicken Tikka Masala.
And their Garlic Naan is always perfection.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I wouldn't go so far as saying its the BEST indian food or anything but.. for SF it sure is a steal! I usually get the spicy lamb curry or beef briyani and no matter what the item the meat practically falls off the bone. Food is cheap (sf cheap) I usually can get away with spending under 12 for a very full meal. 

Extra star for the samosas!
author: James H.

description:
BARF.

My boyfriend and I were in town from DC and decided to give this place a try. It was just okay. I ordered the channa masala and saag daal. I hardly touched the saag daal because it tasted like pure ghee. The channa masala was really bland but slightly less ghee tasting than the saag daal. There is a popular freezer brand of Channa masala that is way better and even cheaper. Also it's cash only. The plus side to this place is that you do get a ton of food for cheap and the naan was pretty decent.  I just hope I don't get sick from this stuff...
author: Alexis A.

description:
Awesome, tasty and fast, pretty much sums up my entire experience there! Love this place! Been to this location twice so far and never been disappointed. 

We had the chicken tikka masala and the lamb karahi, paired with some rice and garlic nan. The portions were perfect for two people, no wasted food!
author: En K.

description:
My new go to spot post Dolores Park. 

I felt like I hit the jackpot when I first came here. High quality authentic Desi food at a great price! You get generous portions and their meat is very tender!   

My favorite dish is the lamb biryani.
author: Ali A.

description:
Pakwan is like your favorite sweater from college.  Sure there are better, newer, more expensive clothes available for you to buy; but every so often you want to go back and enjoy that old, familiar comfort.

Food - good
I grew up in Asia, albeit not in the sub-continent, but appreciate strong spices.  The food at Pakwan is nicely spiced, always consistent, and in general tasty.  We like the saag, the chicken tikka and the yellow lentils.  I would rate their food as one of the 'best in their price category'.

Service - very good
This is a minimum service restaurant.  You order and pick up your food at the counter.  Water pitchers are available for customers in their fridge.  The two things I like about their service are (1) food comes out quickly, and in reasonable time even during dinner rush hours; and (2) you can bring your own beer.  There's a liquor shop across the street and typically we just go over there to get a six pack.
