Also, if you come here after the dinner rush hour they will let you hang out and stay as long as you want.  The restaurant is cash only, but that shouldn't be a big issue as there are ATM's along 16th st.

Price - very good
Average entree costs about $8-$9.  Definitely a great value for your money.

Atmosphere - casual
It's too casual to say bring in clients to impress them, but since it's at the heart of the mission it's actually pretty lively and hip.

Overall - this is a good restaurant.  Perhaps not the 'best' but definitely a very good option when you are in the neighborhood.
author: Andi H.

description: Killer Indian/Pakistani restaurant with minimal frills. You order at the counter, grab a seat as soon as one opens up (be quick as this place is typically packed due to the word getting out about it being delicious), pop open a brew that you brought with (it's BYOB), and go to town on some hella fragrant Indian food. It's a very satisfying experience, and not surprisingly a hit with the drunk crowd.
author: Jack W.

description: No frills. The saag paneer is really great. The chai is delicious, cheap, and unlimited. Don't miss out.
author: Nicolas C.

description:
Oh Pakwan, you've renewed my hope that I would someday remove that awful first time experience trying Indian food (food court, what was I thinking?!? Awful, just awful).

This place is a cash only, self-serve, BYOB kind of joint. Get in line, order (most dishes are under $10), pick up some utensils/drinks and find a seat. Your number will be called on the screen, so pick up your food at the counter! It gets packed during prime time dinner hours...but you can take your food to go if you don't want to wait.

FOOD/DRINKS:
-Naan & Garlic naan - fresh, soft, and warm. $1.00 for regular naan, and $1.99 for garlic naan.
-Veggie curry - SO GOOD!!! A little spicy, but I love it.
-Basmati rice - one order is plenty for 2-3 people
-Chicken tikka masala - flavorful pieces of chicken with the right amount of sauce
-Veggie samosa - one order comes as 2 large pieces. Get some!
-Mango lassi - mango mixed with yogurt. Pretty thick consistency. I think I could have done without this because I was way too full by the end of the meal to finish it.

Overall: 4. In love with this Indian-Pakistani food joint, that I fear to venture somewhere else and potentially be disappointed by another place. Bring some beers, good company, and an empty stomach!
author: Loriel L.

description: So let me being by saying that this place is very noisy. But that shouldn't stop you from going here because they have the most amazing kebabs and tandoori chicken. I had gone with a friend of mine and we ordered 5 dishes cause we wanted to taste it all and every one of them was delicious. Also, this place accommodates BYOB (which we didn't know about, sadly) so don't forget to get yourself that bottle of wine.
author: Prem S.

description: Really good garlic naan. I had the chicken masala (because I am lame and always go for what I know) but everyone else in my group got something different and we all shared. Everything was really good. Rice, FYI, does not come with the meal, you have order that on the side.
author: Monica G.

description:
I have been coming back & yes weekly & recently I've had the pleasure to try the mirch salan & the chana masala & FINALLY actually come & in sit down instead of take-out!

The mirch salan is absolutely delicious! Very flavourful, hint of tang & sourness, super rich & delicious either way!
Chana masala is too bland of a dish for me but it's still executed superbly!

Last thing I definitely recommend for everyone get some friends to come & BYO alcohol of choice & order yourselves some delicious food & hang out! The atmosphere is really fun & crowded & for someone reason it's a really nice place to just chill at and work on your brews even after you finish the delicious food!
author: Zhenya S.

description:
This place is my jam. Really, where are you going to get good Indian food at a reasonable price? And at less than $10 a dish (e.g., Chicken Tikka Masala and Saag Paneer), come on! And it's BYOB! And there just so happens to be a conveniently located liquor store across the street =)

Yeah, it's pretty much self service, but that keeps the overhead down, more money in my pocket and my belly full =)
author: Mark S.

description:
(See pics) Review #1110. Decent meal with chicken tikka, Bengan Bhartha (eggplant curry), chicken Achar, biryani and their daily special vegetable Makhni. Naan was good too. Chai was $1 but free refills.

The great part about most Indian places is that there are many good vegetarian dishes (considering many Indians are vegetarians.) It suits everyone's dietary needs and the dishes are well made.
author: T L.

description:
Good food, decent decor for a cheap Indian place.
Chicken tika Marsala not that great.
The whole experience was ruined when I washed my hands in the FILTHY bathrooms,
Which smelled of mildew and piss.
May want to clean that smelly, moldy mop before wiping it around the bathroom.
Hope the kitchen is cleaner! Saw lots of bleach just out side the bathroom but apparently don't know what it's for.
Eaten here many times, .....clean your bathrooms.. A real turn off !
author: K. K.

description:
Thank God for Pakwan! I was well on my way to starring in The Hangover 3, complete with monkey, face tattoo & uncomfortable male nudity. I needed something the soak up the booze and rescue me from a weekend of pain. Enter Pakwan. I am always on the lookout for good Indian food. In my experience in Chicago, however, that can only be found in one part of town I don't frequent (shame on me). So, remembering that SF opened my eyes to delicious South Indian food, it made perfect sense that I should get a double dose of Pakistani/Indian excellence.

I did.

First off, the place was crazy packed. My suggestion, find a table and start either hovering or leering. I may have been drooling as well. I don't know. I'm telling you, evil liquor was ravaging my system. After scaring away a table of hipsters, my crew sat down (dirty dishes and all) and began a plan on attack. I told my friend what I requested for foodstuff and continued to tell him even as he was in line for our food. I may have been screaming. Again, blame it on the alcohol. 

He paid and then the magic screen flashed our order. Magic! Two biryanies, 4 samosas, 1 saag paneer, a few naans (garlic for me; thanks to the bellow), basmati rice, cholay, & achar later, I started feeling as though I was going to make it after all. My slumped over posture resumed its usual bent over Mr. Burns hump. My cross-eyes resumed beadiness and my slurred speech resumed its acidity. Back to normal, I demanded sweet treats. Luckily, we were in The Mission and Bi-Rite was just down the way. 

Even better, across the street is a liquor store to keep the party going AND it's stocked with coconut water which helped save me from that aforementioned hangover. Yay! Mike Tyson wouldn't be punching me out tonight!
author: Johnny T.

description:
I love 16th street. My friends always bitch at me cus I never want to go anywhere else. Why would I? You have great dive bars, and great food at your fingertips. 

Pakwan is probably my favorite Paki / Indian food joint that I've been to in SF. Fast service, reasonable prices with great portions. It can be really crowded on weekends, and dinner time. I'm willing to wait when I have the crave.

Great taste!
author: Tom L.

description:
Pakwan is soo legit! quick fast and so good!
I get the chicken tikka masala with parpadum
and yesterday I tried the Chana masala and omg SOOOOOO GOOD!
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
My favorite Indian place in the city so far, great atmosphere, great food, you can bring your own booze- 

I got saag, rice, lamb vindaloo and of course naan. Everything we got was amazing, not over spiced and not under spiced. I will always come back here no doubt about it.
author: Matt W.

description:
4 years after my first review and Pakwan still hits the sweet spot!  Prices may have gone up a tad, but portions are generous, service is quick and ambiance is low key, just how I like it.

I hadn't had Pakistani/Indian food since Mexico (I know, Mexico), so this was a real treat.  D.F. is certainly missing out on the real flavors!
author: Christopher W.

description: The archari chicken and the chicken biryani were delish! The best thing was the chicken kebab, it had the perfect spices blended in it. Amazing! The mirch salon was alright. Definitely coming back here again!
author: Tanvi C.

description:
Pakwan was where I tried my first Indian curry. For that it will always have a special place in my heart. 

I've eaten at many other Indian restaurants since then, but few in SF can compare to Pakwan. No wonder it's survived for so long. 

Great value, speedy service, and the creamiest chicken tikka masala around have made Pakwan (and its many Bay Area branches) a stalwart of sorts. Five stars forever!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Wonderful food. Love their lamb biriyani and kheema nan. 

Be prepared to self-serve (order first before sitting down) and for your clothes to smell after, but it's well worth it (so don't wear your best clothes and just go for the food). Also don't complain about the service - this is more fast food than fine dining, so don't expect to be pampered here. 

Fairly clean for a high volume restaurant too. 

Love it!!!
author: Rohit R.

description: Horrible service. Wrong orders. Mediocre food at best. Tables always dirty and people taking orders always rude. Last time for sure.
author: Pablo H.

description: These guys always have had some of the best Indian/Pakistani food around, but lately it seems like Pakwan has stepped up their game even more. It gets crowded, but its a fast, order at the counter kind of place with a friendly staff that knows they sling some great food. They are also BYOB, which is awesome since there's a cash only store across the street with a good selection of beers.
author: Matt V.

description: Decent Indian food at a pretty affordable price. The curry and spices are great. I wouldn't say the food was memorable but I'd come back again if I was in the area.
author: Brian W.

description:
Have loved this place for years. Good, cheap food though the last time we went the food was disgustingly GREASY. I mean, we got containers of grease with a few chunks of food sprinkled in. We were starved, so ate it but felt horrible afterward. 

Not cool, Pakwan. Tell your cooks to not make the dishes so greasy that we can't eat them without getting sick, please.

thanks
author: Teo C.

description: Tip: byob! Other diners had 6-packs of beer and bottles if wine on their tables- doh! The chicken tikka was great- not as creamy as some. We also got a lamb dish which I couldn't tell u the name because it was by recommendation of the gentlemen at the counter taking orders. But it was chunks of tender lamb in a thin, flavorful sauce sprinkled with cilantro leaves. The cilantro was sooo wonderful with this dish, it really made the dish, such a great dish. The basmati rice is flavorful and delicious in its own. The onion naan was pretty good, although I've had better, this ones a little dryer than I like. The raita is also different than others I've had- very spicy (spice-y not hot) almost like cinnamon. You order at the counter and get your own dishes, silverware and even serving spoons from the counter on the side. Will most likely return.
author: Emma H.

description:
This is one of my go to place for comfort food, delicious food. (EDIT: I mean the Hayward location). The flavors are authentic for indian/pakistani cuisine and the price is very affordable. The ambiance is very unassuming and casual but the people are warm and friendly - and the service is pretty quick.

There is SOO many good dishes to choose from but my all time favorite is the Achar Chicken. Blows the taste buds away, reels them in and them blows them again. YEA THAT GOOD! And  their roti is so soft it literally melts in your mouth.

The Hayward location has a lavish sunday buffet that should be tried once - please visit on an empty stomach, please! :)
author: Mo S.

description:
Pros: BYOB, food was ready quickly
Cons: bland food

Brought a bottle of wine, ordered at the counter and they gave us a number. We got an open table as we got there at 6:45. When we left people were waiting for tables. They display the numbers on the TV screen when your order is ready and you pick it up at the counter. We got the Saag Paneer, Chicken Tikki Masala, the barbecue meat kebabs, rice and some naan. I wasn't impressed with any of the food. Saag paneer and chicken tikki were bland, the barbecue meat kebabs were so dry and the the naan was hard. The rice was tasty :)

I most likely won't return for the food.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Pakwan is hands down one of my favorite places to eat in SF! So good! The lamb and chicken biryani is so good! I could and have eaten here twice in one day!!!

Yes, it is CASH ONLY. If this is a problem for you, then you should probably stay home or eat somewhere else. You probably wouldn't know what to do with yourself if you lost your iPhone and AMEX card, so leave this place to the rest of us to enjoy ;)

$1 Masala Chais with refills. Oh yes!!! :)

Open until 11pm! Thank the Good Lord Son!!!!!!!!!! :))))

Park in a metered spot on 16th or look for 1-2 hour parking on surrounding streets around Guerrero.

Order the lamb or chicken biryani or any of their spinach and curry dishes and you won't be disappointed. If you are, then that is on you!!! ;)
author: Dharam D.

description: I'm ethnically Indian. I've tried pretty much every Indian/Pakistani restaurant in town, and this is my favorite. I eat here every week, and bring family here when they're in town. Their Seekh kebabs are pretty much perfect (not pictured, the sight of them causes me to forget my phone, the Internet, and all else). Most homes don't have a tandoor, so I pretty much gorge on their tandoori selections and naan. However their lamb shank special is also worthy of devotion (pictured).
author: Jamil M.

description:
CASH ONLY 
BARBECUE TAKES A VERY VERY LONG TIME

these are signs they NEED to have up. there are no signs anywhere depicting these things & they have an incredibly high volume of people coming through. my friend had to run out to get cash after getting to the front of the line - he'd never been before - and by the time his bbq chicken was done our whole group had long finished eating. he took it to go. 

that said, food is amazing, spicy and cheap. tables are quickly bussed. they're on top of their game. proper.
author: Sonya Z.

description: Very good food although ours took a while to get. Recommend the Tikka Masala. Very crowded and lots of reverberant sound so if you want to talk to whoever you're eating with I'd get takeout. My meal was ~$12 without a drink.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I've  only ordered online before and loved the food so I thought I'd visit the location. Wrong. I ordered the paneer mutter.  The food was ready within five minutes. However, our food was cold, the rice was dry, and it literally had no taste. Maybe they were just having an off day but that's no reason for my curry to be cold! 
I will not be coming back.
author: Sarah D.

description: Best lamb biryani I've ever had. Very quick service. Although, I feel that their cooking kind of lacks consistency especially during busy hours. Also, try to get there as early as you can to avoid long queues.
author: Veronica P.

description:
Good North Indian food, BYOB or BYOW (since we're living in SF) - what's not to love. This is one of favorite chill spots to grab a bite before heading out for drinks in the Mission. Just to clarify this place has good food with a fast food concept - quick and affordable. 
My go to dishes are the Chicken Tikka Masala love the gravy, the lamb Nihari very tender meat with a right amount of kick, beef Notice Kabab, lamb chops are very tender with the right amount of seasoning and char, and any of the biryanis make sure to get the raita with it.
I want to try other dishes but never seem to make it that far maybe the next time when we have a bigger group.
author: Harshal V.

description: I went in here for the first time and it was Delic. Karahi Chicken was so tasty. You cannot leave without trying the Samosas and the Garlic Nan. The staff was great and the guy at the front Ali was so friendly. It was my first time here and he made it a great experience. A+ on flavor and price.
author: Jess C.

description:
I come here for last 15 years occasionally.
Amazing and authentic food.
Great service.
Great humble owner.
Being Indian I'd wish food was more spicy.
author: Nik In C.

description: This place on a good nice night is good, and on an okay night is decent. I wouldn't say this is the best food around 16th st but if you're looking for something quick and cheap, pop in. Beware though, it can be tough to get a table.
author: Isaac R.

description: I came here with my sister to celebrate Eid. The staff was friendly. Started with mango lassi, very delicious. Ordered the lamb biryani, it's cooked with spices and tomatoes, layered in basmati rice. Our other favorite dish was the Karahi chicken, a traditional tomato base curry. We complimented it with garlic naan. Everything is delicious and I'll be trying the lamb biryani again! Also all the dishes are reasonably priced. We ended our night with warm masala chai and Bollywood songs on the TV
author: Sabrina S.

description:
Pakwan forever!! I recommend calling in your order, it's always gratifying walking past everyone in line, walking straight to the register, & picking up your order. WINNING!
Everything here is amazing. Haven't been disappointed yet!

First timers I would recommend:
Chicken tikki masala
Sag paneer
Naans
A biryani
Not sure of the name, but they had an eggplant dish, almost like a spicy curry

...sorry for any spelling typos :)
author: Christine N.

description: This place has solid main courses, amazing naan, cheap prices and is BYOB. My fiancé and I had a great time here and spent $17. Will absolutely be back.
author: Jack J.

description:
This place is huge! Love the atmosphere here! I enjoy the low key setting. I got the lamb biryani. The food was a bit dry but there was definitely flavor in it. Generous amounts of lamb are cooked with the rice. There wasn't much potato but that's fine. I just wish the dish had so more sauce in it so it wouldn't be so dry. Maybe I should've gotten the curries instead?

P.S. is it just me or do all indian eateries in SF are self served? I.E. water and utensils, etc etc.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Found this restaurant on yelp and was so glad I did! We fed 7 hungry mouths for $58 and still had a little bit of food left over. I love the idea of ordering at the counter, taking care of your own water and utensils, although I would have liked to be directed to do so, rather than left wondering for a few minutes. The food came freshly made and promptly. The garlic naan is impressive and generous. We tried about 4 different curries and a couple of other dishes that were all so good. 

Between the cleanliness of the restaurant, the good food, friendly service, and the reasonable price, I gave Pakwan 5 well-earned stars!
author: Vicki N.

description:
Excellent Pakistani and Indian food in the Mission District. I visited San Francisco earlier in 2013, and I was not disappointed with this place.

Few things, it is CASH ONLY and they don't serve alcohol. Person at the counter told me to go to beer store across the street. Five minutes later, I got back with my local micro beer and I was ordering food at the counter.

Service, not that great. You pay and order at counter, and they are not friendly.
However, because of the food, this place gets such a high rating! This is a very popular place, there was a line, but people seemed to be patient and happy or hungry for good food.
We ordered chicken tikka masala, naan bread, and the veggie curry.
author: Rafael L.

description: Can't think of a more perfect place to visit when you're feeling that ravenous hunger that typically only comes after copious glasses of beer and only the most comforting comfort food will do. Though the place is bare bones and the service is snappy to the point of cranky, none of it matters once you have the lucscious curries and fluffy naans in front of your face to stuff into said face! Tables may be hard to get at busy times so be prepared to be assertive to the point of aggressive in landing a seat for you and your buddies. And don't forget to BYOB if you haven't yet had quite enough of previously mentioned beer!
author: Christina P.

description:
What differentiates a good restaurant from a great restaurant (other than decor, service etc)? Consistency. And Pakwan just went down from the usual 5 stars in my book to 2. And, this review is based on 2 recent visits, so it cannot be blamed on just a "one night off" kinda event. The awesome soft perfectly cooked naans were overcooked, cold and brittle - you'd be better off picking up frozen naans from trader joes. The lamb chops were dry and rubbery, looks like this weeks Australian lamb was flown in without any refrigeration. The daal lacked consistency and was watery. The Bihari boti had lost it's awesome seasoning, and there were no onions on the side. 

Lastly, I would give it 1 star, but their biryani was still passable. As I'm writing this review, there's a tear rolling down my cheek. I've been going to Pakwan religiously for the past 2 years. Atleast twice a month, and I've taken every friend and family member there too. 

Hey Pakwan, please go back to your old management/crew/or whatever it takes to be my favorite restaurant in SF again, because you definitely just lost a regular.
author: Aabhas S.

description:
Cheap, relatively tasty Indian food. It's pretty darn great drunk food, or with its BYOB policy you can come here to get drunk! It stays cheap by not including things like rice/naan with your order, so if you like starch with your curry order up. 

In general though I come here not to satisfy my craving for indian food (which is essentially an ongoing constant need), but more to satisfy my craving for not spending a lot of money. Which it does a great job of. All in all A-OK! I will be back, but the first bite won't make me moan the way other Indian places do.
author: Claire G.

description:
Used to drive to fremont from san mateo to eat here so now that I live in the city nothing can prevent me from having it MORE.

Got the lamb biriyani this time and it was fantastic. The portion is enormous though so watch out. Also do it legit and get some yogurt on the side.

Plus it's BYOB so what's not to like?!
author: Misha T.

description:
Right on - a quality, affordable Indian restaurant. 

There are plenty of Indian restaurants in the city and pakwan should be considered one of the best. I was really impressed with my saag lamb (lamb cooked with spinach, spicy). They weren't stingy with the lamb like a lot of other Indian places and the dish was flavorful and just the perfect amount of spice. The garlic naan was a little burnt, but it was still good and went really well with the saag! 

My date got the vegetable curry and loved it. He asked for it spicy, and said it was really spicy! We shared the samosa appetizer which was very pleasant.

After the meal, like after all Indian meals, I felt like I as going to blow up from the fullness I felt. But I couldn't stop eating when I should have because the food was just that good!

Cash only! Also, don't expect fancy. This place is definitely in Mission territory, but not at all dirty. Good stuff!

Can't wait to come back to try their other dishes, including the chicken tikka masala!
author: Junel S.

description:
It's essential to have a good Indian place where you can get something last minute in a pinch. This is my place. I've ordered many times and as it's boring to read about levels of authenticism and what Indian food is, here are my recommendations.

Lamb Biryani
Saag Panner
Chicken Tikka masala
Vegetable Somosas
Aloo Palak

I'm a casual vegetarian, so my boo and I can always find enough variety here to keep us happy and coming back. And it's oh so reasonably priced. Don't forget to ask for the cucumber/ yogurt sauce; it can be poured onto just about anything.
author: Brandon K.

description:
Been having a craving for indian food and found this spot with yelp. Reviews were spot on. Pretty good. I got the chicken tikka masala, rice and nan. Slightly above average but not excellent. 4 stars. 

 Reason for 3 stars is it's CASH ONLY. It's a pain in the ass placing an order, pulling out the card and being told to go around the corner to the atm to pull out cash. 

Food- 7/10
Service- 5/10
author: Michael R.

description:
Ive been to Pakwan 2-3 times a month or more for the last 15 years. The last few times I have gone it has been a disappointment.  
I usually order the lamb chops, chicken tikka masala, and garlic naan. The lamb chops are always good and have beeb for years as Pakwan is known for that dish. The chicken tikka on the other hand has been watered down and yhe flavor is not there lile it used to be. I also ordered the saag and it tastes bland and old. 
Pakwan is still one of my favorites and will go back, hopefully the quality of the food comes back to what is used to be.
author: Satish P.

description: Pakwan is handsdown the best Indian food I have tasted in the city.  Since I moved here from Boston area, a friend took me there for dinner.  I judge Indian food by the flavor taste and many dishes are as close as my mom makes.  There is no other comparison better than my Mom's cooking.  Bhuna Lamb curry,  Briyani (Lamb/Chicken) are my favorites.  Keep up the good work and the place gets packed in the evenings, so plan accordingly.
author: Sarav C.

description: The only Indian restaurant in the city that knows how to make a non-spicy chicken biryani. My favorite.
author: Maher S.

description: Don't let all those Taquerias coax you into believing that the Mission is only about Mexican food. There are a bunch of other 'exotic' cuisine restaurants lurking around in one corner or the other. Pakwan is one of those - a truly Mission-esque Pakistani restaurant that's always noisy, crowded and open till late at night. I come here often because for me it's the closest most affordable place to get North Indian food. I usually have their biryanis which aren't great, but palatable enough to satiate that late night hunger. I wish they would give complimentary unlimited raitas with their biryanis...And I wish they'd accept cards (and not make me go running around the Mission to find an ATM). I wouldn't really go this place of lunch or for a proper/early dinner...but oh heck, you can't win 'em all!
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
Place seems to be extremely casual. Not too clean looking and definitely not for romantic dates.

It was Cash only... we left. I wonder if the food was good.
author: Nona T.

description:
Great Pakistani food and big portions. 

Food: I ordered the beef boti, the chicken boti kabob, nihari, daal and naan. Of all the items, the only one I didn't really like was the beef boti kabob because it was a bit tough and didn't have enough spice. In general, all the food was fresh and hot when it came out. 

Place: Super casual, you can go in sweats if you want. 

Service: Be ready to wait if you are ordering grilled items! It can take a little long, understandable since they grill to order. 

Tip: Cash Only! I didn't pay attention and had to go next door to an ATM and get cash out. There is a Wells Fargo 2 blocks down if you bank with them.
author: Maliha Z.

description:
Pakwan is an absolute gem. The Indian / Pakistani food is off the chains. The guys working the counter care about the food and seem stoked to serve it to you.

It's BYO - and the prices at Pakwan are low enough to justify spending the extra money for that beer or wine you've really been waiting for the right time to try.

Pakwan is super casual, mostly self-service, but it doesn't mean it's a bad place to enjoy a date (or show up in sweatpants).
author: Marcus C.

description: The samosa was one of the best I have ever had in the US. Though, other things (Tandoori chicken breast and naans) were about the same you would have at a okayish Indian / Pakistani place. Had better expectations since this is pretty popular and is based in middle of SF. The ambience is similar to a "dhaba", though the Pakistani music they play is nice. Won't call it too pricey, it costed us ~$40 for two without drinks and desserts.
author: Dhruv M.

description: Great tasting authentic Biryani to indulge your cravings, great to find something close to the original in the Bay Area!
author: Abhishek G.

description: Great Pakistani and Indian food. They've got really good curry, tikka masala, naan, and I love their saag.
author: Peter K.

description: I thought the food was acceptable. The kabob wasn't that good so I would not recommend that dish.
author: Angela I.

description:
Whenever I'm in the bay I'll make it a point to come here. I'll never master Indian food at home, but thankfully places like this exist. I got the Saag Chicken and Cheese Naan and plain Naan. This is how I know this is good. I was ready to pop, but my body was still directing saag soaked naan towards my mouth.

You can bring your booze here. I think there is complimentary chai, which i'm not a fan of but if you want to fill your gullet with chai, this is great for you.

Pros: food is good. Naan is cheap.

Cons: seating is awkward for table tops 5+ and some tables were banged up.

noms.

sm
author: Sajid M.

description: Delicious food, vibrant atmosphere! This one is a no frills, self service place. It would have been nice if they could keep the place a little neater.
author: Aparna P.

description: Awesome experience - loud and hectic like an authentic vibe. Loved the naan and eggplant. Meat dishes were on the dry side.
author: Howe L.

description:
Best nan I have had in ages, or possibly ever. So fresh. 

Spicy eggplant curry, near-instant service, and friendly cashier weren't too shabby either. I'm glad I wandered in here randomly.
author: Maddie R.

description: Sensational food - inexpensive - the Tandoori chicken on the bone is as good as it gets - only in town for a few days  -hope to go back. :-)
author: Bryce R.

description:
This is my first time at this location. I've been to the tenderloin and east bay locations many times and thought I should finally try this one too

This location is great.   Just a couple of blocks from Bart.  Nice employees.   Food cooked fresh to order.  

As always  we love their daal  (we had the plain and the one with spinach), Chicken Achar (chicken curry with roasted pepper cooked in blend of spices), and garlic naan, and a mango lassi


This was plenty of food for two of us.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
what can i say, this place is casual cheap and centrally located in the mission

great food,  great price, great atmosphere
the food take some time but i dont mind because it is always coked to perfetion
author: China D.

description: I'd give it a solid 4 stars. I was really craving some biryani, and decided to check out this place. The biryani was okay. I grew up eating a lot of home made biryani at home, and this one was no where near as good. The lamb curry was amazing though. I loved it so much, it tasted just like how my grandmother used to make it. I also love how you can have unlimited chai - it's perfect for a chilly day. I would definitely come here again, but not for the biryani.
author: Anum H.

description:
Let me preface this by saying I don't eat Indian food; I got sick on a dish five years ago and haven't been able to stomach it since. Plus, I haven't found a place that doesn't taste/smell like baby shit. 

Throw all that out the window. 

I was sitting at Giordano Bros enjoying too many beers one sunny afternoon. My friend happened by. Had Pakwan with her. I was tipsy (read: drunk). I tried some. I didn't die. 

So we went last night, and while the food was to my expectations, the service wasn't. 

Five Stars for the food: the lamb biryani, tandoori chicken and spinach with potato were fucking delicious. I could eat that every day. 

The outside patio was bitchin' on a warm summer night. 

But the service? I had to remove a star for the service. I won't go into detail, but if you come outside to yell at us that our order is up, just bring the fucking order with you. Especially after you mess it up. 

PRETEND to give a shit that I just gave you my money.
author: Mel H.

description:
As of now, Pakwan is  the best Indian food I've had in the city. I came here with my housemates and we all loved the food. The chicken tiki masala was pretty much perfect... spicy but not too spicy and very very flavorful. The lamb biryani was very rich and the rice was perfectly cooked. We also had the creamed spinach with cheese (no idea what it's called) and that was surprisingly tasty. The naan (both garlic and chili) was perfectly cooked - crispy on the outside and moist and flaky on the inside.

It was pretty much destiny coming here because we had no idea it was cash only so when the cashier told us, we all scrambled through our pockets and ended up having exactly enough cash to pay for the meal. If they accepted pocket lint, I would've made it rain in naan.


MUST HAVES:
Chicken Tiki Masala
Garlic Naan
Lamb Biryani
author: William L.

description: Chicken tikka masala, the boyfriend's favorite dish, is always better in Berkeley. Oh how we've compared Indian restaurants in SF to Berkeley and lament the difference of quality but don't want to drive across the bridge. But, our lives have changed with pakwan! After many attempts to find a comparable chicken tikka masala dish, we've agreed that this place definitely delivers. Also, lamb curry and palak paneer were awesome. Enough spice to give you a kick and enough flavor too. This has become our new favorite. Haven't tried the rice dishes but they look so large and delicious. The tandoori is very good also. I look forward to ordering more food from here. One downside is it takes a while for the food to be ready, but that's because they are always busy! Parking is always a drag too.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Best indian food in SF. Thats all you need to know. 

We ordered the lamb and chicken. Got regular spicy -- has so much flavor. We also ordered the fried rice look alike thingy...also bomb. 

Garlic naan --..so fluffy to perfection.
author: Angela C.

description: Eat here if you want to get violently ill. My boyfriend and I ordered a couple different items and both became extremely ill. Go anywhere else.
author: Laura G.

description:
So if you like under seasoned watered down curry... Eat here. The only reason it gets 3 stars is b/c of the BYOB and the fact that the meat well cooked nicely. Other than that. Not a fan of the flavor or rather the flavorless nan, garlic nan and aloo nan and all the rest. 
Probably will not be back..,
Wish I could give it 2 1/2
author: Patti L.

description: This is the best Indian takeaway in the Bay, by far. Casual spot - good for "omg I've been walking around this city all day and I just want to sit down and eat - now". Good variety and some nice twists (adding mint to the chicken biryani - mmm mmmm!). You order at the counter and they bring the food to you. It's BYOB but there are 2 bottle shops just across the street so no worries.
author: Arnab K.

description: Excellent food, amazing service and rocking punjabi music...ordered kabob, chicken curry and palak. All 3 dishes were awesome and the food was priced right as well.
author: Hit D.

description: Prices: ok. Service: fast. Food: Not great. Dry naan, dry rice, portion sizes were wildly uneven (mixed vegetable curry was too small, chicken biryani way too big). The chai is cheap ($1, free refills) but it's not very good. I overhead somebody ask for raita and someone came out to tell him there wasn't any left. If you're in the area, and in a rush, maybe I just didn't order the right dishes, but there are better places a few blocks away if you don't mind walking and waiting.
author: Sam Z.

description: This is not a four star rating restaurant. Even for the price, the food is barely edible. The lamb Biryani tasted like it was being served from several days ago. The naan had the consistency of pita bread. The staff was rude and barely paying attention to what they were doing. The plates and silverware were filthy.
author: Russell J.

description:
This is one of my friend's favourite places to get Indian food. It's a no frills type of place that's similar to Naan-n-Curry. The food tastes better though. We split lamb biryani, some naan and chai. The spice was just about right and the portion was quite large. The prices are within reason too.

The only thing that is bad is that the tables are pretty wobbly so don't try to make any sudden movements. It's pretty busy and noisy inside.
author: Amy J.

description: I love their curries! Not too spicy for someone who can't handle it.  The naan bread is delicious and keeps welllin the fridge as leftovers. My favorite is the eggplant even though I wish it was chunkier than puree.  The tandoori chicken was perfect with its smoky flavor and not as dry compared to Naan & Curry.  They have less of a selection compared to Naan and Curry, but Pakwan's flavors, taste, and freshness of its food is way better.
author: Lisa W.

description: My go-to Indian restaurant in SF. Delicious food, reasonably priced, great location. Oh and did I mention BYOB? Who could ask for more? Just remember to bring cash :)
author: Joe C.

description:
more like  4.5 stars
After our first choice for dinner was closed we hiked over to Pakwan, having already read about it and discussed going multiple times. It's an order at the counter type of place and their menu is rather smaller than your standard indian restaurant but for that you get food that was very good at a very good value.

We ordered chicken tika, naan, saag paneer, rice, and 2 drinks and our total was just under $25. Which, personally, i think was an amazing deal. The chicken tika was rich and flavorful if slightly spicier then i'm used to, and everything was fresh.

Next time we'd skip getting two drinks, since there's free refrigerated water, and maybe pass on the saag panner, which was very good, in favor of another naan and some samosas. It's safe to say we have a new go to indian place.
author: Sara G.

description:
Was never a fan of biryani until I tried Pakwan's lamb version -- it's colorful and delicious with the perfect amount of spices, and the texture is never too dry or too soggy. They give you a lot for a very fair price in comparison to other restaurants, doesn't get better than that. 

I could eat a stack of their perfect crisp-fluffy plain naan for dinner and be completely happy.
author: Angela N.

description:
The food is the best Indian I've ever had. I tried the chicken tikka masala, lamb vindaloo, lamb kabobs, naan and mango lassi.  My ultimate favorite was the lamb kabob. 

As for the service, it is very minimal. It's a "get your own crap you lazy bum" kind of place.

Didn't give this place 5 stars because it's CASH ONLY... Somewhat inconvenient.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Inexpensive, flavorful Indian food. I think Shalimar is still my fave in SF, but this is a close second. 

The palak paneer was well spiced and the chicken tikka masala was tasty. They make their naan looked like it was cooked in the traditional way on the side of a tandoori oven. Although I'm no naan expert, so it could have been a different type of oven, but I did see the cook pulling the bread from the side of some sort of tandoori-looking oven. 

The masala chai kept me tossing and turning all night. Strong stuff!
author: Lee H.

description:
I LOVE PAKWAN!

Why I come here?
Because the food is amazing! The garlic naan is perfectly toasted.  The chicken tikka masala is perfectly spiced and so wonderfully delicious for naan dipping.  The chicken biryani is packed full of flavor and also is very delicious.  Their mango lassi goes so well with the spicy food.  I'm salivating just thinking about it. 

The wait?  
If you come here before 7pm, there is no wait, after 7pm, there is a line out the door and even if you order food, you may not be able to find a table.  

How are the prices?
The prices are super cheap, 1 chicken tikka masala, 1 chicken biryani, 1 garlic naan, 1 mango lassi for about 17 bucks.  They're really fast, no waiter service so no tip needed. Just go up to the cashier, tell them your order, pay, and wait for them to call your number.  Your number will also show up on the tv's they have up in the restaurant.  

What else?
They have fridges full of carafes of water, salsa and mango lassi and you help yourself (you have to pay for the lassi).  The cups, utensils, plates and napkins are all above the water so you just help yourself to that as well.  That's why the prices are so cheap.  

Parking?
You can find street parking here if you come early.  Otherwise, bart to the mission or cab here.

 I cannot reiterate how good the food is here.  COME HERE for indian/pakistani food!
author: Elaine C.

description:
What's not to like about enormously portioned, cheap, hot North Indian and Pakistani food which can rupture your intestines the next morning and leave you sweating all day?

Understand it's cash only, understand that it's in Mission's Hipster central, and understand that you are allowed to bring your drinks inside. 

With this understanding, you can be polite to the man behind the counter who will take your order and issue you a token with a number written on it which you must commit to your short term memory to extract from the cacophonous announcement system resembling New Delhi airport's electronic enunciator while you're sipping your 21st Amendment bought from the Mom and Pop store across the road and wondering  why every white person is an apathetic apolitical struggling artist riding a fixed gear bike.
author: D K.

description:
This is the best Indian food I have ever eaten, I was amazed of how tasty the Chicken tikka tandoori was.
Every time I am around there I need to stop by and get some delicious and yummy Indian food.
My menu is Chicke Tikka Massala / Chicken Tikka Breast / naan / the lentils curry, the spicy lamb.
Also what I like I could bring my own drinks =D
I am so happy this restaurant exist !
author: Fracisca A.

description:
Best Indian food ever! My favorites are the chicken biryani and the beef nihari. Also ask for peppers and onions to really complete the dish. I was introduced to this gem and now I crave it every time I want Indian food. No other place will do. 

Oh a tip would be to call ahead for the nihari. Sometimes they run out or don't have it during the week, which is a tragedy.
author: Courtney P.

description: They used to be really good.  Reasonably priced and good quality.  However recently as of the price increase. Not only do they charge more but their naan is less enjoyable and their food has lost its touch.  I ordered same thing each time along with my girlfriend.  Lamb barrayi and the chicken wrap.  This last two times both our dishes were incredibly oily and sour tasting.  The bread was thin and not fully cooked.  I assumed it was a bad day but seems like it's just how they make their food now.  Won't be going anymore.
author: Nathan A.

description: Expected a lot from this place. I have eaten a lot of authentic Pakistani food so I have some reference point. Given the wait and the crowd, the food doesn't deliver. Maybe it is not my style but it is very aggressively spiced with most dishes containing too much unground cumin which is not pleasant in taste or texture. I think it is popular because of BYOB, which is a great move on their part. Food is not bad though. Price is what you would expect for the city.  Better places in town for my taste.
author: Enoch R.

description: The food is great, but as others have said the ambiance/service a bit lacking (but as long as you come in expecting that, you'll be ok). I've never taken advantage of the BYOB option but love that it's available. Really the only bad thing I have to say about Pakwan is that one time my boyfriend found a few long hairs in his food and we told our friend who then told us that one time she found a rock in her curry. So, as long as you don't get any mysterious foreign objects in your food, this is a great place.
author: Amy Y.

description:
This place has perks

1) BYOB with bottle shop located right across the street, beer, wine, pick it up here
2) Meals are affordable, most around $10 - naan is $1! That's right $1. Love me some carbs

There is no waiter service and you basically gather items to eat yourself (plates, napkins, utensils).
It's also cash only (as is the bottle shop across the road)

Not the most delicious food I've ever eaten - but damn tasty for BYOB and $10
author: Sarah B.

description: This is the best Indian I have ever had. Amazing environments, on a breezy day they open the windows out to the street and you feel as if you are in India. Our favorite dishes are the garlic naan and the ever so endearing Chana Masala, a great vegetarian dish full of tasty curry and garbanzo beans. 5 stars all day and don't forget to add some delicious basmati to any meal:)
author: Tucker D.

description:
I'm not quite sure what the hype is about. The food was ok, and I got to try several items from peoples dishes. The naan was slightly above average and not burned like some other places. The service is good and the workers are polite (not happy peppy energetic and can't wait to take your order, just cool). The utensils were actually a little dirty when I was there, which was admittedly a very busy time, even at around 9pm. They're busy, so they must be doing something right, but yeah, I have to rate based on my personal tastes and I just didn't find anything special here.

Oh, they let you bring in your own alcohol. That's super cool, I have to admit.
author: John N.

description:
South Asian food in the Mission? I was feeling adventurous, so wth. I got a Lamb curry and an order of Garlic Nan.

First bite of the lamb was pretty satisfying, but after the initial rush, my tastebuds gave way to a fat hit of sodium. I tried to keep stirring the dish to redistribute it and balance it out, but I couldn't shake it.

The nan was the size of 2 paperback books - huuuuge. It had the shredded bits of garlic baked on top. It was more subtle than other types of garlic nan/naan I've had in the past and also had a great crispy quality. However it wasn't quite good enough to salvage all the salt in my curry.
author: Alan W.

description: OMG So good!!!! We got a bunch of stuff to share and it was only $45 for 5 peeps- super affordable especially in SF. The rice, the lamb, the curry chicken, the cucumber sauce (i think?) No idea of the names of the plates but everything was so tasty and high quality. A must try! And it's BYOB!  (I should also note that I never get Indian food and 3/5 of us were skeptical but 5/5 of us loved it!)
author: Juls M.

description:
I think I forgot to say in my previous review that this place is BYOB!  

Stop by the liquor store, grab a six pack, hit up Pakwan. 

ENJOY.

I'm adding another 0.5 stars for that. :D
author: Vivian C.

description:
2 stars for their logistics, how hard is is to just tell people "watch the monitor and pickup your food".  And I guess it changes from time to time, grr.

But the food is what really counts and that was amazing and super cheap.  Dear lady M and I feasted for $30, we dined on:

Nan, samosas (comes with a scoop of garbanzo bean something, very good), rice, saag paneer, chicken curry (with roasted peppers, forget the name) and tandoori lamb chops.  I would give the last item 15 stars if the laws of yelp could be bent and that were somehow possible.  Everything was very fresh and flavorful, though the chicken in the curry seemed a little over done.

Don't forget to get your plates and other items!  Sauces were very good, grab those too.
author: Patrick S.

description:
They take way late takeout orders, which is awesome (provided you get there before 11pm closing).  Food was quick and took less than 10 mins. 

I tried the beef nihari this time, and while quite flavorful and the sauce was great, the meat was super lean, which I'm not too into.  I ate it all anyway.  If you're not into bones and something a bit leaner tasting, it'd be fine.

Their saag paneer was great as always though maybe not super incorporated into the saag like usual, but still really tasty.
author: Xue H.

description:
When I'm not at Naan n' Curry you'll find me at Pakwan. 

This place rocks. 

All I ever order is the Chicken Tikka, rice and naan. 

I know it's not the most creative thing in the world, but it satisfies me. 

The place itself is nothing to brag about in terms of decor but the food is awesome. I particularly liked their plain naan. 

Parking isn't too bad. 

Price-wise it was about $12 per person, which is fine by me.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Good solid curry at a reasonable price.  Lots of meat in the curry (the lamb one was super delicious), the butter chicken was a bit too much like a chicken tikka masala for my taste, but I have to admit it went very well with the hot fresh naan (which is some of the best I've had in SF).

I've yet to find an indian place here in SF that compared to my favourites in London, but Pakwan is a decent place and if you're in the area and looking for a low-frills meal, I'd recommend them. 

Also, the best mango lassi I've had in years - perfectly sweet and sooooo fresh!
author: Ali B.

description:
I went here again over the weekend with a friend since it's been years, I had forgotten how good the food is.  Besides the great food, the other reason as everyone else had mentioned, they allow you to bring in your own alcoholic beverages.  Most people go across the street to the liquor store since it's right there...might as well!


Just note: CASH ONLY joint now, before they use to take credit cards.  That's how long it's been since I visited.

Otherwise Enjoy!
author: Monique T.

description: This place was awesome. I really enjoyed the casual atmosphere. Especially that I could grab my own pitcher of water whenever I needed one. The pakora was delicious and the chicken saag was out of this world!
author: Ashley H.

description:
This place is AWESOME! 

The mango lhasi is refreshing and delicious.

The chicken Kabab roll is a only 6 bucks and its enough to fill you up while being out of this world delicious. 

The garlic naan is always fresh, warm, soft and crispy. 

Anything with lamb here is especially delicious ie the Lamb biryani and the lamb tandoori. OH MY.
author: Nasrin M.

description:
Yummy yummy food! I absolutely love the vegetarian biryani and tandoori chicken here.

Knocking off one star for the ambiance ...it can get super loud and over crowded which makes me not want to go there as often.
author: Shruti M.

description:
There's nothing nice about this restaurant.
Not going back!
pros:
we got parking? 

cons:
looked like a really bad area, lots of beggars around, one the beggars tried speaking to my 8 month old baby, really creepy :|
may not find parking
restaurant looked filthy inside, they dont clean their tables, floor and chairs so you can imagine the kitchen.
food poisoning the next day after having chicken biryani and channa masala
author: Sumana M.

description: Wow! This is some of the best indian food in the city hands down! You can't beat the prices here either. Everything we had was good. They grill the chicken in a tandoor so it is incredibly tasteful! The chicken tikka masala is great although it would be ridiculously good if they used the same grilled chicken they use for the kabobs. The naan is out of this world! I think it may be the best I have ever had! Can't wait to go back and visit again. Then after you can go to cream just down the road for dessert!!!
author: Mallory R.

description:
Solid Indian food, my favorite in the Mission, maybe in the city. My go-tos are tikka masala and saag paneer.

Can get pretty busy during weekend evenings (along with the rest of Valencia restaurants, of course).
author: Thuan N.

description:
The place is slightly grungy, the tables could use a wiping & the menus could get some new lamination. 

But the Naan alone at this place would keep me coming back for more warm doughy goodness.

The chicken and veggie dishes I have tried at this place were flavorful and the meat tender. 

I am sure each entry here packs thousands upon thousands of calories, but if you are dieting then you probably aren't eating naan and cream-based sauces in the first place! (Maybe then opt for Roti & some garbanzo&peas dish)

The prices are fair hence I am able to put the "grunge factor" aside & just enjoy the food as I daydream about some beautiful location that is not here. 
Maybe just bring a really good looking date to keep your gaze for the duration of the meal...
author: Nina M.

description: Good restaurant for a quick stop and very reasonable pricing, but not the best service. I really like the lamb biryani and their naans. It is a great combination with their mango lassi. Their foods are also not very spicy, but not very healthy. I will definitely consider going back there if I am in the area.
author: Sasan A.

description:
Note: This is a self served place! 

You first place your order at the cashier. Pay. Then pick up your food. 
You can pour water yourself or pay to get some delicious drinks in the fridge. The utensils are in the front. 

Mango Lassi (Mango drink mix with yogurt) $2- delicious! It's like a creamy mango smoothie! A must have!

Garlic Nan $1.99- I can not taste any garlic whatsoever! I'm sorry but I had better tasting nan. 

Lamb Biryani (Lamb cooked with spices,tomatoes and layered with Basmati rice) $7.99- This portion is huge!!!! Lamb is nice and tender. It's a tad bit spicy, but not too much! Totally worth it!

Nihari (A very special traditional boneless beef curry) $7.99- SPICY curry dish. This dish does not come with rice, so you can add Chawal (Seasoned basmati rice) for $1.50 more. This dish is good, but the Lamb Biryani is wayyyyy better. 

I didn't like the atmosphere much. It was super cold and really dimmed. I went around 3pm on a  wet day, but still... food is suppose to warm up my day and make me feel better, but the food here didn't do that :(  but at least I left full! AMEN!
author: Sandy T.

description:
This is a strange testament to how much I love Pakwan.  I was eating tikka masala there one day, when I bit into something that had an odd texture and a really odd taste. It was so odd that I took it out of my mouth and put it on my plate for further inspection. Looking at it was a mistake.  Prodding it with my knife was an even bigger one. I grew up in FL, home to large beetles and palmetto bugs. That's relevant to the story.

I was pretty sure I just chewed on a big bug and I was starting to freak out. I was dining with the Captain who was trying to convince me that it wasn't a bug, but he's saying it in the same tone that he uses to tell me that I'm just hearing things and that there's no one outside the window at night.  He's not really sure that there isn't, but he's sure enough and he's positive that he doesn't want to go outside and look.  He says that it's just something that got stuck to the bottom of the pot and burned. I'm not convinced. This goes back and forth for awhile and I've stopped eating my lunch.  That's when he reached over, picked it up from my plate and ate it. "Mmmm...good...see, it's not a bug."  If we were in Uganda, he'd be eating grasshoppers with the natives. But we're not. I continue to weigh the situation.  

My first conclusion is "Aww, he loves me so much, that he doesn't want me to be traumatized by the possibility of having just eaten a bug." My final conclusion is "He loves Pakwan so much that, even if it were a bug, he wants to hedge against future objections to eating at Pakwan."  If I'd written this when it happened a year ago I would have said, "Pakwan is so great that even if there's a bug in my food every once in awhile, I'd still go back."  That's love! Pakwan, however, might not have agreed and I still wanted to go back, so I didn't write it.

A few weeks ago I learned about a large spice called cardamom which has tough, thick skin and is shaped kind of like a large pod.  It's used in tikka masala and, when roasted until it's black, can look kind of like... a big bug. I'm sorry I ever doubted you, Pakwan.
author: P J.

description:
Step one: Check yoself before you judge. You will note that the name does not contain the words "Palace" or "Raj" for good reason.  Don't be one of those people that tries to legitimize your street cred with indian food then rag about Pakwan on yelp because it's not served on silver platters by nicely dressed underpaid staff. Get your expectations right, then proceed. 

Step two: go directly to counter, order bhindi masala (if they have it), chicken tikka masala, and vegetable curry. Maybe toss in some jasmine rice or biryani if you're feeling fancy. The naan is whatever so don't complain when you order it and it's whatever. i just told you.  

Step three: pay very little money!

Step four: Eat and rejoice! 

Step five: repeat steps 1-4 throughout the week.
author: Luke T.

description: This is our neighborhood go to for Indian/Pakistani food. The service is really friendly especially the gentleman that is always at the front counter. Chicken biryani is very tasty, the naan is always fresh and they have some of the best saag paneer that I've had! Huge fan and have been coming every couple of weeks to get a fix!
author: Chauanh D.

description: A great place to try North Indian food. BYOB is the best feature. As you pay for food first and then get your food, there will be possibility that your appetizers and entrees all are put out at the same time. So, the tip is to have 2 separate bills. Order appetizers first and after 10 minutes order Entrees. That way the food will come out in order.
author: Pratyush P.

description:
I would have given 5 *s but they lost for 2 reasons. 

Self service. To the extent that you have to get your food from the counter yourself. I have been to other self service places as well where you order and pay first but still the food is served to your table.

Only cash. Now this is a bigger concern. If you are going there carry cash. Else you would end up withdrawing from a dingy ATM outside the restaurant. I had to do this. I'm sure this place is doing good so I can't understand why cards are not accepted.

Food. They get 5+ *s for the food. We ordered chicken seekh kebob, chicken tikka, achari chicken, paneer Masala and naans. I just loved the achari chicken. Tikka and seekh kebob were nice.
author: Kamal M.

description: Amazing indian food!! I had the lamb biryani and it was really good. Portions are really large, so I ended up taking the remaining food with me. I had it for breakfast the next day, and it was still really good although it was now cold.
author: Vassiliki K.

description:
damn..i paid like 8 bucks for some BBOOMMMBB chicken curry and bread..i honestly coudln't finish it all! i really like the pay at the counter and sit down and eat service, its a place you can get in and out if you are in a hurry.

delicious food with great prices!
author: Jaime D.

description:
Fast, no-frills service with tasty, inexpensive food in big portions AND byob??!!  How could you not like Pakwan?!  Chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, bbq lamb, garlic naan, basmati rice are my go-to's.  Ambiance is super chill, don't expect any service since you get everything (table, water, utensils, sauces, beer) on your own accord.  You'll come out a little smelly but so satisfied!

My favorite Indian restaurant in the city hands down.
author: Jane N.

description:
We ate at Pakwan a couple weeks ago and I just got around to a review.

I usually choose Naan & Curry when I need my Chicken Tikka Massala fix - but the reviews were so good for Pakwan, I thought we could try it on the way home from work. My husband was game and so we exited BART at 16th Street and found our way. We were the only people in the place (it was only 5:30pm), but I ordered our usual dishes: Chicken Tikka Massala, Beef Kabab, Daal, Saag Paneer, and Garlic Naan.

The ambiance was as expected, the service was okay too, but the food wasn't as good as Naan & Curry. The Chicken Tikka Massala tasted less creamy/spicy and more tomato-y (hope that makes sense). The Beef Kabab was my favorite, for it was very tender and tasty. And the veggies were just fine, but the Garlic Naan was more naan than garlic. If you order Garlic Naan, you should taste some garlic! 

But here's the kicker that made our experience so bad: as my husband was finishing up the last of the spinach, he found cellophane/plastic wrap in his mouth. It was so actually in the Saag Paneer dish...very unpleasant. He said it freaked him out and it almost made him throw up - it was so foreign to find that in spinach!

We will not return to Pakwan - it wasn't worth interrupting our commute home. Mission folks...you can have it!
author: Deb B.

description:
This place is a neighborhood gem, and the food is always consistently good. Two persons can easily eat for $20. 
I'm a particular fan of their chicken tikka masala, and tandoori chicken, they also have really good khir for something sweet.
They don't have alcohol that you can get beer right across the street at the liquor store and bring it in.

There are many higher priced Indian restaurants in the area, but I feel that this low-priced restaurant is far more tasty then a place such as Dosa.  I'm much more interested in going food rather than fussy service, white tablecloths or a formal atmosphere. I'd much rather just go order at the counter and have them just bring it to your table.
author: Jamey F.

description:
Stopped by Pakwan after my visit to Mission Dolores which is just across the street. The food was good. I ordered a chicken biryani, nan and a curry dish. The service was fast and the place was not too crowded.
The tea was better than what you can get in their Fremont location. The biryani also taste better here in SF than in Fremont. They also give you free yogurt on the side which you don't get in Fremont.
I would recommend this place if you around in this area and craving for Indian food.
author: Raman S.

description:
Came here with Ginger Broty and his lady, El Suze, for dinner the other night. 

Got the garlic naan, it was bland, but still good naan. 

Began Bartha was good! Though it'd have been better if not emulsified. 

Saag paneer was thick and had excellent heat! And the mixed vegetable curry was not mind blowing. 

BYOB + and cash only - but quick service + and felt like we were being rushed out - and loud frantic restaurant -. Also super cheap + and they make the best samosas I've ever had +. Oh, and I didn't get sick!. +++++
author: Emily D.

description:
Jack and I just ate here for a late lunch/early dinner. It was so tasty! We were craving Indian food, and it definitely satisfied the craving.

We both ordered two specials:

The Chicken Vindaloo (chicken curry & potatoes) and the Lamb Shank.  We also ordered rice for 2 and naan.  It came to a little over $20.  

My food was excellent.  Jack's food was good, but he liked mine better.  

There isn't really "service," as it is counter service only.  The guy was very nice.  

The establishment is cash only.  Another reviewer rated it 1 star with a one liner, "Down with cash only establishments?" Not sure I get this.  Visa/Mastercard/everything else not only charges you, but it charges the restaurant.  I respect places that do cash only, as it serves small businesses better, as the 3% of their income impacts them way more!  Anyway, take note.

Also, I have no idea why...the place was incredibly smoky (not like cigarettes, but like fire) when we first entered.  It cleared up by the time we left.
author: cyndi t.

description: As some one who hates most Indian restaurants in the US since they are so Americanized, I have to give them 5 stars! Authentic Indian food that is made with fresh ingredients and its BYOB, which makes its really affordable!
author: Nehal M.

description: Came here based off a friend's recommendation and was disappointed. The Naan came out burnt in multiple places and the chicken biryani was all rice with bits of dried out chicken. How sad :(
author: Van H.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city and top favorite for Indian.   The food is always great.

Favorite Dishes: Paneer Makahni; Vegetable Biryani; Garlic Naan; Vegetable Pakora 

Tip: there is a very big difference between very very very spicy and "Indian" spicy. If you aren't Indian and you really want to that oh-so-good-burn of your insides, ask for Indian Spicy and tell the man you are serious (with a smile of course) and make sure he looks you in the eye and acknowledges your masochistic request AND assure him you won't send it back.  Once you have both agreed on these terms, enjoy a fiery dish of exploding flavor and spice. Raita, mango lassi, or beer helps.

Pros: Indian Spicy is still totally edible. You can bring outside beers (there is a liquor store across the street. goes well with the meal). Price is good.

Cons: no delivery, cash only (ATM is right next door)
author: Anna H.

description: Its a BYOB place with good Indian food. I tried the kababs and palak chicken. It was good. in weekends keep some time if you want to come to this place because you may have to wait 15-20 min for a place. And if you forget to bring an opener just ask your server
author: Soumyava D.

description:
Very tasty,  hot food,  great service.

Just know that when you finish, your  clothes will smell of  food...but it's  worth it.
author: vijay v.

description:
Good place.  Cash only.  Self service.  Cheap.

It was an onion and garlic nan, the tandoori lamb chops, lamb, veg masala and rice for two...good meal.

p.s. the lamb chops were a bomb!
author: Pam S.

description:
Neighborhood Indian food staple in the Mission is always packed so call ahead if you are ordering to go. Otherwise the cafeteria style dining makes for a casual dinner or lunch. Cash only and I have heard that it's BYOB although I usually take out.

What I love: 

- Garlic or onion Naan:  pull it apart when its warm and enjoy the fresh garlic or onions smeared all over and you will be in Naan heaven!
- Saag Paneer: a favorite spinach/cheese dip of mine but they make it particularly well here
- Biryani: particularly the lamb biryani but they are all generously proportioned and perfect

The only thing I tried that I would NOT recommend is the "Assorted Pickles". Should've asked what they were before ordering since what I got was intensely salty, unidentifiable, and disgusting (and I am an open minded pickle fan).
author: Lorraine Y.

description:
It should be said immediately, I review Indian restaurants a lot.

This is one of my favorite places to go for a casual curry. No table service, wood tables, order at the counter setup. Bathrooms are not so clean. AC is non existent and the service behind the counter is hit and miss. Cash only accepted because Allah does not like credit and neither do the Mexicans in the kitchen or the IRS.

What makes this place excel, the meat items mostly but they do a decent job on the veg items. I recommend the tandoori chicken leg, the lamb chop.
author: Curry Man X.

description:
Wanted to try a new halal indopak restaurant in the city during my lunch break.  This one wasn't too far from work, so gave it a shot.

I came in after the lunch rush, so the place was pretty empty, although I did notice there was ample indoor seating and what looked like a really nice interior dining room.  Me?  I snagged one of the few sidewalk tables, since it was a gorgeous day out and you can never go wrong people watching in the Mission District.

Whenever I try a new indopak place I always get nan and chicken tikka masala, because seriously if they can't do that right, then nothing else is really worth trying.  This place did it great!  Huge serving of both, and a really good spice balance in the masala.  Also the manga lassi was a very nice addition.

All in all I was very happy with my choice, and found the CTM to not be as greasy as expected, always a bonus!  Would go back if I am ever in the area!
author: Brice H.

description: Ordered the chicken tikka masala and sagar daal, as well as garlic naan. Such a great meal, I would definitely go again.
author: Jill C.

description:
the best tikka masala! maybe not the best...but really yummy haha.

tip: ask for it extra spicy! it really makes a big difference and gives it a nice kick. for aorund 10 bucks u get a huge portion that a lot bigger and better than most indian places in sf. the service and interior are not great to be honest, but the food makes up for it. maybe the solution is to take it to go?
author: Thach N.

description: The place seems pretty dirty ---- the table was sticky and there were very annoying fruit flies that constantly hovered over my food. Yuck.......... The bathroom floors are unbelievably slippery ----- uh, who knows why.......... The food? I had a tandoori chicken leg. It wasn't bad --- extremely salty though, and the meat was kind of scanty. Perhaps a different type of bird? The thigh was tiny, a part of the back was attached, so it was a whole leg plus bit of back, but the meat was chiefly only on the drumstick part... And the naan was good. That's all I had - I just went in for a quick bite.
author: Gregory N.

description:
This place is off the hook, for some reason the Pakwan's off offarel street is not that great. I always go to this location off 16th street. 

Food is never cold here, always piping hot and tasty. Complimentary hot chai tea with the meal, that have other drinks as well, but chai seems to go better. The best butter chicken and garlic naan by far. You are allowed to BYOB its great :)
author: Shirley M.

description: After 20+ years of visiting Pakwan, I'm now very disappointed with the owner and management who no longer seem to care for their customers.  They forget they live in American and you can't serve meat that is overly dry or have been sitting out for days .... My need tasted like cardboard with vinegar.. On top of that, the token they hand to you for waiting for your meal was so filthy that you can scrape old greasy food off of it with your fork. It is totally disgusting and unsanitary.  I'm surprised that the city of San Francisco hasn't shut this venue down...maybe it's an inside payoff deal.  Ughhh.
author: Pedro D.

description: Terrible. Simply terrible food. I drove all the way up from MV because I was craving Nihari, and this place kind of does the job. But, they were all out. So, I had a whole sample set to replace it. Well ....  The chicken Haleem was tasteless, a purée of unappetizing lentils. I ordered a chicken tikka, but was given chicken tikka masala instead; your average sweetened up pseudo Indian curry, not impressed. I peered over at other folks with their chicken tikkas, and realized I wasn't missing much: plain red chicken legs, no BBQ scorch marks, no dripping succulence, no orange spices. The seekh kabab was not acceptable: over salted and under spiced. Which finally brings me to the tikka boti, beef. Was it simply amazing?  Did it like totally save the day?  Was my journey up 280N totally so worth it?  No. I felt like puking. Average, average, below average, what the hell is this, how drunk are people when they eat here...?  I wanted to give it one star, but the cashier was nice so, here you go, two stars. Begrudgingly. Because I am way too generous. If you are curious about good Pakistani food, I would suggest you venture all the way down to Santa Clara to a place with the initials K&C. No, not kfc... It's the best Pakistani restaurant in the entire Bay Area, by far, with the typical menu set.  So, once again, San Francisco has miserably failed to provide me with any compelling reason why I should even consider moving there: overrated food, underwhelming ambiance, energy-less sleepyheads with the fashion sense of DC comics, lackluster clubs and grungy bars.
author: Van X.

description: Still a great place but I'm taking a star off owing to some inconsistency. Sometimes the rice is great, other times its meh. Sometimes the chicken is great, other times it's overdone. Still my favorite place in the city, although you can get similar quality and slightly larger portions for a little less price if you wonder to south bay.
author: Parry G.

description:
An excellent and affordable Pakistani/Indian restaurant located in the Mission. 

I came here on a Saturday night with my boyfriend and his family around 7:30PM. Parking was extremely hard to find in that area and seating was very limited in the restaurant. The line was also out the door just to order!

Although it took almost 10 minutes to order our food, it only took another 10 for it to be ready. Considering the amount of people there, that wasn't bad at all! This is a self-service kind of restaurant with no tabling service. The pro, though, is that you can BYOB, and pretty much every table but our's did. 

The Chicken Tikka Masala was delicious! This place only does medium spice or higher, so if you don't like spicy foods then this may not be the place for you. The naan was perfectly cooked and the rice went well with the curry. Just FYI but the chai is not free here, unlike many other places. Plus it's cash only. 

Overall an excellent place to visit when you're craving curry! I am definitely coming back and bringing a bottle of wine next time.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The food is good, the wait for a place to sit can be long, but totally worth.  They got their spice and naan game on lock.
author: Bram M.

description: Wow, name change ! It used to be Pakwan. Our one house stop for biriyani cravings. We always do take out for out of town guests and its always been a great hit. Great value for money too !
author: Jisha A.

description: Great good and clean facilities. Our favorites are -- lamb chops, tandoori naan, sheek kebabs, dal, shahi paneer and baingan.
author: A L.

description:
Worst Indian food ever. My garlic naan was almost completely burned on the underside and it lacked any semblance of flavor. The fish tikka masala was flavorless and you couldn't taste any of the spices. The paneer tikka masala was so bland and the paneer tasted old. 

TLDR: White-washed indian food and there is reason why its so cheap.
author: Bob B.

description:
Cheap, fast, and filling. A good variety of vegetarian options.

I ordered take out and it was ready at the counter when I came in 15 minutes later. 

Wish they took credit cards.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Cash only!!! Thank you to the kind cashier who gave us a break when we realized we were short a few bucks on cash.  He was super chill and let us pay with the cash we had on hand.  We had spent our other cash at the liquor store across the street picking up a bottle of wine to share over our meal.

The chicken tikka masala was thoroughly spiced and tasty!  One of the spicier CTMs we've had in a while, and by gum, it really hit the spot!  D always springs for the garlic naan, which tastes like they use REAL garlic instead of just sprinkling some garlic powder on a regular naan.  We like the laidback feel and the self-service, which in no way detract from the tasty offerings and probably contribute to the EXCELLENT prices.  We always feel like this place is such a great local gem, but BE WARNED: this is NOT a mainstream-flavored bland Naan N Curry.  No stomach pains or other associated maladies yet (whew!), but their spices and flavors are much punchier than what you'll get at... say... lunchtime at the office (what?! I promise I'm not bitter that we get fake ethnic food catered by our local deli.).

D and I always enjoy our date nights here, and we ALWAYS leave with our Indian food cravings satisfied and tummies full.
author: Hannah C.

description: I love going to this place.  The portion to price is very reasonable and the food is really good!  I go here all the time with my friends!
author: Johnathan W.

description: This place is legit as fuck. The Chai is only a buck with unlimited refills and it's delicious. It's BYOB, so you can bring a 6 pack on the weekends and enjoy AMAZING food as well. I absolutely ADORE the food here, and the service is swift and accurate. I should get some kind of platinum star card cause I'm here so often ^__^
author: Krzysztof S.

description:
For Desi (Indian/Pakistani) food in the Bay, there are different spots one goes for different dishes. Pakwan has, in my opinion the best Biriyani in the city. For a dinner for two people, get an order of chicken Biriyani and a couple of orders of Kebabs. That will more than stuff your belly. 

Even though their Biriyani is comfort food for me, personally, i find the curries a bit greasy for my taste.
author: Vijay S.

description: Delicious!!  Come in, place your order and hope for a seat. Great active ambience.  Good prices for good food. Food comes out hot and tasty!  Well worth a trip!
author: Amy C.

description:
My sister came to visit me in North Cal this past weekend and she immensely craved Indian food so I yelped, yelped, and yelped some more to find Pakwan. At first I was really stoked about Pakwan beacuse it seemed to be cheap and delicious, a win-win situation! 
We got to Mission district and ate Pakwan probably around 7 on a casual Saturday night, it was pretty packed but we managed to get a seat. We ordered the samosas, normal and garlic naan, chicken tiki masala, and a vegetable curry for her since shes doesn't eat meat. This came out to roughly 21 dollars - a huge round up for two girls and 20 bucks i'd say.

Samosas - I ordered this because I've had a pretty good experience in the past with samosas and she's never tried it. it was good but it wasn't out of the world/didn't impress her much

Naan - the garlic naan was not as fluffy and as enjoyable as other garlic naans that I've tried before. But let's be honest, naan is naan is carb is delicious. So not much complaints here.

Veggie Curry - This I thought was one of the better dishes despite being a bit spicy. There were carrots and potatoes and what nots that were cooked perfectly!

Chicken Tiki Marsala - This was not as good as I had hoped for. Everyone on yelp talked about it but the chicken was dry! The plate itself was just not anything out of the ordinary. 

I think it really is so highly rated because of the amount of decent (not great/bad) food you get for the amount you pay.
author: Jessica K.

description: I was waiting for a take-out order, and I saw a mouse scurry across and dive down a little hole right at the cash register.  I mentioned this to the guy at the register and he said, "A mouse? Maybe just one or two. And the health department inspects regularly."  Ugh -- that doesn't change the fact that I saw a mouse.
author: Geoffrey H.

description:
Not a huge fan of Indian food but this place is always packed so they're doing something right.
