It's good.. The samosas are yum and the tiki masala chicken in spinach was very good!

If you like Naan - you'll like it here. Garlic and onion naan!
author: Monica S.

description:
I came here at 9:30pm on a weekday night for take-out. My food was prepared super fast: chicken tikka masala and garlic naan. Prices are really fair and I just love that it's actually open past 9.

Both items tasted really great, but the Naan wasn't wrapped in foil, only some wax paper, so it was cold by the time I got home. Hence the minus one star... 

Cash only.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
Food was awesome.  I liked the seat your self and BYOB status of this joint.
3 dishes and naan for 27 bucks?  Not bad!

Would've been 5 stars but those dishes were dirty!  Not trying to taste the prior clients meal!
author: Theodore Y.

description:
My mouth is watering as I write this, thinking about Pakwan's chicken tikka masala. I l.o.v.e. a good chicken tikka masala... and this place has it. Served over a bed of fragrant jasmine rice, too. YUM.

Service is friendly and super quick. Be sure to keep an eye on the flatscreen, where they will post your order once it's ready. The first time I was here, I thought they delivered food to your table (what with the placard they give you when you order) -- but nope! It's DIY -- utensils in one corner, with chilled pitchers of water and cups awaiting nearby, and a counter where you pick up your food. The set-up's perfect for families, groups, and diners in a rush... and the food is good for everyone.
author: Julie D.

description: Best Indian in San Francisco -actually the Bay- and insanely cheap. We always mean to try new restaurants when we're in the city but more often than not end up coming here. Delish.
author: Gina G.

description: Love this place hands down the best. The food is cooked to perfection. Friendly staff. My favorite is the Tandoori chicken spicy with the regular rice.
author: Jazmine A.

description: I went her for the second time and the food has been always great. Very casual restaurant were you order first at the counter and they give you a number and wait for your food. Drinks and utensils are help yourself. The food quality is good with good portions. This place can become very busy in the evenings. They have other locations in the city but I have not checked them out.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Worst chicken tikka masala. Skip it.
Best Lamb. Go with the lamb.
Beef stuffed naan.
Beef kabab.
author: N W.

description: Vegetarian options are not great. The place was also a bit unclean. Would not visit again.
author: Murali R.

description:
A night out in town with my sweetie (Rachel Ray, get it?) in the Mission for a delish dinner date here at Pakwan.  I love Indian food and this place had just enough flavor and spice to take me to India.  

Like a lot of Indian places in the city, walk in, order, get your own plates, utensils and grab a seat till your number is called.  25!  Jumped up out of my seat to pick up our food...I was hungry!  Balancing the chicken tikka masala, achar gosht (lamb curry with roasted pepper, extra spicy), naan, and chawal (basmati rice) back to our table, we dug in.  The ctm was creamy and buttery with just a little kick.  The lamb meat was soft and tender, but not soft enough where the meat just melts in your mouth.  Extra spicy was really not that spicy until you get to the bottom of the plate when you are scraping up every bit of the curry with the naan.  And the naan was soft and fluffy as naan should be.  

I give this place 4 stars...for great food and great price.  All that for $16 and change, what a deal!  Onwards to Bi-Rite Creamery for dessert!
author: Amy L.

description: This spot was formerly held in such high regard I even had my birthday here even though you have. 25% chance of getting explosive diarrea.  Byob - cheap - and quick. Just like the gentrification of the mission - things are changing. 7 to 10 people ordered to go after us and got their food before us - weak sauce - the fire out the back side will be in vain - only will go to the tl location
author: Tim G.

description:
I'm not a big fan of Indian/Pakistani food, but this place was pretty good.

-Beef skewer- very strong herbal flavor but it was good. A little dry.
-Samosa- love it, make sure you get the bottle sauces for it. 
-Chicken tiki masala- bit spicy for my taste but it was good. Not as creamy as im used to, but still good
-Naan- I really like their naan. Really soft, but the thinner areas are crunchy. 

Service is a bit odd.. they give you numbers to display on your table, but you are expected to pick up your own food. Why not just have numbers on receipts? 

SLOW. We waited for about half an hour for our food... and when went in, there was only 1 couple in front of us. They have a ton of to go orders, but they should speed things up.
author: Erica L.

description:
I love this place! 

This is my go to place for cheap Indian food. The chicken tikka masala is so flavorful and buttery! Also a fan of the lamb biryani. The lamb is super tender! My two must haves every time. 

My only complaint of Pakwan is that the meat can be too dry. I love the curry of the chicken tikka masala but I am not a fan of the chicken meat (way too dry and overcooked). I find that this is true for a lot of the meats of the curries but I still come back repeatedly for the flavors of the curries! 

They don't serve alcohol at the restaurant but it's BYOB (there is a market across the street). I'm not sure if this is legal but everyone does it.
author: Donna W.

description: Reliable reasonably healthy, inexpensive Indian food. Pakwan was a staple for me when I lived in SF.
author: Ian K.

description:
How is it that a restaurant that serves room temperature curries on dirty plates with food scraps leftover can achieve an average 4 star rating. 

I don't mean to get into the socioeconomic divide that exists in the mission, but something about the demographic shifts have led to poor quality of food throughout the Mission! I first had a plate with food scraps and I kindly returned it to the cashier. No apology, but I was okay with it.

I wanted a spicy dish of Chicken Karahi. Their definition of spicy is just adding a few California peppers. The one thing that I can't stand in restaurants besides breaking cultural integrity and authenticity is refusing to serve quality food to customers. My partner ordered the Masala. It was ice cold, and we had to request the server to reheat his dish.

Poor quality food, unsanitary conditions, and refusing to get the order right on the first try deserves 1 star. Do not go this restaurant, you mine as well collect food scraps behind a better place like House of Curry in Berkeley, CA.
author: Daniel C.

description: Good portions, byob and great fresh naan. The chicken tikka masala has gone downhill but is still decent.  Delicious mango lassi too but there are better main course options at other Indian restaurants around the block
author: Bradlee P.

description:
4 VISITS to this restaurant

Result: twice sick after 12hours... you know... when you stick to the bowl. And these happened to one of my friend too!

Their dishes are flavoursome considering the price, but I would not like to see the quality of the meat used to make it and in what hygenic conditions they work! 

consider this place only if you feel confident on your stomach immunity!
author: TheReal C.

description:
This place is pretty solid. Self-serve and decently priced, the portions were large and I loved their bottled cilantro sauce. 

I think next time I'd ask for my dish a little spicier (the Chana Masala was a little bland), but overall it was delicious and tasted like they use fresh ingredients. 

I was going to give this place 3 stars, but it got one extra because I didn't leave feeling like I needed to run to the nearest bathroom.
author: Meg I.

description:
turnip curry. chana masala. wish it was more of a sit down restaurant, and the temperature of the food coulda been a bit more, hot and spicy wise - had to ask for green chilies but they didnt have proper indian kind, only jalepenos... anyway...

super good curries tho, i am actually still cravin it now...
author: Ann L.

description: I knew this place would be good because it was filled with Indian people eating Indian food. We were not disappointed. We ordered a little bit of everything to try, and loved every bite. The workers were very patient with us and gave us excellent service as we asked for good suggestions on what to order, added more food to our order, and were very touristy in the restaurant. I would go back here without a second thought. I HIGHLY recommend this delicious restaurant!
author: Liesl N.

description: The service is very friendly.  The Tandoori Beef and Tandoori Chicken are both delicious.  I also love their Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Paneer, and Daal Channa.  The naan is close to perfection and the portions are large enough that I always enjoy two meals of yummy food.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Came here a few weekends ago and was pleasantly surprised.  I didn't realize it was a work-a-rant (you get a number and place it on your table).  Not a big deal, but something to know.

More important tip - BYOB.  You can get a 6pack of Kingfisher at the bodega across the street.   

Finally, get a seat by the window.  It gets warm inside the restaurant.
author: Larry L.

description: Please do not visit this restaurant .. I got stone in my food.. Also they do not maintain hygiene
author: Sriharsha B.

description: I met a group of friends here with 1 baby!  The staff was very accommodating and they have a good amount of space in there for groups.  You order at the counter and then find your seat!  The food seriously came up within 5-10 minutes.  I'm not sure how they cook it so fast but it was really tasty.  I only wish the lamb was a bit more tender in the Biryani, but it was tasty nonetheless.  The Saag Paneer (my fave) was delicious and we also had butter chicken, yum!  Chai tea was very good as well and only $1 w/ free refills.  It did get crowded after about 7 pm so get there early.  My friend's son made  a mess with the rice and the bus person refused to let her sweep it up.  He was so sweet.  Enjoy!!!
author: Meli B.

description: Excellent. The Karahi chicken was excellent. It's a Northern Pakistan tomato-based curry dish. The tandoori lamb was amazing. Best tandoori that I've ever eaten.
author: David H.

description: Reasonably priced, but not too impressed. Both the samosa and chicken seekh kabab were spicy. The chicken in the tikka masala was dry, and the sauce was more tomato based. Nan was just eh. Not worth paying the extra $1 for the garlic. Their best dish was the saag paneer.
author: Sophia B.

description: The food here was bad. I had a paneer dish and it tasted the same as a MTR ready to eat. I have been to bad places in the bay area but this place tops it all. Bad Food.
author: Rahul D.

description: We had a great dinner at this low key Indian restaurant.  The decor is nondescript cafeteria, but there are awesome Bollywood videos playing on a big TV.  As mentioned, it's self service.  Order at the window, take a number and take a seat.  The food was excellent.  We really liked the garlic naan, tandoori chicken tikka and chicken biryani, The baingan bharta  was spiced differently from what we are used to, but was still really good.  It's a great meal and a great deal.  We would be happy to dine there again.
author: Joel S.

description: Their $1 Chai is a sure winner! Then, their naan is served hot & comes in many varieties.
author: Catrina G.

description: Love, love, love! This place is ultra low-key, yet absolutely delicious.  No reservation needed, walk in and order at the counter then saunter across the street to the market and purchase some beer or wine to go. Pakwan is BYOB and I recommend an apricot beer to pair with some spicy masala.  Good for eat in or take out.
author: Mariella A.

description: Really really grown on me.  Yummmmmm.  The lamb Vindaloo today was incredible.
author: Frank A.

description:
This place seemed to have "late night craving" written all over it, and lends itself well to odd hour munchies due to the hours - open late and doesn't close mid-day. I wasn't much on the ambiance - there isn't really any, and the day we went, it was so bloody hot inside people were sweating and fanning themselves. Maybe no air conditioning?

Anyway, it's self-serve and the food was decent, very filling, and nothing fancy. The fluffy, huge naan were especially good. Chicken tikka masala  ($7.99) was good, not the best I've ever had, but good. Cash only.
author: Stacy G.

description: This is an authentic pakistani/Indian restaurant. If you want real curry experience, this is the place. I really like how they have added kabob and variety of grilled meat dishes.
author: Muhammad G.

description: I had to wait 40 mins for the food to be ready. Plus I asked them not to make it spicy but the guy that got the order put double spicy on my order and he was laughing. This place is 0 stars.
author: Moyra F.

description:
-1 star cause they're not the fastest tigers in the Changa Manga.

Overall pretty good.  Came here on a Sunday night around 530ish, place picked up around 6 and was poppin' til I left the mission around 8. Their system of calling you when you your food is ready is strange, and kinda of faulty since the numbers are not in numerical order, but whatever, youre served when youre served okay!?

Difference between this place and all of the other Indian food I've had:
GREASE LEVELS! GREASE LEVELS! GREASE LEVELS!

I did not have a greasy buttery naan .. unfortuntely, but fortunately the rest of my other food was not ghee slathered. Food was plentiful and cheeeep cheeeep. Defs worth checkin' out.
author: Heather P.

description: Brilliant food! Very authentic, simplistic, yet delicious, good self service concept has you very comfortable and all that is Really inexpensive. Love it
author: Krupesh K.

description:
Was cruising for something to eat around 9pm after a little concert at the Conservatory.  Lucked into some parking just up the street so we tried this corner shop.  Seemed to be a lot of chefs in the kitchen, and not many customers, but gave it a go anyway - dining options in SF get pretty limited after 9.  

On the advice of the cashier, we ordered the goat curry, which had a good, distinct  goaty flavor but far too spicy for me; and the chicken tikki masala - perfect chunks of chicken in creamy masala sauce = delicious.  The naan was quite fresh, straight out of the oven.  I would come back just for the masala; though, I might try the tandoori chicken as well -- I could smell those tandoori spices from across the room.  Not much for waiter service here; we had to fetch our own water from the beverage fridge.  But I didn't mind, as I knew I'd need a lot of cold water to quench the spiciness.  Just after we entered, it was getting to be about half full with clientele.  Interesting to see the ebb and flow of hungry San Franciscans at night time.
author: Gerald C.

description:
Eat at Pakwan .... here's why... just saw something beautiful

Saw a homeless guy come into the restaurant w/ cerebral-palsy ... the guy at the counter .. immediately went to the refrigerator got him an "orange soda" with a straw... put a plate out of Chicken Tikka Masala with Rice ... put it on the table for him ...

never saw exchange of money ...

Amazing to see that in a big city these days ....


Above all that, their food is awesome and very reasonably priced.
author: Mike d.

description: Sadly the rating comes down... Saag paneer was way too oily today and your dishwasher is leaving dried food bits on plates, tea cups, silverware.  Sad, but true.
author: Jen G.

description: I've been a customer since 2009 and its never been this disappointing,  The cleanliness is a problem, ie.: the  floor and chair is sticky, the utensil still have food debris on it.  The portions have always been small but now even smaller?  Maybe I'm wrong but the chicken tandoori seems to be trimmed off to make the Chicken tikki masala because the amount of meat vs bone is ridiculous as if the chicken pieces been chewed off by an animal.  The meats been filleted as if to disguised the tempering.  If I'm wrong I suggest them to changed vendor because it the chicken have so little meat to start with why bother.  You can changed the name of the dish to "scrawny chicken pieces." There are many wonderful restaurants in the Mission, I would walk another min rather coming back to Pakwan.  I've finished eating, $27 for 2 people and came out very hungry still.  I've ordered 2 veg curries, a tandoori, nan and rice.
author: Mar H.

description: I can't tell you how long I've been searching for Indian food that is pretty authentic in the bay -- okay, it's been as long as I've lived in the bay (two years!). My friend took me here on Saturday night and it was divine! It's not a traditional restaurant where you sit down and order your food. You order at the counter, grab your number and go sit down until they call your number.   The food was good and actually flavorful with spice and heft. You also get tons of food for the price. I got the chicken saag = whoa! So so good! I loved this place so much I went back again on Sunday night for more. Again, I got the chicken saag. I feel like I've been missing spice from food when I eat out in SF but this place delivered. I'm not a Dosa fan because I think it's pretty bland food but this place hit the proverbial spot!
author: Ayele A.

description:
Delicious chicken tikka masala. It's to DAH fo!
The naan is super delicious and fluffy (esp. the keema naan).
Nice service, they always give us extra change. BEST mango lassis.
Decent prices.

Nice place to share Indian/Pakistani food with friends. :D
author: Sophia W.

description:
This place is fantastic! I've been here thrice and everytime I'm blown away. The beef and lamb seekh kababs are excellent. The chicken tikkas are grilled really well, not too dry, not too charred, just right. I've had the nihari a couple of times here and it's bang on. A few people I know even rate it the best nihari in the bay area. They serve a beef and (on special occasions) a lamb shank nihari. Do not miss this!
One of their best dishes is the lamb chops. Excellent dish! The meat is cooked so well its creamy and delicious. Not chewy at all, the spices blend perfectly with the meat. Get this one for sure! Their biryani is pretty good but I've had better. Their butter chicken is really good as well. Worth multiple visits!
author: Mustansir M.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the Mission. I probably get chicken tikka masala and naan here an average of once a week :)
author: Pam F.

description: Horrible food and the catering service was worse. The worst biryani have ever tasted and my guests were unhappy too. The chicken tikka masala had no taste it was totally bland. Ruined my party in terms of food. Pakistani food tastes nothing like Pakwan. Would NEVER EVER go back!!
author: Anam S.

description: Pakwan tastes amazing and it's affordable. Lamb biryani, lamb vindaloo, paneer masala- the go-tos. BYOB rule, rules. But, what is up with House of Curries?
author: Bryan H.

description:
Pakwan's bustling and upbeat atmosphere, along with its clean tables and ample space, creates the experience of enjoying delicious Indian food from the comforts of a friend's home.

Although the lamb curry with fresh spinach is abounding in flavors and just delightfully spicy enough to cause sweat beads to break, the lamb meat itself is not as tender as one would hope.  However, the fresh, warm naan is able to soak up the curry and cover its flaws.  The optional tamarind and cilantro/mint squeeze bottles provide great complements to the naan and curry separately, as well as with everything in a single bite!

Be sure to take advantage of the $1 bottomless Chai tea with bottomless sugar if you do not wish to sleep until 2 am!
author: Andrew M.

description:
All the food were tasty, this was my first time eating Indian/Pakistani food.

This is one of the place where you need to grab a table first and then order your food. (self serve)

I had the Samosa, Vegetable Biryani, Aloo Palak,Chicken Tikka Masala, Tandoori Chicken, Bihari Beef Kabab, garlic naan bread

I love the fact you can go across the street to buy beer and bring it back here.

Always a crowd and parking suck!
author: DVS A.

description: Just happened to walk by this place and gave it a go. I recently moved to San Francisco from London. So happy to have a place with comparable Indian food to London. Chicken saag and garlic naan. Excellent.
author: Rich L.

description:
Love this place.
You can bring your own beer/wine -1 star
The food is affordable - 1 star
The food is amazing - 2 stars
The people are great - 1 start

May have to come back here every week!
author: Tuesday C.

description: I was not very happy with the service and neither the food ordered two items and both the dishes were very cold ordered a side of yogurt turns out that it's sweet and the cashier charged me when I took it back they did not bother to apologize or ask if you would like something else instead.
author: Asif M.

description: Food here is great.  Full of flavor, and reasonably priced.   Few drawbacks: it's self serve, so you have to get your own plates, cups, silverware, etc. and they are cash only, so be prepared for that.  Also a Pro or con, depending who you are: it's BYOB...literally.  We asked for beers with our dinner and they directed us to a market across the street where we could buy our own beer to eat with dinner, because they don't serve it in the restaurant.
author: Sara W.

description:
Located on 16th St between Guerrero and Valencia, Pakwan is in a pretty big space and was fairly clean. It was pretty empty around 1:30pm on a Sat when I came with my sister a few weeks ago. It had the same setup as Naan and Curry where you order from the cashier and pay (cash only), then get a # and pick up your order when they call it. Self serve water and utensils too. Here's what we ordered:

regular naan ($1)  - Came out piping hot and was fluffy, thick and tasty!! Better naan in my opinion than N&C.

garlic naan ($1.99) - Wasn't too garlicky and was topped with fried garlic pieces I think. Not really worth the extra $1 since it wasn't too different from regular one.

(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zf62D_W7iGzgdV6U_CeApQ?select=Anx2lOL8F1eMqwyQJZCz_g)

mixed veggie curry  ($5.50) - Mildly spicy with a mix of peas, cauliflower, carrots, potatoes, and onion. Not very thick curry but was full of flavor...a little too oily for my taste though. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zf62D_W7iGzgdV6U_CeApQ?select=Lz9p6PT3fX-u7Mi1FcVKhw)

chicken tikki masala ($6.99) - Not too sweet or like tomato soup...was creamy and contained a decent amount of chicken. The chicken wasn't the most tender but wasn't bad. It was slightly spicy unlike other tikka masalas I've had and we had leftovers from this dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zf62D_W7iGzgdV6U_CeApQ?select=aLwTGgQmz8M4A_pIkhTdqQ)

Great Indian meal for less than $17 and above all, we didn't smell like Indian food afterwards!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I love this place. 
Food is very tasty, my fav dish is the lamb biryani. 
What I like about this place is the freshness of the food, you clearly can say that is not prepared by the microwave. In addition, the kitchen is open, which makes you feel good, as you can watch them prepare the food. 

reasons why I don't give them 5 stars:

- street parking
- no alcohol beverages, but it's ok to bring your own wine/beer bottles with you. 
(there is a liquor store across the street)
- CASH ONLY (there is an ATM machine in the liquor store)

One more thing, it is pretty casual, you will have to get your own plates, forks etc., however, the food is worth it. In addition, the place it self doesn't look fancy, so don't expect a fancy indian restaurant atmosphere.
author: Kay E.

description: Great food fully cooked chicken no chewiness great flavor only complaint is the naan was subpar compared to other local restaurants.
author: Rupinder M.

description: I loveee their chicken biriyani!! They are fast and efficient and their food is really good!
author: R K.

description: low key, fun and DELICIOUS indian, i love byo beers and friends and i adore the spinach dish the best
author: Belle P.

description: Their achari chicken is my new favorite chicken dish. Like the biriyani too!
author: Mrinalini K.

description:
I stayed away from Indian food for almost five/six years and this place gave me a harsh reminder of how GOOD varied Indian food is!  The place is small and you have to order at the register before you sit.  It is CASH ONLY.  That is the ONLY downside I have to this place.... because it's BYOB!  I heard there are only 4 or 5 restaurants that let you do that, and this place happens to be one of them!  On to the food!

Naan -- they are marked as ONE whole piece of naan, so order multiple.
Basmati rice -- GOOD.
Chicken Tikki Tikki Masala -- Highly recommended
The Vegetarian cheese orange goodness -- another highly recommended dish.
Lamb Shank -- excellent.  It also looks succulent because it's a huge piece of meat on a bone!

I recommend going with at least a party of four so you can try everything family style and bring lots of drinks because that's awesome!  We popped a couple bottles of champagne and neighboring tables cheered with us :)  Go family-party!
author: Kristin O.

description: Cheap and tasty! Highlights include the biryanies, chicken tikka, saag paneer, and veggie makhani. Wait time varies.
author: Mr M.

description:
So salty and oily that it couldn't be eaten.

$20 worth of curry for 2 - straight into the trash.

We'll never be back.
author: Jim F.

description: Food was very good here. Not much for ambiance, and it's counter-style service, but they were very friendly. For the price I wasn't blown away, but was very satisfied. I had the lamb curry and my friend had the chicken. I think it was more money than we wanted to drop on lunch, and I think it would've been better if they had lunch-priced combination plates.
author: Brian C.

description: I've actually never dined here and I've been coming here for years... I always just order take out. However, it's always packed whenever I come to pick up my food... so that's always a good sign! I always order the chicken tika masala and the mixed vegetable curry. The masala is VERY FLAVORFUL... which is probably why I always order it. The mixed vegetable curry is very good too, a nice mix of veggies and you get a good amount of both. The chicken tandori is good too, moist, flavorful, and not dry. Naan is good too.. but I've never really had bad naan (hopefully I didn't jynx myself). Food is reasonably priced and food comes out fast. Definitely recommend this place to try if you like Indian food!
author: Johnson S.

description:
Service - yep, still good!

Interior is now remodeled, though!  And it's clean and beautiful!

Now I can feel classy when I BYOB, and the B is a bottle of Charles Shaw that I drink alone in the corner.  Nah, just kidding - I don't drink Charles Shaw.
author: Alice C.

description:
3.5 Stars.

Such as it happens you get those unmistakable masala, curry, tandoori cravings but you're kinda lazy, undecided about what you want? Unready to commit to stuffing your belly full of naan and curries all by your lonesome, you dial a friend or three and insist that they join you and hanging up on them before they can protest or complicate the matter by suggesting another cuisine.

It's Pakwan!  Not Pak-two or three!  Delicious, inexpensive place to scratch that Indian/Pakistani "itch" in that spot no other cuisine can reach.

There's no table service and there isn't much to rave about the ambiance (the kitchen is rather noisy).  However, large tables make it a very good place for groups -- and bringing a few mouths with you is highly recommended so that you're able to try many of their dishes.

Here's what the table looks like when Ben and his family goes out to Pakwan (identification starts in the upper left, snaking around to the lower left):  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zf62D_W7iGzgdV6U_CeApQ?select=eQPS0TwFsJxjkwMNAiT-Xw

As is his custom, my dad chats up the friendly manager who invites us all into the kitchen so that we can see his tandoori oven and grills.  Sadly we had to take a rain check on that but hopefully next time, I will post pix of that for joo!

Why not higher rated?  Cash-only, no wait staff, meager ambiance.  However, these three may combine to keep prices low for us.
author: Ben S.

description:
Oh yeah, we found a super satisfying spot for a pre-Roxie meal.
We had the saag paneer (fresh, spinachy and not at all pureed), chicken tikka masala (generous portion of chicken, easily twice what they give you at Chutney for the same price), chicken biryani (ahh, you'll feel you've returned to purana Lucknow), and fluffy garlic naans.
Now be warned, here at Pakwan you have to PAY for the chai ($1), unlike at the rest of the desi hole in the wall joints you love. 
Just pay it and enjoy yourself.
author: Lisa T.

description: Definitely not in the 1 '$' category. Food is great, though.
author: Joe D.

description:
Super good food, love the chicken and paneer tikka masalas.. as always.. just wish they would also serve a lamb tikka masala! 

Also, its BYOB, can't get any better than that! Pick up some beers or a bottle of wine on the way over there and enjoy some delicious indian food with friends :)
author: Ganesha B.

description:
The food here is much better than the food at the Pakwan in Fremont. We got Chicken Tikka and Beef Kebabs, exceptional freshness, good meat quality and the taste was incredible. The place has a fun vibe to it, people came grabbed a spot and somehow everyone fits in this tiny restaurant just fine. People were adjusting tables to for their party and at the end everyone had a spot. A fun hang out! 

As for prices, just about average comparable to Nan & Curry or Shalimar.
author: En J.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  This is the best Pakistani/Indian food I've every had.  Period.

My only complaint is that they're a cash only restaurant.  Just need to run to the ATM before picking up, so it's a minor complaint.
author: Brian M.

description:
Come here for the food and you'll be pleasantly satisfied. There is pretty much no service, so you just put your order in and wait for your magical number to appear on the screen. Or, if you have bionic ears, you can actually hear your number with that annoying automated jingle thing.

The chicken tikki masala was very flavorful, but the chicken itself was a little dry. Also had the achari gosht which was bathed in an AMAZING sauce, but the lamb was a bit chewy. The garlic naan is fluffy on the rim and crispy and thin in the middle. Delicious!

Yumm $1 unlimited chai tea! I saw a man pour himself a big cup of ice and then put the hot chai in it. Genius! Must do that next time.
author: Moraia W.

description: Tasty and cheap. CASH ONLY and no frills order at the counter. At first I was turned off by the mango lassi being pre-made sitting in the fridge, but it was yummy so no complaints. The garlic naan was excellent, as was the spinach lamb curry - very flavorful and not too spicy for weaklings like me.
author: Amy X.

description: I love this place. My favorite part about this spot is you can BYOB or wine. Portions are huge, meals are authentic, and prices are fair. Get the Garlic naan, call your mother, and tell her that you love her.
author: Eucalyptus J.

description:
I've been coming here for several years now and this is the best Indian/Pakistani food I've had in the Bay Area. Things I always solidly order are the Chicken Tikka Masala, the lamb chops, and the saag daal. I never feel too creamed-out after eating here like after some other Indian places. And I think their quality is pretty good and consistent. Their lunch wraps are also really good, but they only serve them during the day. The thing that really makes Pakwan better than all the other places is the naan bread. I don't know what they do differently to it here, but it's AMAZING. So soft and delicious! 

As for how this place works, you order at the counter, get a number, and pick up your food at the counter after it's been announced. There are extra plates, utensils, water, etc that you gather yourself and take to your table. It's BYOB so you'll often see people come in with 6 packs or wine. Also, they bus the table for you. I used to be very confused about if we were supposed to put our dishes somewhere, but they take care of it. The older guy who works there always remembers me when I come in and service is usually good, or at least not bad. The bathroom is kind of gross, but it's at least a place to relieve yourself...
author: Victoria J.

description:
I'm surprised this place has an average of 4 stars.  Yes, the prices are very reasonable, but the food I would not say deserves the 4 stars.

The Chicken Achar was good and was 4 stars, but the Chicken Tikika Massala was mediocre (3 stars), the garlic naan was disappointing (2 stars - baking in dried garlic flakes on top of a regular naan does not make it true garlic naan), and do not bother with the chai (1 star - there are no spices in it at all - it is merely black tea with cream).
author: Sabrina H.

description:
I don't think this place is worth the amount of work required to eat the low price food. The entire atmosphere made me shovel the food into my mouth so that I was done in 3.5 seconds. There is this very loud irritating ding every time an order is ready, which occurs every 5 seconds and leads to a very hurried and heart-racing experience.

The food is pretty good, but nothing to write home about. I will not be coming back here, ever.

As other people have said, the rice portions are tiny, and the naan is mediocre.

Bleh...go elsewhere, especially if you want real service and want to relax at all.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Great food!  I love that you can bring your own alcohol, and it's conveniently located in the Mission and across a convenient store where you can buy beer and wine.  Their curry and naan is great!
author: William B.

description: I was disappointed.  This place came highly recommended...but yeah. The tikka masala was okay, nothing special, more tomatoey than spicey, the chicken way WAAAAAAY overcooked, the place felt way more fast food than what I was expecting but maybe that's my fault. The naan was pretty tasty, so was the lassi. Service surprised me - my boyfriend and I were mortified to discover we were a couple bucks short when we ordered but the guy told us to pay him when we could, so we had time to scrounge through our bags and find the errant dollars we needed. A little above and beyond the call of duty there. The last star is mostly for that guy and his general super friendliness. But the food was pretty disappointing.
author: Jessica W.

description:
OHH YES! PAKWAN! I love you!! My trip to San Francisco was ACTION PACKED.. I found myself HUNGRY FOR FOOD at 10:45, in The Castro.. and I was hoping for something affordable, exotic, and quick, so I could get back to guzzling booze with yummy guys... PAKWAN was the answer, and Yelp steered me to the PERFECT spot. SOO DELICIOUS, this PAKWAN! I practically jogged to their door to make it in time, and hit the counter right at 10:55.. they close at 11!! They were happy to take my order, and I even had time to sit down and eat it! Chicken Masala, Basmati Rice, and SO TASTY, THE NAAN. OMG! PERFECT!! 
I highly suggest PAKWAN to anyone visiting the area!!! Quick, affordable, and EXPLODING WITH FLAVOR. :D
author: Christopher L.

description:
Tasty (by tasty, I mean standard fare loaded with cream/clarified butter, all solid, and the best Samosa anywhere)
Clean
Fast
Efficient
Friendly
Open late
Delivers (well, not this one, but the one Downtown does)
Cheap

A dive that somehow managed not to be one. What more can you ask for?
author: Snuffles B.

description:
The basic formula for all these Pakistani Indian (really just Pakistani in practice) kebab houses is a handful of meats available by themselves or in some curry base.  If the meat is not cooked nicely, then the whole menu will suffer.  Though I wanted to like Pakwan because it's not in the Curry Loin, the dryness and toughness of the meat did not win me over.

Saag Paneer: The paneer was rubbery instead of firm.  The spinach was decent, I appreciated that there was some texture instead of just a blatant purée.  

Chicken Tikka Masala: The chicken was dry and far from tender.  The masala was quite good though, with rich spices and a good creamy balance, so helped mask the meat.

Tandoori Lamb Chops: Too tough.  Seemed more like old mutton rather than young lamb.  They either need to start using a better grade of meat or cook the existing meat at  a lower temperature for a longer period of time.  Sadly, there was no curry to cover this up.

Naan: Fresh and fluffy with a few good crispy sections.  About what naan should be.
author: Adam B.

description: Tasty, cheap, and damn quick. Fine cuisine? Not at all. The ordering is a mess, the restaurant cramped and even calling ahead is surprisingly difficult. But it's cheap and good enough to not go elsewhere.
author: Scott T.

description:
Good overall.

I don't know if this is official, but many people BYOB.  It seems to be an unspoken but known rule.

Their tikka masala is very good, but the chicken biryani leaves something to be desired.
author: Andy C.

description: It's good food for the price - has the Chicken Tikka Masala with plain naan. Nothing to complain about except for some swirling flies waiting to land on the food! I'd still return though!
author: Sandy T.

description:
Food is super good, place is clean and portions are great.
However, staff is not too friendly!
author: Sam S.

description:
The number one reason for coming to Pakwan is the food.

That sounds a bit of a foregone conclusion but there really aren't any gimmicks here.  Just plain awesome food that will have you wolfing it down and stopping only when it's too late.  And by too late I mean you're full to the brim and ready for a Thanksgiving style food coma.

For starters, pick your time wisely and make sure you've got cash.  This place can get nutty and I'm sure there is a point where people in line have to request their orders to go since there literally aren't any available tables.  A dinner for two can come in between $20-$40 so be sure you have enough green on you.  If having a dining buddy save a table leaves you scrambling for your order, it's tough to go wrong here.  My "usual" order involves the chicken cholay or the saag ghost.  Though it may sound like a sacrilege to order here, get the chicken.  The tandoori chicken breast is so tasty, you'll find yourself eating the onions that come with it as ravenously as you did the chicken.  Wrap it all up in some of their big fluffy Naan and you'll not only be stuffed but may find yourself with hangover food for the next day.

Hangover food?  Yes another one of Pakwan's claims to fame is being one of the few (the only?) restaurants in SF with BYOB service.  So after you've ordered, nothing helps pass the time like some quick booze shopping.  Hit up K&H directly across the way  (good selection but cash only) or the liquor store by The Roxie (average selection but they take credit).  I'll admit a restaurant experience is definitely enhanced when your preference of booze is satisfied.

Definitely a favorite.  Who needs a server anyway?
author: Steven R.

description: Good food but very slow. Be prepared for a long wait. End the end the quality is worth it, just go with the correct expectations.
author: foodiewithadrawl S.

description:
Pakwan is an awesome restaurant! The food is always delicious, and I am never disappointed when I come here. The chicken masala is probably the most delicious chicken masala that I've eaten before. Everything here is under $10, and the portions are huge! The spinach and lentils, lamb curry, and salmon is good here too. It's BYOB so it's really popular here, and you have to scout out a table while you order, and hope that someone leaves soon. 
Also side note, when I was here on 2/10/12, Dave Chappelle was hanging out here! AWESOME! :)
author: Rachel T.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying I probably know the most about curry out of everyone I know, and I know a lot of people, so I consider myself a bit of an expert when it comes to Pakistani/Indian establishments. I also used to live in Istanbul (which is in Turkey), the undisputed epicenter of Chicken Tikka Masala and curry in general.

I first discovered Pakwan in 1998 and have been dining there ever since. It reminded me so much of the curry I had back in Istanbul that now I can't eat anywhere else. The one thing that's terrible is that they don't offer Chicken Daal, which is bizarre because pretty much every place in London and Turkey sells this by the vat. But their Chicken Masala is pefectly seasoned and tastes exactly like the version I had at Raoul's, my favorite joint in Istanbul.

But the best part of Pakwan is their generous BYOB policy. Back in Istanbul, I used to grab a 12 pack of Tecate and hit up Raoul's with my roommate Darcy and the fact that I can replicate the experience in SF really keeps me coming back. Why people bring liquor store red wine here is a mystery to me. Mondavi was Italian. He didn't make wine to be had with Indian food. I also know for a fact that Robert Mondavi has NEVER been to India or even Afghanistan so why would you drink his wines with Indian food? It makes no sense. Drink beer with Indian food, or sparkling wine if you really need to be a snob. 

The other day I was arguing with my roommate over whether we should go to Pakwan or get burritos. Now I don't mean to brag, but I spent 6 years living in Brazil, so I know a thing or two about authentic burritos. In fact, I probably know the most about Mexican food out of everyone I've ever met in my life (even in passing, which is pretty impressive if you ask me.) He was trying to say that we should get burritos that night and then Pakwan the next, which is hogwash because everyone knows you can't eat curry if you have even minute traces of burrito left in your system, but it works the other way around (curry typically enters and exits your system so quickly that even a one day turnaround shouldn't be an issue.) So there you go: Pakwan is the clear winner in that grand debate.

The one problem I had with Pakwan was how their TV-based food alert broadcast system with satellites and GPS would constantly ping for every single order. Pakwan is usually a pretty busy place at night (unless you go for lunch but why the fuck would you do that?) so hearing constant chimes announcing that my order was ready really grates on the nerves after a few minutes. Luckily they've updated it to ping far less frequently, so I've raised my previous review of one star up to five, which I think is an accurate and fair score. 

FACE YOUR FEARS. EAT AT PAKWAN.
author: Brent F.

description:
After wandering around the mission looking for somewhere decent but not too expensive that was serving after ten, my friend and I ended up at pakwan.
The food was pretty good, no real complaints, your standard Pakistani cuisine. We had tikka masala and naan and some other dishes I can't pronounce :-)

They have a couple outdoor tables which is nice for a warmer night like this was. 
Unfortunately we were unaware you have to go pick your food up at the counter and ours was sitting there for quite some time.

The service was standard over the counter, nothing exceptional but the guy was friendly and the tip jar seemed to be overflowing.

Not bad for a late night dinner, but nothing out of this world.
author: Andrea K.

description: Good value (meaning not expensive) but food is not great. Order very spicy if you can tolerate at least some spice. Sauces are a bit greasy/oily and chicken was not marinated, goat was good.
author: Carlos K.

description: My favorite Indian food place in SF. The staff there is kind, funny, and cooks up some tasty Pakistani food. It's reasonably priced, and the place has a relaxed setting. Get the pakora as an appetizer!
author: Roxanne H.

description: Five stars because we didn't realize this place was cash only and they said we could pay them back the rest later ;) update on food in a bit
author: Alex F.

description:
I came here about six months ago with my parents, sister, and boyfriend, entirely by accident. The restaurant we were planning on going to was unexpectedly closed for the summer, so we just wandered into one of the first okay-looking places we came to. So happy the planned-on place was closed, because this was such a gem of a discovery. 

The atmosphere is extremely casual, which would be a bit depressing if it were empty, but I don't think there is ever a time when it's not lively, cheerful and crowded. The food is pretty much self-serve, which is a total non-issue since it is ridiculously, ridiculously delicious. 

I still involuntarily drool on myself a little bit when I think about this place, and plan on making the trek back with my boyfriend in March for my birthday :3
author: Carrie L.

description: the food was really good I have no complain about that it's just that the service sucked there was a guy and he was cleaning tables so I called him he didn't even look at me and he  was 2 feet away and I called him again and he looked at me and turned away then I'm like excuse me and he walked away.. Fix your service please
author: Nick K.

description: Divey, hole in the wall, CASH ONLY Indian restaurant??  Sounds like a place for really good Indian food to me.  Came here with some friends in the city on a Saturday night and it was jumping.  The food is served hot and piping and the naan is to die for.  We ordered an array of dishes including chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, and some other dishes that I can't recall.  Everything I ate was very tasty and flavorful.  You do need to have the stomach for it though.  It can get pretty hot.  This place serves hot chai that I did not have but there is no liquor on site (BYOB, which we certainly did).  Popular spot, if you're into those loud bustling restaurants where you order, seat yourself and eat fresh, hot food.. I think it's worth the experience.
author: Reena P.

description:
Tasty, juicy tandoori chicken breast.

Bonus points for self-serve fridge (water, sauces, etc.).

Open late.

Cheap.
author: Inigo M.

description: Ridiculously good when you eat here. Painfully memorable in the morning. For $60 five of us destroyed plate after plate of amazing food. BYOB so you know the beers went down smooth. I could eat 17 of their naan breads--best I have ever eaten.
author: Larry W.

description:
This place is inexpensive, quick and tasty.  Nothing amazing, but if you want a quick meal at a decent price, it fits the bill.  Heads up that it's cash only and self service.

The samosa and garlic naan were very good.  The channa masala was also pretty good.  I wanted to get a vegetarian dish with paneer, but the guy at the register recommended against it, saying their paneer wasn't good.  I very much appreciate that kind of honest from restaurant staff.

We also have the chicken tiki masala, which I thought was lackluster--kind of reminded me of what you'd get in a Trader Joe's frozen meal--generic and not fresh but taste was tolerable.  The rice was ok.
author: Caitlin T.

description:
The food here is so good!

Get the garlic naan with potatoes, chicken tikka masala and the chicken biryani. 

Minus one star for cash only and the noisy atmosphere.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
For many years I avoided Pakwan, it seemed so cheap, oily and basic. I generally avoid Pakistani food, because it seems heavier then what I am looking for most of the time. And then I was turned on to Pakwan's Vegetable Biriyani. The rice is perfect, lots of few veggies, some herbs. Now I want every meal here. 

I am so harsh in my judgements, forgive me Pakwan because I love you.
author: Shannon Z.

description: Love this place! Their Biryani is what you want. This is now my go to Biryani craving fix.
author: Don D.

description:
Love their all the birayani rice dish (chicken, lamb or vege).  All the food, rice and naan are all tasty and I always get their unlimited refill chai.

Great food, great price, self-service.
author: Bessie T.

description:
BYOB, walk up and order. wait to hear your number. my kinda arrangement.

the food was delicious and affordable.
author: Ameer N.

description:
So my bf and I were wandering around last night and decided to follow our noses and the evening buzz of restaurants in the mission. I was craving Indian food, and we decided to try this place out. 

Our food was absolutely delicious. We had the chicken masala with rice, garlic nan, and the eggplant dish. The staff seemed friendly, and helpful. If you want drinks it's byob. I'd say this place is somewhere to go and relax; since you order at the register and pick up your own food, there is no waiter trying to get you in and out quickly. The environment was causal, and for the quality of the food the price is very reasonable. I will definitely  come here again!
author: Julia D.

description:
The red spicy sauce!!!! What do they put in there!!! 

And the hot chai! oh my, so yummy.

Great place to make peace with hung-over after your shindig at Double Dutch two doors away :)
author: Chanel V.

description:
Marginally better than the Naan and Curry and House of Curries establishments. A tier below Lahore and Flavors of India in Rockridge. Butter chicken was good and quite flavorful, although chicken was dry. The mixed vegetable curry had some weird Indian picklish undertones. My girlfriend complained that it was sweet although that didn't bother me. Naan was fluffy albeit somewhat doughy. Sounds like an oxymoron, but it's not.

Everything is self-service, which I really appreciate. I always prefer self-service to bad service. Pakwan is a decent and affordable option.
author: Nathan C.

description: HALAL meat! Ummmm I do not know about that. Food is good only insofar as its worth the cheap price and can satisfy the Indian food hunger pains I get once in awhile.
author: Manu M.

description: This place is legit! Friend brought us there for dinner and I had food coma before I left the place. I didn't order and I forgot how to say the names of the food. Lol
author: Mack T.

description: Hey I'm "desi", and often I need to get my fix. Pakwan is close to home, and I've been checking-in more frequently of late. Their food is always pretty good, so I end up paying my respects once a week or so. Say hi if you see me there, either with friends or by myself...hah!
author: Vivek N.

description:
Great tandoori fish and chicken tikka masala. It's quick, reasonably priced, and tasty. I do think the food could be a little spicier; maybe I'll ask if they can kick that up next time.
Anyway, I recommend this place.
author: Colin P.

description: Had a rough day in clinic, needed some Indian comfort food! This is the place! I gobbled up some perfectly spicy tikka masala, and of course broke the " no 2 starches together" rule. Must get the Naan and the Rice, both are as good as any I've ever had. This Indian food is so amazing it makes me wanna go back to school and become an engineer!
author: glenn w.

description:
Still delicious and service is fast.  They even upgraded their outdoor patio furniture- CLASSY.

Naan so fluffy in my mouth and vindaloos with just enough spicy. 
I love me some Pakwan anyday.
author: Skye W.

description:
Pakwan is cash only, but don't you dare let that deter you from eating the delicious foods they offer. As for the basics: the naan is cheap, large, and delicious; the basmati rice follows suit. I ordered the Saag Gosht, which is "tender goat cooked with fresh spinach", and was delighted with the result. It's a rich green hue, wonderfully spiced to the right level, underscoring rather than overpowering the tender pieces of goat meat. It maintains a level of spiciness that I very much enjoyed, staying a few notches below any point of constantly-reaching-for-my-water.

The staff is very kind, but be forewarned that you are to grab your own silverware, extra plates, glass/silverware, cutlery, et cetera. This is a trade-off that I am willing to make in exchange for the fact that this place is BYOB with no corkage/can fee. Bring wine or beer and get to it!
author: Alex A.

description:
More restaurants should adopt this business model: BYOB+ cheap, delicious, ethnic food. Being relatively new to SF, I couldn't help but chuckle at the scene. 24oz IPAs (of varying labels) as far as the eye could see, fueling pseudo-intellectual conversations of art and politics. Patrons felt very culturally enriched given the amount of Garlic Naan and Curry they were ingesting.
   
Though I do appreciate the art of serving, the food ordering system at Pak-Wan is a welcome relief to a traditional restaurant. You can sip on a beer of your choice while patiently waiting for your food to be prepared. I advise using this time wisely to pounce/swoop on an empty table, which might be tough on a Friday night. Soon, your number will be called out by a soothing computerized voice, accompanied by a funny lil ring tone. Dig in, drink up, enjoy. Get something spicy.
author: William H.

description:
Delicious, cheap, and fast! The place gets a little chaotic, but it is of the "organized chaos" nature. It's a serve yourself set-up, and I love the DMV style call/signal for food pick up when ready. This is how it works- you'd place your order at the cashier line, and the cashier gives you a number card. Then, you go and find a table, grab the utensils, water, plates, etc. Finally, you listen for the chime, look up at the flat screen TV to see if it is displaying your number. When your number shows up, you go pick up your food at the counter.

As for the food, everything I tried was yummy. I loved the butter paneer, the chicken tikka masala, the raita, the naan, and the skewered meats. BYOB and beer always goes so well with spicy food! 

 It's almost 4 stars for me, but I heard that the restrooms are disgusting,  our table had a short leg and was wobbling most of the night, and finally, the ventilation is not great- it left an extra strong smoky odor on me (especially in my hair).

It was a good experience, and will def go back, but I will make sure to pee before I go, pull my hair up in a pony tail, not wear  clothes that require dry cleaning, and perhaps tug a small can of fabreeze in my purse.
author: Sandy W.

description:
Best tikka masala in town!  After a few traumatizing restaurants, I've sworn again Indian food..but Pakwan, you have broken my walls down, and I can love again.  I've gotten all of the chicken curries at some point, and they've all been consistently amazing.  The naan is just average and sometimes burnt (bummmer), but get the rice instead.  The rice is mixed with bits of vegetables (I think?), and it complements the curry well.

Tip for those who aren't spiceaholics- go for the tikka masala, it's creamy and full of flavor, and probably the best thing I've ordered.

Pro: unquestionably delicious curries, outdoor seating for Mission people watching (they can get quite interesting...)
Cons: difficult to find parking, naan is inconsistent, CASH ONLY

Would I come back?  I'd drive to the end of the world to come back...or at least to the other side of town anyway, hells yes.
author: Betty W.

description: What happened to this place? The last few times I've eaten here, the food was lukewarm and just average. Even my most loved dish, the samosa, was served lukewarm when it had in years past been served piping hot. Everything tasted different and the standards seem lower than they used to be a few years ago. After a few "meh" experiences, I've stopped going back.
author: Trinh N.

description:
At the mention of "Pakwan", my taste buds go into over drive, and i can almost taste all of my favorites: 

- the vegetable byriani - out of this world...the caramelized onions add just that little sweetness and the blend of spices leaves my mouth wanting more
- the samosas are crispy on the outside, and moist on the outside, and the chutneys have just the right heat
- the bengen...redeemed eggplant in my eyes...i can't have enough of it...
- Chicken Achar - my boyfriend's all time favorite (and he's an expert on the matter)
- the tandoori chicken - my son just demolishes it and always asks for more

I still get a little taken aback at the whole stick of cinammon that is buried in the bengen, or the whole head of cauliflower that is tucked in the byriani - but that's par for the course..and the service, even with take out, has always been friendly. The atmosphere in the restaurant is convivial and the aroma of the spices pulls you in the moment you step out of the car. And the quantity for the price and the flavor - it's the perfect equation.

To say that a week does not go by that we don't order from here is an understatement. It's more than a repeat for us.  All other indian take out places pale in comparison to Pakwan, and in the tasting contest we had of Shalimar vs Pakwan, Pakwan won hands down for both of us...yep, you have ruined me...for the better!

So if you haven't been there yet, GO!!!
author: Laurence B.

description:
Food = average.  Their curries are good.  Naan is a bit doughy for my tastes (hey, it's too doughy for me, maybe not you.)  Their kheer was very, uhm, greasy?!?!  Their chai is excellent (but then how hard would it to f*ck that up?!)

Service = mostly self-service.  Yeah...carry your own stuff to your tables.  Grab your own water, glasses, table settings, etc.  Hell, we cleaned our own table before sitting down to eat.  

Decor = total hole-in-the-wall feel.  Enjoy.

Prices = moderate.  

I'll come back here for their chai and their curries.  But I'm staying the hell away from their kheer...*screams*
author: Fannie S.

description:
so we went to the city for weekend and were on ahunch for a place to eat some one in the group suggested to this place, first the parking around the place is tough, i think the city SF has a problem itself after a walk if 15 minutes we reached the place, the place has been for a long time i guess at around 6 pm also you could see the place to be half full. 

Its a self service place so you order and go to the counter when its ready. food is ok not wow, and the place is not clean as it should be, the place is cashing upon the goodwill and its long existence. after having food we decided to have tea which was finished in the big self service flask so we were told to wait 10 mins, but after 20 mins they kept telling us that it will take 2 mins more and returned the money, that's bad service, if you know it will take time don't take order/make anyone wait.
author: Raj M.

description:
This place is great- close to my place, near Bart, super good food and reasonable priced. I have not  done so yet but I beleive it is BYOB- which is very cool as well.
I come here when I am looking for easy and good food.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I am vegetarian, I do not go nuts for this place. 

I had the following:
Butter Paneer - gravy was good, paneer was days old
Garlic Naan - average
Samosas - average
Sliced Onions (free) - really good 

Use fresh paneer next time please
author: Saumya B.

description:
Love love this place.

Order a ton of quality vegetarian and non-vegi plates for really cheap!!!

Nuff said.

[posted via mobile device -- typing w/ my thumbs]
author: Ken H.

description:
I was just gchatting with a friend of mine about my plans to eat dinner at Pakwan when she made perhaps the strongest possible case for any restaurant: "It's the only Indian place i trust with the well-being of my gut."

This friend, I love her. Girls like her are the reason I love being a girl, because she's super classy -- sharp dresser, ladylike, into the finer things in life, you get it -- but when it's just the two of us, the girl is straight up candid. When I told her I was writing about her in my Yelp review, she said, "You should mention your friend gets the shits when she eats at any other Indian place." And so I did.
author: Amy Z.

description: Panneer makhani and dhal were very tepid in spiciness but served wonderfully hot in temperature. Butter naan was nice and yummy but onion naan was not great. Galub jamun was good but cold. It feels like this restaurant has great ambience but can't get their recipes together. Not sure I'll come back to try again
author: Sandhya S.

description: This was a delicious Indian meal with a very different atmosphere from many other places in the area. A friend and I came here on a Saturday evening, and it was jam-packed. By a stroke of luck, we were able to grab a table outside, which gave us a breath of fresh air and front-row seats for the show off many other groups waiting to grab a table. After ordering at the front, it took only a few minutes for our food to come out of the kitchen, streaming hot and delicious. The chicken tikka masala and naan were fabulous, though I wasn't as much a fan of the paneer makani. I'll definitely be back!
author: Tasha A.

description:
Pretty solid Indian food. Best in the Mission for easy, inexpensive, delicious Indian food. 
Secret menu item: Navratan Korma
It's not written, but they will make it for you and it is epic. 

Why oh why did they get that ridiculous TV order announcing system!? It is so annoying. So annoying.
author: Michelle C.

description: Today the special was goat curry. It was baaaaaaahd assed good!
author: Cindy J.

description:
Chicken Tikki Masala was the only thing I would go back for if I ever came here again.  The spicy lamb curry was too salty and the lamb was too over cooked and thus, too chewy.  Garlic Nan bread is the worst I've ever had.  It's doughy and on the dry side.  If you re-heat it, it turns to stone, literally--crumbling to pieces.

Prices are decent and service was quick, but the guy taking your order at the cash register can be rude at times.  He rolled his eyes when I asked for a mint sauce.  He yelled at a customer who asked a dumb question as to why it's a 15min waiting time for pick up, by saying, "Of Course man, the food has to be cooked.  What did you think?"  Just thought he could have answered the question more politely.

I'd go back if I was starving for Indian/Paki food but only for the Chicken Tikki Masala (with just rice-no nan--probably.)
author: Kay T.

description: Okay so I've had a lot of Indian food in my life and this is probably the best I've ever had! There was a bit of miscommunication while ordering, I wanted a samosa but the guy didn't hear me apparently and thought I ordered something else. He let me keep the accidental order and ordered me a free samosa as well. Also just a heads up the samosa was excellent but much more spicy than usual. The rice was fluffy, meat excellent quality, and very reasonably priced.
author: Hannah D.

description: Food was tasty, big portions, prices were great and BYOB! No reservations, order when you get there and try to find a table to sit, which can get crazy if you have a group of people.
author: Stu H.

description: My favorite place for a quick Biryani or Indian food! Remember to take cash since its a cash only establishment. The food is great and incredible value for your $$.
author: Anwar H.

description: Its PAKISTANI food people, not Indian. Good food, zero service. The Pakistani way!
author: Jonayd A.

description: Love the Nan, any Nan they have (plus about anything else), BUT watch out when they are busy - they will quote you a very unrealistic time for food.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
i been here tons of times. fresh food. great stuff. you can just open the menu and order anything everything i tried is really good. a must have is chicken masela with nun and some kabab. 

make sure you have cash. they dont accept cards

dont use the bathroom.
author: Abdul I.

description:
Food is solid.  A bit pricey, but well worth it.  I've tried almost everything and they're all good.  The lamb chops that aren't on the menu but often listed as special for the day is delicious.  Ask because they most likely have this.  

Only 4 stars since they only take cash.  This is 2012!
author: Jo B.

description: This place, in my opinion, is overrated. I like to order my Indian food mild, and Pakwan is the only Indian restaurant I have ever been to that consistently makes food way too spicy after I request it mild. I realize that "mild" Indian food isn't authentic, but I'm paying for the food and think it's reasonable to request it how I like it. If you don't mind spicy food, this restaurant might be a good choice.
author: Diana G.

description: I love this place. The staff are always super friendly, and it is just comfortable to be here. Relaxed, casual atmosphere but still classy. A lot of self-serve, which I actually appreciate rather than waiting for someone else to bring me something when I only have 30 min for lunch. Mango Lassi's are awesome, chai tea is excellent and only $1 (if you are doing to-go, bring your own cup though--they don't offer lids or very big cups, but environmentally I'm behind all that!), Naan is delicious - especially garlic Naan - fresh and not reheated or overly greasy. The chicken Tikka Masala is my absolute favorite go-to dish. A little spicy, not at all dry, made to order and very satisfying. I get it with extra rice so I can share with a friend or have more later. Super reasonable prices, especially for the quality. This is one of my favorite places to get food in SF.
author: Alyce K.

description: Great divey place...the food is excellent and the prices aren't dirt cheap (anymore, or so my memory goes) but are reasonable.
author: Henry Y.

description: Love the food but I hate way I'm treated when I have waited in line to order or sit down to order here. Second time I've felt judged and treated rudely. It seems that if your not a drunken yuppy or hipster or and middle age customer buying up the whole menu they can give a crap less about your business. Yesterday I ordered to go. They are cash only (didn't see any signs about that!) so I left to get cash even though I should have just said never mind. I came back paid and was handed a crumpled paper bag with my tikka masala, rice and naan smooshed on top of the containers because I'm not worth napkins a plastic spork and a plastic bag over the paper like all the other people I saw picking up. Bad energy from the owner (the little guy that never smiles). They don't really care about their customers they all just like money. Won't be back.
author: Beaky L.

description: A friend of ours owns a restaurant in the area and he suggested this place for dinner. Alright! Here is goes! This is by far, the worst Indian food I've EVER had! Horrible! The dish that they call "Tikka Masala" is everything but Tikka Masala! I have no idea what that was ! The chicken they use in the chicken tikka masala isn't chicken breast! It's extremely dark and fatty chicken. The beef kabobs are awful to say the least. Weren't cooked and had no taste. They were also out of a lot of things that they had on there menu. Now what I'm about to say is going to completely turn you off and I really hope they look into this because it was the most disgusting thing I've experienced. I was eating a spoonful of rice when I discovered a piece of red plastic  (I'm guessing from a bag or something)!!! I was disgusted ! Never again!
author: Helen G.

description: The flavors here are sophisticated as they should be with Indian curries -- but not at all spicy. Even dishes advertised as very spicy and ordered "as spicy as you can make it" aren't really spicy at all.  If you are accustomed to spicy indian food, look elsewhere. If you like mild flavors, this is a strong choice.
author: Daphne M.

description:
Total diamond in the rough, I love love love this place.  As mentioned in other reviews, the people here are awesome.  The food is top notch and yes, the liquor store across the street makes everything oh so that much better.  

Top menu picks:

#1 Mix Vegetable Curry
#2 Chicken Boti Kabab or wrap, either one is amazing
#3 Chicken Tikka Masala

Things to note are the place does get packed, so weekday dining is best.  Make sure to grab both bottles of condiments from the fridge located to left of the line, they are amazing!  Pay attention for your number when called, it shows on the TVs as they come out.
author: Peter R.

description:
Three words: Cockroach, in, rice.

Thank god we found it before we dove into anything else.  

To give Pakwan credit, they were very embarrassed and didn't argue at all when we asked for our money back.  

Not much else to say, really.  :(
author: Abbey L.

description:
Big Bollywood musical numbers are so cool...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jUBEBbhowE&feature=related
...pretty clothes...athletic women...leering men...aerobic choreography...Aishwarya Rai...what more could you want?

So what does this have to do with Pakwan? Not a hell of a lot. No one dances here, and I'm probably more likely to wear a sari than the staff. And there ain't that much atmosphere here, at least from what I recall. But it does feel like a busy eatery you would find in downtown Delhi...without the howler monkeys running amok.

You have to order your food at the cashier and don't expect personalized recommendations. It's all about speed here. Grab an available table, not an easy feat during the dinner hours because this place is hopping. Make sure to get your dishes and utensils before you have a seat. And sign language probably helps since the decibel level is awfully high.

In places like this, the food better be good. Luckily it is...it's very good, as a matter of fact, much better than places like Naan n' Curry. My friend Michael and I shared the $6.99 Chicken Tikka Masala and the $5.99 Saag Gosht (Lamb Curry)  - both were excellent, just enough spices with the meat very tender. The $1.99 Garlic Naan is the perfect picker-upper for all the savory sauces. 

I'll be back - preferably during an off-peak hour if there is one - since the place is so convenient to BART. I still love going to Golden Gate Indian Cuisine and Pizza way out in the outer Sunset on Judah, but Pakwan is a worthy alternative and a quicker trip.

FOOD - 4 stars...really good and really quick and really reasonable Indian food
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...WHAAT?...WHAAAAAAT?
SERVICE - 3 stars...point for speed but little else to it
TOTAL - 4 stars...no-frills Indian is essential in the big city
author: Ed U.

description:
Two curries, 2 naans, and a plate of rice came out to $24. The place is a little dinky, but who cares when the food is good?

I did think the naan was a little dry, but other than that, thumbs up for a cheap and filling dinner.

Pro-tip: carafes of water are located in a fridge by the counter with the utensils.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I couldn't tell you what authentic Pakistani or Indian food tastes like. 

I could tell you that my neighborhood standby, Golden Gate Indian Cuisine & Pizza makes food that is far tastier than what comes out of Pakwan's kitchen.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Good. Quick. Cheap. BYOB. Convenient location.

I always get the Daal, Channa Masalla, Naan, and Mixed Vegetables.

The Tandorri, and Sausage are killer too, but I cut meet out of my diet.

Great for vegetarians, not certain about vegans.
author: David K.

description: I'm eating the chana masala right now. It's awful. It is a bowl of mush. Brown and green tasteless mush. The complete opposite of what I wanted out of Indian food. Too bad it was take out so I just lose. Thanks dudes.
author: Kaytee T.

description:
Self-service restaurant: get your own table, order at the cashier, get your own food, utensils, napkins and water.  Great value for food quality. Some patrons brought their own alcoholic beverages. The place was a little stuffy on a warm night.

Chicken Tikka Masala : good sauce but the chicken chunks a little dry. Overrated, I'd get Tandoori instead.

Tandoori chicken: juicy and flavorful.. yum!

Chicken briyani : good spices with big chunks of chicken

Seekh kebab : very tasty and at the right point between dry and greasy

Saag paneer: average quality

Spicy eggplant curry: very spicy, could only ate 1 spoon

Plain naan : meh quality.. maybe order garlic ones next time.
author: Agustinus T.

description:
After hearing how great the food was here, Iwas excited to come here on a Thursday evening before flying to the tundra for the weekend. My first oh-oh, was the BYOB policy. How strange in SF. Then I saw that you had to stand in line to order the food. Whereas normally I do not like this I make exceptions for the occasional Wendysburger or any great Taqueria food. So I still was happy. I had to go potty and went to wait in line in the back hallway. It stank like rotten garbage. OK, still pretty happy. I'm not a stickler for hygiene; afterall, I'll eat ceviche at a local market in Mexico!

Then the food came. What a disappointment. Everything had the same consistency. Flavors weren't bad, just not as pungent as I like my Indian food. I was ready to give this place perhaps even five stars had the food been as spectacular as I had heard. Even my Indian food is way better.
author: Nobbi L.

description:
After a disappointing meal at Mehfil last week and coming back to Pakwan for the second time, I can say that Pakwan is in a higher tier of Indian restaurants in SF (along with Lahore Karahi).

Everything I've tried here has been good but I loved the lamb curry the most.  Expect lots of oil, though.

Cash only!
author: S L.

description: Tonight we got the butter chicken, pakwan style eggplant, rice and garlic Naan. It was fast, hot and tasty. Chicken was a bit dry. The eggplant was yummier than expected. The rice went really well with the eggplant. The Naan was not as fresh as it usually is. I smelled like curry walking out and still do.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Been here twice now and enjoyed it both times. Most recently, I went after an afternoon of shopping in the Mission. My friend and I were walking by looking for a place to grab some dinner and the pungent smell of spices and curry drew us in. Got the garlic naan and paneer tikka masala. Both satisfying on their own, but together? Amazing! The curry was rich and creamy and the naan was fluffy and garlicy. mMMmm. 

Chai tea here was also tasty and delicious. Worth the dollar extra. Only draw back is that they don't take credit card. Had to borrow money from my friend as I had no cash. I'll be back for sure!
author: Natasha H.

description: They have awesome skewered chicken, but horrible service. We sat down and they asked us to move and said that they would help, but instead they just moved the table they needed and left our stuff on the other table...
author: Thomas C.

description: Excellent inexpensive Indian restaurant. I've been going to this place for many years now and it doesn't disappoint. At popular times it gets really crowded so I'd definitely recommend going off peak, which is easy because they're open really late. It's BYOB and there's a liquor store across the street. It's a fun place to bring a lot of people because you can push a bunch of tables together and be as loud as you like.
author: Alex A.

description:
Food:  This is the first time I had Pakistani food so I did not know what to expect.  I took the safe route and ordered the Chicken Biryani which is 
chicken cooked with spices,tomatoes and layered with Basmati rice.  This dish was amazing.  Tons of flavor and spices and huge portions to top it off.  2 out of 2 stars.

Service:  The guy behind the counter that takes the orders (seen in Spencer W.'s photo) has no customer service skills whatsoever.  My coworkers and I came here for lunch on a Friday and we walk up to the counter to order.  We request separate checks and the guy ask "why do you want separate checks, it's harder for me" and rolls his eyes at us.  I then ask for a cup for my soda and he just points to the cups and walks away.  When I asked for a to-go box he just points and walks away.  Not a good first impression. 0 out of 1 star.

Price:  My Chicken Biryani dish cost $7 and I couldn't even finish it.  Prices don't get better than this.  1 out of 1 star.

Wow factor:  The self service "cafeteria" style just brings this place down a level.  The low light levels doesn't give this place a "romantic" feel but makes it feel "cheap."  0 out of 1 star.

Bad service usually ruins a restaurant for me where I wouldn't return but the food will make me come back again.
author: Danny P.

description:
Not sure if its just the hipster vibe, but yes this is a prime location and a great predrink eating spot.  Everything is casual and it feels like you're ordering from a cafeteria as you pick up when your number is called.  

Foodwise... it was just ok.  The taste doesn't make it stand out from other spots like naan n curry or what not.  In the end....a bit dissapointing, but i suppose it kicks off a good beginning to a friday night on the mission.

We had the following:
-Chicken Tiki Masala - nothing special but always a fallback dish
-Beef Curry - lacking flavor and substance. Never again
-Garlic naan - probably the better choice
-Beef filled naan - weird but worth the try.  Beef is really pasty
-Sic Paneer - spinach and cheese another staple but it was just ok
-Chicken biryani - pretty good.
author: Vincent K.

description:
We had the special, chicken madras curry (excellent) and the boti kebab. Everything is absolutely sensational. The rice is perfectly steamed. Naan is excellent. The dahl made with yellow split peas is also recommended. Friendly counter staff.
Highly recommended. Table next to us raved about the lamb shanks.
My all time favorite Indian restaurant in the city.
author: Kelly F.

description: My friend Rita and her son, Tommy took me here for the first time and wow, I really liked it. Everything we ordered was delicious, from the tandoori, nan, chicken masala, etc. I mean really delectable and a reasonably priced Pakistani style dining adventure.  You can bring your choice of wine and you can get it at the liquor across the street, how convenient is that? The only thing- it's can get crowded and its in the Mission, like most good restaurants, so parking may be hard at times..But that won't stop me from going back. It is worth it and heck, I'm craving it now !  They have other locations in the city and from what I heard, the food all taste the same giving you that Quality we look for in food- and you must have it with wine so don't forget the wine.
author: DJ Nocturna R.

description:
This is definitely indian fast food, but its a step up from cohorts Naan 'n Curry and Naan 'n Chutney in the same category/genre.   Pretty crowded, so expect to wait a bit for a table in the smallish dining room. Not super clean either (there were fruit flies buzzing around the bathroom), but its *dirt* cheap (pun intended).

Update 7/15/06:  In March '06, this restaurant received a score of "75" (out of a possible 100 points) with the Environmental Health Division.  This is a fairly poor score.
author: Rick H.
