description: Doesn't compare to Lahore taste-wise. Sorry. They do have a good system down. One star for the fact that I had an upset stomach from the minute I left this place - which lasted one week. Not cool.
author: Andrew K.

description: I love Pakwan. The best Indian/Pakistani ever. Good price. Quick service. Always fun.
author: Timothy M.

description:
Cheap, dirty and DELICIOUS. Format is similar to Naan and Curry in that it is self-servie. You order your meal at the counter and then you get a number and grab a seat. It's also pretty awesome that it is BYOB. So definitely grab a beer or two from the liquor store right across the street. 

Dropped by Pakwan in the Mission after rock climbing at Mission Cliffs. I love how they are open until 11PM on the weekdays. The chicken tikka masala was delicious (chicken tasted almost grilled) and the spinach and lentils curry had a nice little spicy kick to it. The naan was also yummy and it was served hot right out of the oven.  Great place to grab a quick cheap meal.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Mmmmmmm... spicy. Or, whooooooooo.... spicy. 

I love the food at Pakwan because it's a flavor explosion. You could take a few spoonfuls of the tikka masala, mix it with a plate of rice, and you'd be set. You could turn one order into 4-5 meals, easy. 

BYOB is a great feature of eating at this place, although trying to find parking in this area is a bad feature of eating at this place. The food is very good. The flavors and spices are intense. The heat sneaks up on you as you eat. The chicken in the tikka masala and the biryani is a little overcooked. The samosas ($2.99/two) are excellent, and they come with a garbanzo bean side. The Baingan Bharta is also excellent. 

You get a ton of food, the prices are very reasonable, and the food is very good. I also find their paging system kind of interesting. You get a number and this really loud PA system calls out your number when your order's ready. A bit of overkill, if you ask me, since you can pretty much see the counter from wherever you're sitting.
author: Saunders C.

description:
More of a 2 1/2 star effort.

Conveniently priced and located for Mission Hipsterones. But consistently average, characterless food. I guess fine if you don't know any better.

With much better options like Lahore Karahi and Shalimar in the city not sure why Pakwan is so popular... Oh wait, it's the "I had the CTM crowd," that's why.

Waiting to be proved wrong, but I just think that Punjabi fare made solely by non-Indian cooks lacks real nuance and depth.
author: Tak N.

description:
tastytastytasty

I don't know about Mumbai, but these two get along wonderfully in my stomach.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Last weekend while I was still in SF, I went out to the Mission district with a big group of friends because Earl and Joyce were hyping me up on the cornbread crust pizza at Little Star. Well, when we got there, it was closed, and I was mad.

So we wandered down the block and came across Pakwan. It looked pretty good from the outside, so we decided to give it a try! Good choice!!! 

Earl and Joyce took care of ordering for our huge crew - standard stuff like saag paneer and tikka masala and garlic naan and a buncha other stuff. I loved getting down with their drinks - the mango lassi was AWESOME, and i also liked the spiced chai tea with cardamom. what the heck is cardamom anyway? sounds like cardigan. i have no idea what it is, but i guess it tastes good cause i liked my drink.

We all loved our dinner at Pakwan. Awesome flavor, and it wasn't too expensive!

One thing I must complain about though... the restrooms weren't too clean when I was there. I won't go into detail about this, because even I thought it was gross. And I'm a GUY who normally doesn't trip on disgusting stuff.

So just go to Pakwan, eat, and get the F out! And tell your gf to hold her pee til you can take her to a better bathroom!
author: Antonio A.

description:
If you had to feed a family of 20, this is where you would go. Plus self service style for those just sliding in for a solo meal!

Yay for being able to see and treat Jenny and Calvin on the trip to SF (never forget your cat urine soaked Mission apt bathroom)! 

Seriously. The lamb biryani can be at least two people. I had enough to take home for another lunch despite scarfing my face. 

The Masala Chai is only $1 and self served and free refills! 

And to what Jenny pointed out. Yes, they apparently needed two LCD TV screens to display the current serving number.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Pakwan, you are delicious. Though you seem dimly lit and casual, you take food and value seriously and you always perform admirably. I've never had something bad here, and I've had a lot of good things for cheap. I've come to adore the little table by the window, even on a dark night.

Take food out from here and maybe check out the remodel some other Yelpers are mentioning. I haven't seen it but I look forward to it; old decor was, again, dark and on the delightfully seedy side of 'this place is so great.'
author: Megan G.

description:
After many years of not being in the city, I was so glad to find Pakwan is still here. It's definitely a great place that offers YUMMY Indian food at great bargain prices. If you like true Indian food, you'll be hard-pressed to find something you don't like here. It's all yummy.

CONS: 
1) It's always super-busy. This was the case when I was regular when I lived in the City 10 years ago (and around when they first opened). But it's gotten progressively more packed... I guess the word's been out about how awesome the food is. 

2) The self-serv style is all-encompassing... you go to the counter and order your own food, you buss a recently-vacated table yourself (if you want a place to sit sooner than later), you get your own water/lassi/chai/etc.

3) The service of food was quite discombobulated. They called my number and the order wasn't compete. We had to have our samosa appetizers after the meal. 

4) In all the frantic crowded-ness, the young man who took the order was snippy and impatient. Now, I sympathize w/ the stress but there's no such thing as a slow night for them... three previous attempts to dine at Pakwan on a weeknight fell thru because I couldn't bear the wait. Shouldn't their Front of the House person know how to handle it and still offer great service?

In any case, it's a place with great Indian food. It's really worthy of all the hype and the crowds. Just might enjoy your meal more to go... and maybe picnic at Dolores Park?
author: Len B.

description: Hands down favorite Pakistan food. Self serve, friendly staff, and incredible food. Can't believe how cheap it is, best parking is on Guerrero if you're looking. Good vegetarian options as well.
author: Zach M.

description:
Being able to bring my own bottle of beer is a nice, unexpected treat that I wish was more common in SF, but let's be honest, the food here is only okay at best.

There are 20 restaurants in a one-block radius of this place that are orders of magnitude better, food-wise. It's a shame, but Pakwan doesn't live up to its location, location, location.
author: JR H.

description:
I am already feeling guilty about the four stars.  But it's only because their lamb could be better... and it's not bad... it's just that it is not tender in the way I treasure my lamb to be. I used to get my indian at Indian Oven in the haight and Aslam Rosoi's in the mission.  Then after a few years my budget changed, and I was cast out of those societies. I was honestly forlorn (I am not being melodramatic either).  Every other indian place I went to or ordered from disappointed, left me embittered... longing for indian food of the days when cash came easy. And then, like lightening striking down from the sky, God created Pakwan.  Actually what happened was that my friend invited me there (about 5 years ago) and I have never turned back. I eat there at least twice a month, and if they were a block away instead of six I would be eating there once a week I am sure. Favorite dishes are the butter chicken and the vegetable byrani. Butter chicken is the perfect blend of succulent chicken, smokey roasted flavor, tangy and creamy. Byrani is by far the best byrani I have ever had.  The carmelized onions, perfectly cooked cauliflower, and the tartness combine to make a very gobble-iscous rice dish. Portions are perfect in all cases, but in the case of the byrani the portions are HUGE.  The lamb vindaloo has amazing flavor, but, like I said the lamb does not meet my standards in the tender department. I am forever grateful that Pakwan exists.  The prices are better than reasonable... they border on cheap! The atmosphere here is very casual, but somehow festive even though they obviously don't try to be.  I think the feeling of elation in the air there can be attributed to really happy customers who are terribly excited to be getting a delicious, cheap meal. One very odd-ball thing about Pakwan is their airport announcer style of order system on the loudspeakers.  It never annoyed me, but it does tickle my funny bone. 
Lastly, I went back to both Indian Oven and Aslam Rosoi's within the past two years... and I realized that Pakwan is better.
author: Amphianda B.

description:
I found this to be a great place. 
It is set up similar to Panera Bread in how you order your food. Basically it's a do it yourself kind of feel. The people working there are extremely nice and helpful and will do anything to serve you. Excellent service. I walked in and we needed a table for six and there wasn't one, so they made made room for one.
I took the advice of the chicken tikka masala and got a vegetable curry and one of the specials which was the chicken curry. 
It was all great, well done with flavors.
Even if you are not familiar with Indian food the food won't be scary! :) 
I would recommend this place! 
Once you sit down it feels classy as well. 
Go for it! This place is great
author: Trevor B.

description: I was really disappointed by Pakwan after reading all the great reviews! Along with the place being so loud I could barely hear even my next door neighbor at our table, I found my food to be exceptionally mediocre, as well as the food I tried of one of the other people in my dining group. The chicken was tough, the goat was rubbery and hard to eat, and none of the food was well-spiced. I wasn't expecting exceptional brilliance for the low prices, but man, it didn't have to be *this* bad. I ended up taking 2/3rds of my food "to-go" - not because I wasn't hungry but because I couldn't force it down. I ended up buying a lassi, which was pretty good, and downing that to calm my hungry stomach instead of eating any more food. Thank god for high protein desserts!
author: Denise B.

description: Love love love this place. Great food at a great price. You can get by with just $20 for two people and still have left overs! Word of advice - BYOB - go across the street to the liquor shop and grab a couple of beers for your meal. Try to sit next to the window as well so you can get air - it can get stuff in here. Nonetheless, the food was incredible! You can never go wrong here at this price.
author: Pablo P.

description: I love the fact that the name means Watermelon but it serves Pakistani and Indian food. I enjoy spicy food and it isn't a meal unless I'm sweating bullet and drinking down a couple glasses of water. I got the lamb curry with garlic naan. At first I thought it wasn't spicy at all. Five minutes into it I start having water drops in the back of my neck. I thought someone spilled water on me, but it turned out to be the curry. I instantly fell in love with the place. I've been here a couple of times now and enjoy every dish I eat. When I'm in the Mission with new people, I always drag them here.
author: Nam T.

description:
LOVE THE BYOB!
hate the phone that is used to take my take out order :(
get a new phone pleeeeease!
:heart:

I still love you
author: Cub H.

description:
1. I like cheap food.  Nights out that include a movie, beer and dinner all under $8.00 is awesome.  (Sure sure, the movie and beer part were sponsored by Yelp but hey, the $8.00 I spent was all me.)  Additionally, all this happened over in the Mission so it's always a good thing to not get your car towed.  

2. I like Indian food.  I ordered the Paneer Tikka Masala and my friend ordered the chicken Tikka Masala.  Considering it was only $5.99, it was pretty darn good.  I also wasn't burping up weird flavors for the rest of the night which is also a good sign.  (Sorry if that's TMI, I'm in the mood to share today ....)

3. I remember last night over dinner that I wanted to be sure to point out that the color of the walls, is the same as the Tikka Masala sauce.  I'm certain that you find this tidbit of information very very important.  I wonder if Benjamin Moore carries a line of paint called "Tikka Masala Orange"?

4. I'm not sure if I'd ever come here again intentionally because there is just so many eats in the Mission - but it was good while it lasted and I don't regret the visit.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
If you are looking to get waited on, hand and foot, then this place is not for you...   BUT If you want tasty food at a great price, this place is the best!

The Tandoori Chicken Kababs are excellent!  The best I have found in the city.   The all white meat chicken breast is so juicy and flavorful!   It is spicy, but it's supposed to be.  My daughter does not like things too spicy but even she loved it and endured the heat because it was that good.  You got to get their Cillanto sauce with it, it is the BEST.  I am real picky and usually make my own sauce, but this was really good. 

This place is totally worth going into the Mission; I will be back!
author: Dana H.

description: One of our go-to late night dinner spots! Food is so good. My fave is Tikka Masala and the Chicken Biryani. My husband loves the Chai Masala drink, and it's refillable.
author: Thea S.

description: Dude, every time I walk by this place, I'm going to have to stop by for a savory bite of cheap and delicious Pakistani food. The garlic naan is excellent. The lamb in the lamb biryani was tender (although probably too saucy compared to the average biryani), and the host was friendly. Definitely a spot to hit up for super casual lunches and dinners. And would definitely come here over Naan n Curry.
author: Stephen H.

description:
If you are concerned that your blood pressure is dangerously low, I recommend, as your doctor, that you eat here. 

First claim a place in line to order, then grab a table IF YOU CAN. If the bus boys have started wiping down the table, it's already too late. Someone else will have sat down already. You'll need to slide in as the previous party's collective knees begin to straighten.

Now that you've wrested away a table, grab plates, flatware, etc from the corner (remember to squeeze through the line) and pour yourself whatever you BYOB-ed (you remembered to hit the corner store first right??).

Then a soothing tone plays (ahhhh, breathe out!) and a number on a screen appears. If it's your number it means your food has emerged! Now grab your food and scarf away!

Oh, not all of this food is exactly what you ordered! And some of it is overcooked! Oh well, at least it was cheap. Make sure you clean your plate for maximal blood pressure uptick.
author: Alan F.

description: The service is good, as long as you expect counter service, not table service.  Excellent food, they will follow your request spicy, mild.  It is moderate priced, and you can bring your own booze, another huge saving.
author: Carol K.

description:
Came here for the first time Sunday night.  My friend told me this place was good for cheap Indian eats but how good would the food be?  After ordering veggie samosas, the chicken kebab, and the mango lassi, I was hooked.  The mango juice was fresh and not canned, the samosas had a spicy kick to it, and the kebab was cooked with onions and not overcooked to the point of dryness.  All that together was $14 and not including a bunch of naan(I tried regular, potato, and ground beef naan) that was not only cheap but fresh tasting and steaming hot when it comes to you.  The food takes a little while to come out but it's definitely worth the wait.  Sometimes, they don't call out your number when your food is ready but one of the workers will come by to remind if you are a slacker.

If I'm ever in the Mission again and if I have to wait 30 mins in line for a taqueria or a tapas place, then I'd definitely come here as a reliable backup.  I paid in cash so I'm not sure if they accept credit cards here.  The decor is nicer inside as it is repainted and the room looks larger than before.
author: Ben H L.

description: Butter chicken and chenna masala were missing some flavor but saag paneer was delicious!
author: Daya A.

description: So my first time going to Pakwan was April 19,2014. Overall everything was pretty good for having Indian food for the first time. I got the Bhuna (Lamb Curry) and my friend got the Channa Masla. When we got our food it was a bit cold because we didn't hear the guy yell our number, so that's our bad. But overall like I said before the food was pretty good. Also if you do get the Bhuna and is looking for some spice definitely get the extra spicy one! But like I said pretty good for having Indian food for the first time!
author: Oisis J.

description:
OMG!!! Devoured the Nihari and naan. Nothing fancy at all and just the way I like it. Better than any of the establishments I frequented in Edison, NJ.

Though I question the recent addition of two flat screen TVs to display your order number; kinda 'techno-tacky' and looks like it should be used for Keno nights in a casino in Reno. But hey, as long as I get my Nihari and naan, it's ok.
author: Gregg M.

description:
I have had many discussions with friends about whether service matters or if it's all about the food.  I am always on the side of service being able to make or break the restaurant experience and determine whether I return.  

But Pakwan is interesting because there is no expectation of service.  If you're lucky, someone will bus the dirty table you leaped over a million people to snag, if you're luckier, they'll do it before your food is ready.  You wait in line and order, then you go pick it up yourself when the giant tv that sounds like Muni calls your number.  You get your own water, tea, plates, napkins, silverware, dishes...

I guess this does not bother me because you go into it knowing what you're getting in to, and you're not paying for service via inflated food prices.  So, all of this is to say that the complete lack of service does not detract from the Pakwan experience in the least.  

The food here is great.  Nothing has ever disappointed me.  Tonight I had aloo palak and bengan bartha pakwan style with garlic naan.  It was amazing.  And the prices are equally amazing. 

I do think the cash only thing is annoying though.  But otherwise, I love this place!
author: Linda L.

description: Fun , byob ! Plus you smell good like BBQ tandoori when you leave ;)
author: Louise L.

description: This place has the best Indian food in San Francisco. Trust me, I'm Indian. The vegetarian options are so-so and greasy but their tandoori food and Biryani and Nans are pretty good. Go here for kebabs.
author: Indu M.

description: it really doesn't get better than this. fantastic food, giant portions, dirt-cheap prices. my personal faves are the lamb biryani-- perfectly spiced, fluffy rice, studded with fried onions and giant chunks of deliciously seasoned lamb; and the chicken tikka masala, which has this incredibly deep, smoky flavor unlike any curry ive ever had before. get a garlic naan and byo some riesling because this place tastes like home and i love it.
author: Meg K.

description:
Such a nice divey restaurant for sharing, especially for double dipping your naan in the butter chicken or tikka masala sauce (which we learned tofay was the same sauce)

Crazy cheap 

Clean 

Tasty

Better location than Shalimar!

note:The trick to double dipping = tear your bread so it's not gross to your friend.  :)
author: Athena S.

description:
Good naan, hot and quick food, cheap enough that you can try a couple dishes per person without too much hesitation.
But flavors... leave so much to be desired - quite bland. I have tried the paneer tikka masala, bengan bhartha, mirchi salan. The food is greasy, as I suppose is to be expected. More importantly I always feel like I have a rock sitting in my tummy after a meal here... will probably avoid this place in the future.
author: What's in a nam e.

description: A fantastic value for high quality Indian/Pakistani cooking right in the mix of the Mission. A feast for four--naan, rice, four entrees--rang up at just about $10/person. We left stuffed and happy: a satisfying option particularly for those bar-hopping and taking in the nightlife of the area.
author: Josh L.

description:
Pakwan is your neighborhood DIY cafeteria for Pakistani and Indian food. The food is cheap and the service is minimal. Grab a plate a fork a knife a spoon a glass an onion a napkin a table and wait five minutes until your number is called.

Their vegetarian menu is plentiful and you can't go wrong with nan or basmati rice for an extra dollar. The restaurant serves an excellent chana masala which is garbanzo beans seasoned in a spicy curry and aloo palak which is sating mixture of spinach and potatoes. The curry is perfect during cold, rainy nights in January and February.

Although the cashier-manager dude is tragically bitter, I can overlook any feigned smile for cheap food. Lighten up.
author: Chris G.

description:
My experience at Pakwan this evening was the impetus for me signing up for yelp to write a review. This is my first yelp review ever. 

I used the Eat 24 app, and ordered Chicken Tikka Masala, Raita, Naan, and Rice - thinking I was ordering from the Pakwan on 16th street. Twenty minutes later I show up to pickup my food and I'm told there is a second location on Ofarrell street and that is where my food order was actually sent. 

Cue my Hanger (that's hungry anger FYI)

Come to the rescue awesome guy working there. He says your order is easy and I'll have them make it right now, call and cancel the order from the other location, and since they did not have canned beverages, he'd refund my money for the prepaid drinks. In CASH. Thanks!

He's done everything right so far, but my hanger still leaves me unconvinced that my food will be in my mouth promptly. But, to my pleasure, he brought out my food in three minutes! Epic recovery! 

The food was delicious. Warm fluffy naan and well spiced tikka masala. Love this place and if the staff is half as good customer service as the guy working this evening then you are in good hands! Great job guys.
author: Michael O.

description: My wife and I go here when we are craving real Indian food. We enjoy their chicken tikka misala along with their speciality rice. Grab a Garlic naan and you are set. Find a seat and enjoy your meal. You won't regret going here at all.
author: JM S.

description:
I went to Pakwan for dinner on Monday and there was a sizable crowd there during dinner time.  The wait for the food was a bit long even though the self-serve feel of the restaurant made it feel like there wouldn't be much of a wait time.

I ordered the daal (lentils), chicken tandoori, plain naan and a soda and it came out to a little less than $14.  I did not realize that it was cash only until I finished my order but luckily, my friend gave me the $2 I was short of.  

I thought the daal was pretty good - it's my favorite dish and from my experience, it's hard to mess up on it.  However, I thought the chicken tandoori that I ordered really lacked in flavor.  I definitely needed the lemon that went with it.  

The prices were definitely reasonable and there is a fairly good variety on the menu to order from.
author: Anna V.

description:
We ordered the chicken biryani and the lamb vindaloo. 

The biryani was little more than some chicken and rice mixed together with a little color added on the top. We even asked them to make it extra spicy (which I know they didn't forget because they warned us about it when we picked it up) but the entire dish barely had any flavor.

The vindaloo was much worse. I knew something was wrong when it came out and it looked like liquified lamb, which is pretty much what it tasted like. Vindalooo should add some flavor, not just cook the meat in a pressure cooker for 24 hours with some cornstarch and a bell pepper for "flavoring". This dish was pretty much inedible.

I gave one additional star because the food came out fast, the naan was pretty good, and the place was clean enough.

If you are afraid of flavor and spice but want to be able to tell your friends that you ate Indian food, you should eat here, but I won't be coming back again.
author: Marcus L.

description:
CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA & BYOB!!!

Stumbled upon this spot by chance... we were trying to get a table at Andalu, but since we didn't have reservations, there was a 45 minute wait... and no offense to the people at Andalu, but a 45 minute wait was NOT gonna happen given the situation of our group being extremely hungry and in dire need of some drinky drank.  

Someone had mentioned this spot was BYOB (for all of my acronym-deficient friends out there, this means Bring Your Own Beer).  They don't serve alcohol there... but they certainly encourage it!  We went across the street and picked up some bottles of wine... and GUESS WHAT?  The place doesn't even charge you a corking fee.  They hand you a wine opener and it's game on!  #winning.

We had a group of about 10 people or so... they squeezed together 4 of their tiny tables to accommodate us.  Great service?   I think so!

You order and pay up front at the cash register.   The guy working the register was cool... funny and polite too.  You also pick up your own silverware and dishes on the side.. no complaints here though.  

I went with the Chicken Tikka Masala after numerous recommendations, and I must say I couldn't have been happier with the decision.  It had some spice and zing to it... but it was the right amount of heat.  Affordable and Delicious!  Also, the table ordered a few plates of the basmati rice and garlic naan.  IT WAS ALL GOOD.  Give this place a try and you will definitely agree! 

*** FOLLOW us on Twitter @FoodieDuty ***
author: Matthew C.

description: The best I have had, ever. Very flavorful. Everything is made from scratch. This place is very affordable. I will be a return customer.
author: Kat F.

description:
I am a pretty huge fan of Pakwan. It's BYOB, great to eat with friends on the cheap, and totally satisfying. 

I'm borderline obsessed with the Benghan Bhartha. I've probably eaten it 40 times. pathetic, yes.

SAYING THAT, the past 3 times I've eaten there, the Benghan Bhartha is totally different and TOTALLY NOT AS GOOD. I'm not sure if they got new management, messed up the recipe and haven't been told how to fix it or changed the recipe, but it gone. Benghan Bhartha used to be this delicious greenish goo with peas and cilantro. Tonight, it was burnt red much, no peas, no cilantro. And has been for the past 2 months. Sad story.

So, Pakwan, PLEASE, PLEASE change the recipe back!!! I miss my BB.
author: Mars R.

description: Love this place! I always grab a beer across the street and enjoy it with my chicken tikamasala
author: Michael H.

description: The naan here is fresh and fluffy. You won't go wrong with the briyani (i tried the chicken briyani) I like how simple the place is. Unfortunately there was quite a queue, which is expected  of it given the great food at a reasonable price. Worth the wait though.
author: Melly S.

description: Amazing food, great prices. DELICIOUS!!!! One of my favourite places for Indian/pakistani!
author: Athanasios E.

description:
To some it might look like a run down hole-in-a-wall place, with so-so interior, and it is usually very loud, but the food  served is awesome. Whenever in mood for Pakistani/Indian and not in mood for dressing up ( think Dosa) this is the place.
And those decanters of cold water stored in the fridge close to the entrance below the bar with silverware and condiments, comes very handy after all the spicy awesomeness!
author: M. M. K.

description: Not as flavorful as the Fremont location or as tasty as Shalimar.  Food at this location was lacking in sufficient use of spices.
author: David L.

description:
Great food
Fast
Cheap - 5 plates, total $32!
Free pop refills 
BYOB!

Hell ya!
author: Alex M.

description:
PERFECTION!!!

Omg, I freakin' LOVE this place!!! It is AMAZING!!! 

Everything here is incredible. Deliciuos, soft naan. The chicken tikka masala is the best I have ever had and the best in San Francisco.  The bhindi masala is also amazing. The palak paneer is terrific. The pakora and samosas here rock. Chicken tandoori here is also phenomenal. I seriously walk ten blocks to this place for dinner rather than hitting the Indian place on my block, because I love this place so much. Prices are totally reasonable, too. If only they had delivery....
author: Jessica L.

description:
I've actually eaten at the Pakwan in Fremont more often than this location. We came here on a really hot Friday after rotations (I ended up walking from SFGH b/c I got out late). I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and a Mango Lassi. The chicken chunks were a little hard to chew and the Lassi was a little too sweet (but that's probably just a personal thing). Overall the food tasted okay for Indian food. I wouldn't call it authentic though. We also had a plate a Samosas for our appetizer. Maybe it was the weather and lack of cool air in the restaurant that makes me less enthusiastic about this place, but the food was still good!

Get your own table, utensils, food, and lassi! Some people were confused hehe.
author: Yumi H.

description:
Good and greasy. Always, always get the chicken tikka masala, the naan and rice.  They let you bring your own beer, too.

they used to let you pay after you ate, but maybe they had trouble and now you pay when you order.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Don't even hate...  Pakwan is hands-down the best Indian/Pakistani place in town.  Sure, it may not have the "mystique" that Shalimar has or the white tablecloths at Indian Oven.  But what it DOES have is awesome food.

Every time I go to Pakwan (including tonight) the food is phenomenal - the tastiest Indian/Pakistani food you'll find in SF.  It's true that I'm not Indian or Pakistani but my friends assure me that this is as authentic as you get (as far as San Francisco :-) ).  As always, my favorites are the chicken tikka masala and the general vegetarian dishes (channa masala, saag paneer, etc.)., and I also really like the tandoori chicken and lamb chops.  And best of all, you don't get all smoky and gross from the smoke like you do at Shalimar...

AND it's BYOB.  :-)
author: Wendy L.

description:
How can you NOT like this place? I wish I didn't live so far otherwise I would do takeout and not have my clothes smell like their awesome curries and tandooris. 

They're not shady with their meat portions either. It's not like you'll order the tikka masala and get like 3 pieces of chicken.
author: Earl G.

description: They raised their prices.  I can't afford to eat here anymore after 15 years.  Sorry Pakwan!
author: laurita r.

description:
My go-to spot while drinking in the Mission. It's always full, but service is quick and friendly & food is great and cheap! What else do you want? A great Mission spot. 

My friend and I love Indian food, and go here often enough to call ourselves regulars. Great in the summer, or on those warmer nights, cause they have a couple of tables outside (score!). 

Surrounded by lots of bars, this is really the best spot for a (late night) dinner. Besides, you are allowed to bring in beer from the store from across the street (or from wherever for that matter). What more could you ask for? 

Yes, I'm a fan!
author: Helen D.

description:
Checked out Pakwan for the first time last night for a friends' birthday dinner. I haven't had much Indian food in SF since moving here, and after hearing that it was BYOB I didn't know what to expect. After a quick stop at the liquor store across the street for a 40 oz beer our party of 9 people rolled in, pushed a few tables together, passed around a menu then maybe 20 minutes later had 7 entrees, 3 plates of rice and 3 orders of naan for $65!!! And it was delicious!

How it works: You seat yourself, review a menu then jump in line at the counter to order. They give you a number then you can watch the fun TV for your number to pop up with a delightful *BOING* noise. Very cool. The atmosphere is homey and the people very nice.

I'll definitely be back. ENJOY!
author: Lauren J.

description: Went here after jummah with a friend and we both got naan wraps. I had the chicken tikka boti wrapped in a naan and oh my god, it was EXCELLENT. It reminded me of the food in Mecca (yes, it was THAT good).
author: Aneesa M.

description: Halal meat is served here. Owners are known Muslims. Went here for an early dinner (approx 6pm) on a Sunday evening.  The parking in this area (Mission District) is very difficult.  When we got in there were plenty of seating, but they did not have a lot of the popular dishes available (No Haleem, No Nihari and No Chicken Kofta).  So we just got some Tandoori Chicken, Seekh Kebabs and Daal along with some Naans.  Food was good.  Self-service like most Pakistani places, but this location did seem a little nicer in terms of decor and cleanliness.  Downside: they let people bring in their own wine/beer, and the prices are a bit higher than other locations, but I guess because it's in a hip & trendy location of SF, they can get away with it. Complimentary tea was strong, but perhaps that was the dish soap that we could still smell in the cups!  Tip: Ask the cooks (Mexican) to put some butter on your naan when you pick up your food- Naan tastes better with butter:)
author: Irfan R.

description:
Love me some Indian food, anytime. My cousins and I wanted to eat in for the night so we went ahead and ordered dinner from here. In about 15 minutes, we walked over to pick up our order. 

I usually like a drink to accompany my meal. Masala chai it was! And unlimited refills in house? Darn. Maybe I should've asked if the option was open for me to come back for refills every 15 minutes considering I was staying literally across the street. Haha. I took one sip and knew I had to fill my cup to the brim because it was SO good. I trekked back to the apartment walking gently as to not spill any of my chai, with one hand covering the cup so no rainwater could get in. Yes, I walked VERY slow in the rain so I could lose as little chai as possible. Haha! By the time we actually got back to the apartment, there was about 90% of my drink left, the other 10% was spilled over onto my hand and sleeve. Such a shame. 

Anyway, the food at Pakwan is fantastic. No complaints. Always order more naan than you think you'd want because when you're down to that last bit, you'll be wishing there was more.
author: Elaine T.

description: I have been going here since 2001 and it is really rocking these days. Very busy, noisy, but clicking right along. The sabsi (vegetables in a nice sauce )are my main stay and the tandoori chicken is real good. nan=yes, basmati rice =yes. authentic, priced right and getting better than ever-except maybe when i used to go in 2001-4 when i used to live in noe valley and it was my second home. This place was the first place I took my gal to back 7 years ago and we are still going here.
author: Lantz G.

description:
Well.....the food is good I will not deny that at all EVER..Flavors are rich and hearty the sauces are also nice and hearty. ........BUT...

when I went and ate there....I had to immediately go home and make......and that's all I have to say about that.
author: Dean M.

description:
Thank you, powers that be, for creating Pakwan, bearer of all that is good and pure in cheap Indian food.  I mean that literally, for the wonderfully low prices are no harbinger of post-yogic stomach aches.  They are fast and there's outdoor seating and plenty of room for your posse.

I highly recommend daal, in either of its two possible forms, and the chicken tikka masala.  Their naan is light and fluffy just out of the oven, and the samosas/vegetable things are delicious, though they tend to run out of them early on weeknights.  Eat family style with friends so you can try some of everything.  The food is also lighter on the cream than many Indian places.  It takes some doing to order a meal that will cost each of you more than $10.  I'm always full and a little blissed out afterwards, something I can't always accomplish in yoga because my stomach was growling in anticipation of the Pakwan.
author: Sydney H.

description:
There's no bias, but I never considered myself a fan of Indian food.  However, I ended up having such a meal because of a co-worker's retirement luncheon and this was the place selected and seems like the manager owns the staff here.

The place is fine, definitely nothing fancy.  You order at the cash register before sitting down and then you pick up the food yourself also (therefore saving money by not having to tip a waiter or waitress).  I ordered a tomato-based curry chicken which, according to the menu, says it's Pakistan-based recipe.  It strongly resembled things I order at other Asian restaurant that I enjoyed it.  Also prices weren't bad, seems like all entrees were under $10.

Therefore, I'd say this Indian food experience was a positive one.
author: H K.

description: Was excited to come here for lunch so I skipped breakfast to make room for a big early lunch. We came at 10:55 am so the guy told us that they open at 11am. We said ok we will wait right outside. 11:15 and still they were not ready to open. I checked in with them and another guy said 11:30! Being 8 months preggo I was mad that they mislead me to wait so long!  How dare them Starve me and my unborn child. That's just cruel.
author: Cin T.

description: Amazing Indian food! I got the lamb biryani which came in a huge heaping plate and would have fed two people by itself. The rice was really moist with lamb fat and spices, and the amount of lamb was pretty high. Between the BYOB and the huge portions its a great place to come with a group. 5 stars, would definitely try it again.
author: Vincent B.

description:
Yum! Recommended by my friend, hen a. (shout out!), I had their lamb saag, chicken tikka masala, and nihari. They were all super delicious. They were so generous with their meat -- the lamb and beef stew dish in particular. And the spices... wow! That'll clear your sinus! 

Two thumbs up!
author: Jane C.

description:
After walking all over the city for the day my cousins, friend and I went to Pakwan for dinner. The moment we walked in the door, I could already smell the goodness that was going to enter our stomachs! 

The food was absolutely great! The garlic and onion Nan bread was soft, a little salty and delicious! Not to mention the chicken curry and spicy chicken curry was tasteful and too good to pass up! We also had the spinach and cheese dish which was also great. Sadly, I don't remember the names of all the dishes but I do remember what was in them. Also another great dish had good chunks of lamb, potatoes and jasmine rice mixed together. 

The restaurant itself is nice, but this place gets crowded quick and seating is what keeps people waiting, besides the food. The restaurant was clean for the most part and as many have said before, it was in a nice part of town. 

All in all, I'd love to come back to this place more often, but only if they had a location in LA. It's worth the wait and it's good food if you're in the Mission/ Lower Haight district of SF
author: Mark E.

description:
Placed an order for 4 through Seamless. I tend to tip in person out of concern that Seamless takes a cut of the total (not sure if that's the case or not, but whatever). So the delivery guy opens the door waving the receipt at me going "no tip?!" and I tell him don't worry it's right here, and hand him a very gracious tip to calm him down. He takes it and leaves. My friends ask what the fuss was about and after explaining, we open our food. Only my chicken tikka masala is missing. So I immediately call the restaurant, which looks up my order and tries to tell me I can either take it up with Seamless or wait 2 hours for my food (the first order had taken 30 minutes). I tell him I made a generous tip and just want my food, and he says he'll call the driver. He starts questioning the driver on another phone, then tells me it's on the way and hangs up. Five minutes later the driver knocks and sheepishly hands me the food. I ask him what happened and he walks away.

Not sure if all this happened because they thought I wasn't going to tip. My dinner should have been in the bag with everything else. Whatever. The food was fine.

Update: we spent all night wreaking havoc on the toilet. NEVER ordering from Pakwan again. If you choose to place an order, be sure to get a side of toilet paper. And don't let them forget it in the delivery car.
author: Chris M.

description: Out of all the places I've ate at, this is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I've worked my way around the menu. My favorite is the Chicken Tiki Masala and garlic naan. Mmmmm, I could go for this right now.
author: Monique Q.

description:
I used to work in the Mission and would eat at Pakwan with my colleagues on almost a weekly basis.  The food at Pakwan is really full of flavor.  This restaurant is one of the things I miss most about the Mish.  The owner is great.  At first you may not thing he's that friendly, but really he's a great guy.  He not only cares about his customers, but he cares about the community.  I've seen him prepare meals for the less fortunate on the street.  Speaking of less fortunate, I did share some curry goat with a guy who looked like he hadn't eaten in a while.  We both enjoyed it!

Pakwan is on my list of places to eat at if/when I ever get back to the Mission.
author: Robby F.

description:
Do not heed the fearmongers! I'm a white girl raised on grilled cheese in the Midwest, and I don't think the starter tikka masala is spicy at all. If you want spice, ask for it, but don't worry. You won't start breathing fire unless you want to.

However, if "spicy" is just meant to indicate a lovely blend of flavors, this is true. The main dishes at Pakwan are in no way bland.  The rice is delightfully fluffy, as is the naan (I would especially recommend the aloo variety). I have never tried a mango lassi, but I can report that they are appropriately orange and elicit positive reactions from other diners. 

I would highly recommend Pakwan. Grab a few beers at Gestalt Haus, then stumble across the street for some comfort food. Now that's an evening well spent.
author: Janna M.

description:
Dang the food was off the hook. Lots of flavor and seasoned just. They were a little to stingy with the rice with small portions. 
Its a self serve place which I don't mind. 
 all in all I wouldn't hesitate to come back again.
author: Errol M.

description:
Large portions and quick service are offset by bland ambience and annoying chimes announcing order is ready every 2-3 minutes.

I appreciate that the chicken palak I had wasn't overly creamy and had plenty of meat, but the garlic naan and mango lassi tasted very processed.

This is basically Indian fast food. For the price you really can't complain too much, but I'm rating 3 because my first impression is it's just serviceable northern Indian for when you need a fast fix of flavor.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Love this place. The chicken tikka massala is very good.
The owner is very sweet and makes small talk while I wait for my order. 
The service is very minimal but you can't beat those prices
author: Isobeth Z.

description:
Best Indian food I've ever had. I've introduced a few people and they absolutely love it! We've tried Beef/chicken kebab, saag dal (my personal favorite), garlic naan, beef curry.

Call ahead to avoid the wait and make sure to grab the green and brown sauce from the fridge.

Cash only.
author: Effie G.

description: im only reviewing the food as i got postmates delivery but it was friggin delicious. we ordered so much, i cant tell what was what but trust me it was all good. i highly recommend!
author: Sean K.

description:
This is the semi fast food version of Indian food. You order, get a number and wait for them to say your order is ready. Then you pick it up and have a seat. You grab your own drinks and condiments as well - pretty much no wait staff, you do it yourself.

The food was good, not the best I ever had, but for their prices and the speed it's totally acceptable. It's a good lunch place for sure, you can run in, get a good hot sit down lunch and be on your way. It's NOT a place you want to wander into drunk and try and get some food to dump in  your belly, even though it's in the Mission.

Their food tastes pretty much like what one would expect, but they do have a few twists on a few dishes, and everything the last few times I've gone has been pretty spicy. I liked their Naan, it was big and fluffy, not gummy like some places who make them too fast. Over all it's a decent place, I'd go back again if I'm in that hood!
author: Erik B.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant! Where else in the city can you go out and eat REALLY good pakistani/indian food for less than $20. The "white-tablecloth" Indian joints up Valencia (and anywhere else in the city for that matter) can't even come close to the deliciousness Pakwan dishes out.

If you want "white-tablecloth" service and experience, this place is not for you. If you want awesome food and an unpretentious atmosphere, come here. Oh yeah - and BYOB!

What to order:
Keema Naan!!! OH MAN -this stuff is awesome.
Chicken Tikka Masala buttery goodness
Bainghan Bartha Pakwan Style. 
Kabab (same meat as the keema naan)
Garlic Naan. Fluffy and hot out of the oven.

I can't recommend their Samosa - not the best item on the menu.
author: Aaron N.

description:
awesome for BYOB!

I can't believe there's actually 787 reviews for this place ... haha wow.  Great food, casual atmosphere.

When I went like 80% of the other patrons are mid-20s, educated-but-casual, and BYOB-ing themselves.  I liked being around other people "like me."
author: Michael B.

description: I am a regular at this establishment and usually LOVE the food.  I typically get their veggie dishes here but am by no means a vegetarian.  I was in the mood for lamb and got the Ashok Gosht [sp?].  It was absolutely delicious.  However, later that night and for the next 2 days, I had gastrointestinal issues of nightmarish proportions.  I could hardly stand, I was so sick.  I seriously love this place, and it's been my go-to spot in the mission for great chana masala and saag paneer.  But after getting sick from their meat, I don't even want to risk going back for more vegetarian dishes.
author: Seghel Y.

description: Food is good. Nothing special. Their Chai masala is bomb. I can drink liters of that stuff! Also, BYOB! run across the street and grab a bottle of something..then run back over here to enjoy with your dinner!
author: Cecilia B.

description:
My boyfriend and I ordered take-out from Pakwan a couple of weeks ago. We had: chicken tikka masala, chicken korma, plain naan, garlic naan and a side of rice. 

The portions were pretty big, which is great if you like having leftovers. My chicken tikka masala was good, but not completely amazing. However, it was a little on the oily side. When I opened the container there was an oil slick on top that didn't seem to want to combine. I think if I had eaten it in the restaurant it would have been great. His chicken korma was better and also just 'good' rather than mind-blowing as some of the reviewers have said. The naan was a bit too dry, but that did mean it was great for soaking up sauces. And the rice was just right: kind of buttery and just plain delicious. 

Three stars for being good, but otherwise unremarkable.
author: Meredith D.

description:
So good in tastes; feels like authentic Indian. I would recommend Alu-naan with Aachari lamb.
The utensils were NOT clean; so I would just stop at 3 -stars!
author: Aru S.

description:
I'll keep this review short and sweet... I stopped into this place after work one night with a plan to buy food for two. I got 2 onion nan, 1 garlic nan, 1 order of Chicken Masala, 1 order of Chicken Biryani, 1 ground beef kabob and 1 BBQ chicken breast. The bill came to $30.18 - the guy took my $40 and gave me back a $10. This was just awesome in my book! Not because of the 18 cent savings, but because no one wants to carry around a handful of jingling change in their pockets... especially in my hospital scrub pants with all of ONE pocket!

Upon getting the food home, I noticed how nicely everything was packed in the bag. The Masala was in a plastic 'spill resistant' container... there wasn't a bunch of grease and sauce thrown around inside the bag. This was a nice and often overlooked plus to the whole 'takeout' experience. I didn't eat there, and probably won't any time soon, but the dining area looked neat, clean and welcoming.

Furthermore, after those cartons were opened, a feast commenced! D and I ravaged through the food like bears at a camp site... The Biryani was excellent, and the Masala was spot on - both were FULL of chicken. The beef kabob was amazingly moist and delicate, the BBQ chicken was on point, and both the onion and garlic nan pieces were delicious, as well. 

I grew up with Indian cooking, and this stuff was AUTHENTIC. This amount of food fed two adults... twice! The price, the ease of ordering and picking up, along with the fresh and authentic flavors made this a very worthwhile dining experience. This place has become a weekly usual for me now... BEWARE - this location was CASH ONLY.
author: Steve D.

description:
Holy crap! This place is delicious. I really liked the chicken tikka masala, and the garlic naan. The lamb and spinach was alright but I've had it better elsewhere. We got there at a decent time and beat the dinner rush so dinner came and went pretty quickly! Also being able to bring in your own beer of choice makes it even better.

How have I lived here for 3 years and never gone to this place till now!?
author: Lauren S.

description: Pretty good Indian food and good portions. The mango drink was good also the Chicken Tiki Marsala and the Chicken Briyani rice.
author: Philip Michael G.

description: Ordered regular naan, garlic naan and lamb biryani.  The naans are okay but lamb biryani is super delicious.  I rarely eat Indian food; the last time is a few years ago!  Now I can't wait to try other dishes at Pakwan! I can see myself becoming a regular here.
author: K L.

description:
After hearing "you have to go" so many times and craving Indian food tonight, I did. Let's take it from the top:

Food: Chicken Tikka Masala wasn't bad, although I had better before. Chicken Korma was over-salted and I've definitely had lot better before. Someone said here that the dishes were $7 each, so what can one expect for that much, but the benchmark for comparison I'm using is from places that are just as cheap as this one. 
Their naan and chai were, in contrast, great, I must say. 

Service: This gets tricky. You order your food, get a number and then, after being prompted by an automated voice system, have to pick it up yourself and go back to your seat. 

My question here is: If you invest money into two flat screen TVs and pretty decent sound system, wouldn't it be better to use it to play some Bollywood music and add to the ambiance than for the DMV-like calling of numbers in the queue? But let's get back to the important stuff.

Cleanliness: I will (rather) assume that their dirty, sticky forks are not the overall picture of this place's attention to hygiene and cleanliness...

Sorry folks. I am afraid this will be a no go for me in the future.
author: Jana C.

description: This place is amazing! I have been eating here for 2 years and they never let me down. Chicken Tikka Masala and nan is my favorite. The only bad thing is after eating here you will be disappointed with any other Indian restaurant you try in the future. Pakwan simply sets the bar for delicious. 5 star!
author: Mike D.

description: If you live in NOPA and your old favorite Indian restaurant burnt down, this should be your new delivery choice.  It is less expensive than others, good value, flavor, spice level and I am told...pretty authentic by some Indian friends.
author: Jenn D.

description:
After a wonderful morning of scavenging through used CDs and records and junk in Amoeba with my bestie for hours, we decide it is time to feed our music loving souls (and stomachs).  She dragged me through the sketchy area in SF, by foot.  I dodged imaginary bullets just for practice, just in case, and just kidding.  We finally end up at this corner restaurant.  It seemed small and sketchy, but went in anyway 'cuz she loves this place and her tastebuds are better than anyone I know.

We walk in.  It is small, but relatively clean.  I got the saag paneer and some naan and tried to locate the bathroom.  It was like a scavenger hunt.  Downstairs, around the corner, pass the kitchen and the line cooks, and through this tiny Alice-in-Wonderland door.  At least it seemed like a really tiny door in a higher area.  You'll have to see it to know what I'm talking about.

When I went back upstairs, my lassi was ready.  I love lassi.  Mango-y goodness is all I ask.  And pretty soon, my food was ready.  Spicy enough to feel it in your throat, with a hot piece of naan.  It was genuinely good, even people watching the random sketchy people outside added to the experience.  I am not used to a hole-in-the-wall place like this, but it definitely has its own sort of flair and I would love to come back some time soon.
author: Nina P.

description:
I need to start remembering that on yelp, having a meal cost $1 or *gasp* the unthinkably magnificent $2 less than normal will yield at the very least 1, but in many cases 2 additional stars.

Pakwan is one of those cases.  It's edible, as in you won't die, be sick, go blind, lose your hearing or any other sensory deprivation, but it's not good.  You could spend an extra $1 at a lot of places and get lamb vindaloo that actually has some flavor (Pakwan's is blander than canned beef stew).  On that note, if you really can't find the spare 4 quarters to eat somewhere else, just don't get lamb here.  It's somewhat dry and chewy.  Stick with the chicken, the chicken in the tikka masala is pretty good (even if the sauce is somewhat bland).

The naan is good, the rice is good, the inside is nice for a dive, and the location is great (for me), so I'll be back here.

but on my future visits I will remember that I am getting what I pay for and this is really just a 2 star meal.
author: Greg J.

description:
Love this place.

I ordered the paneer tikka masala and it had surpassed all other tikka masalas that I have ever had -- except for my friend's mom's tikka masala (can't burn that bridge; she's my tikka masala hook-up). Their tikka masala had a good kick of spice to it; I really like to sweat when I eat Indian food. I didn't sweat like it was a cardio workout, but it was equivalent to that of a good jog. The garlic naan is fluffy and tasty -- and had garlic in it. The food was so delicious that I ate it kinda fast, and on my way home on the Bart, I would burp a little... which is fine because it tasted like tikka masala. Thanks Pakwan!
author: Nicole P.

description:
Dropped by here for lunch on a trip to SF after doing a little gift shopping. I don't know why these places call themselves Pakistani/Indian joints when they're really just Pakistani. They can just drop the Indian part cuz everyone in SF knows the deal with these curry joints. 

Extremely tasty cheap eats. Order lots of dishes. You can afford it. Don't forget to order some naan here. It's very good.
author: Huy N.

description:
Great cheap eats...fast...and byob.
We always over order and over stuff ourselves.
Didn't care for the chicken korma every time I've had it I tasted PineSol..but everything else is pretty darn good.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I find their Tandoori baked Fish terrific.

When they brought the food to my table, I could tell everything was fresh, it  looked Fresh.  

 For $10.85, I ate two generous portions of  fish which were seasoned with a blend of sublime spices and then perfectly cooked in the clay oven. I ordered a piece of garlic nann too. 
   You can taste the quality ingredients here; the fish was fresh, moist and flaky; it came on a serious bed of raw onions (yummy) sprinkled with fresh cilantro and two halves of limes. Nice. A cold one would have been stellar.
   Bonus: the windows get southern light so if you sit next to the window , its delightful. Decor: nice tables.  Cool paki beats eminate from somewhere above.
This is the best tandoori fish I have had in SF.
 Other places may give you more food, but this place has quality you can see and taste.
author: Bert K.

description:
Yes you hav e to get in line to order food. Yes you have to pick it up yourself. Get over it or go back to the Marina you jerks!

The food is consistent and I like it a lot. So why the 3 stars? Well the guy behind the register is the rudest person in the place.
author: Angelito R.

description:
Kinda in the honeymoon phase with this oh-so-fine establishment. What else can be said? Fast, inexpensive, and delicious. Nevermind, please, that everything is rather mild. For me the flaws are inconsequential, and you'll have no trouble making your own judgment.

Really, it comes down to this. When you've ripped off a piece of naan (yes, I take the plain) and pressed it down to pick up savory curry and rice, when you taste that combination of elements and feel those basic, ancient textures, what else are you thinking about? What cares enter your mind, aside from the fact that you were hungry and now, natural as can be, you are getting precisely what a critter like you needs at such a moment?
author: Peter B.

description:
My favorite indian dish is chicken tikka masala...and so my indian friend tells me thats not actually really authentic indian..but who cares its SO good!

Food: Chicken Tikka Masala, chicken Saag garlic naan
Sauce: The green sauce and chutney in the fridge. I really like the chutney!
Drink: BYOB or $1 refillable chai! YUM i heart chai!

Nothing bad to say..except parking can be a bummer! 
price is definitely a steal! so cheap!!!!
author: Joanne H.

description:
everything about this place is amazing except that one dollar chai... but hey. it was only one dollar. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Button L.

description:
I have been to Pakwan once before and visited again today; their kitchen has clearly had a fall from grace. To start, our order took 25-30 minutes to prepare. When I checked on the status, I was met with sarcasm and a very dismissive answer. Whatever, I can handle slow and rude service if the food makes up for it.
We ordered garlic naan, rice, chicken makhani (butter chicken), chicken tandoori and aloo gobi (which was one of their daily specials). The naan and rice were served at room temperature, the butter chicken lacked the right flavor (tasted more like a really boring chicken curry), the aloo gobi was tangy and had several half-cooked potatoes and tough cauliflower (which you wouldn't expect if this was a special and they ostensibly had it marinating all day like good restaurants do) and the tandoori chicken was the worst I've ever had; tough, tasteless and didn't have the tenderness you'd expect from the tandoor and the flavor was basically limited to the seasoning on the outside of the chicken. I'm not sure what happened as this place used to be pretty good, but if you've had good Indian food before you are likely to walk away extremely disappointed in Pakwan.
author: Austin B.

description: Ordered lamb biryani, saag paneer, and chicken boti Kabab with naan. While the paneer was a little disappointing the chicken was very good and the biryani was the best I've ever had.  Very moist and tender.  The naan was good as well. Not much atmosphere to this place but the food is quite good and the prices are cheap. If I lived here in San Francisco I could see myself coming here a lot.
author: Emile M.

description:
Good concept and location.

This is a limited service restaurant that serves decent Pakistani/Indian food.  A good late night option after hitting Mission bars.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Yes, service is almost nonexistent here (you have to get your own plates and utensils and listen for them to scream out your order so you can pick it up) and the decor isn't a lot to write home about, but the food is SO delicious and inexpensive that you don't even care!

To tell you how inexpensive it is, my friend and I had the Pakora appetizer, Achar Gosht (a super spicy lamb curry served with a roasted pepper), Chicken Tikka Masala, rice, and an order of Naan (er..."Nan"...as they call it) for only $22.  The serving portions are generous and the flavors are rich.

Oh, they don't serve alcohol, but they don't care if you bring in your own adult beverages.  Last night we saw people drinking everything from wine to a 24-pack of PBR!

The line can get kind of long (especially from 8PM on), but be patient...it goes fast and it's so worth it!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
My favorite place for Indian/Pakistani food. Never lets me down. 

Good prices and the food is consistently tasty. My fav is the Nihari. Then the standards, chicken tikka masala, sagwala, skewers, garlic naan, rice, blah blah blah, all good. Not much more to say here.

The only thing that's weird is that I feel like I'm in a cafeteria. Your number is called, then you gotta go fetch all your food and plates, forks, etc. It's not that bad though, just something you don't really expect. 

The TV that announces the orders that are ready does get really annoying though. -1
author: Harold C.

description:
I'm not a big Indian food lover, but the scents wafting through the air as you walk past Pakwan are so tempting!

I've only been a couple of times, but it's pretty inexpensive, quick and easy.  I've always ordered to go, but there is plenty of room to sit and eat there as well.  Pretty casual place to grab a quick tasty bite.

These are some of the things I love:

Samosas
Potato naan
Spiced chicken breast
Chicken tikka masala
& LOVE the seasoned Basmati rice!

Definitely coming back soon!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Wack food, inconsistent. Ordered chicken biryani, rice was hard and chicken was very dry, ruined my mood and appetite. If you don't know how to make biryani just take it out of your menu. Why do you even serve food to people you inconsiderate A holes. Terrible will not recmend anyone. Do not eat here !
author: M C.

description: Food was low quality for the price -- the veg curry dish and the breads were lacking in flavors. Service was fast and the venue clean and spacious. Cashier was curt. I recommend Shalimar over this place.
author: Matthew F.

description:
What isn't there to love about this place? Cheap food, delicious, quick and easy, and BYOB!

The food here is sooo good.  My favorite is the Chicken Saag - probably the best I've ever had.  I've also tried their Chicken Tikka Masala which is also solid.  And of course you can't forget the garlic naan! NOMZ.  I also really liked the veggie samosas.  They were really flavorful and cheap ($2.99 for 2) and really fills you up! The chai is $1/cup and I didn't know the first time I went so I poured so many for my table.  Oops.  

Overall I love how casual Pakwan is and the food is so comforting!  One of my new favorite spots!
author: Helen V.

description:
Ok so the price is right.  Two of us ate the dahl, squash curry, nans and rice for under $20.  Great deal right?

The problem was that the dahl was runny and did not have much flavor and the squash curry was too oily.  I am somewhat of an Indian/Pakistani food snob though.

Since it's in the neighborhood I will go back and give them another chance.
author: J. S.

description: Would you like salty greasy one note garbage? Great! This is your place! Otherwise, keep looking and let those who wouldn't know good Indian from a punch in the face eat the "food" you are not at all missing out on.
author: Natalie G.

description:
I love Pakwan. It is loud and funky and a perfect example of why the Mission rocks.
My wife and I eat vegetarian when we go there together - we've tried everything (except for the mushroom dish) and it's all delicious. We usually get one entree with vegetable biryani and a naan and it is enough for two people, coming in at under $20.
I have eaten various chicken dishes there, which are also good - especially the chicken chana.
This is a good place to bring out-of-town guests too - I think it represents why SF is such a great city...casual, diverse, and funky.
author: Barry M.

description:
If you are one of the few people who are blessed to actually, you know, be in person acquainted with me and spend some time around me, you may be wondering how I could give a place that I go to almost every other week only a 3 stars.  The rest of you may also wonder just how many times I can reference myself in one sentence.  Make that one paragraph.  

Anyhow, Pakwan is pretty tasty.  Pakwan is close to where I live.  It is also not too expensive.  But, really, that's just it.  It's pretty ok, but never have I gone to Pakwan, gotten a dish, and said, "wow, this is really delicious."  I've said "wow, that's a lot of grease" (numerous times), and "wow, that was fast," but that's about it.  

In conclusion, you should go to Pakwan if you want cheap, fast, solid Indian curry type food in the mission.  Especially if you want a place that encourages BYOB.  But don't expect anything more, I don't!
author: Leon K.

description: It's really difficult to find a good Indian restaurant when it's your local cuisine. The food here was rather disappointing. Pretty bland overall. Didn't live up to the hype, as I was hoping it would.
author: Ruth R.

description: By far one of the most interesting restaurants I've been to in the city. If you like middle eastern/Indian cuisine, this place is a must.
author: Josh R.

description: I wouldn't have minded the self service aspect if the food was good. It was barely average. It was bland and the menu had little variety. Also, not only was I approached as a worker there (I'm Indian) but I saw a man who was eating there with his family stopped by a white couple to ask about there food. I wouldn't ever return to Pakwan.
author: Megha B.

description: Great food, Great prices and BYOB. I recommend the Chicken Achara. Definitely will be coming back here.
author: Jaron N.

description: Awesome counter service Pakistani Indian food.  I love their Tandoori Chicken Tikka Boti. Also, the place is BYOB!
author: Nick F.

description: Good quick and relatively inexpensive food. The tandoori chicken was moist and flavorful and the grilled fish melts in your mouth. We also tried the mixed veggie curry with basmati rice and the chicken tikki masala with garlic naan. Both were spiced well & tasted yummy. Would definitely come back to try more stuff.
author: Tawny L.

description: Food was decent, ok, 3 stars. Naan & curry OR Chutney is a lot better. Utensils were dirty. And it gets really noisy around 7ish bc of the large group of ppl. But the good part is that you could bring in your own drinks~ that was cool!
author: Mindy H.

description: DELICIOUS food -- I had the garlic naan, biryani rice, spinach & potatoes, and veg curry. :) Quite good serving size, and good price for the location. The man behind the counter was EXTREMELY nice! It's cash only, and I was lacking a few dollars, so I embarrassedly asked him to take one item off my order, and he generously just said to pay him back another time. I'll be back for sure, not just to pay him what I owe but also to enjoy the food again. :) Thank you so much!
author: Silvia M.

description:
I have been going to this place for over 8 years. Back in the day, I used to average 2-3x a week. But, then I had to slow my roll a bit. 

The paneer tikka masala is my favorite. and their mint chutney is the best i have found. 

And while, i have never been lucky enough to have indian or pakistani food in the countries themselves, this stuff is the bomb. thats all i know and all i need to know.
author: Milo B.

description: One of my favorite Indian restaurant in sf. Great food and service. Chicken tikka masala is a must to try if you haven't already. Would recommend this place to anyone looking to eat some Delicuous Indian food.
author: Aman K.

description: Every time I hear about Pakistan it has some negative cannotation whether hiding out Al Queda leader(s), the long history & rivalry in Kashmir, and frankly, I'm tired of it. Come to this place called Pakwan and you'll forget religious differences because the food is that good. It's clean. Lots of vegetarian options that are yummy & spicy. The biryani is full of flavor. You can also choose chicken breast tandoori dishes. I can't say enough about the Chana dish...I love it. And, that says a lot from someone like me  who swore never to eat another garbanzo "when I become an adult."
author: molly m.

description:
I'm a fan of this place because:

- the food is great. Good portions, very flavorful Indian food, reasonable price and I always have a good dinner with my friends here. 

- it's next to the BART station and plenty of cool bars, hangout spots in the Mission District. What more can you want then good food and good fun on the weekend.

- I didn't know this but apparently you can bring drinks from the nearby liquor store. Next time I will definitely be doing that!

Sometimes it does get a little busy during dinner time on the weekends, so seating might be harder to find. But eventually we are always able to find one. Great place!
author: Dechawuthi D.

description:
Since they don't deliver I had to call in my order to go.

99% of the time when I order food spicy they either don't care or don't believe me. I must have sounded Indian on the phone because this was the hottest Chicken Tikka Masala I've ever had; I loved it!

The portions, prices, and quality is about on par with Alhamara. http://www.yelp.com/biz/alhamra-san-francisco#hrid:rjQZKcbMUN294O1e9E_SLA/src:self Pakwan has a better atmosphere but they don't deliver so I'll stick with Alhamara.
author: Manny F.

description:
One of the best and most affordable meals I've had in San Francisco!

Everything within context.  And since it was ten at night after the World Cup final; and my brother and I had been walking around the Mission for nearly an hour not finding a place we could decide upon eating in; and we hadn't eaten in a while.  Well, it would be understandable for people to presume my rating is inflated due to hunger pains.  No.  This is not the case.  This place was delicious, and I place it within the contextual sphere of where I live, San Diego.

San Diego does not have cheap, delicious Indian/Pakistani food like this in the city.  Yes, it has some good Indian restaurants.  But my brother and I ordered the chicken akbar; a vegetarian dish made with garbanzo beans ( I forget the name); rice; and two order of naan for under twenty dollars.  That's unheard of in SD for this type of food.  I would have paid twice as much in my city.  And the food was absolutely perfect.  The chicken was moist, plentiful, and spicy, but not overly so.  The peppers were a great addition, and I loved soaking up the curry with the naan.  Even the chickpea dish was amazing.

I also liked how they had carafes of water chillin' in the fridge by the door that any customer could just get up and bring back to the table.  And the wait for food was trivial.  And a homeless dude came in, filled up a big jug with soda and walked out without any worker saying a word.  So you know it's a dope spot.  

Basically, I'd go back in a heartbeat when the food is this good and the prices are this reasonable.  San Diego Indian restaurants, take note.  You deserve a nice kick in the balls from Pakwan with your price gouging.
author: Brendan Jude L.

description:
Another fantastic late-night option, and conveniently located as to make it a good pre / post-drinking option.

Pakwan is to Indian as Sushi Delight (Market & Duboce) is to sushi:  You can get better, but it's disproportionately more expensive, and you can get cheaper, but it's disproportionately less tasty.  Dollar for dollar, Pakwan is some of the best Indian in the bay area.

My favorites are the chicken tikka masala (big chunks of chicken in a creamy, slightly spicy tomato-based sauce) & the saag dal (a thick spinach-and-lentil soup).  I used to get the sabzi (stewed or boiled vegetables in some kind of sauce, I think?), but it started getting more and more greasy, so after I while I stopped getting it.  It's clear that the tikka masala & saag dal still come with a fair amount of clarified butter, but we usually manage to drain most of it off.  The rice is tasty, and the naan is better than some I've had at much pricier Indian places.  We usually get two entrees, rice for two, and two naan, which tends to run ~$17.  Given how tasty it is, you really can't ask for more than that.

Other important points:

- Open late.
- You can eat in or take out.
- Cash only, but there's an ATM next door.
- They don't serve booze.
- No table service; you order & pay at the counter & get a number, then get your own plates, silverware, napkin, glasses, water, etc., grab a table, & wait for your number to be called.  Don't expect any additional service.

It's not health food, and it's not *the* most amazing Indian ever, but it's damn good, quite filling, and cheap as all hell.  Love it.
author: Angela B.

description:
Great food that's worth the fight. And believe me, when an awesome restaurant like Pakwan runs on a "first come, first serve" basis, a battle for a table is bound to happen. Pakwan is an oasis of cheap and tasty Pakistani food. They do their chicken tikka masala justice, and you can't go wrong with their naan. Fast service and BYOB/W. No wonder this place draws serious crowds. 

On another note: For all of you Mission haters, I think there's an Indian fusion restaurant up in Pac Heights. It definitely screams authenticity...
author: Alex H.

description: The food is good, the prices are excellent, and the ambiance is always hopping.  BYOB
author: Kurosh H.

description:
The chicken achar and tandori chicken are outstanding! Paired with some garlic Naan and you are set to go. Did I mention is it BYOB!!!  Done and done.
.
author: Bri R.

description: The best Biryani rice I've ever had. Fragrant, not greasy. The other dishes are excellent too.
author: Aileen B.

description:
Being it was our first time dining here, my boyfriend and I were definitely a bit confused about how things worked around here. No one told us that we were suppose to get our own drinks, utensils, condiments, etc. from the shelf, and pick up our food at the counter. We understood that you were suppose to make your order at the counter, but had at least thought our plates would've been brought to our table (we got a table card # after all). We soon caught on after waiting and observing others... but it would've been nice if the staff informed us... it was pretty clear we didn't know (and we sat in clear view of them too).

Besides the confusing self-service ordeal... the taste and the large proportion of the food was fantastic for the price. The tandoori lamb chops comes with four tender pieces, only for the price of $9.99! The order of saag paneer was also very generous, with plenty of paneer to share (something I haven't experienced at other Indian restaurants -- they are generally more stingy about it).

If I lived close by, this would definitely be a place I come to regularly when I don't feel like cooking.
author: Steph C.

description: This food is amazing and it is a reasonable price. I find being in the restaurant comforting since I have so many fond memories there! A cup a tea in hand and a fresh nan on the table.
author: Jessi S.

description: Pakwan is the running the table. They are the best Indian restaurant in San Francisco and possibly the Bay Area... They also operate as one of the best restaurants in the city! That's amazing. Community style seating with great menu options. Sometimes hard to get a seat but it always works out. Pakwan is a weekly visit for me. No question.
author: Spencer R.

description: Been here twice now and the food is just OK.  Had spinach curry with chicken that was very bland but super greasy Naan bread was good.  Worse part was upset stomach next day.  Ayy not good when you are here for vacation.
author: Konki T.

description: I am really confused about why this place has a four star average.  Is it the cheap prices and bring your own beer policy?  I've never had Pakistani food, but I've traveled to India and this looks like Indian food, it even smells like Indian food, but it does not taste like Indian food.  We tried the onion and plain naan, and split the chicken tikka masala.  While we ordered I watched as an employee rolled out the naan flour dough and noticed fresh naan cooking on the grill.  Yum?  Nope.  What I tasted was nasty naan.  It was nothing more than a flavorless, puffed up piece of dough.  The tikka masala was watered down with a canned tomato tasting base.  It is not difficult to create flavorful, rich Indian food.  Maybe in order to keep their prices low they skimp on spices?!  As we were leaving a girl ran out and started vomiting street side.  Hmmmmm curry barf.
author: Lana S.

description:
I really enjoyed the special of the night; chicken vindaloo. My buddy and I split 3 skewers of the chicken Seekh kebab and another curry. Normally, vindaloo is very spicy, but it this didn't seem that crazy. There was a little bit of perspiration, but not much.

I thought about the chai too, but I think it had been sitting all day, and the container was only mildly warm.

I'd definitely go back, as the price is definitely right.

Also, of note, they are cash only.
author: C S.

description: Bomb girl bomb. Spicy, cheap...this place is legit! I've had the chicken tikka masala and the saag aloo (spinach & potato) over and over, and they're amazing. Cash only and not for those who can't handle spicy (unless the other items aren't spicy). I don't even need hot sauce and that says a lot. I'm embarrassed to admit it, but the food was so good I ate the leftovers for breakfast. At 8am. Disgusting but oh so good after a night of drinking. I usually get food to go, but if you don't mind eating in a dive, it's fine and in a convenient location with so many bars around.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Pakwan rules. The place all other quick-and-dirty North Indian/Pakistani places aspire to be, but can never touch. When I lived in San Francisco, Pakwan was a frequent, sometimes weekly ritual.
