I tend to order the same things every time, so I am not very well-traveled with respect to their entire range of offerings, but the achar ghosht (lamb curry with spicy yellow peppers), seekh kebab, garlic naan, and eggplant are all outstanding. I don't like most cheese, but my friends tell me the saag paneer is very good as well.

Anyone who complains about the minimal decor, street urchins accosting you for money, or grease level doesn't get it, and probably never will. Buy your beer of choice across the street (it's bring-your-own), scope out a corner table by the window for optimal people-watching, order more than you think you'll want, and enjoy freedom.
author: Gabe R.

description:
Super tasty very reasonably priced food. I am addicted to the Daal saag with naan and the rice. I wanted to try the Lamb byrani but they were all sold out so I have to return there for that.  

Its sad that they only accept cash.
author: Christina L.

description: The best down-and-dirty Indian in the city, hands down. One star off for no delivery - please o please, deliver!
author: Erica W.

description: Awesome biryani!! Great food, good service.
author: Romita J.

description:
No service at all, take a number and pick up yourself.  Not the cleanest- don't just grab any fork in the bin.  Cash only.  BYOB.  Chai is always out or on the verge of it.  So you squoosh the thermos button and it farts air into your half full china cup.  That's because it's so damn good.  Beware, because you won't stop going back to refill your tiny cup even after you can't stuff in any more of the generous portions.  Then you will be wired all day and night, and do a 2AM yelp review about it.  $7-10 buys more than you can eat, and you will be drooling for more of the spices all night too.  

2 blocks from our place, so if Ben is actually home and asks if I wanna get dinner, we don't even have to ask where.  Pakwan.

Surprisingly peaceful place to read books at the sunny window seat, on an uncharacteristically bright november sunday at noon.  

Central to the 16th street karnival kreepshow and the sidewalk homeless bazaar.  In case you want to bring spare bills for dubious junque that's probably hot (stolen and/or radioactive) or from a garbage can, and you definitely won't want to wear it.

Don't change, Pakwan.
author: Pat L.

description:
Having walked past Pakwan while ravenous many times, and been intoxicated (in the "excited or exhilarated beyond self-control" sense, rather than the more common usage) by the delicious aromas emanating from within, I was very disappointed by my experience there the other night.

The guy behind the counter was surly. And it took about 15 minutes, and no fewer than 3 requests to staff, for even the poppadoms to arrive. 

The lamb chops were very good, but the chicken tikka masala was bland and uninspired.

As was I. (Uninspired, not bland).
author: Jonny P.

description: This place has a cool location and interesting vibe. It's initially off putting as you order at a counter but it makes up for it in the food. It's set up like a casual Indian place but with a hip vibe, and best of all it's byob, and there's a liquor store across the street. The food and the chai is amazing. Great for a date or with a group of friends.
author: Alex H.

description: Who to believe? The 1-star reviews or the 5-star reviews? Such a wide discrepancy. Went there tonight. Ordered goat curry + bengan bhartha + rice. Took 30 minutes for food to arrive. When it arrived, the goat was not edible. The meat was horribly tough and totally uncooked. In fact, it was so cold and raw, I just threw it away. The bengan bhartha was edible, but terrible. I have that dish everywhere, including Shalimar, and have never before tasted one this terrible. It was like curried salsa. I'd never go back here.
author: Eater S.

description:
Pretty good food, for a nice price. This place walks a line between fast food and restaurant, leaning toward restaurant. 

No beer?! Also, terribly LOUD at night; you'll be hoarse and deaf if you stay too long.
author: Jade P.

description: I had never had Chicken Tikka Masala before, and I'm so glad my first try was here! I am addicted to the sace and could enjoy just the sauce with nan for a meal I'm sure! This place if fun and hip, a bit loud at times but hey! Your in the city so enjoy the atmosphere! Its BYOB so you can hit the liquor store across the street, and if your lucky on a nice day you can use of the few tables outside. My one complaint is the parking so I suggest barting in if you can!
author: Ashley H.

description:
Pakwan is an amazing Indian Restaurant.  It has very fair prices, amazingly delicious food and a friendly and efficient staff.  This is NOT a nice restaurant to go to for a date if you are looking for primo service as it is a relatively inexpensive restaurant with good food and a typically crowded and semi-loud environment.

The Good Sh**:
Aloo Palak is really good (garnbanzo beans and light spices)
Chicken Tikka Masala (slightly spicy chicken with a super delicious sauce)
Any Nahn (particularly garlic for me)
Lamb Briyani (or any of their Briyanies)
Saag Paneer (this spinach and cheese delight is super tasty)

I live above Pakwan, literally, so I wanted to love it and super conveniently... I do.  I've been to this place probably 20+ times and will continue to go.  I always bring friends from out of town here as it's a real treat for most people to have delicious Indian/Pakhistani food as many people rarely eat Indian food, let alone high quality Indian food.

I recommend this to anyone.  Usually a good mix for a 4 people is a 3-4 Nahn's, a Briyani and two or three side dishes like Saag Paneer, Aloo Palak or Chicken Tikka Masala.  

Enjoy, I know I do!
author: Bryce G.

description:
These guys are super friendly, serve good cheap HALAL food, and have a nice social atmosphere.

The Raita and Kabobs are great, as well as the palak paneer. I'm not a fan of their paneer tikki masala, but there are plenty other dishes.

They don't serve booze, but they let people BYOB, for your dhimmi friends.

They also have a nice clean area to make salaat if you find yrself there at "that time of the day".

My fav place in the mission to grub with a group of broke friends. Naan is cheap as is a big bowl of raita and ALL YOU CAN DRINK CHAI FOR $!.

Can't beat that.
author: Daood L.

description:
The naan (spelled nan here) here is thicker an fluffier than naan I've had elsewhere, and it was still crispy on the bottom without getting burnt. I didn't want to get the garlic naan because I've had too many bad experiences with charred garlic, but my friend's looked really good.

Saag Paneer was tasty and the right consistency, not watery like other places. Achar Gosht (lamb curry with roasted pepper, extra spicy) was good as well. The lamb was only slightly gamey and like the menu says, it's on the spicy side. It's also a bit oily, so be careful of your clothes. The mint sauce helps with the spiciness.

Whenever I see fish on the menu at Indian restaurants (in this case a Pakistani Indian restaurant) I order it. It's not that common, and even though they only had tandoori fish I wanted to try it. On the menu it's simply "Fish". Fillet of sole, very lightly spiced (they mean it), marinated & cooked on skewers in our clay tandoori oven. I liked it a lot (mm, fish!), but I wished there was a fish curry so I could have some with my naan.

Here's how the place works: Order at the register, grab utensils (CHECK your silverware before eating 'cause some of it was still dirty), drinks, plates, and your number and bring them to your table. They'll call out your number when your food is ready to be picked up at the counter. I like places like this because you get to enjoy your company and food without being bothered. If you need anything, just go up to the counter and the people there are responsive. It's also affordable. Don't forget that Indian food is really filling.

This place falls at 3.5 for me. I liked it, but I've had better mango lassi elsewhere. What pushes them to the 4 rating is the naan. It's made exactly the way I like it and is my favorite so far in the Bay Area.
author: Amy N.

description: Wonderful every time!! ... love their lamb biryani's, chicken tikka masala, sambosas and  variety nan... CASH ONLY and limited service (as far as waiting and limited drinks selection)
author: Dale S.

description: I just want to spread the word about a little known item on the menu here called the "Pakwan Wrap". It's chunks of tandoori chicken breast in a delicious korma-y sauce, with onions and cilantro all wrapped up in a naan. It's just super good and you should try it. Oh yeah, you can bring beer and wine in from outside, which is cool.
author: Joe R.

description:
I've only been here 3 times, but here are a few tips...

1. Each time I come here, I get a lamb dish and all three times it has been tender. I like my lamb soft and this place has performed well to my liking all three times. 

2. Other favorites include: 
~ Chicken tikka masala is great with basmati rice with a dash of saffron. ~ Garlic naan is warm and fluffy. Never been stale. 
~ Tandori chicken has always been moist (in my 3 visits).
~ There are other dishes that I have tried that have been pretty good. Once I have the information from the site, I will name the dishes. 

3. You MUST BYOB. You can go across the street to the liquor store or if you know you are coming in advanced, bring some Flying Horse.
author: Rox T.

description: Open late. Great food. Quirky service. Not too heavy. Try the lamb (better quality than many restaurants that charge more).
author: Omar M.

description: The Panda Express of Indian food.  Pretty bad even at these prices.  Even the Naan sucked.
author: Erick Z.

description: Really good Indian food for Mission.  However, I still slightly prefer the food at their other location in Tenderloin.  This is my go-to Indian restaurant for the area.
author: Jacob A.

description:
Good value for the money. Good variety of dishes and decent pricing on most of the stuff. Quality and Quantity was very good for the money. Biriyani was not that great. But the other stuff was good. Will go back again.

You can try it once and see if you like it, chances are, you will.
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
Dirt-cheap and tasty!

Rich & flavorful Indian/Pakistani food, at rock-bottom prices.  Most of the entrees are in the $6-7 range, and rice & naan are only a buck each.  Even better, they're BYOB!  They don't have a liquor license, so they let you bring your own paper-bagged-booziness to accompany your tasty curries.

The space itself is pretty large, clean, lots of earth tones.  It's also cafeteria-style:  order at the counter, get a number, and go pick it up when they call it.  Plates, silverware, water, and chai tea are over by the cash register.

Things to know: the naan is awesome.  Seriously.  Reliably the perfect blend of crusty outside, soft chewy deliciousness inside.
They believe in the power of ghee (clarified butter) and its tasty-enhancing powers.  Health food it ain't, but health food isn't why you're here, is it?
If a dish has chicken, unless it explicitly says "boneless" it'll have bones in it.  This usually means you get less tasty bird flesh.
Cash only.

My favorites:
chicken tikka masala - their version of this classic is rich, slightly smokey, and very good.
saag dal - probably one of the healthiest things on the menu, being not much more than spinach & lentils.  The thickness of the soup varies from day to day, but it's hearty & flavorful, and doesn't feel like it's clogging your arteries while you eat it.  Bonus!

Pakwan is also one of my favorite places to get takeout - $15 = 3 meals worth of food for me, and I eat a lot!
author: Don H.

description:
The best Indian food in the city. In fact, just writing this review is making me hungry for it. 

Actually, I'm afraid to suggest this place because I want it to myself.
author: Neil C.

description:
This place is awesome.  The food is great.  You should try their palak paneer, it's delicious. 

The $ is accurate.  If you show up on saturday night (which we did), you should expect to wait a bit. But the wait is worth it.
author: Yann L.

description:
I went to Pakwan every Saturday for the past three years and stopped approx. in February, because the chef changed. I still like the place (in particular their interpretation of the Chicken Biryani as well as the Kebab's), but the chef changed and my favorite dish (the Chicken Tikka Masala) went downhill. It was one of the best I every tasted (I work for an Indian company and I am in North and South India four times a year), but the current version is more like Punjabi cuisine (I love punjabi) and is by far not as flavorful as it used to be.
I still recommend Pakwan for the reason I mentioned above and if you want one of the most flavorful chicken in SF go for the chicken Kebab (juicy and very flavorful)
author: Werner M.

description: I love this place!  My favorites include the samosa appetizer (served over chick-peas and with two dipping sauces - spicy mint and milder spicy/sweet tamarind - add a naan and you've got yourself the most affordable and awesome meal!), lamb biriyani, Pakwan style eggplant, saag paneer, and aloo nan.  Splurge on a chai or mango lasse.  Get extra for leftovers.  Cash only (ATM nearby).  Friendly, down-to-earth atmosphere.
author: M S.

description: BYOB no charge and quality hot yummy food for a great price.
author: Allison H.

description:
We've ended up coming back to this place every time we have an Indian craving, which says a lot. San Francisco is full of amazing food, so finding a place you're willing to bypass Yelp and go back to without doing research is a rarity with us. 

If you want spicy, you have to ask for it spicy. Otherwise the food is a little bland. But we're not taking points away here. Just a heads up. 

The nan! It is the best nan I've ever had! So fresh and pillowy with the perfect amount of baked crunch. Get two orders or you'll end up disappointed. 

The price can't be beat. Cheap cheap cheap, and quality. And the take-out service is quick quick quick. 

A point was lost after the paneer tikka masala, despite asking for extra spice, was still almost too bland to eat. the aloo palak, the palak paneer, and a few other dishes have always been good. 

Check it out. you're in the mission anyway, right? 

Oh! Don't forget to order rice. It doesn't come standard with the dishes.
author: Lindsay J.

description:
Ok, I usually love the cheap Indian food at this place.  It's fast and convenient.  But lately I've noticed that:

1.  The service has been very rude especially the guy taking the orders.
2.  The food has become very salty.
3.  The place has become dirtier and dingier.  

Has there success made them complacent?  I am thinking yes.
author: Thang H.

description:
I forgot how much I love this restaurant!  The food is top-notch.  They offer a whole section of vegetarian dishes which is convenient for non-meat eaters like myself (I hate having to search menus for items not containing meat).

I really like being able to bring your own drinks, all though they have drinks for sale and free water pitchers.  The mini-mart across the street is really big and has a wide selection of beverages to bring over while eating your meal.

The bathrooms are kinda shady, not SUPER dirty, but definitely dirtier than any bathroom in the United States should be (I just got back from a year in China, so I'm pretty much an expert when it comes to nasty toilets).
author: Bunny R.

description: I wasn't happy with the fact that they don't accept credit card. However, the portion sizes here are pretty huge, so you are totally getting your money's worth. I ordered the mango lassi, which pretty much tastes the same anywhere you go. I ate the lamb kabob, and although it looked like a piece of poop on a plate, it was quite delicious with lime squirted all over it. I wrapped it up in the thick naan that they served, then dipped it in my pak wan style eggplant dish, and squeezed the cilantro sauce over it. It was really yummy. I am not a cilantro person, but that cilantro sauce would taste delicious on anything! The next time that I visit this place, I will try to not order so much, as the food is really filling.
author: Rosie M.

description: Tasty dishes for the most part, reasonably priced, generous late-night hours, friendly/prompt service, and I love the BYOB policy (convenience store across the street has an excellent craft beer selection). The goat curry was terrible, though -- just a mess of tiny bones and fat. Nearly every bite had me embarrassingly extruding bones from my mouth.
author: Ben R.

description: This place is the BUSINESS. Seriously, it's always packed every time I go, the service is fast, it's super cheap, and it is freaking DELICIOUS. A friend recommended it as she's been going there for years, and I am hooked. I now live in San Diego and every single time I'm home, it is one of the first places I go to eat. I always get it to go, but people seem to dig on the BYOB aspect. Plus it's in the Mission and easily accessible by BART. This is also a great restaurant to eat at with groups of friends. Don't come here expecting ambience and a romantic dinner date, though- not the place for that!
author: Stefi P.

description:
I am almost tempted to give this place full stars because paying $6 for a sit-down meal in sf is an exciting event.

I don't think I'm going back though. The curry we got - chicken cholay, chicken with garbanzo beans - was swimming in bright orange oil. I love curry and do not expect it to impart health benefits but I'm pretty sure I ate mostly salt and oil, and 10 garbanzo beans. And a few chunklets of blander chicken. Maybe I just got the wrong dish? 

ps. the naan was ok
author: cecilia y.

description:
CHEAP!!!! and very good!

I had the chicken korma with naan - perfect spice, great naan. under $10. 

It's a bit serve yourself but it totally works. And the fact that Gestault was out of BUNS at 8pm was ree-dic.
author: Jessica L.

description:
If you are looking for good Indian food w/a laid back atmosphere, this restaurant is definitely a good choice.  You order your food and get a number.  Once your order is ready, you pick it up.  
  The food was tasty and enjoyable. The quality is good based on the price.  
  Since this place does not have a liquor license, you can B.Y.O.B. (bring your own beer) and drink it inside the restaurant.  
 This place does get busy so you may have to wait for a table.
author: L Y.

description: This place is a wonderful little indian place. Prices are reasonable and it is a byob establishment so run across the street to the liquor store while you are waiting for your food.
author: Shamus C.

description: The food is decent and you can't beat the fact that it's BYOB.  It loses point for the layout and the fact that it's self-service. While that keeps the cost down, it's a little annoying to have to have to hover for an open table. Great option for takeout though-- everything is pretty good and a great deal.
author: Will A.

description:
Very good Pakistan place, you will have have to wait, though!
Go with your friends, make a selection of plates and eat all together instead of separate meals for each one: with 10 bucks you'll eat a lot, and with a lot I mean too much!
Bread with onions is a must!
author: Luca D.

description:
This is white people Indian/Pakistani food, and it's delicious. I am not calling it white people food because of the multitudinous herds of white folk that soberly and drunkenly stampede in and out of this place, but rather by the fact that none of their dishes are spicy...these people know better.

Location: Half a block away from my house. That's all I need to know to love a place. It's such a great place to go before the bars, or after the bars sine their open pretty late. If you're in the area, this place is always open...and that's a good thing.

Ambience: Hipsters everywhere; Hipsters sho love their Indians foods. It's fun. Although what's really annoying is that these hipsters travel in herds so there's always a herd in front of the register, instead of a line to order. The menus are also at the front, so you have to weave through the, sometimes douchey, aggregation to get to the menus...luckily, I've memorized it.

Service: Pakistani/Indian style. Disinterested expression, slight joke to the fellow compatriot in a foreign language and the yelling your name out, only once, when the food is ready.  Gotta love it.

Space: Ghetto

Food: Pretty effin good. It's quick, it's greasy, it's pretty cheap and it's pretty delicious. They do naa'n really well. I heart their samosas, pekoras and beghan bharta pakwan style. Although I do like spicy, it's nice to eat Pakistani/Indian food once in a while that doesn't scorch your tongue. 

Overall: This is a wonderful place. If you manage to weave your way through the rude hipster concentration, have tough skin for Pakistani men yelling at you and a good $15 in your pocket, this is a great place to stop by anytime you're in the 16th & Valencia hood.
author: SF N.

description:
Pakwan is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, bar none -- even your Gary Danko and Boulevard.  Why?

1.  The food is great and without pretension.  Chicken Tikka Masala's sauce is a delight, as are the veggie dishes.  The lamb chops will knock you out.  I'd gladly pay 50% more for this food if I had to, but it's a delight to have dinner for two for about $25.

2.  You can bring your own booze.  They don't care.  That means beer, wine, watever.  Just bring it.

3.  The atmosphere.  This is a normal Mission person's restaurant.  Comfy.  Eclectic crowd.

4.  The help is always polite and professional.

The only negative is  you kind of have to wipe down the silverware and you have to get your own tableware, but really that just ads to the charm.

Pakwan, I love, love, love you.
author: Paul S.

description:
Cheap, delicious and right in the middle of the action.

One of my favorite places to grab dinner and people watch. It's magical!  Even though Pakwan always packed, you somehow manage grab a table and chairs right before your number is called.  

The best way to enjoy Pakwan is to sit outside with a bunch of friends and drink beer that you bought across the street.  

My favorite is Chicken Achar, naan and a raita - for 10 bucks!
author: Krissy M.

description:
Pakwan is my go-to Indian restaurant. The location is really central, the prices are super affordable, you can bring your own beer, and the food is amazing. Since I stopped eating meat recently, I've taken for substituting it for paneer instead for every dish. Indian food makes it so easy and delicious to be vegetarian!

Come here with a big group, bring your own alcohol, and you're guaranteed to have a great time. Or just call in an order for some tikka masala and naan, pick it up on your way home, and enjoy a delicious meal at home. If you get rice as well, you'll have leftovers!

My favorite dishes, in order:
1. Aloo Muttar special (potatoes with peas, tomato sauce and paneer)
2. Paneer Tikka Masala
3. Aloo Gobi special (potatoes with cauliflower and other veggies)
4. Palak Paneer (delicious spinach sauce)

Yumm!
author: Christine R.

description:
Best late night Indian Joint.. love the streets here, and definitely great food.
not like other Indian restaurants, where by the time you finish your meal, the dishes look like ish where the fat/oils start to solidify.. HERE you can tell its some good ish.
We ordered :
Spinach and Lamb (BF and I killed this, very tender Lamb meat)
Tikka Masala (I like the one at Naan and Curry better, sauce is sweeter and Naan and Curry)
Samosas (Greeeeeeeeeeeeat)

Word of advice, most dishes here are a tad bit spicier than most other Indian joints.
Also, unlike Naan n Curry, you can't customize your dishes here. WE tried to add Cauliflower to our Tikka Masala, but owner said "no can do".. oh well, still good tho, their just tryin to make their money off their dishes.. so if you want your Cauliflower, order the "vegetable dish"
author: Linda C.

description:
My girlfriend and some friends and I visited this place last night after it was recommended by some good (Indian) friends of ours.

We came in and were immediately confused by how we were supposed to order. After taking a seat, we quickly realized that we should be in line ordering. I guess the ordering system is more obvious when there are a lot of people in line, but we came in right before the dinner rush so the small line looked like people paying their tab at the end of the meal. It was no big deal, but it did cost us ordering our food after others who arrived after us so it was mildly annoying. A simple sign saying "order here" would have gone a long way to make us feel more welcome.

But the deal breaker came when I went to order. After getting done ordering a big meal for my six friends who were sitting at the table, I handed the cashier a debit card. He quickly rolled his eyes, visably annoyed for me wasting his time, and said, "cash only" without making any eye contact. At this point there were atleast 15 people in line behind me, so I was pretty embarrased for not seeing a cash-only sign because I didn't have cash with me. Luckily, one of my friends (who I wanted to treat to dinner) was carrying cash, so I paid the guy. While he was getting my change, I looked around and saw no cash-only signs at all. At this point I was pissed for how he handled the situation, but I calmly asked him why they didn't have a cash-only sign up. He coldly replied "We've been cash-only since the day we've opened", as if he was the f*#@ing Soup Nazi! Had I not just paid and had my friends not been super hungry, I would have walked out of there. Instead I waited for our food in the chaotic dining room that was filled with hipsters who apparently feel right at home with Pakwan's pretentious ordering system.

So how was the food?...it was ok. I definitely enjoyed the cheaper prices and the fresh naan. My girlfriend and friends with me, who are all Indian, seemed to like it ok. But at that point, the rudeness and arrogance of the cashier (and the owners, who apparently prefer to have their employees roll their eyes at confused first-time customers instead of putting up simple signs) had already ruined my experience. And did I mention the bathrooms were gross?

They get 1 star for their BYOB policy, which I, of course, didn't find out until later reading about it here on yelp. There are plenty of good Indian restaurants in SF, and even better ones in San Jose. I suggest everyone go to them instead.
author: Nick J.

description:
This is a great place to get my indian fix when I just want to have a chill night.  The prices are wonderful and the portions are great! My bf and I ordered naan, chicken tikka masala, chicken tikka, some kebabs, and rice....AHHH SOOO SATISFYING!! The bill was even better!

The location is great because it's close to all the great bars in the mission.  

Remember, this is a no-frills experience, so don't expect someone to wait on you hand and foot. But, the plus is that you're paying for great indian food at really cheap prices.
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
Pakwan provides comfort zone for fast inexpensive Pakistani and Indian dishes. 

My review stands alone for vegetarians:

I would dissuade vegetarians from eating at Pakwans due to limited vegetarian options. Their fist-sized potatoes swam greasely with frozen vegetables in a stomach wrenching oil. Basic naan lacked the light doughy texture I long from the most spartan of Indian/Pakis place. 

The vegetarian biryani was well cooked. Given that it's a fast food place, I would say it exceeded my expectation. However Pakwan is definitely not a "bargain". The overall lack of spices, overwhelming sense of grease really tempted me to leave. Given different circumstances, I would've crossed the street to Mali Thai for a healthier meal.
author: Jack C.

description: Generally quick and affordable cooking.  Indian is never ultra cheap because it all comes a la carte.  Loved the spice in every dish.  You almost never find a place serving spicy Tikka Masala.  Now your chicken was quite overcooked.  Your naan was fairly bland, as well.  I've heard this puppy gets hella crowded.  Also, don't eat before going drinking.  However, it is BYOB.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
If I was to rate Pakwan for the food and price only I would rate them 5 stars, unfortunately for them there is a thing called service which they suck at. How often do they bus their tables so you have a clean place to sit, and when the first 5 spoon I grabbed out of their community grab your plate and utensils are dirty, and not just kind of dirty we are talking really dirty. To top it off the main guy there is probably one of the most unpleasant people I have ever met, I have never had him smile or even look at me, my friends have all commented on what a jerk he is even when we say thank you he won't acknowledge it, and we are the ones paying him! 

I do have to admit I do enjoy the food there though, the nan is great and so is the skewers and chicken tikka masala is one of the best dishes on their menu. It's just too bad that they have to have such a jerk running the place...
author: Bobby B.

description:
Alright, people. This place is good. If you want a big bowl of curried goodness it ranges from 5.50-less than 10. And naan the size of your forearm is a dollar. Yeaahhh thats right. Reasonably cheap delicious food. 
I haven't rtied any other indian in SF, but I'm more than satisfied to keep tis place in mind for awhile. That Daal Chana is so good. The naan is perfecto. Very vegetarian friendly.
3 vegan curries on the menu, but not vegan naan! =( UGH. 

Only problem with this place is cashola only, folks. Really inconvenient.
author: Shaina P.

description:
Pakwan, please never change (unless, the changes involve having more seating and a tad friendlier service). Seriously, more like packed-one. And, it wouldn't hurt to crack a smile every now and again, I understand you're busy, but it's no excuse. 

Now, for the good parts.
Everything I've tried on the menu so far has been great -- fresh, delicious, well-portioned. I am a fan of their vegetarian entrees, but it's not to say that their meat dishes aren't good. There's just something about the way they blend spices that makes me absolutely crave their chana masala. 

And I wouldn't be the first one to remark on how incredibly affordable it is. CHEAP, even. Which just perplexes me. I mean, the food is so great, and the interior isn't even mangy enough for me to call this place a 'hole in the wall'! It's nice there, people.

Also, did I mention BYOB? Sold.
author: Katia I.

description:
I adore this place- the meals are reasonable sizes and the service is always prompt. I love the chickpea curry, and it is cheap!!!
also try the potato nann- hands down the best nann I've had. The mango lassi is also great for dessert.
author: Sam S.

description:
The lamb biryani, chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, and one of the appetizers were all tasty. 

BYOB, so you can make it a party if you want to. 

Only downside is the poor ventilation. Anything within the immediate area will smell like Indian food when you leave. Plus, after about 30 mins, my friend's eyes started to water. I thought he was just being emo, but then my eyes started to get irritated, too. It was caused by the excess smoke/oils in the air coming from the kitchen (it's set up like a diner, so in the same space as the dining area)...at least that's what we'll tell everyone.
author: Joe A.

description:
Finally went to Pakwan after many years of hearing and reading positive reviews. I've been walking by it for over 8 years - it's one of those places that isn't particularly inviting or sanitary looking from the outside but remains on your to-try list because others like it.

Well, I'm happy to report that this place ROCKS!  Awesome food, awesome prices, awesome portions, cool vibe (due to diverse array of diners), fast, and did I mention the awesome food!  Tried the chicken korma, filet of sole, samosas, and nan. Everything was SO tasty. I've never had fish at a Pakistani-Indian restaurant and I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious it was (although it could have been a tad warmer). My only other complaint was that the nan was little too thick for my liking around the edges.

Order at the counter, grab a table, and get your own napkins, cutlery, extra plates, water and drinks. They'll call your number for pick up at the counter when it's ready. Cash only. Totally worth trying!
author: Vicente G.

description: Never fails...simple and low cost. byob allowed. Can get really crowded but if you avoid the rush hour you'll be ok
author: Jeffrey M.

description:
We came here for dinner and I believe the Chicken Aschar tasted better at the Pakawan in the Tenderloin. 

This place is a little bit more fancy (nicer plates and tables) compared to the Tenderloin location.


I was disappointed they did not serve any Okra.


My top Indian joint is still Shaliymar.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Pakwan was not love at first sight for me, but it had me at the second try. They give you a lot of food for the price. The saag paneer is amongst the best I've had. The naan is cooked perfectly, and I think they make it in house because all the pieces are shaped differently. 

It's not a classy restaurant, so I wouldn't take a date here. I would go here again to fill an indian food craving.
author: Vivian W.

description: Great food and one of my favorite take-out spots. While you should not expect a quiet sit down dinner, the food is great for take-out or a quick dine-in meal. The prices are good and it's byob! I recommend!
author: Casey P.

description:
Pakwan is my SF restaurant of choice for delicious Indian/Pakistani food.  I've now been to enough (e.g. 10+) Indian/Pakistani joints in the city for the claim to be meaningful.

Also, I'd like to add Bengan Bharta to my list of recommended dishes at Pakwan.  I'm not generally a fan of eggplant, but I love this particular dish.
author: Grace W.

description: Amazing food, through and through. Get a beer at the liquor store across the street (and some cash at the ATM next door) and enjoy some really, really good Pakistani food. Their order number system is a bit chaotic (no real order to the numbers, some people after you get their food before you even if they order just as much), and you have to seat yourself. But it's worth it.
author: Jesse G.

description:
Fast, cheap, popular, loud.

The Chicken Tikka Masala is tres tasty.  That is THE reason to go to Pakwan.
author: Colin S.

description:
You serve yourself so if going for the first time, you might be a little confused, but if you go with people who know the know, then you're all good.

The food here is really good with plentiful options. 

Great for groups! I came here for a birthday dinner and only had to pay $10 to be filled and satisfied. Nice!

You can even BYOB, so that's another convenient and cool factor.

I'd recommend, but parking is kind of bleh.
author: Susan Y.

description:
The price point and portion size is great. I found the food to be not spicy enough for me. Props for the chai, it was quite delicious.
The service is minimal but fast however if you are not familiar with their serving style it might throw you for a loop. 

I would return if I was in the neighborhood but I don't think I would make another trip out just to eat there.
author: Roger H.

description:
This place reminds of Naan and curry in Berkeley. Grab your own utensils, your own water and your own hot masala tea ($1 isn't bad at all for free refills). That's fine by me as long as the food is good.

It's pretty popular on yelp so I came here for lunch with high expectations but was a little disappointed. We got the chicken tikka masala and it was alright. I'm surprised they never asked us how spicy we wanted our food to be. Why not?! I'm going to eat Indian food so I would love having the option of spicy food.

I like mango lassi that are little more sour and runny so the mango lassi here was just alright. A little more on the sweet but not mango-y  side. 

It's slightly overrated but still a decent indian place.
author: Jun Kang C.

description:
A coworker suggested this place since we were in the area for a documentary screening. And so we went....

The menu didn't have much of a selection so I ordered the chicken makhanwala with basmati rice. It was a little odd that they didn't have wait service. I ordered, sat down and when my number was called I had to get up and get my food myself. That was kind of a new experience for me....

The food was pretty good. In the middle of eating, one of the latin dudes gave me free nan. I think it was free...I didn't order it. My coworker seems to think he was interested in me so he gave me free nan. Haha....whatever.

If I was in the neighborhood, I'd probably check out other Indian places before I come back to this one.
author: V M.

description: The veggie biryani is off the chart, as is the lamb curry.  It seems that there is a new recipie list for the old favorites...the Nann is even better than before: CHOMP!
author: Kirsten F.

description: Cash only.  Veggie biryani, tandoori chicken, saag paneer, and nan (plain & garlic) are my favorites.  Not a great place to go if you have plans afterwards, as the smell of their delicious food will stick to you.
author: Marleen C.

description:
Chutney (511 Jones/Ofarrell) is the wife and my favorite Pakistani/Indian restaurant.  Every "Naan" place we go to gets compared against Chutney, and we usually end up never going to the compared place again.  So since we always compare every Paki/Indian place to Chutney, I will do so here in this review!

Our order is almost always the same:  Chicken Tikki Masala, Aloo Ghobi (cauliflower/potatoes), Naan, Rice, Mango Lassi.  Aloo Ghobi is not offered at Pakwan, so we ordered Bengan Bhartha (eggplant/onions) instead.


Pakwan vs. Chutney:

Price:  Advantage- no one
* same, just under $20.  

Service:  Advantage- Chutney
* moments after ordering and sitting at a table at Chutney, 1-2 employees will come over with a carafe of water, plates, forks, and a FREE lettuce/tomato/onion salad.  Pakwan does not offer the salad, nor do they have anyone bring anything to your table.  Get your own plates/water/forks and even get your own food! (they just call your number)

Chai Tea:  Advantage- Chutney
* free at Chutney, $1.00 at Pakwan.

Mango Lassi:  Advantage- Chutney
* wife drinks it, not me, and she says Chutney is better.  Also, Pakwan pre-fills quite a few cups of ML and leaves it in the fridge.  Chutney pours ML fresh into a glass.  How long was our ML sitting there before we bought it?!  

Naan:  Advantage- no one
* always light and fluffy.  Can't really mess up this one, and any restaurant that does should not be in business!  Same price at each ($1.00).

Rice:  Advantage- Pakwan
* rice is tasty at both places, but plate size is larger at Pakwan, so we get more rice.  Same price at each ($1.00).

Chicken Tikki Masala:  Slight Advantage- Pakwan
* at Chutney, the tikki masala is always orangy and creamy and oh so good to dip naan into.  at Pakwan, the tikki masala had more texture and was less creamy, but still good to dip naan into.  I would call this even as each tikki masala is great on their own merit, but the slight advantage goes to Pakwan because Chutney gives only 6 pieces of meat, and Pakwan delivers with double the amount of chicken... at least!

Bengan Bhartha / Aloo Ghobi:  to be determined
* we have not tried this yet at Chutney, and cannot compare Aloo Ghobi because Pakwan does not serve this dish.


I cannot give Pakwan a 5-star rating because of the lack of service.  

I normally don't care if I have to pick up my food at the counter, but with Paki/Indian food, we can easily have 4-6 plates, which means multiple trips back to the counter.  Pakwan will definitely be revisited and we are not giving up on Chutney, but have finally found a formidable alternative to our favorite Pakistani/Indian restaurant.

(Pakwan's TL location at 501 Ofarrell is a stone's throw from Chutney, so we plan to check that out, as well as try Bengan Bhartha at Chutney)
author: Alan R.

description: One of my favorite Indian restaurants. It is self service meaning you pick your food after you order. Get your own plates and utensils. Find your table. My only complain is their restroom, they need to fix it. Otherwise, I enjoy the food. It gets very busy here too so avoid rush peak hours or order to go.
author: Joel Q.

description: Love this place! Love their chicken briyani, chicken tikka masala and tandoori chicken. They have the best mango lassi and Palak paneer I've ever had. The only problem is parking sucks and they occasionally burn my naan but other than that they have the best paki food in the city.
author: Shaz M.

description: As of now, this is my favorite Indian in the city, above Indian Oven and Aslams Rasoi (both of which have gone a bit downhill as of late 2012). Pakwan is cheap, byob, and has well balanced curries. It does not have the refinement of other Indian places, but the taste to price ratio is 5 stars for sure. Great Tikka and Lamb Curry, decent samosas at a good price. I did see a mouse running around the back near the bathroom once so if I could I would knock off a half star. Didn't see the mouse near the kitchen, so 5 stars seems right.
author: Sean H.

description:
Dear Yelpers,

THANK YOU for introducing me to a great new Indian restaurant. This place is definitely a restaurant I'll be returning to. It's a great place for a late dinner to start the night, where you can show up around 9:30, eat a great dinner, then head on to the surrounding bars.

Here is the important logistical information: cash only, wait in line to order, get a number, seat yourself, listen for your number to be called, BYOB drinks (this is the most important!), get your own plates/utensils. 

I ordered Chicken Tikka Massala, because it's my favorite dish, and everyone recommended it, so I can now be one of the hundreds to also say you should get it, it has a little bit of a spice to it too like most people say. I also got garlic naan which was delicious. My friend got Chicken Bryani and that was also really good. 

You get a lot more than you pay for. I definitely recommend it - but don't tell everyone, I don't want to wait in a super long line!
author: Ashley H.

description: Great food at an incredibly low prince for San Francisco. The guy who took my order was very accommodating as well. I'm no expert at Indian food, but it was delicious and served relatively quickly. You get to grab your own water caraffe too, which not a lot of places do and was kinda cool. I dunno, I'm strange like that.
author: Spencer B.

description: Really good food for a fair price - you can easily feed 3 people on $30-$40. Nice, fresh flavors and spiciness is just right. Tandoori fish is my favorite. Atmosphere is very loud and chaotic (we were there on a Saturday @ 7 PM) and it's hard to get a table, but once you manage to snag a table and start eating, it all seems to fade away. It's kind of cool to have the option to BYOB, but then again, you run the risk of having to sit next to a table of people partying on a 12 pack of Budweiser.
author: Diana M.

description:
WARNING: this restaraunt takes cash only... 

Walking into this restaraunt i was a little confused on how this little pakastani restaraunt worked..you fall in line, look at the menu, tell the cashier what you want to order and grab your number or ticket.  I've recently started to have a great appreciation for Indian food, so when i saw the menu i wanted to try EVERYTHING.

I ordered the chicken tikka masala, an order of naan, side of tandoori chicken leg, and an order of rice.  The chicken tikka masala was really good, i loved dipping my naan in the creamy tomato masala sauce.  It had just the right amount of spice for me too.  The tandoori chicken was pretty good, honestly ive had better tandoori chicken at masala bowl, it was a tad dry but still good.  If you order a side of rice, its enough to feed to people FYI.  some of my friends that i dined with are vegitarian, and i was able to try Pakwans vegitarian dishes and they were realllly good!.....The samosas were way too spicy for my tasting..i could only handle one bite.  Overall i was completely satisfied with my food, i couldnt finish it all, but it did make great left overs.
author: Xandy M.

description:
I really like the Independence of this place. I don't mind getting my own plate,spoon,or glass of water. The nans are always nice and fluffy. I usually order the Chicken Tika Masala and rice to share with a friend, we get that plus simosas and two nans for less than $16. Super deal and we end up super full. 

The staff is always kind and fast with our orders. I live a block aways and always see customers, for me says a lot. 

F.Y.I don't forget cash, they don't take plastic.
author: Claudia G.

description: I loved the basmati rice, garlic naan, tikka masala and saag paneer. The beef kabob was just ok I've had better. The cilantro sauce was delicious, the plum sauce was ok. We tried the samosa also again I've had better. For the self service style restaurant it was expensive, I come back if in the area.
author: John G.

description:
Great food. Very plain and simple decor. Was here for lunch. We ordered at the counter and picked up our food at the counter and brought it ourselves to the table, so no full waiter service.
The Tiki-Masala was flavorful and the curries were spicy, but not much. The Nan is really good too. They also have a big pot of Chai Masala and you pour your own cup for $1 and refills are free. Very nice..
I liked that they have take-out boxes available to take home what we didn't finish. Again, self-service.
We'll definitely be back.
author: Neil S.

description: I absolutely adore Pakwan for some very specific reasons that might not be everyone's cup of tea/plate of Nann. First, cheap prices, large portions (the chicken biyrani regularly shows up in my dreams!), BYOB, fun night-life sort of atmosphere. It's not your place for fine, classy dining or to be splitting hairs about the nuance of food preperation and ingredients (no harm in that, just not that kind of place). It is the best place ever, however, for a large group of friends looking to enjoy a fun evening. I hope we all keep supporting this great SF staple!
author: Virginia W.

description:
When I'm in SF, Pakwan is the base of my food triangle. My kingdom for their chana masala! Aaaah... So delicious; so well priced. 

Lately I've been encountering a friendly counter person. Which is shocking, because for years, a leering, bordering-on-harassing creep always took my order. I hate me a leering, harassing creep, but I love the chana masala enough to grin and bear it.

I greatly appreciate the recent bathroom renovations: It's no longer nauseating to pee at Pakwan. 

Great eggplant dishes; perfect fragrant rice; tasty chai; mouth-watering breads; awesome chicken saag.

I love you, Pakwan!
author: Kate C.

description:
After we ordered and sat down to wait for our number to be called, we noticed at least 5 tables around us that have not been cleared.  It was a bit off putting to see everyone dirty napkins and leftover food.  However after about 5mins someone came by and cleared up the tables.  After this it was hard for me to not think about the cleanliness of the establishment, but I've been to many sketchy dining places...  

The grilled beef thing was very overcooked.  tough and chewy.  
Their chicken masala was good. 
Their naans are cheap.

I would go back and try their curries.
author: dublin a.

description:
Pakwan restored my faith in Naan.

Their fluffy, tender, just-right naan, whether onion or garlic, has just the right mix of crispy, nearly charred spots and tender, fluffy parts and is always piping hot.

They also restored my faith in Chicken Tikka Masala and Chicken Korma which were nearly ruined by the rampant inconsistency of the Indian places we had been patronizing.  

IQ prefers the Pakwan in Fremont, while I prefer this location.

Look, it's not a place  you go to for the atmosphere, which is non-existent--this could be a Bingo hall in any frosty Midwestern City--you go there for hot, fast, fresh Pakistani-Indian food.

Period!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Inexpensive, tasty, no frills, awesome naan, cash only.

Casual place, order up front, get a number, sit down, get your food your order is ready. This is basically a self service place. But the prices are really inexpensive, $6 for a dish, $1 naan.  Loved the chicken tikka masala and tandori.

The ventillation isn't the greatest, so if you are by the kitchen, your hair/clothes might smell like spices long after you've left...
author: Caroline I.

description:
Anna G.: "I have a bottle of champagne that's been burning a hole in my refrigerator." 

Pamela D.: "It should be burning a hole in our LIVERS." 

Funny!

Hence, we went to Pakwan for dinner before a show at the Independent. Because it's BYOB and spitting distance from my apartment. We noticed several people order their food, find tables, and then run across the street to the liquor store to buy some tasty beverages to accompany their meals. 

Food is relatively cheap, tasty, low-maintenance. I managed to open the bottle of champagne without spilling and/or putting anyone's eye out. It was a good night.
author: Anna G.

description: I wasn't too satisfied with the flavor of the dishes I got here. Maybe I came on an off day? People seem to love this place. Pluses are fast service and good-sized portions.
author: Olivia P.

description:
Cheap
Tasty
BYOB

4.5 starz, .5 for the free PTM after they gave us CTM instead.
author: Chris S.

description: Today my sister and went to Pakwan with high hopes of delicious food. We didn't even make it through ordering before we left because of some rude and inappropriate comments the cashier made about our weight. So I can't vouch for the food, but the customer service is appalling.
author: Elise C.

description: I love going to this place! From the outside, it seems really dark, but this place is actually really great for some Indian food. My friends and I love to get tons of naan and chicken tikka masala. The people here are also extremely nice. Wait time is very short, and the prices for the naan and other dishes are really great. My friends and I come here fairly regularly, and the food and service is consistent every time! The only issue I have is that the tables are not exactly stable, and the utensils look super old and somewhat dirty with age. Otherwise, this is one my favorite places to eat!
author: Marjorie M.

description:
If you like Paki and Indian food.. you have to try this restaurant!
I love the informal vibe!

Chicken tikka massala is fantastic!
All the Byriani rices are great and tasty..specially the lamb

WARNING: everything here is spicy! I cannot finish a whole plate without going through a stack of napkins~!
author: Fran M.

description:
Man, I love this place!  Now that I know you can bring your own booze, I'm even happier!

You can't go wrong with any dish.  My favorite though came from their Specials menu -- Squash Curry.  So FREAKIN' amazing!!!!  We stuffed ourselves silly but I nearly bought another dish of it to take home with me.  By breakfast time the next morning, I was really sad that I hadn't gotten that extra plate to go!
author: Melissa Q.

description:
-The food was strictly okay. We'd heard good things about the place, so we were disappointed. We ordered biryani, naan and haleem, and none of them were memorable. As South Asians, we know what the authentic stuff tastes like, and this didn't match up.
-Cash only, which is a pain.
-Slow service. We had a really long wait with an annoying pinging token system going off every minute or so.

Perhaps this is considered good fare in San Francisco, but the South Bay is overflowing with comparable and better options. So we'll give it a miss the next time we're in the Mission neighborhood.
author: D B.

description:
No frills, no fuss, just good Indian/Pakistani food, served cafe-style.  BYOB is a bonus, as are the incredibly reasonable prices.  The food is delicious, tho often times give me a serious case of fire-belly, which inevitably leads to a serious case of fire-butt.  A dangerous place to take a date, as you never want to get caught trying to balance after-meal sexy-time with a serious case of fire-butt.

(On a related note, I think in a weird way my love of Baingan Bartha has a lot to do with the fact that it looks the same going in as it does coming out.  Ew.  Wow, this review has tangentialized into TMI territory.  Sorry folks, pulling it back together now.)

Um, yeah *cough* Pakwan is good for groups and stuff, and... yay for takeout, and BYOB...wait I already said that. 

Ok, better to quit while I'm still not too far behind.

I like the food here!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Was taken out to Pakwan for the first time last night by fantastic person who helped me celebrate my getting laid off yesterday in style. 

Pluses:
Food is amazing! I loved the saag paneer, eggplant dish & garlic naan 
Nice tamarind & mint chutneys
Can bring in your own bottle of wine
Affordable prices (as long as you are employed)

Cons:
Not halal :(
Tables were not cleaned apparently in some time
Chai is not free
Raita costs extra and was too runny
Food could have been spicier, well spiced but wasn't hot enough

Still not as good as Lahore Karahi, but yummy.
author: Cara J.

description: Reasonable price, great location, BYOB (with a liquor store across the street), solid Indian food. This place is a great way to start a weekend night and is still solid for a real meal.
author: Ojus P.

description:
The saag paneer is just great here. Very rich and aromatic, with dark well-seasoned spinach and savory cheese. My friends and I also love the Mirch Salan roasted hot peppers (light green, like banana peppers), cooked in a dark brown tamarind curry. 

My friend used to date a Pakistani guy who declared Pakwan "the real thing."  The guy's no longer in the picture, but this has remained my friend's favorite restaurant ever since. 

Tips:

- Bring your fast-moving aggressive friends.  This place gets packed, and the seat-yourself policy means you have to hustle when a table frees up.

- The overwhelming aroma of tandoori will stick to your clothes and bags and jackets  -- keep that in mind when you dress up to go here.  The scent kept me hungry for days as I'd catch a whiff of my messenger bag every now and then.
author: angela n.

description: BYOB, delicious, no frills, lamb falling off the bone winner
author: Jade H.

description: This place is inexpensive which is great but honestly the food is sub par. I ordered the lamb kabob which smelled like poop and had old wilted parsley and sliced onions with the papery onion skin still on them. At least the mango lassi was good. Otherwise...disappointing.
author: Erin W.

description: Went to Pakwan on Saturday night for the first time ever and I really enjoyed it.  We were a party of 4 and we walked in at about 10:00 pm and got immediately seated.  I love the fact that they are BYOB.  We brought a bottle of wine with us to enjoy with our meal.  Since my friend is a regular here (to the point where he knows the owner on a first name basis), I let him do the ordering for us.  He ordered more than enough food for the 4 of us and within 10 minutes we were served.  What a delicious meal!  I would definitely come back here if I had the opportunity.  Oh, and if you're looking for something to do afterwards, Double Dutch next door is a great option (no cover charge and good stiff drinks).
author: Omar G.

description: Excellent match of budget and an average introduction to oriental dish. Self service, you can even get your drinks across the street!
author: Ozgur G.

description: I'll never understand why this place is so popular.  The food is mediocre, at best, rather bland, and there are several Indian restaurants in the neighborhood who serve better tasting, fresher food.  It's certainly not worth waiting for a table when there are so many other choices nearby.   Service is non-existent - you pick up your food at the counter, bus your own table, and fetch your own water.  I'm very turned off by how filthy this place is.  The tables do not seem to really get cleaned between seatings.  Also, I know it's the Mission, and pests in restaurants are a reality, but they should be invisible to me as a patron.  There are roaches in the restaurant every single time I go here... at least sometimes they are dead.
author: Heidi M.

description:
Freakin love Pakwan!

cheap, dirty, tasty. Some people look down on the dirty part but cmon now The Mission is a gritty place- love it or leave it ....

My friends and I often come here and choose to sit outside. The bums and other spacecakes that occasion our table are just part of it, a part the neighborhood really. 

The man with the space goggles is always an interesting diversion.

One of the greatest things beside the cheap tasty food is the fact that they let you bring your own "adult" beverages to the restaurant. Whether sitting  outside on a summer night with a couple of IPAs or on a colder night with a bottle of Dewars and cigarette or...few- good/interesting dinners are to be had.
author: Thomas P.

description: Pakwan now delivers and the guy on the phone and the delivery guy both spoke English perfectly!
author: Wakako U.

description: For inexpensive pakistani indian food d, this is as good as it gets imho.
author: Michael R.

description:
Oh Pakwan, you're leaving a lot to be desired . . . 

If you are truly an ardent lover of Desi food, you'd give this place 2 stars. I seriously gave it an extra star because it's a BYOB establishment. If I didn't have high food standards is give this place 4 stars just for that!

The nitty gritty:
It took for what seemed like forever for our number to come up (no wait staff here), the masala was just kind of 'meh', and the lamb skewer was really disappointing, overly salted and not fresh tasting. The nan, well, the nan and chai were awesome. 

If you're craving some Indian/Pakistani food because you can't get it in your neighborhood and you just happen to be in the Mission, Pakwan is cheap and convenient enough. However, if you've been dying for some superbly tasty Desi food, pass it up an look elsewhere.
author: Kari G.

description: My favorite Indian restaurant in the Bay Area. Love their lamb biryani, seekh kabab, ahari gosht and bhuna gosht. I'm typically there once a month; almost always very happy with the food.
author: Ankur V.

description: Love the local BYOB feel, so it's quite cost-efficient if you get a few dishes to share with some naan and rice to go around. Strong curries with ample amounts of flavor and spice. I had the special for the evening, the chicken vindaloo, which was a tad small, but I think with rice and garlic naan, it was just enough for me. Really nicely prepared potatoes still with some texture to go along with large pieces of chicken. Menu is pretty solid overall, but my only gripe is that it's limited seating and can get a little hectic around dinner time.
author: Travis L.

description:
Today, my friend and I were traversing the Mission District and stopped at Pakwan for lunch. I've heard some good things about this place, and by the power of Yelp, went in since the good folks on here had positive marks for this place. 

Initially it seemed alright, some seats available during the mad lunch rush. The menu looked interesting and scrumptious. When the man at the counter rang us up, it was crazy cheap compared to some other joints. Anyways, by the time I shuffled through, and picked up, the only partially clean plates and cutlery's. Our number was called.

The food was great, up until my friend stopped eating and had a very disturbed look on her face. 4 seconds later, she told me to stop eating and showed me the small, but plump, cockroach (about the size of a pumpkin seed) that she scooped up from either the eggplant dish or the chicken tikka masala. I know they would throw all kinds of spices not known to some of us, but I'm pretty sure spices don't have legs.  

We didn't make a scene, but we did show it to the man at the counter. He gave us our money back, apologized, and offered us desserts for free. No thank you.

We were both a little shaken as we wandered the Mission disappointed. This surely left a bad impression on me and a taste in my palette that I will not soon forget.
author: Chris E.

description: Best indian food I've had in SF for def and it's ridiculously cheap!  I'm always astonished by the price considering the massive portions and the quality of the food!  It's not a beautiful setting or anything but who cares when the food is awesome and you can bring your own booze (there's a pretty reasonable store for alcohol across the road)!  Definitely recommend the tikka masala, butter chicken and lamb kebabs!  The Naan is so soft and light and fluffy- amazing! And one portion of rice is easily enough for three people if you have naan as well!  Definitely going to be a regular at this place!  Awesome.
author: Ashleigh R.

description:
Glad I succumbed to the many good reviews and decided to try it for myself. Asking for quite the risk by bringing it to Indian food loving friends, it hit home and served its purpose. 

We had eggplant dish (forget the name), saag paneer, chicken tikka, chicken achar, and busha (curry lamb) - all good. Naan was decent. Samosas were quite yummy. Rice was blah. For mere $60 we feed the five of us.

Pakwan is a quick & easy + tasty take out choice worth a return visit!
author: Kirsten L.

description: Price and quantities are good and some dishes are better spiced than others.  But, it's more like "junk" Indian food.
author: Jessica P.

description:
BYOB - W #1*

So, the let you bring in your own beer, saving you the markup on alcohol that you would get at other Indian restaurants. However, the food costs just as much as a sit down and you have to wait in line, fight a group of hipsters for your table and go pick up your food when it is ready.... which is a little odd, since they send someone to your table anyhow to let you know to go get it. Why not just bring it to you?? 

On top of that, once you reach the counter, if they are out of what you ordered, they will sub out what you ordered with something else, without asking you. Are you telling me that in the 5 minutes from order to pickup they didn't know? Plus they have someone walking up to your table to tell you your food is ready but they don't tell you you are picking up something other than what you ordered?

I don't know, Pakwan. I think I'll just go to Naan & Curry (but not the one on Van Ness, you have been warned) where I can still bring in my booze, I can find a table, they bring me my food and I actually get what I order.
___________________________________________________

*Bum wine consumed;
Thundrebird, The American Classic - very sweet white wine 17.5 % alohol. Probably some of the worst bum wine I have ever had. 
Night Train - The red version of Thunderbird. 17.5 and super syrupy, but it had fruity undertones and is much more pallatable provided it is served ice cold.
author: Drue C.

description:
**WARNING!!! If you even REMOTELY like animals, this review has the potential to induce projectile vomiting and long-term trauma. Consider yourself warned**

Allow me to lay the groundwork with a few facts about AK:
1. I LOVE(D) meat
2. I am NOT a sap
3. I RARELY cry

That said, when I am eating food at an Indian restaurant, the last thing I want to see is a parade of entirely skinned lambs (head and all) carried through the front door of said restaurant on the burly shoulders of men old enough to know better. YES. 5 or 6 WHOLE, SKINNED lambs were carried right by my table in front of my eyes and the rest of the patrons in the place, at 7 p.m. on a Saturday, during the dinner rush. 

All you need to know is I cried, I shook, I vomited, and I had to be rocked back and forth like a baby before being taken outside for a breather. I am fortunate to have Matthew r, Jason K, and Kathleen L, who were equally shocked and horrified, but managed to keep it together. 

I won't even review the food. After the dead animal parade and ensuing nausea and nightmares, I'm beyond the food (which is pretty standard), service, location, etc. 

Meet the newest card-carrying member of the Vegetarian Yelper Club! Who's bringing me a welcome basket?
author: Autumn K.

description: This food is so tastey and has a nice kick of spice.  The nan bread is par non!  Try the garlic non.  Lamb sag is delcious and aromatic with cardomon, be careful not to eat the pods. Chicken Tika Masalla is buttery, tangy and yummy.  The vegetable dish with cauliflower is spicey tastey and not over cooked. The daal is delicious.  Thic chicken boti tika is large chunks of spiced up chicken breast meat that goes well with their green sauce.  The food is served efficiently and quickly..  One oddity is the flat screen TV's that has a robotic announce when your order is ready to pick up self serve and bring it to your table.  Its also fine to bring your own wine or beer in to enjoy with your meal.  This place is so affordable and usually you have leftovers to take home. Whenever I bring out of town guests, this is where they want to come back to when they return to the City.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I often feel like a horrible host to my visiting friends.  

I get them blind stammering drunk every single night and this ensures they never see the light of day and spend gorgeous afternoons cooped up on my couch watching whatever has been on my TiVo for the last 4 months, eating Cheetos and Pepperidge Farms Cookies in filthy sweatpants.

Welcome to my world.  I'm not gonna sugarcoat the "Kirsten Experience"  It is what it is and it aint what it aint,  (that was weird to type).

So after 3/4 of a beautiful day was obliterated it was actually my guest that had the idea to go to Pakwan and indulge in a good old fashioned Indian Food Grease-A-Thon.  The cheetos and m&m's and cookies were really doing a crazy dance in my stomach and i was hoping to silence the torture with a nice spicy Indian lube job.  haha, gross...just gross.

The freaks on the Mission-14 line on the ride over were really in full effect that night...some guy started shaking uncontrollably and picking at scabs on his arms.  Another guy was listening to a walkman (a walkman!  A real honest to god walkman!) and screaming incoherent song jibberish at the top of his lungs.  

I started to have second thoughts if this was really worth it.

We got there without being shot or just giving up and going to McDonalds and I'm totally glad we did.  

Sitting outside and dining directly on 16th street was a new experience for me.  I was only approached by 3 derelicts during the meal, which to be fair included the coolest homeless guy ever that told me "Baby girl you put all the bumble bees out of business by stealing up all the damn honey!"  I dont really know what that means but i took to mean i'm smokin' hot...which suited me just fine.

Food was pretty damn good.  We ate everything like it was the Last Supper....ferociously shoving piles of chicken and naan and strange orange sauces into our mouths.  The chicken might have been as dry as the L.A. River, but the kebabs were screamin'.  You cant really screw up naan or basmati rice - but it was a solid effort nonetheless.

We got yelled at for bringing little containers of that mint sauce outside to our table.  Some guy came out and took them away from us and said if we wanted sauce we had to use the bottles, not the containers.  That pissed me off.  This is the main cause of the three star rating.  I mean, really?  Did that fool just come and take my sauce away?

For the most part i was impressed and it really put me into that blurry-eyed food coma thing that was going to usher me into a glorious post debauchery slumber.  Totally awesome.

Oh and the coolest part was we made it home in time to finish the Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia marathon we started.  

If anyone wants to sign up for the Kirsten Weekend Fantasy Camp please let me know.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
I love Pakwan. I have been here many times over the years, but had never reviewed it on Yelp until now. I have decided not to deduct any stars for the semi funkiness of the place. It's a dive, but it's not trying to be otherwise, so why deduct a star for that? 

At Pakwan, everything is self serve. You order at the counter, collect your serving utensils, plates, glasses, napkins yourself. When your food is ready they call out your number and you pick up the food from the counter. Yes, Pakwan is a little funky, but the food and the price is great. By the way, the current decor is a big improvement over its past look.

I had dinner with a friend last night and we ordered way too much food, or so I thought. The food was so good that we both stuffed ourselves silly (eating every scrap) for only $25.00 each. Since Pakwan is BYOB we brought a bottle of Lambert Bridge Zinfandel, which was a MUCH better wine than there would ever be at an Indian/Pakastani restaurant. Nice. I like BYOB: no corkage.

We had naan, tandoori lamb chops, lamb biyriani, saag paneer, achar gosht (lamb), and a chicken dish with chickpeas. Everything was fantastic. Big yummy flavors and well prepared.

I consider myself an expert on Indian food (although I have never been to the continent of Asia), but I have many Indian cookbooks and have been a student of Indian cooking for 20+ years. Cooking Indian food correctly is very time consuming and many Indian restaurants cut a lot of corners, not so here. The meat is always moist and tender, the sauces flavorful and fresh. Pakwan's food is not swimming in oil either!

Pakwan is my favorite Indian/Pakastani restaurant. For a similar cuisine, I also love the Nepalese restaurant Little Nepal in Bernal Heights. I still have to try Vik's Chat Corner in Berkeley.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Anyone who's read my reviews knows I likes me a good curry, and Pakwan in the Mission is wonderful. In many ways it's like a dive bar in its down to earth presentation, minimal service, and BYOB, but like dive bars it's great value, good food, and pretty fast. I went there with 6 people and we did a family style thing, ordering several dishes, some rice and a few Naan bread (which Sav pronounces differently to me, and it drove him crazy, hey you say tomato and I say go fuck yourself :-) Anyway, we ordered a lamb curry (lots of cardomom, medium spice, lamb on the tough side), chicken korma (mild, nothing to write home about), chicken tika masssala (very very good), chicken tika breast and leg (brilliant), and the Naan was just how i like it, with little charred bits right out of the tandoor. 

So why 5 stars if everything wasn't amazing, well it's a price/quality thing, this was cheap, cheerful and everything was better than expected.
author: Karl L.

description:
Good food and good people, if you're into this food and show up with the right people.  

Yelper friends can become real friends, I am discovering.  A couple of Yelpers invited me to Pakwan for dinner, where they are regulars.  Although the line seemed long when we walked up, we had two tables to choose from when we finished placing our order.  The food was good, about what I expected.  The company was good, even better than I expected.  Yelp has definitely improved our social lives; we can reach out electronically, share thoughts, and be ready to feel good about each other when the face time begins.
author: David D.

description:
Whenever my man takes me out for the occasional surprise dinner he teases me that he's going to take me to Pakwan.  He thinks he's being funny, but the truth is, I love Pakwan.

One day, he will pull up in his ride, and Gary Danko will be the furthest from his mind.  Instead, we'll swing around the block to Pakwan, make a grand entrance in our finest and gorge ourselves on samosas, tikka masala, tadoori lamb and mango lassi. Yummm.
author: Nicole G.

description:
The last Indian/Pakistani restaurant I ate at was Dosa.
Pakwan is leaps and bounds better, all while being a tiny little fraction of the cost.  
No ambiance whatsoever, no alcohol (you can bring your own), but the food is phenomenal and the prices make me giddy!
author: Christine M.

description:
found this place on yelp and decided to give it a try. so happy I did because the food is really good, especially for the price. moreover, the fact it is BYOB is also a huge plus! 

the samosas are delicious. we also had a cauliflower dish which was very tasty. didn't get to try the tandoori chicken, but it looked incredible!

only downside is that this place gets really busy so people are like vultures snagging up tables. they also get mad if you take your sweet old time which is what we did, after all 2 bottles of wine and some beer takes time to drink! 

bear in mind there are no servers, you order your food and pick it up when your number is called. It's a fun, low key and inexpensive dinner place, love it!
author: Jae C.

description:
Something strange has happened. 

That strange thing is that I used to openly dislike Pakwan... but somewhere along the line, that dislike turned into a hardcore craving for Pakwan every single night. I love BYOBing there with my friends after work. And the other night I even took a cab there *alone* with the plan to cab it back to my apartment. I can't stop thinking about that apple chutney. Everyday, I want to put it all over my sagg paneer and tikka masala and then drench it raita. Maybe I've been brainwashed, or maybe I was just totally wrong about this place and it's actually deeeeeeeelicious - I think it's the latter.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Good ingredient.  Real spices and slow cooked.  Just a great down to earth Indian food place!
author: Jay H.

description:
Oh, Pakwan! How could you, on our very first date? I had such a simple request, veggie samosas... and you lied! You lied! You took my money and said you've give me samosas. But you didn't. You gave me some deep-fried... well, I have no idea what it was. Maybe the veggie pakora? If so, you owe me 99 cents! How will I ever be able to trust you again?

And you let so many people through you, it was like you barely had time for me. You sent someone to tell us that our food was ready... you couldn't even be bothered to bring it yourself. You don't really love me, do you?

I feel so used. At least you let me drink cheap booze from the local grocer in the back seat.
author: Paul B.

description:
3.5 stars.

We came here last night for take out. The food took about 5-10 minutes to be ready (it was around 8pm on a Saturday night).

We ordered:

Chawal rice: As good as other places I've tried. Perfect seasoning, has the bite that I look for in this kind of rice.

Garlic Nan: Not as garlicky as Alhamra, but delicious nonetheless. I think I like this one better than Alhamra's.

Aloo Palak: Good, but I think it would have been better with more flavor. Maybe the dish is supposed to be light? The spinach and potatoes were cooked just fine.

Chicken Tikka Masala: Chicken was good, not too dry. The sauce was very flavorful and had some texture to it, which I enjoyed. Spiced perfectly.

We ended up only finishing half of the rice, aloo palak, and chicken tikka masala (we only got one nan, so that was finished). We were stuffed! It cost about $18. I would come back again. It's probably on par or a little better than Alhamra, I think.
author: Angela H.

description:
In my opinion, this is one of the better cheap Indian/Pakistani places around. It's true that the ambiance may leave a bit to be desired, (howver, they have repainted recently), it tends to be quite loud, and the staff a bit terse, but the food never disappoints. I have a strong appreciation for hole in the wall joints, so it doesn't bother me that it's a bit grimy (I've seen worse), to me, it just adds to the charm!
 
The chicken Tikka Masala is always delicious here, it is the right balance of spicy and smoky. I have also enjoyed the Saag Paneer, chicken Tandoori, Gosht Bhuna (not sure of spelling?), and the vegetable korma. Usually the naan is served fresh out of the oven and still warm, which is always a plus for me!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Quality to price ratio is very high.  It's a seat yourself, bring your drinks, food, and plates to your table kind of restaurant, and yet that is what makes it so charming.  The food we had was as good as others I have had and the atmosphere was very homely and inviting.  We were able to hang out for quite a while and it was pleasant.  The dishes we tried were the Chicken Tikka Masala, Tandoori Chicken Breast, and Aloo Palak with sides of tandoori rice (for two) and three naan.  Three of us had plenty to go around, and one of us had a mango lassi which was good.

Definitely would go back.  Parking is a bit rough around here - took about 15 minutes of circling to find someone leaving - so you may want to just park 0.8 miles away just as you come off the 101N, since there were some spots over there.
author: Bryan M.

description:
YumYum time. I just can't get over how silly I am for having lived across the street for months and only visiting for the primera vez yesterday.

Daal Chana lentil concoction - good
Some kind of curried eggplant thing - GREAT
Chicken curry - delicious

Garlic naan and raita are always a win.

I really, really liked this place.
author: C P.

description:
BEST Indian food I've had in North America. (that was a period at the end).

How do I know?  Because I have eaten at every Indian restaurant in the continent.. that's not true (sorry) -but I am Indian (British Indian but we both like cricket).

Speaking of which, here's a tip for first timers and large groups.  Get $15 from everyone at your table and make a mass family style order of roughly 3 dishes per 4 people along with starters, rice, naan etc.  Then take the rest of the money (there will definitely be a good amount left over if you're 8 or more people) and go opposite the street (obeying California law on jaywalking of course) and pick up some drinks from the liquor store.  Head back, put the money left over in the middle so people can get more dishes, sit back and relax.  Good job chap!
author: Amit V.

description: This place has an amazing atmosphere.  Had a large group dinner with about 8 people for two hours. The BYOB policy is great, we brought cheap Safeway wine and beers.  The food was pretty good too, I tried the lamb biryani.  It wasn't very spicy but it was very flavorful, the lamb was a little on the dry side but good, especially for the price.  I also tried my friend's Chicken Tikka Masala, the sauce was excellent but the chicken tasted a little strange.
author: Tim O.

description:
You don't come here for the atmosphere. Just good Indian/Afghan food!

The restaurant is delightfully simple. You order at the register and take a number to your table. Water is self-serve carafes from a fridge. Very little in decor, but the food is excellent and very affordable.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
