My earliest memories of Pakwan was seeing a mouse scurrying across the floor...

The interior has since undergone a re-design (and now looks pretty clean).

The food has been pretty decent, generally freshly-made and tasty, though oily. (I discovered that sticking to the specials of the day, a tandoori and naan and avoiding the lassis, reduces the possibility of one of those excruciating, after-dinner, all-night experiences on the toilet). 

The kitchen staff looked clean and seemed to handle food properly. With the exception of someone who looked like the delivery guy hanging around the kitchen, looking stoned and scratching his rear.
author: T S.

description:
WHOA! 233 reviews. Good job Pakwan, you are popular. Congrats.

Well congrats on the food too! Cheap and delish. And I am not a fan of Indian types... of cuisine.

Quick eats kind of place and a nice surprise. 

The white yogurt (riana, i believe) and naan, mmm. A couple of my friends thought the food was too spicy? but I thought it was as spicy as like a watermelon.
author: Angel S.

description:
Yep. It's that good.

The only time I had a better "OMG, I can't believe I overstuffed myself that badly, but I had to because it's just so divine"-bloated-belly was after eating myself through Malaysia for 9 days without a bowel movement.

Eat everything you can of the menu and just deal with the gas, it's worth it. And prices are so cheap that you'll still pay less than anywhere else on that street.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
I love Pakwan. It's tasty, fairly consistent, cheap. Their chicken tika masala is delish, and their tandori fish, while on the small side, is always a nice choice when you're not terribly hungry but need something somewhat healthy and tasty. They do have a bit of attitude in there, and it's also insanely crowded sometimes, both of which suck. Fun place to go with a group, bring in a couple bottles of wine or some beer and chow down on some great Indian food.
_____

Update 06/08: Food safety scored recently published show Pakwan has a nice array of violations on their record and a food score of 62 (not good folks), including the high risk "Food Contact surfaces not clean/sanitized" and "Improper Cooling Methods." Now I'm not saying I'll never eat there again, but it does cool my love affair with this Mission cheap eats staple some.
author: margot b.

description: One of the best places in the mission. The masala is amazing, the nan is about as fresh as you can ever get.
author: Josh B.

description:
Comfort Indian food.  It's not crammed with spices, so I feel that I could actually eat it more than once per week without feeling saturated.

I had their version of butter chicken, and their chicken rice.  (I can't remember the authentic indian names).  The masala chai tea was also good.
author: Niniane W.

description: We came on Saturday night and were able to be seated right away. Food was fantastic - one of the best Indian food experiences I have had. The crowd was diverse & lively {goes without saying though, right?} and it was a beautiful cool night to sit by the open window! We will DEF be back!! The funny thing is: the only thing we found incredibly annoying was the method of announcing orders that are ready - a super loud chime that goes off like every 5 seconds and then a super quiet voice saying which order is ready. They should just have a person announcing - it'd be louder than the recording! And again I say -that chime was irritating lol.
author: Shawday B.

description:
Great food, mostly prepared when you order. Yummy mango lassi and everything else! Great value too!!!
It's CASH only, and they don't have a liquor license BUT you can bring your own little brown paper bag ;-)
author: M C.

description: My sister shook her head in disappointment when I asked her about Pakwan's food. She is however a spoiled San Franciscan not to mention her and I have had eaten amazing Indian food all of our lives. In case it matters to you, we are both Indian, have eaten Indian food all of our lives, and have been to India several times, also our mom is a food scientist. Against my sisters advice I went and tried this restaurant. Easily the very worst Indian food I have ever tried in California. Such oily greasy crap slapped together. Gross!!! I am sure this place can please those who are looking for greasy, creamy meat dishes but if you want real Indian food look elsewhere. I had the mixed vegetable curry and the channa masala, both way off and gross.
author: Neil W.

description:
I had the Chicken Korma and Naan. The naan was great but the korma sauce was a bit weak I thought. Kind of a disappointment compared to places like Chaat Cafe in SOMA.

But what was really weird was that it's self-service. Which is a bit odd since there's a station near the front set up with utensils and glasses and water pitchers as if a waiter would be serving you. But you order at the counter and get a number plaque, except instead of someone delivering your plate, you have to go back to the counter and return the number plaque to get your plate. 

I guess it keeps the costs down but the place looks like it was designed for a full-service restaurant but they made it into counter service.
author: Lucius K.

description: I ate at Pakwan several times and ordered takeout, too. Food is always great and prices are really fair - a great value for money place. It's self service though, and the interior is nothing special. So if you're looking for a nice dinner atmosphere this is not the right place. If you're looking for delicious Indian food for small money this is ideal! Cash only!
author: Sebastian S.

description:
Pakwan is sooo tasty!  Really affordable too.  It's cash only so be prepared.  Whether it's dinner with friends, with my bf, or visitors from out of town, I've never had a complaint about the food or service.

They also cater, and I fed a party of 15 for $200 having ordered the day before the event!
author: Andrea S.

description:
I don't get it.  How this place has averaged 4 stars with over 300 reviews is beyond my comprehension!  Are you kidding me?!!!

I can't believe I'm writing a one star review, I never thought this day would come!  Thanks Pakwan for breaking me out of my shell.  

There is absolutely nothing redeeming about this place, nothing.  With the 5,000 other cheap and great Indian eateries in SF, I really don't understand why anyone would support this venue.

Why I would never go back:
- crappy service.  Even with a please and thank you, the guy at the register didn't crack a 1/4 smile
- they charge $1.00 for chai!  That's illegal!  No one charges for chai at a fast food type Indian restaurant.  They need to pass go, not collect $200 and go straight to jail!
- they were behind replenishing the water jugs and there was no one around to get us one so we ended up having to buy water bottles.  Not cool to deprive customers of free water!
- the food is "so so".
- there was a GIGANTIC crack in the glass window next to us.  With the rain pouring outside and people's umbrellas constantly brushing against it, I sure felt safe.
- the ambiance SUCKS!  You have to SHOUT to have a conversation.  Loud music on top of the cramped noisiness makes it an utterly miserable dining experience

My recommendation:
Shift your craving to Chinese instead and grab a peaceful meal at the Big Lantern next door, soo much better!
author: Swetha G.

description: Good Indian food doesn't come cheap.  That's just a fact.  This place's specializes in straddling that border between a cheap price and good food, so don't expect a culinary masterpiece every time you go in.  I tried the Palak Paneer, with Naan and a mango lassi for ~$13 is a very good price.  The dish was decent.
author: Raman S.

description: Solid choice if your in the mood for fast/casual Indian/Pakistani food.
author: Honeya O.

description:
There are lots of good Indian/Pakistani restaurants in town but when the mood strikes and "ambiance" isn't an issue my friends and I can always agree on Pakwan. Nothing is ever extraordinary but I have never left disappointed, besides there is something to be said for "Bring your own" establishments.

Celebrity sighting - Last time I was through, Parker Posey stopped off for a Mango Lassi
author: Mingus R.

description: AMAZING! I eat here so often, they know me. The chicken tiki masala seemed to have been altered recently. It changed from amazing to OMFG. And it is just as good the next day. The aloo nan is perfect with anything. And the prices are GREAT. This is one of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Beatriz A.

description:
My brother turned me on to this place, and I've been coming back ever since.

The food is good and cheap.  That's really why you came in the first place, right?

But there's oh so much more.  The best is the old guy who sits on a stool and watches the customers.  He kind of stirs the pot every once in a while, literally, but I think he's more of a calming presence than an actual worker.  (Maybe he owns the place?)  Then there's the guy who takes your order.  He used to have this weird habit of never ever ever looking you in the eye.  So he would literally be looking down when you walked up, and as you ordered, he would look in every conceivable direction except directly at you.  I'm serious.  He doesn't do this anymore, but I wish he did.  It was cool.
author: John S.

description:
I absolutely love Pakwan. I go here at least once a week and am never disappointed. Their menu has a lot of interesting and tasty choices, the latter of which i have yet to try, mostly because I'm so in love with the few things i have tried (chicken tikka masala, samosas, seekh kabob, chicken byriani, mango lassi, garlic and kheema naan, chicken cholay). 

I definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants to try some real good Indian and Pakistani style food. 

My main plus about this place: They use all chicken breast. I personally hate going into a place like Naan n Curry and getting dark meat with bones.... also the fact that you can bring in your own beverages...

My main gripe about the place: aside from knowing what you are ordering, they punch all the numbers into the register without actually saying anything and just give you a total, so I'm never 100% certain they are charging right, but who cares, its so damn good. Sometimes the workers there can be a little self-centered.

Minus 1 star for the last time i went it, the guy at the register was talking to some other guy in another language. The guy wasnt even ordering anything, and we must've stood there at least 5 minutes before he decided to break off his conversation and even acknowledge us.
author: Ruben S.

description:
5 stars for taste and price. It is pretty scummy inside. You don't want to use their bathroom ... or sit near it.

Best naan I've had. We never order rice, because the naan is so good. Garlic is the best. Onion is my 2nd favorite.

2 people can eat for less than $20, and you can bring your own booze which also makes dinner cheaper. You do need cash, but you can use the ATM at the C-store across the street.

We've been coming here for years and literally love everything we've had, so I'm not going to recap with descriptions but some of our regular orders are saag paneer, tandoori chicken (be sure to grab the green and red sauces); chana masala; chicken tikka masala.

Lots of vegetarian items for your picky friends.
author: Ana D.

description:
This place has seriously good Indian/Pakistani food. Somehow their chicken tikka masala is better than Shalimar, I've enjoyed every dish I've ordered there and they have samosas, which is a big plus. I still prefer Shalimar but go to Pakwan when I don't want to go to the TL.

You have to get your own plates, silverware, etc., but that's fine by me. The take out is a good option when it's crowded during peak hours and survives the trip nicely.

Tip: BYOB
author: Kristina A.

description: Cheap, fast, salty, heavy, dirty, crowded. I take myself out to dinner here sometimes. Me and a book, naan and chicken saag. Works for me.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Do you LOVE fighting tooth and nail for a table? How about paying just $10 for dinner, and bringing your OWN booze for FREE!? Well, if you're into Naan 'N Curry, the you'll be into Pakwan. It's the same deal, just a different name.

I liked the tikka chicken masala and beef shiskabob. Yum.

Not ideal for a large group on Saturday night. No reservations.
author: Misha F.

description:
First of all, the naan and the chicken tikka masala are both pretty good, and the chicken korma is alright too. I know that some of you consider the food to be the most important part of a restaurant review so we'll just get that out of the way.

I want you to know, however, that evidently Pakwan does not have a service entrance in the back.

It doesn't matter 90% of the time, but it may matter a lot if it's dinner time and they're receiving an order of skinned gutted lamb carcasses from the butcher and marching them through the front door and through the middle of the restaurant and right past the table where you're eating. 

Depending on how you feel about meat and sheep in particular, this might be kind of odd and a little unsanitary, or a bit of bizarre gruesome theater, or something thoroughly disturbing. My reaction was the first of these; Another member of our party was much more upset.

But if you like lamb it's probably pretty fresh on saturday evenings around 7:30.
author: matthew r.

description:
Why have I spent the last three years of my life thinking that Pakwan was greasy and gross?

It it NOT either of those things.  Quite on the contrary, it is DELICIOUS.

Despite having lived within a few blocks of this place for 2/3 of the time I've been in the City, I never went in, I guess on some imaginary bad tip.  But now it's definitely at the top of the list for close/cheap/easy Indian food.

Love the self-service plates and water and chutney.  Portions are big, the chicken tikka masala and saag paneer were decidedly NOT greasy, and the naan was hot and fresh.  The bf and I can satisfactorily stuff ourselves for less than $20.

YUM PAKWAN.
author: Megan D.

description:
I would not have came here if I had read Shatangi O.'s review with the link to the health department. That is one of the lowest scores I have ever seen. After reading the inspection I am sure I will die of somthing scary real soon.

So anyway, the food was still real good. The silverware could have done with being cleaned.
author: Brendan R.

description:
the place is clean,very nice people ,food is good  and cheap too.They don't sell alcohol..i always bring my own wine(everyone does).

I love this place!
author: Myo O.

description:
Loved the cardamom in the vegetable biryani. I'll go further and say it is the best biryani I've had. Light, fluffy, fragrant. I'll be returning soon, although now that I've read the cautionary reviews with regard to the restaurant's health code score I will be spending my couple minutes in line surveying not the menu for the next culinary delight but  the kitchen counter, sink, and floors for a reason to flee. And then I'll spend a couple additional minutes at my table scrutinizing the silverware and removing hardened pieces of food residue that mingled time and time again with a previous patron's tooth decay.

Service is quick and the food is cheap...unless you bring your grandmother here. Your $4.00 dinner will turn into a $25,000 hip replacement when she slips and falls on the strangely slick floor. I slid out the door and my friend slid after me. We both managed to land on our feet on the pavement outside in the fashion of a breathtakingly beautiful, orchestrated dance.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Pack it up, pack it in, let me begin. I like Indian and Pakistani food and for me that ain't no sin!
Pakwan is solid.  Solid like that shit I just kicked it for y'all old skool style.  My only reason for taking off one star?  No Aloo Gobi.  I GOTS to have my aloo gobi!  They add that to the menu and it's 5 star city fo' sheezy.
I had the Lamb Biryani, the Chicken Korma, the Naan and the Raita.  Yummy!  I will say that I think their ice cubes in the soda machine may have a wee bit of chlorine in them but fuck it...it's probably one of the more healthy chemicals I've put in my body lately.
author: Jill D.

description:
Solid 3 stars, maybe 3.5 since it is SO wonderfully affordable and the people are so friendly.  The dishes were full of wonderful flavors and fragrant spices, but I can't rave over the general quality of the food.  My sister and I ordered two chicken dishes--chicken achar and chicken biryani, and the chicken in both dishes was incredibly dry and almost not worth eating.  (Thankfully there was a lot of yummy sauce to compensate for the dryness of the chicken....)

Get everything yourself--water, utensils, food--I'm glad I read some reviews before I came so I wasn't standing around like a total noob wondering where everything was!  We came around 8 PM on a Tuesday night and the place was full, but we didn't have to wait in a long line.

Also just a note--the doorknob to the back leading to the bathroom is locked, but just pull the door and it will open.  Sadly, the locked doorknob was enough to deter me from trying any other way from opening the door.  *slightly embarrassed*

If I'm in the area, I would gladly come here again, but I'll probably just stick to all vegetarian dishes.
author: Eileen H.

description:
Time/Date: Tuesday night around 7 o'clock.

Type/Quality: The Pakistani/ Indian food at Pakwan is served OPSE (order, pay, seat, eat), but the menu is small and well prepared; rich flavors, creamy curries, and light fluffy nan.  T-a-s-t-y. BYOB * I suggest Anchorsteam beer from the liquor store across the street ; $9.

Price/Quanity :For $20 you can get two meat dishes, nan or rice, and  2 samosas; feeds two well. *all the water and milk tea you can drink free *add lemon juice to the milk tea for milk tea jello.

Service/Accesibility: There is take out and indoor seating. The line can go out the door but it goes quickly; seat yourself and they will bring the food to your table. The venue has tough parking, but if you circle a few times and know the basic rules of parking you will be fine; otherwise walk from bart, 15 min. 

Structure/Ambience: The place is insulated from the cold sf weather. Its has a clean but  hole in the wall/local alternative feel. Its filled with diverse people but not overcrowded. My favorite "people" sighting from the night was the "Biking against oil wars" girl who was wearing a "Fashionista for child labor" outfit. There is backround music and noise but you can still have a conversation without yelling.
author: Justin L.

description:
Let me say I LOVE Indian food. I complain to my husband for the lack of one in our neighborhood.

This is usually my go to place, but two things have made me unhappy. 

1) my friend Michael finding a rubber band in his food. Granted his dish was vegetarian &  the rubber band isn't any form of meat, but come on!!

& 

2) When they recently redid the place [which looks great BTW] they decided to start charging a dollar for their tea!! Seriously? The tea was a nice thing you did to make up for the greasiness of the food; now you're charging money? I used to use it to wash down the oil. Now I let the tears falling from my eyes catch in my mouth.
author: Rebekah K.

description:
Tasty Indian food at a reasonable price!  Seven or eight bucks for an entree, plus a buck for warm, fluffy nan, and you've got dinner!

I've been searching for a go-to Indian place since I moved into the city, and places are either overpriced (I paid about twice as much at Maharaja) or not very good (think Naan-N-Curry).  Finally I found a good place, and it's only a few blocks away!

My only suggestion is to not try dining in at peak times.  When we went, there weren't any tables available, so we took it to go and ate it at home.  This might not be an option for everyone, though.
author: Mike G.

description: Everything here is solid and cheap (we are talking under $10)!  The lentils, chicken tikka masala, and saag paneer were all hits!  The place was hopping, especially because it's BYOB!  I'm sure the liquor store across the street loves this place.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Fills a niche in my heart! When I'm in town Pakwan usually happens. My favorite dishes... Sag Paneer, Baigan Bharta, Chicken Tikki Masala, their naan and basmati rice is good.

Run across the street to buy a beer or bottle of wine after you order your food. Grab a table and your food will be out before you know it!

Quick, cheap, convenient, and pretty much the same every time! I like the new paint job. Now it almost resembles a restaurant in a way. :) Pakwan is a special place that I had to move away from before I really appreciated. I love it!
author: Audra K.

description:
I really started to appreciate and enjoy Indian food while I lived in Berkeley. There were so many places serving up delicious Indian dishes. After moving to the city, I knew I'd still be surrounded by great places to eat but I'd have to find new favorites. 

I've been to Pakwan several times already and while I love to try the new, I always end up with my regular (and everyone's favorite) Chicken Tikka Masala. Bright orange curry made with coconut milk, it has a lot of spice to it but not spicy, which I love. I'll also order another spinach or other veggie dish too to share. I really enjoy their veggie dishes because they all go well with the tikka masala with potato/regular naan and rice. BTW, Pakwan's naan is my favorite! Though the naan is smaller than a lot of places, it's the softest that I've had and I love the fluffy goodness. The perfect naan for curry.

Notes: 
1. If you ever order the Tandoori Chicken, just be prepared to wait a little longer than when you order other dishes. 
2. I was not a fan of their Mango Lassi. Way too thick and it tasted more powdery than mango-y..
3. I guess I've been spoiled in Berkeley but the chai tea here is not free. I know it's only $1 but free is way better!
author: Julia T.

description:
We love Indian food, so we gave this place a try based on the reviews.  It wasn't bad, far from it, but Naan n Curry is just a bit better.  I'd eat here again though, if I was in the area.

Very hole-in-the-wall.  You know the drill, get your own pitcher of water, utensils, and napkins.  Try to scope out a table while your friend orders because it can get pretty crowded.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I was inspired to write this review after eating some of the nastiest Indian food I have ever had last night. Flavorless, oily and texturally repulsive. Enough about that...
Pakwan was recommended to me by my upstairs neighbor who is a chef from India. so basically, a great source. It is now the ONLY place I will go to get my Indian food fix. I always get the Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Paneer and Garlic Naan. All are extremely flavorful with just the right amount of spice. I like some spice, but not so much that my taste buds are dulled by burning heat. You can really tell that they start with fresh, not frozen ingredients. 

I would recommend that you get the food to go, and eat in the privacy of your own home, as the ambiance is nothing to speak of.
author: Liz R.

description:
With so many reviews for you to go through, I'll be quick.

Cheap. Delicious. Chicken Makhanwalla (Butter Chicken). Naan. BYOB. Cash. Self-Serve. Multiple Orgasms. 

The end.
author: Niraj P.

description:
Maybe I had "tourist" written on my forehead.

Or it was Frugal Friday.

Or they just didn't like my predilection of upper body cotton garments... you know how offensive those plain white fruit-of-the-looms can be.

Whatever the case, they gave me and my partner a tiny ass portion of food with all the fat trimmings to satisfy a border collie.  All served with an inverted smile.

Wouldn't even go back with my dog...and he's a border collie.
author: Pete M.

description:
One of my favorite places for cheap, yummy grub in this food-filled city.

So, yeah it ain't all that clean.  And yeah, the service isn't the perkiest.  And, yeah you gotta be your own table service (picking up your food, plateware, silverware & drinks).  But who the eff cares????  The eats are cheap, the service is lightening fast, and the food will satiate any hungry palate.

The Chicken Tikka Masala is off the hook delicious.  I also dig the Veggie Pakora, and the Naan.  But you pretty much can't go wrong with whatever you order.  

And I love that you can bring your own booze.  I used to come here a lot with an ex, and we'd always pick up a nice framboise at the liquor store (conveniently located across the street!).

This might be the only place in the city where you can order a couple of appetizers, and two or three entrees for around twenty smackers.  And you'll have leftovers for work the next day.  Money well spent!
author: Christopher S.

description:
UPDATE: August 2007
Well looky-here, Pakwan's gone all makeover on us. It is now pretty much clean and has a snazzy new paint job inside (though you can still barely see out the windows). Rumor has it the restroom has gone through rehab, though I have never dared go in there myself.
Best of all, the food is still dang-fabulous. Prices went up about a buck, I guess to pay for the new glassware and dishes and maybe even some hot water to wash them.

ORIGINAL 2006 REVIEW:
Love the Pakwan food.  We eat here up to 1x per week. LOVE the lamb with spinach (saag gosht) in particular, and anything with lentils. The naan is superb in my opinion, although I see that it gets uneven scores with other reviewers. Cheap, cheap prices, too.

As I said, love the food, BUT this place is dirty! You have to select your own plates, utensils, and glasses and it is always a matter of choosing the ones with the least amount of dried food on them. (I thought hot water dishwashing was a health requirement.) Otherwise there would be more stars in my rating. Where are the health inspectors?  Blech. Takeout is probably the better bet, as you won't miss anything about  the atmosphere either.
author: Sandra M.

description:
Romantic ambiance? No. 
Accept your AMEX black card? No. 
Clean bathrooms? Absolutely not. 
Clean silverware? Sometimes. 
Good food? Without a doubt. I just hope you have a strong constitution. 

A hole-in-the-wall that really isn't, Pakwan is surprisingly large, feeling more like a chaotic 3rd-world cafeteria than a restaurant. 

Plus, Pakwan can serve as a good measure to determine if your date is a gold-digger:  If she's so into you she'll get over the less-than-romantic ambiance, you're off to a good start. 

The last time I was here we ordered the chicken dish on special and it was horrible. We told the counterman and he brought us a dish of the excellent chicken tikka masala on the house instead. And then he kept checking on us to make sure we were happy. Damn, why don't I get service like that in restaurants 5x the price?
author: Umami Y.

description:
The first time my man ate here, he loved it so much that we went THREE times in one weekend - no joke! I thought he was going to start carrying around chicken tikka masala in one pocket and garlic naan in the other.  I could just imagine him offering it to people like gum: "Would you like a piece of naan?" 

Tasty and inexpensive, it's always a good meal. One dish I get here which I don't normally order at other places is their tandoori fish. When I took my family, the fish was my mom's favorite. It's one of my faves too.
author: jenn h.

description:
I think this has got to be the best Indian food I've had in my life.

I eat lots of Indian food because I love it to death, but nothing comes close to how good this is. Not even just good, but the best prices around. This place is always packed...but the lines move at an okay pace.

Sometimes people literally loom around full tables to get them other people to leave! But you know what, it's all worth it.
author: Carleen W.

description:
Pakwan generally scores higher in my mind than 3 stars but I have been recently disappointed. 

On the positive side, the lamb dishes excellent. You can't go wrong with either the Bhuna Ghosht or the Achar Ghosht. 

The curry for the Nihari was excellent but the beef left a lot to be desired. This was painful since Pakwan is one of the few places that actually has Nihari on the menu. The naan at Pakwan has never been that great and that proved to be true this time around. 

Still, you get all this for $20. Not a bad deal but the standards seem to be slipping as I believe they have at Shalimar.
author: Abhi S.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't reviewed Pakwan, for the many times I've been there.  I will say, it's definitely not fancy nor expensive but that's what gives it character and charm.  

I walked in with my favorite guy and without a doubt it was packed. Every table, inside and out, was taken but we were willing to stand and eat if we had to.  

A quick peruse of the menu and we defaulted to the old standby.. Garlic Naan, Chicken Biryani, Sag Aloo and Achar Gosht.  extra spicy and super delicious.  

I love that you can park yourself in a chair, swing by the station, pick up a pitcher of water, sauces ( i do like sauces... shall we say I'm saucy?) and start enjoy.  I'm not shy and when I say eating with my hands makes me happy, watch and learn.... 

After a long weekend in wine country, it was nice to be back in the city, enjoying a little ethnic culture and most of all, reliving the wonders of SF food.  I  miss you SF.  Oh and all the characters....
author: Aimee C.

description: We hardcore!  We first enjoyed Pakwan's smoky flavors while nervously sitting behind bars in the heart of the Tenderloin and ravenously gnawing on the tandoori lamb chops.  Then, we hopped over here to this happening area and relaxed, continuing our enjoyment with an upgrade in atmosphere.  Mango Lassi is thick but not too sweet.  That alone, I wish they had a stand near my house for.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
Pakwan makes Naan n' Curry look like the BK lounge.


You know this place rules when:

1. It's an Indian restaurant that Indians actually go to eat.
2. only 2 out of 20 tables are vacant at 6 p.m. on a random monday.
3. You end up leaving smelling like you worked a full night shift slinging Naan
4. You find yourself thinking about every plate later while at work miles away.

I forgot about this place for a while until I had to go to the area to get my car worked on. I used to go all the time when I was semi-foot-loose-and-fancy-free living the life in the mission, trying to be a hipster (and failing) with not much a care in the world. Now with kids, its a little different (beware hipsters..kids extinguish yer hipster status) but will make an effort to go more often. The Tika is the real deal.... a touch spicy for my tastes but thats how its sposed to be silly. The meat is seasoned to perfection with a real-deal smokey flavor that'll keep you coming back for more.. The Naan is fluffy and not doughy like some places....Try this place!!
author: Lindonesia S.

description:
Really, really like this place for the following reasons:

1. Prices are decent / avg. for Indian food (comparing to Naan n Curry and Shalimar)
2. Portions are MUCH larger than the two named above. I swear you only get like 5 pieces of chicken, but at Pakwan it's like double!! How great is that! haha...
3. Pretty decently clean

The food I would say is comparable to Shalimar and Naan n Curry's... taste wise they are all pretty good, but what realllllly gets me here is the portion size. So if you are all about more bang for your buck - come here!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
This place is great! It's super cheap & delicious :) Get there early so you can get a table - it's super packed. 

LOVE the naan - best naan I've had ever - hands down. 

Also - cash only!!!
author: linda t.

description:
Such a great deal!  My girlfriend and I had the saag daal (lentil spinach), tandoori chicken and a piece of garlic naan to share (yes, the naan was big enough to share!)  The saag was great and went perfectly well with the naan.  However, I would skip the tandoori chicken for some other curry dish - many people around us had the chicken tikka masala, and it looked yummdiddlyscrumptious.

We went on a Saturday evening and the place was bumping.  There was a big line of people waiting to order and pay, while right next to them along the wall, other people were grabbing chai tea, sauces, water, forks, napkins - it was chaotic!  Towards the back of the room, it was a little too dim for my liking, so we snagged a nice people-watching window seat.

Overall, great deal for good, fill-me-up food.
author: Mads M.

description: Outstanding! Never tried a dish that I didn't like! Always perfectly spicy and aromatic. Great specials.  Just be sure to guard your purse if you choose to eat outside!
author: Lorraine M.

description:
After hiking half dome, their $6 lamb biruani tasted better than any food I could remember having eaten prior.  In fact, it spoiled me for all the food which was to come afterward, so now I just eat spinach from cans.

Furthermore, in addition to being a big bang for the buck, you can bring your own beer, and the naan and samosas come to you straight out of the oven/fryer/whatever.  I've never had samosas that good by a long shot.
author: Wesley W.

description:
This place is pretty solid, inexpensive Indian fare... I've found the food to be a little inconsistent, sometimes exceptional, sometimes just pretty good. The free all you can drink chai is nice... Good place for a quick, casual dinner in the Mission.

Update 7/1/07: OK, they gussied up the interior here, knocking out a wall and painting the place. It looks nice but the food has taken a turn for the worse. The last two times I've eaten here it has been quite terrible, and actually made me sick. The first time I thought it was maybe a fluke, but after the second time I don't think I will be eating here anytime soon. No more free chai, very bland benghan bharta and paneer tikka masala, and hours of abdominal discomfort = demoted to 1 star. (I thought about keeping it at two stars because it does seem like a drastic demotion, but trust me, it has been THAT BAD).
author: Brian H.

description:
Pakwan is a Hipster hangout where you can hangout for hours, eat cheap Indian food, and bring your own beer.

This place isn't very customer service oriented, but that's okay because you pretty much pick up your food at the counter, grab your own utensils, glasses, water, and napkins. 

Yes, they do wash their utensils, I did a complete surveillance myself just to make sure. . . and yes, if you were wondering I did bring along my trusty spy kit to inspect on this lovely occassion.

I wont mention any names, but my friend is pretty much a regular here, so the people working the counter sort of treat us nicer than if we were just some hobo type hipster walking in from the streets.

We normally order chicken tikka masala, vegetable curry, rice, and $1.00 Naan. The food here is decent for the price and the location

Although, I honestly love Pakwan, I'm not sure if I can come back here again for awhile. I think I have had my fair share of cheap Indian food if you know what I mean. Well if you don't know what I mean, then I guess you will just have to find out for yourself.

Hmmm that reminds me. My friend sent me with the leftovers so maybe I might just send them your way. As I tried to push the leftovers onto her, she made some lame excuse and I ended up with them.
author: Cellina B.

description:
This is by far the best Indian food I have found in this city.  The samosas are quite excellent.  Delievery is a good thing too.  My only complaint is that the pakoras could be less dry.  Bring on the grease!

DO IT!
author: Arthur E.

description:
Things I like:
+Picnics
+Large Containers of Beer
+Spicy Food

And PAKWAN!
It's not supposed to be fancy ("Um, can I get a bottle opener?"  *Silently gestures toward the bottle-opener-magnets stuck on the soda machine* "Ah, niiiice!"), it's not supposed to be.... served to you?  Pick it up your damned self.  And don't forget to grab napkins, silverware, and plates.  Sit in rubbermaid chairs on the 16th street sidewalk, take the 32oz beer out of the bag, and wet your mouth before the homemade spicy goodness comes forth.  Then sop up every last drop with naan.  Booya.
This stuff is good.  And it's cheap.  You provide the volition and the appetite.  
Easily the most simple, solid South Asian food I've had in SF thus far.
author: Eric S.

description:
The only thing that sucks about this place is that it is so close to my house that eating basic indian/pakistani food is no longer a luxury but now a meat and potatoes experience. Believe it or not that is a compliment. Thank god Tartine is 6 blocks away rather than 2 or I'd be dipping my croissants in tikka masala cream.

Oh and I don't know what some are thinking here but they have some of the best naan I have ever had. A wonderful combination of a thin crispy center with fat and moist chewy edges. I never eat in the restaurant since I live so close but it seems social and people are enjoying themselves. Be sure to get the Chicken Nihari when it's on the daily specials board - better than the beef in my opinion.

Update: The last time I ordered the Nihari it was boneless which is a shortcut that makes me sad. When it's slow cooked on the bone it's much better. Let's hope that this isn't a permanent change.
author: Miroslav W.

description: Its the best Indian food Ive ever had and I have tried alot of Indian food restaurants. When I'm in SF I usually make a trip there. There all ways busy! I love the fresh naan, everywhere else i go to get naan its some what greasy. Its so good I get extra to take home for the next day. Its very casual and you serve yourself  but, the food it so good i couldnt complain.
author: Alyssa T.

description:
This restaurant once had five stars from me, and had been a favorite of mine for many, many years.  Sadly, the quality of the food has declined markedly over the past year.  

They have doubled the amount of oil in their dishes.  It was always a little oily, but that's what one expects from a low-priced fast curry place.  But this is ridiculous. The food is swimming in oil now.  you can pour off a good deal of it if you get take out, but that doesn't make it more appetizing.

They use way too much pepper now.  I have developed a higher tolerance than many for spicy Indian food, but there are times lately I can't even eat what I get from Pakwan.  

Finally, the flavors are lacking.  Not just for the above reasons, but the basic flavor is off.  Its as if the old chef has moved on, and a new chef is using the old recipes.  A new chef with half his taste buds burned off from overdosing on cayenne all his life and insisting that everyone else has the same disability., and using less expensive produce.

I hope the owner gets his food back into shape.  I can't go here anymore.
author: Ken R.

description: I guess what is the only thing that is good about this place is that they give big portion and that its fairly cheap comparing it to naan and curry on irving. But I must say this is probably the last time im coming here. Since I really like Chicken tikka at naan and curry better.
author: Aniko N.

description:
This is Pakistani food.

(at least comparing to my two trips to the country)

It's cheap, too. It's actually better than in Pakistan, because you don't have to watch your stomach. I have not had anything I didn't like here, and my favorite are the chicken or lamb rice plates and the more spicy chicken dishes. Any day of the week.
author: Lion K.

description: The eggplant curry and the biryani are definitely recommened.. If you want a really spicy curry, you can try the squash curry =). There is not much waiter service there cause you mostly have to get everything yourself like forks, napkins, water,etc...
author: Gillian T.

description:
Pakwan has steadily gone downhill. All their sauce-based dishes are overly salty and spiced, tasting like they could have come from one of the instant-Indian packages at the grocery store. Worse, their automated system that calls out numbers when your order is ready sounds exactly like an announcement at the airport: intrusive, mechanical, and in a restaurant setting totally obnoxious. 

In short, I'm happy to eat here if: I'm ordering tandoori chicken, and I can sit at one of the two outside tables.
author: Charlie Bolognese Z.

description:
"How to make a non-fan out of a Pakistani patron."

This should be the motto of the Mission's incarnation of Pakwan.

When I saw the sign for Pakwan go up on 16th St. what seems like an eon and a half ago, I was more than stoked. A Pakistani joint just 3 blocks away from my apartment? What could be better? I made myself known to the owners the very day it opened. Back then, no one else really knew it existed, for everyone was still enthralled with Indian Oven (conjurers of my ire). 

The Pakwan owners, two men in their 40s, were really nice and always gave me great service whenever I went in there. Back in those times, it would still be fairly empty so I was able to eat and have a conversation with them for much of the time. Impressed with the place, I went on a mission to de-Indian Oven-ize my non-Pakistani work colleagues and roommates. They were all hooked at first bite,  and eventually word got out about the prices of this little Mission eaterie and Pakwan became the place to eat at.

The food was always decent, although their paltry portions of chicken in either their chicken boti or chicken tikka masala/makhanwala never escaped my attention. Drowning 3 cuboids of chicken in radioactive orange sauce may fool some people, but not me. But over the years I've had every single item on the menu and for the most part, they've all atleast tasted pretty good.

However, the owners soon moved on in order to open more Pakwans elsewhere, leaving a younger guy at the register in his place. Royal jackass, this new guy was. Friendly to white people, and an asshole to his own. Yeah, it doesn't work that way, buddy. 

Being a big stickler for service, I started taking my business elsewhere. Sure, I was missing great naan just down the street from where I lived, but I'm not going to have a rude punk treat me like shit just for walking up to the counter. 

It's too bad. The Pakwan owners definitely won the game in bringing Pakistani to the Mission and creating an ambiance which matches what the crowd is looking for, something the nice guys who own Al-Hamra (and then Taj Mahal which closed up shop soon after it opened) are still struggling with. Maybe Fawaz or whatever his name is isn't working there anymore. Then perhaps I'd head on back.

As for the sanitary thing, Pakistani restaurants and sanitation are not synonymous (atleast in San Francisco) which is still ok, apart from my friends spotting a rat scurrying past their table one time. Luckily I wasn't witness to that. Ignorance is bliss, I guess?
author: Mr K.

description:
One of my favorite places for many years. Great selection and affordable. I have liked everything I've tried. The seekh kabob is great, the chicken tikka masala also. Garlic and Keema naan are also delicious.

The only negative I can say at all is parking nearby is very difficult most of the week, so leave an extra few minutes to park a couple blocks away.
author: Eric B.

description:
Love this hole-in-the-wall place.  It's cheap, it's pretty authentic Indian-Pakistani food, no frills place where you can get some cheap eats that are filling, deliciously satisfying, and won't break the bank.  Don't expect service here, that's not what it's about.  

And for under $10/person I wouldn't expect it either.  I rate most Indian food in comparison to my mum's (not really fair, I know, but that's my yardstick!) and this comes in close to my best friend's mother from back home.  So it's pretty damn good.  Won't ever find a place that does anything as good as my mum or grandmum but this is a fair substitute.  

I know my Indian food and the city lacks really good stuff so I'm lucky enough to live around the corner from the one place I will recommend over most anywhere else.  The only other place I would recommend is Vik's over in Berkeley. Dosa is a good vegetarian south-Indian alternative (pretentious and over-priced for what is really "street" food) but hands down, if you want real Indian food with no BS, this is the place to go.

Not particularly friendly which can be annoying but it's not about the 'experience' anyway. Get it to go so you can avoid the possibly not-so-clean cutlery and non-ambiance and enjoy it at home.
author: Saloni D.

description:
I can't be sure how good the food was because my companions and I were at that "tipsy enough to eat anything put in front of us" stage. But I remember thinking it was served quickly and cheaply. At the time, that was our primary interest. I wasn't really interested in a fine dining experience, I just needed something in my belly to soak up the alcohol. WHY does Indian food taste go SO WELL with drinking?

I don't think this will be my number one choice for Indian food in SF, but if I need to get my food on quick, I'd definitely come back.
author: Pumpkin K.

description:
I know I had to do it, I had done it for Shali, and pissed on N-N-C, Pakwan's time was coming, but just wasnt sure what I was gonna say.

So here's the deal, this place is good-enough that we use it as verb. Lets pakwan it daw (g is silent),or lets pak (pronounched as puck) it daw (g is silent). 

I usually stay away from standard shiet, that everyone, I mean everyone except me orders there, of course I'm talking about CTM. Sorry just never been a fan. Other than that Chicken Korma, and Mixed vegetable is safe bet.

Hesus knows its true, how many times I've sneaked in for quick meals before heading out to "intimate dinner parties". I know I'm sorry, but I ate plenty of shitty food at college dining hall, and fuck you, aint gonna repeat it no more (sorry for double negative), but you get the point.

What I really go there for is their daily specials, if you go there back to back, sometimes their daily specials becomes biweekly specials, boo. But they usually update dishes frequently.

Here is an incomprehensive list of items you have to sample -
Chicken curry in mint and cilantro sauce. (mad tasty and unique)
Chicken Nihari (original dish uses lamb or beef, but damn tasty), I order at the table and make one to go.
Aloo keema [minced meat (chicken or lamb depends on the day) with potatoes.].
Chicken Haleem (another dish originally done with red meats, but adapted to Chicken here, cooked with beans and barley and other grains for a longtime) fuckin great.

Btw when you get there (unless you are solo), get someone to scout for a seat, while you wait in line, makes life easier.
Don't forget to clean your plates, glasses, and knives'n'forks, before you use them, because you can't trust their dishwashers, or manual dish washing skillz, sorry that puts me off everytime. I mean for fucks sake just clean them up good the first time.

And I really dont get it when non-indian folks start dissecting the quality of naan. Not too fluffy, just enough crisp, better naan than other place, WTF, dude, don't get me wrong I got taste buds, just dont waste em on analyzing naans. And no this place is not dumbed down to please american tastebuds, its just good the way it is.

Interesting trivia, did you know that owner of the joint used to run a just as popular italian restaurant at the same location? and after a fire, he decided to ditch italian restaurant concept and started pakwan, people protested, but rest is history.

Anyhoo forgot to mention that bihari kababs (my favorite of the trio of chicken tikka boti, Lamb chops, and tandoori beef chops) are great!

My buddy Nate would eat a feast up here, goto their bathroom come back and eat a plate full of dem behari kabobs. Shit is good. Samosas aint so bad either.

But Aloo Naan and Seekh Kaababs holds no light to Shalimar. Thats just the way it is, and I have learned to live with it, by frequenting both of dem places. Oh totally forgot, chicken/lamb biriyani though overloaded with shiet, is good but the vegggie biriyani is surprisingly tasty too.

Don't butcher the name - say with me Puck-Waan, wasn't so hard no was it folks? good.
 
So there, Pakwan's out of the way too.

EDIT - Just got back from London, UK, and tried all sorts of hole in the wall indian/pakistani joints, Pakwan is still much better.
author: An u.

description:
Pakwan's saag gosht is good!

It's so good that my friend and I agreed it was an excellent idea to order it to-go for a picnic dinner at Dolores Park Movie Night.

It's so good that mere moments after we unpacked it to eat, an adorable black lab eagerly broke free of his owner and ignored the dozens, nay hundreds, of other picnic meals spread out around him to bee line across the park and stick his entire maw into the middle of our dish - yuck!

And it's so good that even after the unruly dog violated our dinner, my friend and I looked at each other with our faces scrunched in part-uncertainty, part-disgust for only a few minutes...before shrugging...and continuing to eat it anyway.

You would have done it too. It's really that good.

I've also heard that a dog's mouth is cleaner than a human's.
author: Stephanie K.

description: BYOB, cheap food, loud casual atmosphere! We got samosas, chicken masala, lentils, and tikka and everything was really good. I will reiterate, you can't beat the atmosphere, food, and price at this place!
author: Brandon R.

description:
Pakwan is DA BOMB!! They just remodeled so it's a little nicer and cleaner now! :)

They have a lot of veggie options and vegan options too. My favs are the chick pea dish, eggplant, and spinach. (sorry I don't remember the names of them). Those are all really good with naan and rice and the reddish sauce from the fridge. 

For a group of 4 or 5 people 3 dishes is plenty plus rice and nan for everyone. Each dish is 4-5 dollars and rice and nan are 1 dollar each. CHEAP FOOD DUDE! AND you can bring in whatever alcohol you want. Wine, Beer, Vodka, WHO CARES!! lol. hahaha.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
I love... LOVE Pakwan.. 

anyone who works/lives in the Mission knows my dilemma...lunch time is torture...you only give yourself an hour to order/eat/clean and get back to work..because time is money...and i'm freakin broke

meaning my ass is staying within .5 mile radius of my building...as far as fast, quick, t(not to mention cheap) take-outs go, mission cannot be beat..

but after awhile, lunch becomes as exciting as my dating life..chinese on monday, burrito on tuesday, hamburger from slowclub on wednesday, thai on thursday, japanese on friday.. repeat, rinse, repeat again...sigh..

try pakwan...can't say for sure that it will be added to my regular weekly lunch roster..but today, it was right on the money.  fast, cheap, but had enough grease and meat to get me through the day..

if they have the lamb shank curry special when you happen to pass through, get one for lunch, dinner, and to stick in the freezer ... *drool*
author: Je C.

description:
My friend and I came here on a lovely Friday afternoon. We chose a nice table outside so that my friend's dog could sit with us while we ate. 

I just have to say that the service here is absolutely stellar!! Why, you ask? Because *I* served myself! I would've even given myself a tip if I'd had enough change.

The food here can rival that of many Indian restaurants that charge three times as much. The prices are really great on top of that. I almost ordered way more than I could eat since the prices were so cheap. I was thinking that small price = small plate, but fortunately that turned out not to be the case.  

The other cool thing about this place is that you can bring in your own liquor and there just happens to be a liquor store conveniently located across the street. Sweet.
author: Victoria D.

description:
yummy in my tummy!! the only place I eat lamb!!! 

Biryani, achar ghost, naan, and beer and Im in heaven!!! 

You are missing out if you havent had this yet!
author: Angie C.

description:
It was like I ordered chicken tiki masala twice.

Ew.
author: Isaac L.

description:
SO YUM!

The menu may seem small, but everything is delicious. I've had everything (literally, everything) that does not contain meat and it is all excellent.

No liquor license, but BYOB and the convenience store across the street sells beer.

My faves are the veg biryani and eggplant pakwan style.

Lassi is slightly on the sweet side.

Open late, take-out is super quick, have not tried delivery yet.

Portions are also fairly generous. 2 entrees plus biryani/bread is more than enough for 3 hungry hippos.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
UPDATE: Over the course of the year, I have developed a serious addiction to the Saag Paneer. It's all that I will order from Pakwan. I crave it at the mere mention of anything Indian-related (I had a fit while watching Ghandi).

I still maintain that this place is kinda grimy, so I'm sticking with 4 stars, but if you're a vegetarian....try the Saag Paneer. Best I have ever had. Anyone seeking an elegant or romantic dining experiece: head to the Indian Oven in the Lower Haight.

_________

Last night I finally had the pleasure of dining at Pakwan, after enduring the ongoing demands of many of my friends who are obsessed with the place. It almost lived up to the hype. I gotta say, it was pretty loud and pretty scuzzy inside and I didn't expect that. The walls and floor (and tables?) seems to have a film on them. Is it the effects of the air pollution or did they forget to clean the place last year? Certainly, this is not a first date spot. But ambiance aside, it's a fantastic eatery.

The food was tasty, especially for the price, and the service was fast. I love the Indian restaurant get-your-own-plates-bitch! style of service. Quick & easy, yet by no means "fast food." There was lots of flavor and a surprising lack of the normally present ghee pools, like I find at my other quickie Indian favorites. I was also pleasantly surprised and pleased by the firmness of the paneer. Best of all, you can bring your own booze, and for that reason alone I will ignore the dirty walls and yucky clouds of meat smoke and return for more scrumptious Pakwan eats.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
We have been going to the various Pakwans since they opened.  Khalid and Shabaaz Bhai are good people.  I love talking to Khalid after Pakistan loses a cricket match to India.  I wish they made the food they make in the Fremont location everywhere.  The veiggie food in Fremont which is tailored more to Indians is pretty good.  Karhi, Bengan Aloo, Daal is a good complement to the awesome dishes on the Non Veg side.  Stay far away from the Mixed Veggies.  BTW, the best food and selection at Pakwan is during Ramadan.  We had them cater for us for our Diwali party this year and the food was super-fantastic.  Well priced, well delivered and well portioned.

Pakwan is in the Top 3 in the Indian Food category in the bay area.
author: A K.

description:
If you're a person who expects to be waited on at all times, receive excellent service, vallet parking and someone to offer you an ass wipe after sitting on the toilet.  Don't go here.  (Yes, I'm referring to you "foo foo shee shee" folks.)  

It's within walking distance from where I work, and the food is satisfying and great for it's price.  The set-up is a little weird, having to get your own utensils, napkins, water and such, and you have to seat yourself (which may be difficult during busy times), but, all of the other pieces are there for a good experience.
author: Dudley F.

description:
Just good food.  Always hits the spot.

Always good spices, always easy and laid back (except for the entertaining hipster drama), and it's perfectly located for that quick and satisfying start to the night.   Or day, if you end up here for "brunch", because too many of those mission brunch places are pretty awful.
author: Shanan A.

description:
I eat at Pakwan all the time, since I live round the corner and none of my 4 roommates ever cook. And we love Indian/Pakistani food. After a long day of work, some curry and naan really hits the spot. I usually get it to go, so I never really have to deal with the crowds etc.

Anyways, Indian food purists will complain about the sweetness of the dishes and chai (dumbed down for American palates) but I like it anyway. I recommend the biryanis, the fish, and the chicken tikka wrap.
author: Ahmed A.

description: Naan & Tandoori chicken is  good. The chai however, lacked in flavor.
author: Geordie E.

description: Hands down, the best Indian & Pakistani food I've ever eaten. The lamb biryani is a must, and the beef nahari is rockin'. The chicken tikka marsala has a little kick to it, but it's really good. I've eaten here six times and never had a bad dish.
author: Matt M.

description: All right, I'm not going to lie to you, Yelpers: I'm a total amateur when it comes to Indian food. This place is literally the second time I had it. The place serves up really tasty nan and the plates aren't too spicy (just how I like it). It's not what I would call a pretty place to dine, but serving up cheap delish dishes; it totally earned 4 stars in my book!
author: Lisa R.

description: Pakwan is CHEAP and EASY. And cheap and easy is good when it comes to indian food.  The guys there are super friendly and they recently repainted the place so it looks less like a dive.  I like the aloo nan and chicken tikka masala - nice combo.   The aloo saag is a bit of a downer -- kinda bland, but the other veggie dishes are great. If you are ordering the tandoori, get more than one order - it is a bit skimpy on the meat.
author: Kamael S.

description:
Not horrible, just bland.

Do Not trust the taste of anyone who tries to tell you that Pakwan is just as good as/better than Shalimar!!


PS The naan was good.  That and the new paint job pushes them from 2 stars to 3 stars.
author: lisa g.

description:
The eggplant and cauliflower curries were fine, but not as good as Chutney's.  Also, I like a doughy naan, not flaky, thin, and burnt.  So the food here was passable.  But later...

The bathroom here was just as terrible as reported.  No, that's not true, it was worse.  It took some real effort to get in and out of there w/out actually having to touch anything.  I understand that you can't really help what gross customers do in there, but could ya clean it up?
author: CAKE E.

description:
You can bring in a bottle of wine, two glasses, a corkscrew and set yourself up right there for a nice little dinner. I do all the time. So much that the friendly guys who work there say "hi Rebecca!"  

Now why would you go to Indian Oven and spend three times as much for the same quality food?  The ambiance, you say? 

Puh-leeze. I've been all over India, and the ambiance at Pakwan is much more authentic.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Let me start by saying that I am of North Indian descent, and therefore, hate Pakistani food.  I tried this place anyway, based on the recommendations of Yelpers and friends.  I tried the chicken tikka masala, chana masala, chicken saag, and naan.  Bland, greasy, creamy, and I'm glad it was cheap.  The food is identical to Naan 'n Curry, though this place seemed to be cleaner.  

Oh and the tea is NOT free.  When I went for a second cup, at about 8:30pm, they were out.  It was well before they closed.  I asked if they would put out more and the cashier dude said 'No. Next time.'  

I just added a star because, my friend who is a Hindu and never eats beef, ordered a Seekh Kabab assuming it was lamb.  When I pointed out her mistake, at least ten minutes after she ordered, she talked to the manager who pulled cash out of the register to give back to her.  Rather than fueling the Hindu/Muslim fire, he said 'koi nai,' meaning, no worries.  Class!  

It's not Indian food.  Please stop calling it that.  Indian food is hard to find in the bay area.
author: Amy D.

description:
They did not put much money into ambience or service at Pakwan. But those savings are passed on to our customers!

So yeah: cheap but tasty. Decent portion sizes. I could see this being a regular hangout for locals.

Bathrooms could use some attention.

BYOB makes this place a clear winner.
author: andy d.

description: Love this place!  Pros are food is great, prices good, and BYOB  stellar!  I love chicken tikka masala with nan, like everybody else ...... go get some!
author: Jae L.

description:
An oasis of tasty, tasty cheap eats on the drunkiest block in the Mission!!!!  While I'm not 100% sure I want to know how they can afford to sell goat curry for $5 a bowl, there is no denying that this is a great spot to hit whether your drunk or not.

Just.... do me this one favor:  Don't order the smelliest thing on the menu, and take it to go so that you can eat it at Elixir across the street.  That place is stuffy as hell and second-hand lamb naan smell is totally unpleasant when out of context.
author: Laura F.

description:
CHEAP, MEAL FOR TWO IS UNDER $20.
NO SERVICE=NO BIG TIP
TASTY
SUPER CASUAL ATMOSPHERE
GOOD SOLO, EVEN BETTER WITH A GROUP OF FRIENDS
BYOB!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
INTERESTING MIX OF HIPSTERS, STUDENTS, BAR HOPPERS, HOMELESS, MISSIOIN INTELIGENCIA, FREAKS, ETC.

DOWNSIDE IT'S  A BIT DINGY

I love this place!!  Whenever a friend wants to grab a bite and hang in the Mission for a few drinks Pakwan is always on the top of my cheap eats suggestion list. 

DO IT RIGHT BY RUNNING ACROSS THE STREET TO THE LIQUOR STORE GRABBING A BOTTLE OF BEER/WINE AND DOING THE BYOB THING!

Favorites dishes include:  garlic nan, chicken masala, chicken tika, chicken venadlou.

* Oh, be forewarned that eating at Pakwan before going out on the town looking for love is not likely to land you much attention.  After all, who in their right mind wants swap spit with someone who smells like garlic nan and chicken masala??!
author: Christopher Y.

description:
I rarely go for Indian cuisine, but this restaurant is a good choice. Thanks to Sav B. for letting me on to the place and hooking us up.

Yelp says it's open only till 11. Is that accurate? I could have sworn we were in there much later.

Cheap eats, tasty for the price, and good sharing portions. Ambiance is loud, busy (at least during weekend evenings), brightly lit, and bare in decor. Great dinner for casual groups. The meat dishes came out a bit dry, hard, and overcooked, except for the chicken tiki. Now I see why Sav so heartily recommended the tiki. It was the best dish out of all the ones we ordered. The different kinds of naan were all savory in their own right too. The mango lassi is also recommendable - thick, delicious and well mixed.

After dinner don't forget to grab a spoonful of seeds from the bowl at the cashier counter. Anise, is it? Like some organic after dinner mint. Sav was munching on the stuff by the handful. Me... ick.
author: Clar L.

description:
NEW DECOR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!WOW. what an improvement. amazing... clean, colorful and good.

on the food, it's good, not amazing, but very quick, and in the neighborhood there is no better place for Indian/Pakistani food. i love the naan - the dishes are a good size and fresh...

good for a bite before going out, or take-out to bring home.
author: Erika Y.

description: great.  BYOB, street seating, dirt cheap prices, big tables, whatever.  a great place to go between bars.
author: Spencer W.

description: Good, but I tend to favor Chutney and Shalimar, which are both a half a block away.
author: Paul O.

description:
AWESOME FOOD and CHEAP!!! We had lamb saag, cheese saag, 3 kinds of naan bread, rice, chicken masala, two glasses of mango lassi, and chai tea.. it was all for only $37! Pretty good deal. The only things I didn't like from this place and reaped a star or two away are: 

1) I couldn't find parking for almost half an hour 
2)The utensils were dirty, so we had to clean them again before we used them, and 
3)It was almost fast food style where we order, sit down, and waited to be called for our food, BUT the person behind the counter expected tips from us. I mean... come on!! I know your place has good food and popular and all, but you can't neglect the CLEANLINESS of your place! 

So, maybe next time, I will return and get some take-out.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I would pick Pakwan over the snooties at Naan 'n Curry any day.

Snooty in question: the NNC on Irving Street. I love that part of town so I frequent the restaurant a lot, but mostly to get a piece of naan as a snack to go. For some reason, I always get the same bald guy to take my order. And every time I say, "A naan to go, please." He gives me this annoyed look and says, "That's it?" Hey, a dollar bill is still a dollar bill no matter how much food I order. Pa-leez. 

Anyway, as to Pakwan, the food is excellent. Today I had the chicken markhalwan (something like that) with naan. The curry is creamy, the flavor of the spices fabulous, and the chicken chunks huge and soft (not tiny ones like the other aforementioned establishment). Man I love to dip my naan in the curry-one of the best meals ever.

And yes, the free masala tea is nice and I love those fragrant seeds at the counter you can chew on. If you're looking for cheap, fast, and filling Indian-Pakistani food, Pakwan's the place.
author: Linda L.

description:
The vast majority of my visits here have been very satisfying. They do suffer from a slight case of inconsistency, and I have witnessed a misstep or two here and there (over a period of many years as frequent customers) but I can highly recommend their saag daal and aloo palak. I'm mostly a veggie girl, but my husband (a Pakistani, so I encourage you to take his opinion even more seriously than mine) almost always gets the chicken tikka. The chai is excellent, the prices are quite low, and they've recently renovated the place, so it creates, if not more space, at least the illusion of it. 

Why 4 out of 5, you ask? One of the missteps mentioned above was bad enough that, had it been my first visit, I'd not have returned. Also, their samosas have decreased in size over the years.
author: Amy K.

description:
i'm a big fan of Naan and Curry - i'm a frequent customer despite the constellation of bright yellow curry spots that end up on my shirt, and the layer of curry cologne that you cannot avoid.

Wifey and i got take out from Pakwan after watching a flick at the Roxie.  we waited for about 15 minutes - the place drew a nice crowd for a Monday nite.  we only spotted one cockroach (small) crawling up a column near the counter.  the rest of the cockroaches were probably paralyzed by the curry fumigation.

Wifey had the chicken in spinach sauce, and i had the lamb curry.  we each picked up a naan stuffed with beef.   i really enjoyed the sauces in both dishes.  even after 24 hours they retained their flavor.  of course, at a place like this, the sauces are so oily and full of spices that styrofoam would probably taste good in it.  luckily for Pakwan the sauces are so thick that dead cockroaches of the small variety could float around in there without being identified.

anyways, i enjoyed it.  go there.
author: Jimmy F.

description:
The chicken tikka masala here turned a veggie friend over to the dark side.  The saag paneer is also very good.

The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is the loudspeaker for the orders.
author: Shannon W.

description:
First...its BYOB...that means "Bring Your Own Beer" for you non-acronymic  folk. Second bring CASH...thats not an acronym...this place doesn't except anything other than old white dudes printed on funny green paper. 
The menu is filled with fantastic little morsels that guarantee to excite even the most finicky of pallets. Try the the Bengan Bhartha, a delicious cream based eggplant dish perfectly spiced...a perfect compliment for any meat on the menu. The Nan is light and soft, the rice plates are exciting and flavorful. The place can be very crowded, but thats whats fun about it...its a party for foodies. If you're craving a gastronomic journey through some authentic Indian/Pakistani flavors...Pakwan will not dissapoint.
author: Diego C.

description:
1. Walking distance to public transit (BART)
2. Bring Your Own Beverages
3. Cheap ($10-12PP)
4. Tasty

Restaurants like this are the reason I live in SF.  The food is excellent, and so well priced.  Pakwan is on my weekly rotation.  

It's not hard to find good food in SF, it is a bit more of a challenge to find good, cheap eats--and for that:  5 stars.
author: Scott H.

description:
A good place for cheap, spicy food.  In fact, if you want not-bland food, this is the perfect price range, b/c the more a place charges, the more offended people are if their meal ends up being too spicy for their delicate tastebuds.  I usually end up ordering more than I can eat here, which includes either the chicken tikka masala or some variety of saag, a pair of samosas, a side of rice, & 2 naans, each the size of a dinner plate.

They don't wait on you here, thank god, just give you a number at the register and call you up when your food is ready.  Drinks also are self-service, and if you don't feel like buying a soda they've got a fridge with large carafes of water you can bring to your table.  They're not one of these places that gives you a dixie cup if you have the temerity to ask for tap water.  Inside the fridge there are also squirt bottles of a chutney that goes great with the naan & samosas.

It's clean, no music, no tablecloths, and when it's crowded it can be difficult to hear the person sitting across from you b/c everyone's conversation echoes off & is amplified by the hard surfaces.  Thankfully, however, even though it's in the heart of the Mission, the worst of the Mission poseurs tend to stay away.  This place is about the food, not the attitude.
author: Ryan G.

description: The owner was very friendly and the chicken Tikka Masala was fantastic.  The mango/yogurt smoothies were also very good.  Great value and great food, I'd definitely recommend.
author: Josh D.

description:
DUUUUUUUUUDE, Their minty spicy sauce is enough to make me come back multiple times a week. 2 Samosas for 3 dollars. JESUS! and my favorite part is that they let you bring in your own beer or wine or whatever you want to enjoy with your meal, I think ive found my little nest of pakistani heaven right here in the mission.
Thank You Padwan!
author: Kevin M.

description:
Hot spicy and lacking in variety.
Pakwan seems to cook it's meat and then add spicy sauce, rather than marinade then cook. The result is bland (if that can ever be true of spicy food!). 
The Nan bread is good, very impressed with the onion Nan. 
Service behind the counter is a little arrogant, I guess they get fed up with customers not having read the menu before arriving to order. 
And some of the chicken pieces come from places on a chicken j have never seen. 
Best going there with eyes wide open.
author: keith w.

description: When I think of Indian/Pakistani food, three places pop up: Naan-N-Curry, Shalimar, and Pakwan.  It's hard to resist a family style restaurant that serves authentic food fast with this much flavor.  Try the lamb curries and chops!  If you need to counter the spices, coat your mouth with kheer, a rice pudding, and gulab jamun, a dessert with fried dough balls dunked into a a bowl of chilled, sweet syrup.
author: Jenny L.

description: It's shocking how good their naan is. Don't expect friendly service or always clean silverware at this joint. But it is cheap, and overall, quite tasty.
author: Miriam W.

description: It says a lot that we drive all the way up here from the boonies of the Peninsula just for some good cheap Indian food. Anyway, I just had nose surgery so I haven't been able to smell anything, but the tandoori smoke was so powerful it opened up my nasal passages and was the very first thing I was able to smell in a week.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Came here for dinner today. Good for groups and flavorful food, but too greasy for my taste. Our spinach and dal curries were soaked in oil.
author: Margaret H.

description:
love this place!

tandori chicken thigh, rice, tiki masala, and saag daal is a must for me everytime!

last time i came here, and ordered 4 tandori chicken thigh, which usually takes a bit longer to make. they forgot 3 of them and because i loved them so much, i decided to wait. they were really sweet and made 4 of them and gave it to me on the house for being patient. what great service!
author: Connie C.

description:
Update as of March 2007, moving from five stars down to three:

Pakwan - you let me down.  My boyfriend and I have had an ongoing debate about who was better Naan n Chutney or Pakwan. This whole time I have been supporting you Pakwan. A couple of weeks ago as a special surprise my wonderful boyfriend brought Pakwan take-out home, just for me. After that gooey liquidy tikka masala sauce, lackluster naan, and icky gray overcooked spinach even I had to admit it's just not as good anymore. I don't know what's happened to you Pakwan but whatever it is I hope you'll recover soon. 

*********************
Oh Pakwan, how you are my friend. When I feel too lazy to cook on a weeknight you always come through for me. When I want a cheap and delicious place to take friends, you always impress. When I am hungry you feed me. You are almost as good to me as my favorite pair of jeans.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Pakwan is a standard in my rotation of regulars. It used to be one of my go to places for 3pm breakfast when recovering from those early days of partying in SF. Now that I've gone and joined the wake up early crowd, it's still good and I appreciate its continual service throughout the day (rushing to make it to brunch by 2pm sucks, especially when hung over). 

I was surprised when Pakwan decided to spruce itself up a bit inside with some minor remodeling in the last year, nice. 

CTM, spicy, is required, as is rice and naan. The other dish that I order might end up being one of their daily specials, chana dal (I love garbanzos), saag, began barta, or a lamb dish, any of the above ordered spicy, because that's how I like it. The naan is occasionally very good, with the right amount of blistery bread and hot doughiness, at other times it's fine. For the price, location, BYOB policy, and the flavor, it's a great option. I do wish they delivered, but then I suppose it would be even more slammed.
author: Candice L.

description:
You see people brown bagging their 22's and you think, "did they buy that here, or I can walk to the well-stocked liquor store across that street and bring one back?"  I don't know how that policy works, but it made my dinner so much more enjoyable to have a Big Bear Black Stout.  
This place is pretty cheap and is not waited, comparable to a Naan n Curry.  Cheap decent food, what one would expect of the Indian places in the City.  Could be your local fave if you lived close by.  Masala chai was acceptable, tandoori lamb was solid.  good spot to roll out to some bars afterwards.
author: Cole M.

description:
Affordable and delicous!!

We came here after Bombay Indian Restaurant nearby wouldn't accept a $20 certificate we paid $10 for... So glad Bombay's bad service directed us to this place because it was exactly what we were craving.

To eat, we had plain naan, garlic naan, veggie fritters, the eggplant dish (AMAZING), paneer curry, chicken curry, and rice pudding dessert. Everything was absolutely fantastic, especially the eggplant dish and veggie fritters

We came in craving samosas and were disappointed when they didn't have them. However, this forced us to try veggie fritters which totally fulfilled the craving. If only they had both!

We also had the mango yogurt drink and chai. The chai was only ONE DOLLAR for UNLIMITED refills!! What a deal.

If I didn't live an hour away, I'd eat here often. I will definitely be back next time I'm in the city!
author: Alex S.

description:
I really liked the chicken tikki masala here. The naan is soft/crispy and plentiful, but the one my friend got was burnt. Saag paneer was also good, but a bit bland for my tastes. Great dining spot for under $10 and you might have enough for a leftover snack. 

Next time I want  to try the mango lassi.
author: Amy D.

description:
cheap tasty byob
try to go when its busy so you can experience how they call out yr order
author: Zachary B.

description:
Every time I go to Pakwan I remember how much I love it. And it doesn't take too much time spent not going there before I miss it and have to go back.

It's not the fanciest or most gourmet; it's just really good. And the bare bones decor and service just remind you that you're spending your money purely on the food and nothing else.

Their Bengan Bertha ("Pakwan Style") is my favorite incarnation of that dish anywhere, but really, it's all good.

You can BYOB (and there's a liquor store across the street if you forget that till you get there).

I always have a moment of anxiety when I see all the tables are full -- you order at the counter, get a number, and are left to fend for yourself to find a table before your food is ready -- this gives you maybe 10 minutes, eyeing the other waiting people competitively and trying to pounce on the first table that opens up -- but somehow it always works out fine, and tables do become available as people need them.
author: Matt G.

description: I enjoyed the food here alot.   The food was well seasoned, tasted good and wasn't overbearingly spicy.  The set-up was standard Indo/Pak for the city (bus your own table, free chai, decently clean) so I wont knock it for those reasons.  My only gripe was that the naan seemed to be a tad over cooked and dry.
author: Aasim K.

description:
If I had one meal left to eat in my entire life, this would be it.  Best Indian/Pakistani food I've ever eaten.  This place has the softest and most delicious nan in the city, plus amazing curries, plus it costs next to nothing, especially when you account for the BYOB factor.  (Liquor store right across the street.  Go ahead and ask the Pakwan counter if you can borrow a wine opener.  They'll joke about charging you corkage, but they do not.)

I do not like eggplant.  I have a thing about gelatinous foods.  Yet, the baingan bartha pakwan style is incredible.  I also love the tikka masala and the saag paneer.  Oh, and the mint sauce is incredible -- spicy but not too spicy -- don't forget to grab a bottle of it for your table from the cooler.

Only bit of warning is that the bathroom floor is sometimes INCREDIBLY SLIPPERY.  What do you expect when you're on 16th street and you're paying about $10 a head?  Great food, trust me.
author: Nathan F.

description: The best chicken Boti you can have. I happily drive many miles to have dinner at Pakwan.
author: Eduardo A.

description: I like to come here every so often when I get the taste for some Indian food and don't feel like shelling out a ton of cash for full-service restaurant.
