The folks who work here have always been very friendly to my family, and the food is good .I generally get the Chicken Tikka Masala and Naan like everyone else, but I've had other items on the menu and have never been disappointed.
author: Russ N.

description:
My friends know I'm as picky as they come when it comes to food.  Let's just say I'm not the most adventurous when it comes to trying new foods.  

A friend of mine lives above Pakwan and every week I come to the Mission, as I enter his building, walking up the stairs, I smell the spicy aroma of what seems to be delectable foods being served and eaten below.  After months of evading this place, I finally gave in today. WOW was I impressed!!!!!!!! I kick myself in the arse for not patronizing this place before. 

Chicken tika masala w/ naan accompanied with rice = wholesome goodness.

Lamb chop = edible orgasm - The most tastiest, delicious piece of meat I've eaten in many moons.

Conclusion. GO THERE!!!!!  Put it this way; I live in the South bay and I would drive up to the Mission just to eat here.  Go, now.  Log off Yelp and enjoy the greatness!!!!!!!
author: Ryan A.

description:
Not too impressed by this place. Their business model is a lot like Naan n' Curry, but not as tasty. 

First of all, the food was not very spicy. Is that so wrong to ask for spicy Indian food? The only time I've had non-spicy Indian food (other than when I visited Pakwan) was in France. We spoke to the owner at the restaurant in Bordeaux and he said that was because the French don't like spicy food. Understandable. But, San Francisco is in the United States. We like our food spicy, dammit! 

The samosas were crap. It seems like they took all the ingredients and put them in a blender in order to produce a tasteless mash. I love to bite into samosas and see chunks of potatoes and tons of peas. Plus, the crust was not crispy. In fact, it was a bit soggy. 

The only saving grace was that the Sag Paneer had a lot of paneer in it. Otherwise, it was disappointing. They also need to wash their spinach better because it was grainy. How hard is it to wash spinach? Talk about lazy.

If you want good Indian food, just walk down the street to Alhamra. The food is exponentially better there. You'll spend the same amount of money.

I was going to give this place two stars, but after writing this review I decided it only deserves one star.
author: Mark G.

description:
I kinda don't understand the attitude people have on Yelp; everybody loves everywhere. Please be a bit more critical and let's find good places to enjoy our city life. Don't give 4-5 stars to places that just had good bread or the service was good. Look at the overall experience.

Speaking of which, Pakwan is quite mediocre, but again it is one of those places people love to love. I've been there twice and both times was ok. If we lived in South Dakota, yes I would have given it 4, hell, 10 stars, but we live in SF and we have fantastic places and this place is just ok.

Sorry Pakwan lovers out there, this place is just OK. You want great Indian cheap eats, try Chutney and Rotee to name a few.
author: Lo F.

description:
I am so completely bummed tonight. Pakwan had become my tasty and reliable indian restaurant ever since Nan-n-Curry became jerks and their food became bad. Well, tonight I have to scratch Pakwan off my list, too. 

We ordered a curry for take out and it came with over a quarter of an inch of oil floating on top of the curry. That was bad enough, but when ladling the oil out, we realized that the large black chunk floating atop was not a cardamon, but a huge, giant bug complete with antennas. Ugh.
author: Casey D.

description: Just found a cockroach in my Saag Daal. That's the last time I am eating at Pakwan :(
author: Adam H.

description: Great curry for an amazing price. Naan was amazing fresh from the oven - pretty much as good as it gets. We ordered 2 up front, and decided later that it would have been better to order them as needed since they're just so good fresh. Curry sauces were good - we ordered Tikki Masala and Chicken Achar. I felt the chicken in the Tikki Masala was a little dry. Liked the Mango Lassi, and chai was so-so. Reminded me of the places I went to when I lived in SE Asia, so yeah, cash only, mostly self serve, but that doesn't bother me.
author: Sonya C.

description:
After the Fremont location having the best paki food I have had in the entire country, this location was such a disappointment.  Yes, it is cleaner and maybe a tad bigger with quicker service, but the food was awful in comparison. Still better than most places, but disappointing for a Pakwan. 

The Nihari barely had any sauce, and was loaded with chunks of fat not meat. The chicken tikka masala was better, but not in competition with the Fremont location. In addition, they charge for tea here whereas it is free at the East bay locations. 

On a stand alone basis this place would probably get 3.25 stars. I mean the Hayward location is not as great as the Fremont, but it's still good. However, this place was just such a let down. Stay away if possible.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
Okay food.  Must say- found a STAPLE in my chicken tikka masala.  I will give them the benefit of the doubt that this was a fluke, but it did happen.  
You know how I figured it out?  Hmm, what is that metallic reaction to my fillings?  Why is this so chewy?  OOOWWWW!  I think three stars is very generous.
author: Ann C.

description: came here for the first time with a group of friends for lunch and found the place to be quite delicious. In our group of 4, we all ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala. The Chicken was tender and sauce was very flavorful. We also got nann bread and rice to go with our Chicken Tikka Masala. Had their Chai Tea, and i wasn't too thrilled about it. the only thing about this place that i didn't really like, was that everything had to be ordered seperately. For example, rice, nann, chai, chicken tikka masala. so it came out to a little under $12.  I would definitely come back again to satisfy my indian food craving.
author: Lily S.

description:
After a several-year hiatus, I went to Pakwan for dinner again last night.  Why did I wait so long?  This place is awesome!

Despite the stress of hovering over people to pounce on a table, Pakwan is worth a visit because it's flavorful, cheap and filling!
author: Marcus C.

description: You won't find better Indian / Pakistani food in San Francisco for the price!  What I really appreciate is the way they handled themselves when things didn't go right.  We had a slight issue with a to-go order, and they went ABOVE and BEYOND our expectations.  They have earned our trust and we will be ordering at least once a week now.  Nicely done Pakwan!
author: Joel C.

description:
People always talk about this place for the "cheap eats".  I guess they can charge less since they save so much money on hair nets.  I had a hard time enjoying my meal when I bit into a HUGE, LONG hair.

Not cool.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Good and fast. And one of the last few places in the city where two can dine for under $20. Of course you pay for it--your clothes smell fuuunky afterward. Oh well.

Here's our standard meal, almost every time we come here:
- chicken tikka masala
- the spinach and garbanzo bean combo
- two orders of regular nan
- sakora (vegetable fritters) or vegetarian samosas
- rice, as needed
author: Genevieve R.

description:
I wrote the review below a long time ago. I went back there with a friend yesterday and we both got sick. My friend had diarrhea (sorry about the details) and I got really bad food poisoning - meaning, i was in bed for 24 hours, with nausea, vomiting and unable to stand. Maybe we got unlucky with a piece of bad chicken or something else, but the outcome was so bad that I needed to share what happened.

-------------

This place looks like a dump but is great, it is an institution in the Mission. The food is excellent, cheap and you can bring your own booze. What else to expect from a restaurant: you eat well, you pay little and you can drink whatever you want without being bothered...!

Don't take your girlfriend there for a romantic diner, but go there with a bunch of friends and enjoy the experience...
author: Steph S.

description:
I freakin' love Pakwan.

Honestly, I've had nothing but truly excellent meals here.  From quiet lunches for two, to big (15+ people), loud, long dinners, they are very accommodating, and the food is always awesome.  The Bengan Bartha and the Paneer Tikka Masala are my favorites.  But the Saag Paneer and lentils and naan and everything else is amazing.

I like how dive-y it is and that it's BYOB.  If out-of-towners like Indian food, this is where I take them.  Sure, the atmosphere can bit a little off-putting, but the food is completely worth it.  Plus, it's cheap.  Plus, it's 3 blocks from my apartment.  Thus, it has pretty much all the features needed for it to be my favorite.

Personal note: when I was camping in Canada for two months, the folks from the Bay Area and I used to reminisce about the awesomeness that is Pakwan-- there's a real statement.
author: Christy T.

description:
Yes I know; this isn't the season for gluttony.  But I just merrily binged on their savory (spinach and potato) Aloo Palak -- Yummm!

Tip well and Happy Solstice.
author: Mennlay A.

description: Yum! Pakwan serves some of the tastiest Indian food I've had. Order the Chicken Masala, Garlic Nan, rice and you're set. Spice it up with a little bottle of green sauce & you'll leave feelin' satisfied for sure. Theres a liquor store directly across from Pakwan, where you can scoop a beer to drink if you please. They have no problem if you BYOB. Too bad Indian restaurants leave you smelling like food, but hey - this spot is worth it!
author: Felicia G.

description: our 7 year old says, "this is the best restaurant i have ever eaten at. chicken tikka is my favorite food."
author: Franz T.

description: Look, this place is delicious. Go there. Do it. This is my choice Indian food restaurant in the city, and I often always bring friends and family from out of town here. It's seat yourself which I like and BYOB which is nice too. The chicken tikka masala is so, so satisfying especially after a long day at work. Split a side of rice with a friend and order the garlic naan. Friendly staff and a laid back atmosphere. Highly recommend.
author: Liz L.

description:
Thank you Yelp for coming through with a great recommendation for cheap and delicious Indian food. Pakwan is as good as everyone says it is and very reasonably priced. 

The chicken tika masala was very flavorful with the right amount of spice and the cashier's recommendation, the lamb curry, was delicious. I was really pleased with everything down to the naan. 

Perfect place for 2 people to eat great food for around $20. (Beware -- cash only).
author: Asheley W.

description: The bread was light and crispy.  The food was surprisingly light.  The service was good.  It was a little empty and a little dingy.  We had the naan, the rice, the butter chicken and the saag paneer.  It could have used a bit more seasoning.  The sauce wasn't heavy like a lot of other lower end south asian restaurants.  the price was reasonable.  (Between 7 and 10 per plate).  It was a la carte.  (didn't come with bread or rice)  My sister said it used to be better.  But, it was cheap.  So, I can't complain.  not a place, i would go out of my way to visit.  But, plenty fine if you live in that Nopa area.
author: Andrew W.

description:
If someone came to me and said, Marcus since you were up in the Space Shuttle once you can only eat one type of food, I would choose Indian. 
I Like Chana Masala.
Now normally I am harsh on places that are cash only but if my meal is less then $10 we are cool.
author: Marcus R.

description: I came here as part of a food crawl in the Mission.  They serve Masala Chai for $1 (unlimited refills) - which is a great deal for some excellent masala chai (in case you don't know what that is, it's a refreshing spiced tea latte).
author: Bee M.

description:
Let me begin by saying I don't relish writing negative reviews and I try to avoid doing so as much as I can. But it has gotten to that point where merely thinking about eating here gives me a stomach ache.

I used to be that person who was so completely loyal to the Pakwan experience. When I lived in the South Bay I used to drive all the way up to eat here. I recommended the place to everyone. But goodness! The quality of their food has just gotten so bad over the past year that I can not, simply can not eat here again. Nausea, stomach ache, I think you get the picture...
author: N K.

description:
I love curry. I grew up eating curry. I've eaten more curries than you could shake a big fat stick at. If I ever end up on death row, I will be requesting curry for my ast meal. I like Pakwan. Do I love it? No. But it's still some of the best curry I've had in the US, and for the price, it's pretty darned great. If Pakwan were more expensive, it would get a 3-star rating, but as it's relatively cheap, I'll give it a 4.

I usually plump for the tikka masala - good tasting sauce, good consistency, white meat, although the meat is often a little overcooked. They do a real mean Keema Naan, though...one of the best I've had, so that makes up for things. If you're fancying good curry and dont want to spend a whole lot, make sure you check out Pakwan.
author: Dan L.

description:
I don't like it. 
Call me spoiled but there's nothing quite like the Indian food I used to find in Manhattan. Since I've never been to India or Pakistan this is all I have to compare my Indian/Pakistani food experience to. 
I've tried it several times over the six plus years that I've lived here in San Francisco but every time I go I am disappointed. 
I don't even go with great expectations anymore. Last time I went I thought, "Well, it'll be difficult to be disappointed this time around." Yet, there I was, still disappointed. 
Sorry to those who like this place but I think it's only good if you're looking to get a case of the trots.
author: Jes M.

description:
The first time I went  I was skeptical, passing by at 10pm on a Friday night - the place was packed, yet there was an alarming paucity of people of South Asian origins inside, which is never a good sign.

However, Pakwan is a pleasant surprise - tasty, good portions, and great value.  Don't come here expecting something classy or odor-free.  This is simply for good, cheap Indian.  Perhaps most importantly, let's just say that Pakwan is safe - my friends and I have never encountered the dreaded "naan and curry s**t" from eating here...
author: Justin S.

description:
Oh Pakwan, you are my guilty pleasure. 

Is it authentic?  No.  Is it healthy? No.  Is the food good?  Heck yeah.

This is Americanized Indian food at its finest.  Their tandori chicken is great, but their chicken tikka masala is AMAZING!  It's soooo good and flavorable and addictive!  Don't try a bite of your dining companion's chicken tikka masala because you will want to have it all.  Trust me.  It's happened to me more than once.

Dependably good, cheap Indian food.  And it's much cleaner than other dining establishments with similar food I've been to (e.g. Naan n Curry).
author: Sara K.

description:
Pakwan is my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurant. They have the best nan, which is freshly made after you order. So its always warm and soft.
The few dishes on the menu are all tasty and most complement the nan well.
Pakwan is not the cleanest place and it is self-service. 
You go for the food not the ambiance.
author: Boba P.

description:
Great food for a great value. And hey - you can bring in your own adult beverage!

I'm a vegetarian so I try to squint past the giant skewered meat slabs. My favorite dish is the Paneer Tiki Masala. It is nice and spicy. The papadam is crispy and delicious and the garlic Naan is great too. If you like spicy food, you'll want a mango lassi to drink, it helps quiet the fire.
author: lisa l.

description:
Although I'm not a fan of heavy Punjabi food (I prefer the lighter South Indian,) I actually enjoyed the food here. I didn't feel like I had cement in my stomach! We ordered the spinach and paneer, the lamb lofta special, a bowl of dal makhni, biryani rice, and some kabob. It was spicy and flavorful, without the sweetness that sometimes characterizes  Americanized Indian food.  The cashier says that the the meat is halal (kosher by Muslim standards.) My meat eating friends and family said that the meat was tender and mild, especially the lamb. The naan was light and fresh. We had a side of Indian pickles, too. These spicy, sour and salty pieces of lime and mango are a must with any Indian meal. I liked the fact that there were bottles of green chutney on the counter; I was able to really spice up my vegetarian food without having to wait. 
It's really crowded and noisy inside, almost like a high school cafeteria. There were lots of tipsy, happy people , because it's BYOB and the liquor store is right outside. I'm sure the Taliban back in Pakistan does not approve , but I do!
author: Elena I.

description:
I love Indian food, it tasty, flavorful, and fun.  Plus, proper Indian food is light on the wallet, which is always nice too.  Pakwan is a great place to go for a simple Indian meal with a bunch of friends for any ole' reason.  The menu is basic with just the good stuff on it, service is minimal (besides bringing the food to you, it is pretty much do-it-yourself) and the food is mighty tasty.  

I typically go with a friend or two and order three entrees plus some naan, always a treat and just enough to fill us all up.  They don't serve alcohol, but there is a liquor store across the street where you can grab a beer for liquor store prices rather than restaurant prices.  Plates, silverware, glasses, and water pitchers are all in a shelving unit near the cash register.  

Overall, I think it is the best of both the eating out world and the eating in world.  You don't have to rely on wait staff to bring extra plates, silverware or water, but you also don't have to cook or clean anything.  Super tasty, not very expensive, and very good.  Highly recommended.  Only gripe is that it is sometimes a little warm inside the place.
author: Eric M.

description:
Roses are red
Violets are blue
Garlic Naan at Pakwan
I love you

PS. I love BYOB too.
author: Jen C.

description: We were hungry, very hungry. We wanted Kababs, and Tandoori chicken. This is the place for it. They have a rustic ambiance, and the food is in the spirit of Indian street food. Oily, colourful and tasty! Enjoyed it, but cant make a habit of it !
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
Being from Texas, its usually very strange for me to walk into an Indo-Pak restaurant and see people that aren't from that region of the world.  Admittedly, I was with a group of fellow brownies, but still...it was refreshing to see a diverse clientele in this type of restaurant.

Now, I disliked the fact that it was super crowded and we had to wait on a table, seat ourselves, and then order cafe style.  But when the food came out that changed everything.

I am very used to Pakistani/Indian food, growing up in my family, but everything tasted authentic, fresh, and dare-I-say as good as my mom's and aunties'!  

Chicken tikka and chicken tikka masala was excellent as always.  The Bihari kebab, something I don't usually like, had a perfect texture and great beefy taste.  The Eggplant I had was phenomenal, as well.  The naan was hot, fresh, and chewy-delicious.

The best part was the price.  For about 10 dishes, eight people paid about 10 bucks each, taxes and tip included.  We had much left over, as well.  WHAT A STEAL.

Of course, kinda lame that we had to pay for Chai.  It's usually tradition to include that.  Oh well, it was so cheap always.  Highly recommend to desi folk and pardesi folk alike.
author: Ibrahim M.

description:
Unfortunately, I eat here so much they know me by my first name and what I order.

The people here are friendly but definitely possess the no non-sense style.  Get your food and go... the food is priced really well (good enough if you want to eat here everyday) and it's delicious!
author: Emily Y.

description:
I swear, I'm not a food snob. I couldn't get into this place(that food, that is). i ordered the chicken korma. The chicken was overcooked and tough. The curry was bland "salt please". The rice was clumpy and cold. Just not a good experience. The chai tea was good though. Free refills as well. Nice deal!
I've had better Indian in San Francisco. Maybe it was an off night for Pakwan, who knows....
author: Kevin D.

description:
Very tasty Kebabs.
highly recommended.
Excellent Biryanis and everything else as well.
author: Honor G.

description:
Perfect SF Friday evening - hang out with your buddies at 111 Minna, drink happy hour booze, listen to groovy 80's, then end-up at Safeway looking for cheap wine, then open the bottle with friends at the pakwan on guerrero/16th. Fantastic food (spicy!), excellent location, energetic people and a steady vibe - all goes to wee hours at night. And yes, if you run out of booze, run across the street.

go pakwan.
author: Sav B.

description:
The key to Pakwan perfection is knowing what to order.  The chicken boti (chicken kebab) is amazing.  I crave it often.  The veggie dishes are good.  I don't like their saucy meats - oily sauce and lots of bones.  The simple solution is not to order them.  I love everything else.

I had to subtract a star for the bathroom.  It should be quarantined.
author: Melanie K.

description:
Our Usual after VBALL dining place

Good food, fast service, hella good price

Tandoori chicken - is off the HOOK! It's so juicy and flavorful
Tikka Masala - has the right amount of kick, thickness, and spice

Everything else is good and cheap. 

Rule: Order, pay, get your utensils, sit, and then wait for your food to be delivered.
author: Hebert J.

description:
Whenever I go into a new curry dive, I order the chicken tikka masala to gauge and compare to other similar eateries.  Pakwan's is by far the best for a place like this,  but it's glory is not limited to one dish.  Add the tandoori chicken, beef skewers, and naan for a terrific low-priced meal.

And to get the full palate of the curry, stop by the Korean liquor store across the street for your favorite forty.  Bring in as much booze as you want actually.  Neither Pakistani Tony Danza nor the number-bellowing man with the mic will care.

It's 'git-it-yo-damn-self' service which means you're gonna have to set your table, but that also means unlimited access to the much-coveted 'purple stuff' and 'green stuff'.  These magical liquids will enhance your already tasty meal guaranteed and at no extra cost.
author: Neej M.

description:
Well, see, here's the thing about Pakwan.

Their food is *really good*.  My meat eater friends swear that this is some of the best Chicken Tikka Masala in the Bay, and as a vegetarian I know their Chana Masala and Saag Paneer are basically pretty much awesome.  It's amazingly  cheap -- we're talking maybe $5 a portion, here -- and since there's no table service, there's no tip necessary.

The place is a *little* divey, but it's not nearly as bad as most dive-like places in the area, but, see.. there's this one little detail.  I've gone to Pakwan multiple times, and each time I have to pull a hair from my food.  Sometimes two.  And they ain't mine.  And they ain't my dates.  So it kinda makes you wonder.

Now, before that turns you off from the whole experience, you have to remember -- this food's *really good*.  And it's *REALLY* cheap.  And, come on, let's be honest; with all the sexy and willing hipsters at bars going au naturale in mute rebellion toward our SoCal porn-star neighbours, it's probably not the first time you got some stranger's hair in your mouth.  And was it a big deal then?  Probably not, right?  And this hair's not only probably *cleaner*, it's *also* got delicious Indian food on it.

I rest my case.  ... But I still have to take off two stars.
author: Juliette S.

description:
This is my go to place for Indian food because it's literally a block from my house, but it's also because it's hella good! Pakwan never disappoints and they're open late on weeknights. 

The chicken tikka masala is super yummy, though i wish it was a tad spicier.
author: Erin D.

description:
The Lamb shank special....i'm fainting....
The guy behind the counter recommended the dish to me as the first step of hitting on me. It is indeed, very very good. Juicy and tender lamb braised in the spicy curry sauce. Dip the garlic naan in the sauce....oh....

"Madame, oh no, sit down, here comes your food...."

"Number 37, where is number 37? I'm calling number 37!!"

(number 37 raised his hands)

" Come get your food man, I'm calling your number!"

"But...I thought you would bring the food to the table...like your did to the lady..."

"She is Madame, you are number 37!"

"@#$%^&&$#$%^&*............."

"Thank you madame, see you soon!! See you very very soon!!"


Oh...nice try...I'm so blushed...but really, I'm not that old....stop calling me madame.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
1.) Pakwan has one of the best lamb curries I ever had.-- I HIGHLY recommend their #1 Lamb Dish (I believe it is the Lamb Acchar, or something similar to that). The words "extra spicy" accompony it, but In reality, it is a 5/10 on the spice scale and absolutely delicious.  Their other lamb dishes are great too.

2.) The portions here are far better than the portions at Shalimar-- no longer do me and my friends have to battle over pieces of meat, because there is an ample supply.

3.) 16th and Valencia is a cool neighborhood--- no more dodging the crack bums and dope fiends that inhabit Shalimar.

4.) There is not a single bad dish on the menu--- anything you order will be prepared with excellency.
author: James M.

description:
I went into Pakwan for the first time last Saturday night. The confusion kicked in as soon as we walked in the front door. You order at the counter, they give you a number, and you are on your own. Good luck finding a seat! We lucked out, and begged chairs from other patrons -- the table we found had none. Aah, a place to sit. Is the drink I ordered going to show up, or do I need to do something to make that happen? It turns out, there is a self-serve soda fountain hidden behind the line of folks ordering. No ice, ugh. 

The place was so loud, that you can't carry on a conversations. Nomadic wanderers looking for seating was also distracting. I didn't see any violence break out, but could feel that anxiety and frustration of the nomads. 

The food was ok.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Pakwan always feels inviting. The big glass windows let passers-by see that everyone else feels the same way. They've gotten their quality control down, so every dish is a winner, but I am a sucker for palak paneer and you should be, too.

I find that I have the tendency to over-order at Pakwan. Repeat after me: one main dish, rice and naan for each person. Split appetizers between two people or more. Increase dosage only for very large appetites.

The bathrooms tend to reek there. They should just spritz some eau d'benghan bartha in there and all would be well.
author: Blake E.

description:
Okay, the food here is the cheapest Indian food I've had outside of NYC.  The quality is... decent.  Better than you would expect for the price.

The naan is really interesting-- much crunchier than I usually expect naan to be.  

Eating here late at night was a nice way to top off a girly-drink induced buzz from the bar next door.

Best part of my experience here: listening in on the gay guys out on a date sitting next to us.  Random people from San Francisco who have much more interesting lives than me... check.
author: Fen Z.

description:
I love this place! The prices totally reasonable as well. Thank goodness they remodeled a bit, because I used to want to vomit walking into here because it was so filthy. Nevertheless, I was once dragged into the place, where I ate the most amazing tasting kebabs, naan, and rice. 

Con: Their glasses always look dirty, as do their water pitchers, kinda nasty.

But the food is incredible...
author: victoria s.

description:
I just came back from India 2 weeks ago and literally had curry coming out of my ears. I swore that I didn't want Indian for a good year. Well, I walked by Pakwan the other night and just about gave into the heavenly smell that wafted out of the place. 

This is a great, divey place to get cheap Indian/Pakistani comfort food. Lots of flavor, portions are huge and the price is right. BYOB makes it a huge plus. I've never had something that I didn't like here. 

My only beef is that I ask for "spicy". I ask for "as spicy as you can do it". I ask for "Come on, I know I look white, but I can handle your shit spicy". They just won't give it to me. The spiciest I've been able to get from them is "ok, there's maybe some semblance of heat here, but I'm not impressed". It was the same thing in India, they see a white girl and they dumb down the spice. I will have my spice one day!!!
author: Jenny S.

description: Yummers. Really great food. Quantity and quality. BYOB is pretty cool too. The Naan was bomb as well as the tikki masala.We sat outside and was fun to people watch. Highly recommend if you're in the mood for Indian food. Go hungry for sure.
author: Tara M.

description: Best chicken Tika masala ever. Very goon naan and chana masala. Wife like the fish tandoori. I have indian friends that introduced me to this place. And i have tried many other indian restaurants.
author: Cal B.

description:
I live across the street from Pakwan and I gota say its one of the best places to eat in the whole city.  I eat here way too much so I am an expert on this place and let me tell ya EAT AT PAKWANS!!

My 3 favorite things.

#1Aloo Palak
Nutritious combination of spinach & potatoes

#2Saag Daal
Delicious combination of lentils & spinach

#3Nihari
A very special traditional boneless beef curry


Also you can bring your own beer.  They even allow beer that is not served in public places anywhere else to be brought and drank in public such as the 40oz Old English, King Cobra 32's, and Sir Billy D Williams's Colt 45.
author: Shawn L.

description: Tried Pakwan for the first time after rave reviews from my friends.  I placed an order by phone for pick up.  It took probably less that 15 minutes for my order to be ready & I was greeted by a very friendly man who had already packed up the order when I arrived.  The food was great for the price.  The yellow dal was amazing.  Will definitely be eating here again.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
139 reviews for Pakwan. 1.  I am clearly in the wrong business. 2. Only someone desperate like me would do the 140th review. I mean, what's the point? 3.  Obviously price does matter a lot with restaurants because Pakwan is seriously cheap for what you get.

Pakwan does a few things superlatively: hot, piping, tasty food; really cheap prices; fast service.  What else matters for $6.50?  

Well, ambiance certainly isn't one of the things Khalid and Shabaz spent a lot time on when they drew up their business plan.  Clean bathrooms was another omission in the strategic planning.  It's awfully hard to pee when the floors are this slippery, guys.  I would advise women to get their business out of the way before hitting Pakwan.

But, in spite of these infrastructure issues, I _love_ Pakwan and have been 25 times for lunch in spite of the long walk.  Go now.
author: Jeff W.

description: This place is tasty!! You want good Indian food; hit this place. You order at the counter, get a number and then wait for it to be called. Very casual. You even can BYOB and there's a liquor store across the street.  I came here with an Indian buddy so I knew walking in that it was gonna be good.  Enjoy!!
author: Steven D.

description: This place is awesome! You get so much food for such little money. Keep in mind that there is no table service, you get your own silverware and water and when your food is ready you get your lazy ass off the chair and get it yourself. The good thing is that you'll need the exercise from the amount of food on your plate. The price is right, the food is complex and delicious and there is plenty of it. My friend and I stuffed ourselves for $10 each. Pakwan is a great, quirky, mission hot spot, not to be missed.  So next time you're in the area, swing by a liquor store, grab a 6 pack of IPA (that's right, it's BYOB) and head over to Pakwan for more great food than you can handle.
author: Spencer C.

description:
Great pakistani/indian food. If only the two countries could coexist together like the cuisines do at this awesome, though totally crazy restaurant. Expect to be a little stressed out by the experience, as it's loud and the counter service can be a little hectic.

I highly recommend the BYOB option--there's a liquor store across the street, though you have to bring your own openers.
author: Jesse E.

description:
This is my favorite indian place in the city.  It's incredibly cheap, great food, and you can even bring your own beer/liquor (there is a liquor store right across the street).  

The chicken tikka masala here is awesome, and the tandoori lamb chops aint so shabby either.  For a group of 3 it only cost us 30 bucks, can't beat that!
author: Amul A.

description:
Fucking fantastic.  This place has NEVER let me down.  I eat here as often as possible and have yet to find another restaurant that is as consistently good as Pakwan. The samosas are extra delish and I'm stoked that the tikka masala comes with all white meat.  Ali at the counter is always cheerful too.

I'd eat here every day if I lived closer.
author: Shauna H.

description:
I've never had indian food despite wanting to try it for many many years. finally got to try this place last night with a few friends and thought it was really great. Indian food is really flavorful and heavier than you think it might be. a little goes a long way. we ordered the chicken makhanwala, onion naan, lamb chops and a plate of rice. everything was really great. the naan and rice went really well with the chicken makhanwala and the lamb was actually pretty good. it wasn't over cooked and it didn't taste that gamey...(i don't typically like lamb)...

the makhanwala has a bit of spice to it.. not over bearing, at least to me.. but thought i'd warn some of you so that you know what you're getting into! :)

remember, a little goes a long way!! :)
oh yea and it's super cheap. 1-2 bucks for naan that is bigger than your face and about 6-10 bucks for dishes (chicken was 6.99 and lamb chops were 9.99)
author: Jean S.

description:
garlic naan is a must get! goes great with their chicken tiki marsala.

Great flavors and clean.

Can also BYOB.
author: Jessica L.

description: I love this place. The Naan is always perfect. The Saag lamb is the best of any of the near by places. it is good balance between meat, greens and spices.  The other places in the area usually skimp on the lamb.
author: Bob b.

description: Food was great.. well my boyfriends food was.. I didint enjoy mines as much... nice atmosphere... quiet and chill...excellent on a rainy day near the window...Fast service
author: Summer M.

description:
Go in and get the specials...

I almost always order, 1 veggie special of the day, 1 meat special of the day, 2 orders of rice, one regular nan...  IF I'm feeling extra special, I'll also get the steak kabab's... They are awesome...

It's also BYOB!   Woooot.

And... if you need more rice, they'll hook you up if you ask... Also eat their green sauce... jalapeno chutney?  I dunno... But it's good, fast and cheap... 

And if it's busy... DON'T sit around forever at your table, go next door to a bar and talk... And for gods sake, don't post up at a table, before you've ordered... :)
author: Will W.

description: I came here with a big group of friends for a birthday dinner. The place was packed but we were lucky enough to grab a big spot in the front. We all put in $10 and ordered a ton of naan, chicken tikka masala, spicy lamb, rice, and a few other dishes. Everything was delicious! But the very best part about this place is their BYOB policy! We all brought our favorite happy beverage and enjoyed a cheap delicious dinner. I will definitely be back!
author: Casi C.

description: Pretty good food.  I really like the naan here, fluffy and satisfying.  Chicken tikka masala is good and has a high chicken to sauce ratio.  Good saag paneer as well.
author: Steven B.

description:
I've been meaning to come to this place and finally did when my friends and I were looking for a good cheap place to have dinner. First off, it's cafeteria style, where you pay and get your own water, plates, silveware, etc. I was running late and forgot to tell my friends this simple fact and they went in asking for a table for 4 please. I wish I had been there to see that...lol.

Food was good! Achar Ghost - spicy, oh so tender lamb goodness! Chicken Tikka Masala was nice, flavorful, and not too creamy. Their nan is pretty good, a little on the crispier side. The mango lassi was good and not too sweet. Overall, great food, decent environment, but you might smell like curry afterward. Small price to pay for good food while laughing away with good friends.
author: Linda C.

description:
Ugh. That about sums it up. I've passed by this place a thousand times and despite my love for Indian food, the fact that this place is always crowded and the positive Yelp reviews I have never been inside. Just did not look appetizing.

So when the craving for some Chicken Tikka Masala became overwhelming the other night I took it as a sign that I was meant to try Pakwan out. Apparently I am not so good at reading signs.

My first problem is that Pakwan is actually not that cheap. Why pay 7-8 bucks there when you can pay $10 and get a good entree at a real Indian restaurant? So the Naan is only $2 instead of $2.50? Maybe that's because it barely resembles Naan. Plus if you like rice you have to pay for it negating any money this place might save you.

Secondly, Indian food is all about the spices which is why it is usually so expensive. My Tikka Masala had none of the tastes I have come to expect from the dish- at first it tasted kind of bland and then... Well it was still bland. The white meat chicken was tasteless and made me wish I had ordered a vegetarian option.

The Seekh Kabab was probably the best thing I had there and I've had better elsewhere. In conclusion, ignore the Yelp reviews that praise this place because it seems as though most San Franciscan's have no idea what good Indian food tastes like.
author: Galen M.

description: This is our favorite Indian restaurant. They dont deliver but we still trek there for pickup when we dont want to eat out.
author: Amy H.

description: Best.  Naan.  Ever.  Order chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, no rice, extra naan, beers from across the street.
author: Sondra H.

description:
If I had a choice, I would give Pakwan 2.5 stars.  But I decided to swing to 3 because this place serves up the best fast IndoPak food in The City.

But seriously, that's not saying much.

Warnings: Greasy, not spicy, crowded, stuffy, dirty, and cash only.   

Suggestions: Order a kebab w/ naan, it's a good $5 meal.  They go completely overboard with the onions, so opt out especially if you get a wrap - and the chicken wraps are pretty good.  And by all means, avoid the Saag.  It tastes like what I'd imagine creamed seaweed to taste like - disgusting and unnecessary.
author: Maulie D.

description:
For a long time, I was a fan of NnC.  When I tried this place for the first time, I wondered why I had stuck with NnC for so long.  Thanks to fellow Yelpers, I discovered this place and this is a weekly stop for take out!  

I've never eaten at the restaurant, but it seems clean.  I always stick to the basics ... chicken tikka masala and a garlic naan.
author: Rod C.

description:
Best. Indian. Food. Ever.

Always busy but I've never had trouble finding a table and I'm usually there with a large group. Had to wait once for our food for a while but once I told the guy we'd been waiting he moved my order to priority. 

There's not much else to say - good food, good people, fun atmosphere, you will want to go back for sure.
author: Brittney E.

description: Yay! I dig this place!  Not sure what else to add to what yelpers have already mentioned about Pakwan. Just came here saturday and had the chicken tikka masala, garlic nan, lamb curry and rice.  Drizzling the tikka masala on the rice and dipping the nan in the sauce is ohhh so yummy! thank you Pakwan my tummy is very happy!
author: Jasen L.

description: We live just around the corner from Kasa, but that place just doesn't taste authentic.  How would I know, I'm Chinese, but I swear I can _feel_ it!   Anyway, Pakwan is now our destination Indian restaurant.  Love the self-service everything and bottomless cup of chai (which tastes like sweetened Lipton to me, but no matter).
author: Lisa S.

description:
1. BYOB
2. Near Bart
3. Near Dolores Park
4. Near Bi-Rite Ice Cream

If you have friends visiting and want to show them the hipster mission culture this is a good place to go.
author: Cristal G.

description: I can't imagine how this food could get any better. I even had my graduation party dinner and birthday dinner here. It's delicious and so affordable. The chicken tikka masala is so thick and yummy. The chicken is so tender and there's never any fat or grisle, which I'm always a stickler about. I could probably drink the cilantro sauce if I really wanted to, but instead I just douse my food in it. The chana masala is also really yummy. I've never had a bad or even so-so dish here. A real surprise was the fish tandoori. I'd never tried it before and my friends ordered it and it was the most tender and flavorful fish I've ever had! They are at the top of my list and my girlfriend and I always bring friends/family from out of town here and it's always a big hit! The BYOB policy is very cool too. Try it!!!
author: Lani R.

description:
When you scroll over the star ratings for 2 stars it says: "Meh. I've experienced better."  Honestly, that really sums up how I felt about Pakwan. It isn't expensive or out of the way, but honestly the food really isn't that great.

I'd rather go out of my way and pay more for a better meal. Sorry Pakwan, you've failed me.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Pakwan probably isn't the "coolest" place to eat, but it is dang cheap and the chicken tikka masala is the best I've had. The dining area is pretty big and noisy so it works well with groups. They also let you bring your own alcohol, which just adds to the affordability. I wouldn't recommend it for a date, but calling in for pick up or starting here for a night out with friends are really the best ways to enjoy Pakwan. BEWARE: cash only.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
Everytime I go in there the counter guy asks me if I'm from Northern Pakistan, Southern Iraq or Iran. Other that that the food is nice. B/C its pakistani its definatly spicery than straight up Indian. 
Lamb Vindalu is my rec. 

There is never a crowd for lunch M-F.

The bathrooms make you feel like your in Born into Brothels
author: Joe G.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city - cheap, easy, fast service, good food, open late and BYOB - you really can't get better than that.  

I laugh when I look around and notice that everyone else is enjoying the same dishes, my usual order includes - 

Chicken Tika Masala
Spinach with Lentils
Samosas
Rice & naan for two.  
(and a 24 oz beer from across the street).

Love love love this place.
author: Alice H.

description: This place is pretty bomb for a fast-foodie type of place. The food was good and I didn't get a post-Indian grub bad belly, so thumbs up for that. Also, it was reasonably priced. My girl and I ate 'til we were full and had plenty of left overs. I'll be sure to go back when I'm craving korma late-night.
author: Nikki B.

description: I like it so much here, I've had my birthday party here for a few years. (I also had a gay wedding reception here. Dinner was better, and lasted longer than the relationship.)
author: Timothy M.

description:
this is it!
tasty indian food, the counter people really helpful, great ambient.
thanks to the MAYAN'S kitchen guys too, they can execute the recipe really well.
its the coolest place to eat indian food!!
author: Davis E.

description:
I have been to this place multiple times. Food is really good. Especially I like the Tandoori chickens they make. Place is Ok-Ok. Not a great dining place if you are expecting a fine interior dining experience.

For the dollar value, food is cheap and good.
author: Sri R.

description:
One star for:
 - Mango Lassi

Two stars for:
 - Warm, fluffy naan

I think the curry my friend suggested I try was way to oily/creamy.  I need to give it another shot.
author: Charm N.

description:
+Affordable. Two curries, rice, samosas, two naans (less then $25)
+Very fast service
+Personable staff. I was quietly belly dancing while waiting for my take out (which took 15 minutes, NICE, that gets another +) and they engaged me in conversation. Good people.
+Tasty. Rice, Samosas (oh the foodgasms I had), Naan (onion and garlic). 
- SPICY. The butter chicken, Korma, Tikka Masala, and Murga are all SPICY. I have a more delicate palette then Joe, so he is absolutely hooked on this place. I think that if the spice level were toned down then the other flavors would be more expressive. Essentially I ended up eating really fast because my tongue was burning the disco inferno and continued to hurt-burn for probably two hours.
author: Terika B.

description:
I came here, and honestly, I wasn't expecting much. Just another indian place like naan n curry.  Loud, with the dude behind the counter yelling people's numbers so we know to go pick it up.

They had some specials. One included lamb shanks. Sure, I love lamb. I'll give it a go.  Mildly spicy, the sauce was perfect and the lamb wasn't chewy.  AND it was a big ol' piece of lamb shank. I appreciate that.

Wow. Awesome. I'm coming back for more lamb.

Five stars cuz they got it right.
author: Robert L.

description:
My friend and I ate Chicken Birani, Tandoori Lamb and eggplant&tomato dish.
It taste all OK. Chicken and Lamb was a bit dry though. But I actually  have never ate juicy meat at Indian/Pakistan restaurant. It's always a bit dry. I think Thai Curry or Thai meat is always better for that matter.

I liked the eggplant & tomato dish - It was pretty good. It was not curry but spiced and cooked down until I couldn't see the shape of eggplant nor tomato and ate like curry with rice.
Even though the Chicken was a bit dry (like I already said 300 times by now), the flavor of Birani was quite good. The rice was not too sticky like "naan and curry" and cooked well. 
If I have to say, I wouldn't get the Lamb again even though I am Lamb lover. But I would go back to try something else.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
Pretty damn good man. 

As i recall, they didn't take credit card.. which blows, in my opinion.

Otherwise, it was tasty. And... you're usual like curry and naan like crowd/atmosphere.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
I really love this place. Savory, flavory, spicy Indian food. Best samosas ever, maybe second only to Mehfil Indian restaurant. Comes with perfect spicy green chutney.

Chicken tikka masala is salty but delicious. 

I also love the service at this place - nice, good guys who take your order and deal with the chaos of this often crowded place professionally and kindly. 

It's BYO alcohol here!
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
Don't let the snobs fool ya, it may not be glamorous, or even slightly pretty.. but this place is low maintenance and DELICIOUS! One place where the service doesn't bother me- that's how good it is! Plus I've seen Dave Chappelle there a few times! 
Oh, and you can bring your own alchol and they don't charge a "corkage" fee or anything... and there's a liqour store right accross the street. Booyao!
author: Kissandtel L.

description: Inexpensive and unforgettable. Spicy lamb curry is a must, go enjoy!
author: Mario C.

description: First time there and I got the usual chicken biryani.. It was not real biryani as the rice was not prepared well at all. Further more they only accept cash and so they'll give you a hard time if you don't have it. The servers are loud and have a abrasive attitude. This place is not worth it!!!
author: T K.

description:
so excited to find a good indian place in the city!!

one of my best friends from college is indian and the food here is comparable to her mom's home cooking..so it's definitely good!

the food here is tasty and cheap. ive had the chicken saag-amazing, the lamb curry-so good, and the chicken tikka masala- alright. the garlic naan here tho is great, a big serving and fluffy. also refillable chai for $1. don't forget to get the green sauce and the chutney from the fridge by the drinks! amazing! o their cucumber and yogurt is soo authentic, must try wtih everything
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Love this place but I can't give it more stars and here's why:

Too grimy.  The only time it gets cleaned is when they paint.  Despite the recently cracked front windows and questionable looking silverware, I'm sure I'll go back for the tandoori fish and chicken tikka masala.  I need the Pakwan fix sometimes.
author: Colleen C.

description: OOBER DELICIOUS. 'nuff said. and inexpensive food tastes soooo much better in my mouth and in my pocket!!!!!!! ;)
author: Danielle C.

description: Awesome food. It was my first time trying Indian/Pakistani food in San Fran....and it was amazing. I was a little skeptic at first but when I saw how the food looked...I changed my mind instantly.     The garlic nan was baked perfecty, the flavor was just right. I loved eating the rice with the kababs.....beef and chicken I think. If I ever went back to San Fran again, Pakwan is a must!
author: Penny S.

description: I don't know that many Pakistani restaurants, but my friend took me here and the food was really great.  It's BYOB so we picked up some beers from nearby and drank them at our small table.  It gets pretty crowded, so it might be nice to get take-out, especially since the atmosphere isn't that great (can be kind of cold inside).  Really enjoyed some of the classics like Chicken Masala and Biryani, but was happy to try some new things.  It's a nice place to run into in the mission.
author: Jessi I.

description:
Actual conversation:

"How about Naan and Curry they have the all you can eat buffett?."  Garbage. I took a wrong turn the way to the crapper and ended up in the kitchen which basically looked like the crapper. Lets just say I didn't finish my meal. Garbage.

"What about Dosa, that place is super good and they've got great wines." 
Wines? Wine with my Briyani? Please stop talking to me. 

Pakwan has always been my go to spot in SF. You're in, you're out, you're sleeping. Hands down the best in the city. Fed me and the lady for under or slightly over $20.00 Chicken Tikka Masala and the Keema Naan is incredible. For the price and spice it can't be beat. There's a liquor store across the street to pick up some beer if you want one (or 6) with dinner. Just go and try it. Seriously.
author: Kevin K.

description:
For cheap Indian eats, this place is at the top.  The inside is very run down and nasty, and the bathroom ... well, don't even go there, but the food is spectacular.

This location definitely has better food than the O'Farrel one.

My personal favorites are the Chicken Tikka Masala, Fish Tandoor, and Onion Naan.

One of my favorite places in the city.  It's not exactly upscale, but it is delicious and cheap.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Great food here. Service was awesome, came out pretty fast, and was very decently priced.

Also, you can bring in your own liquor, which pretty much rules.
author: Marty K.

description:
I'm going to cut to the chase, like most people on here... I LOVE PAKWAN.

I could eat here everyday!  This is a no-frills place, you get your own plates, food, etc, but the food is delicious!

I love the chicken tika masala, bring on the curry baby.  The chana masala (garbanzo beans) are big and so damn good.  We always get the shish kabob; it  is meat goodness with spic, onions and herbs. The nan is moist and fluffy, and the mango lassi is sooooo good with the spicy food-it cools you off.

BYOB is another great part of Pakwan, I always bring some good ales of Hefeweizens...yum!

The prices cannot be beat and the food is divine.
author: Michi R.

description:
Yes, it's a greasy spoon. But they shouldn't take it literally!

I don't know why this place gets anything more than 3 stars. The food is too oily. The chicken tikka was undercooked (a health hazard, if you ask me). The palak-paneer was loaded with the paneer, not in balance with the palak.

Add to it the lack of service (you have to pick everything up yourself), the lack of clean tables (my friend forgot to check the chair and sat on some freshly-dropped rice), etc. and you wonder how this place survives.
author: A J.

description:
I don't know much about this style of food, but I do know that the stuff they serve here tastes great. Although I wouldn't be able to compare it to anywhere else.

I've been there when its super crowded and again when it was almost empty.  Neither time I had to wait too overly long for the food.  The garlic Nan is great.  

It's true, they're not big on customer service, but I don't mind picking up or clearing my own food.  

My only real complaint: get bigger drinking glasses.
author: Levi B.

description:
Why do people like this place? I'm not usually snobby when it comes to Indian food, but this was the worst chicken vindaloo I'd ever tasted: the meat was grisly and tough, and there were little bits of peppercorn floating around in it. To its credit, Pakwan is super cheap and you can BYOB, but no amount of alcohol can make the food taste good. 

Maybe I should have ordered something different, but I won't be back to find out.
author: Andy S.

description:
The food at Pakwan is okay at best. It's BYOB, so the drinks are as good as you want them to be. The service is fine - not the friendliest, but relatively quick. The atmosphere is that of a high school cafeteria. 

In a nutshell, I wouldn't recommend Pakwan, but it doesn't suck.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Turnip curry. Turnip freakin' curry. Large turnips cut into quarters. Delicious, light curry sauce. Turnip freakin' curry.

I almost ordered the eggplant curry. Then I noticed the turnips.

Then I was in heaven.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
This place is a refreshing change from the once humble king turned grease ball giant naan and curry. 
Its a seat yourself, order at the counter, small open kitchen with hommies making naan to order right in front of you kinda place. 
After I ordered, I went back up to the guy at the register, and asked him to make it comically spicy. He heard un-commonly spicy, as in there is a hot for those who ask for hot food, and then there is a step above for those who do not have american spice standards.
It had two out of three of my white friends glistening with sweat. the third was exempt as he has just returned from the jungles of bolivia, where the are well aware of what real spicy food is
It still was not too spicy, but hotter than some, and the flavor was very on point. and....
Under $40 for four people with tip? AWESOME! 

you can eat outside, which is cool,
when we showed up there was a group of people eating, and one of the dides was wearing an i-pod ear bud in one ear.... I could only imagine that he was very upset with his friends and blatently trying to show them disrespect. 
eat with your friends. talk with your friends. leave the i-pod alone
author: Isao K.

description: Pakwan is the best Indian-Pakistani restaurant in San Francisco. Its delicious and spicy food cost very cheap too. They have friendly employees too. Pakwan is one of my favorite places to eat.
author: Ira S.

description: Pak Wan has the best Chicken Tikka Masala that I've ever had. It's a must for any hungry person in the mission!
author: Steph M.

description:
I'm sure this place was a lot  better and more authentic N. Indian / Muslim food joint a couple of years ago - in line with the Shalimars and Kebab and Currys of the area.  

However I think they've totally lost the plot here.  The food was bland, the tikka masala tasted like tomato puree, the achari chicken you could barely taste the pickle.  The only semi-decent thing we had was the tandoori chicken.  To add insult to this, we ordered a lamb dish but they just didn't give it to us - when we said we had a missing dish they said "we're out of lamb" - well how nice, were you planning to give us our money back or a replacement before we asked?

The final nail in the coffin was the beer on every table - yes, you can BYOB, but that is so against the fundamental Muslim culture it means this place is no longer "authentic".  I guess they are now catering to the non-Asian crowd (which was 90% of the clientale when we were there) with bland food and beer - I for sure won't set foot in there again.
author: S C.

description: I have probably been to this San Francisco eatery more than any other because it's one of my boyfriend's go-to spots. Always really, really good, and the staff (especially the manager/owner-type-person) is always warm and friendly.  I am especially fond of the tandoori fish & garlic naan. [But seriously, if a place screws up the naan, they might as well pack it in, am I right?] I have a tendency to find one or two things I like on a menu and stick to them, but here I have been more adventurous, and never disappointed.
author: Alexis R.

description:
There's no way Pakwan can get 5 stars!!   I would give it a 2.5 but the cheap prices and one or two face saving dishes bring it to a 3.   I do wish this rating system had half ratings included in our choices.  

It's cheap indian/pakistani food and i mean cheap in both price and quality, in an extremely basic setting.  Pakwan's interior is a bit grungy, even.  That I don't mind.  Except for the rats others have mentioned that i've never seen, so I've put my mind in a state of denial.  But many dishes are average, and some items are soaked in too much oil.  The food overall... just so so.  I've had better indian/pakistani food elsewhere.
author: Animal K.

description:
So, I am not an expert in Indian food at all. This place was delicious, the chicken masala is wonderful! The spinach/chicken dish (not sure what it's called) was very good, and I don't care for cooked spinach much. This place is cheap, good, convenient, quick service.

Just note: its Cash Only
author: Chili B.

description:
Pakwan is definitely one of my favorite last minute group dinner spots.  Regardless of the time, we can almost always shuffle a few tables to get a bunch of friends fed with hot and tasty food in a hurry.  A handful of friends I introduced to Pakwan have now started bringing their friends here, which tells me I am not a liar when I say it is great.

I almost detracted a star because recently I have had a couple dishes that were very oily, but I had to keep it because of the fact that I have brought quite a bit of cheap wine/beer into here and had so many fun dinners in the process...

-food sometimes oily
-cash only
+byob
+easy for groups
+delicious
author: Morgen N.

description:
Joyous!! Another badass establishment that shares my love for the 'pay first, then sit and grub' process. But let's get to the major plus of Pakwan: the ultra-cheap and ultra-satisfying food. Can I reiterate how much I love Indian food? God, I love it. 

Homeboy and I ordered: 

Tandoori Chicken Boti (boneless marinated chicken on skewers and grilled) and Sabzi (mixed vegetable curry). 

Both dishes came in their own big bowl and were piping hot, spicy, and fresh tasting. 

We ordered garlic naan, which was made-to-order, hot, as thick as pizza dough, and all-around amazing. If you prefer thinner naan, you might not like it...pussy. 

We also tried our friend's Saag Paneer (a spinach and mustard leaves-based curry dish), which was a little mild, but yummy. 

One word on the B.Y.O.B: It's rad and all, but if you're thinking it might be a good idea to sneak a few of your leftover beers into Kilowatt (the bar next door), it's not. It's a bad idea. Just finish your beers in Pakwan. Getting kicked out of a bar can be embarrassing. Especially if you retain absolutely zero dignity whilst being ejected from said bar. Not a true story or anything. I'm just saying.
author: Nikki H.

description:
Great Pakistani/Indian food. We didn't have to wait for a table on a saturday night. This restaurant is self-service. We had to place our order at the counter, which only took cash; got our table number and seated ourselves with utensils and water. We didn't mind one bit with good company and all. Within 10 minutes, our order was ready. We order 5 entrees and one appetizer. Too bad they ran out of the somosas, my favorite. 

I will have to come back again. I love the garlic naan.

I will definitely come back.
author: Mauling W.

description:
I used to be the hugest Pakwan fan and we'd get takeout from there at least once a week.  Several months ago, though, they switched to plastic togo containers that are obviously filled very early in the day.  Chicken tika masala was formerly my favorite but the last few times it has been dry and certainly reheated (microwaved) for our order.

This place is still cheap but, unfortunately, not even worth it's low prices...
author: Bob C.

description:
UH OH! SF Food Inspection Score: 66!!! That's horrible....

This place was really good, dare I say great! But damn that score is bad.

I really enjoyed the fish (not sure of the name) but it was really tasty. I'll definitely go there again but I don't think that I can go back until the score is better.

As if Naan n curry is better...which it kind of is cuz it's byob for free and free chai. but that score...i'm just so upset.
author: Kristina C.

description:
another 5 stars from me. i write about the places i like. i'm not a basher, . 

anyways. this is the best there is. pour off the oil. get the chicken tikka masala, it's the best food and it's cheap and fast.
author: tod f.

description:
I have walked past this restaurant numerous times and didn't go in.  Maybe it was the fact that it was always packed with no available tables, or that you have to pay in cash... just seemed kind of a cheapy place, walk up and fight for a place to sit down.
My roommate's new beau is Indian and when he told us he wanted to take us to an Indian place in the Mission we happily agreed.  I have to say, when we walked up to Pakwan my first thought was "Oh... this place?" But after our meal I am definitely a fan.
I have had Indian food all over the city.  To be honest, most times I've been disappointed.  (refer to my Yelp review of another place)
But I was pleasantly surprised at Pakwan.
Now, ambiance is definitely lacking... but for a group (which we were) it can actually be fun.  It's BYOB which is kinda cool, since you can bring exactly what you want to drink (don't forget your wine key).
Also, the bathrooms left a lot to be desired.  But for how packed the place was, they were spending 100% of their effort cooking and not cleaning the bathrooms, which I can respect.
We ordered Naan, Chicken Tikka Masala, the Beef Kabob, Samosas, Rice, Chicken Biriyani, one of the specials with black eyed peas and lentils and a couple orders of Jasmine Rice.  
I liked it all.  The Tikka was delightful, the beef kabob - to die for.  Samosas were spicy and crispy.  I have no complaints.
Now, I have had better Indian food... but all of this at a restaurant in SF for about $45... you can't beat it.  Plus I have spent $15 on 1 takeout Indian entree at other establishments in the city and have been totally disappointed.
I will most likely get take out next time (better ambiance at home) but I will be back.
author: Alisa M.

description: i brag about this spot to everyone,,,i love it so much I think I am like a walking talking free advertiser for them lol,yeah chix tikka masala,basmati rice,garlic naan bread so so good i have to come here atleast once a month just my new tradition..eat good and eat well why not get the best stuff...so my top 1 favorite spot ever.
author: Nina B.

description: Went here on a Monday. Didn't really expect it to get to crazy. I was wrong. The crowd starts rolling in hard about 7. I can see why though. The food was so so good. I went there with some friends from out of town. We were all impressed. And the portions were surprisingly enough for three adults. We were all very full and there were even left overs. We all shared garlic nan, a curry dish, that spinach dish, one other dish and rice. I would have put the actual dish names but their web site sucks and doesn't give u the menu. Either way the meats were very tender and full of flavor. (I have an issue with dry and over cooked meats) Another good thing is it is really close to bart and I can just take the train over whenever i want Indian food from the City.
author: Tamika C.

description: I ordered chicken tikka masala, saag paneer & rice to go.  Omg....I just finished eating & I feel so satisfied. There was so much food leftover I have some left for my lunch tomorrow. Finally an Indian food restaurant that's reasonable :-))))   big grin & delicious too. I would've given it 5 stars but I had to take one star off for having no utensils or napkins in the bag for my take out order. "BOO"... definitely recommend if your craving Indian food.
author: Sheila C.

description:
Ok, so I thought Naan and Curry was good.... boy, was I wrong...
This place is TOP SHELF.

The spices were subtle, had different layers of flavor, and just makes you want to eat! The Saag Paneer is the best I've had. Their vindaloo is completely divergent from what I'm used to, but it's so damn good.

Best of all, they have the best chai I've had in SF. I love chai, I make chai, this chai I would happily pay for (consequently, they charge $1 for it.), and have.

Also, while small, this is the best naan I've had in SF. This place is going to give me more of a reason to take the 22.
author: Dave M.

description:
..Eh.

This place is confusing -- because it almost looks like a nice sit down and be waited on place. But it's not. It's one of those go up and order, get your own silverware, get your own water/tea, etc. Which is fine -- and I'm used to that at other indian food places, it just took me awhile to realize they weren't going to walk 10 feet to hand us our food. (So why did they give us one of those order number markers that they usually give you - so that the waiters can find you? Even at naan'n'curry they bring you your food, even though you have to get your own plates, etc.)
It was either not spicy at all, or too spicy for me. I like mild spicy, so I stuck to the tandoori cheesy cubes. It really didn't stand out for me, the prices weren't so amazing that it was anything to note, I doubt I'll come here again.
author: Serene L.

description:
This place is the best.
I have never been disappointed at Pakwan, and this location, on 16th is the greatest. I really appreciate the remodeling they did a few years back which really opened up the place. Also, it is extremely affordable.
The only real drawback is lack of alcohol, but if you are extremely cheap (full disclosure: I am extremely cheap- er I mean thrifty) this is actually an plus.
author: Doug W.

description:
Oh Pakwan...I truly believe that this place, much like La Rondalla, should roughly translate to "I hate you, dear friend."

The food is always delicious.  Always.  The price point can't be beat.  The service and ambience is classic India.  And it's almost inevitable that someone in your party will get a quick bout of delhi-belly.  But much like a 24-hour flu right before vacation, this culinary game of Russian Roulette is completely, and totally worth it.

Try some of the lesser known dishes such as the Bhagan Bharta or the Chana Masala -- they really stand out (as does the saag gosht!).
author: Aaron G.

description:
So good!  Don't let the "atmosphere" put you off.
Hey, unless I'd been taken there by a very good friend, I don't think I'd have ventured inside.  Do.  Everything is wonderful and it costs like no money.
If you like wine, as I do, make sure to bring your own along.
author: Kara H.

description:
Hit and miss!
My last meal here was the best of its competitors, ever...I want to give a five star, but I have no idea what will happen when I go back...

I have also had very average food here a year or more ago.
author: Ross J.

description:
There is stiff competition in the  under-$10/entree indian/pakistani food market. I can't say that any one place is better than the rest, but if I could - then  this Pakwan joint would be it. 

My favorites here include the Aachar chicken and the Biryani. The aachar chicken might be a little spicy for most - but it can be easily overcome with some yogurt on the side, or just larger chunks of naan.
author: Asheem M.

description: awesome.  every visit has been a success. hot, fast, high quality.  my favorite (like many others) is the chicken tikka masala and plain naan.  it's byob.  great place.
author: A B.

description:
Much like the Pakwan of Civic Center this joint is a good value for the money.  I never leave hungry, but somehow the portions here seem skimpier compared to the Tenderloin location.

It's a tasty dive.
author: Maya C.

description:
3.5 Stars would be more appropriate.,
I'm cool with this spot. I would order again but mostly out of convenience, and for price. Peeping the most recent review my wife and I split the chicken Tika  Marsala, naan, rice and samosa. I love getting change back from a $20 for a meal that satisfies the two of our hungers. 
The portions were large but not overwhelming. We actually don't have any leftovers. This does speak more to our hunger though and appropriate sizes than overall flavor of the meal. Bear in mind that there was nothing wrong, chicken was done well, samosas were not too greasy, but the Marsala was kinda ketchupy and just a little heavy, and salty.  Initially my wife described the taste as that of hotdogs...not a compliment from a converted vegetarian. But we would try something else here I'm sure and call on this place again when in the mission looking for a quick, cheap good meal.
author: Kennan S.

description: Hands down the best Pakistani restaurant in San Francisco!!! The best food, at amazingly affordable prices. My boyfriend and I eat here all the time because it is the one place we can afford to go regularly. Our favorite dishes are the chicken boti and tandoori chicken. The curry is also the best in the city! Service is friendly, kitchen is in view and food is always fesh. Now I'm hungry!
author: Georgia H.

description: God have mercy on my soul, I am home. Allow the smells to enter your face. Allow the glow to bask over you as the glory and excellence of it's Pakistani employees enshrouds you. I frequent Pakwan no less than once a week. It is inexpensive and delicious. There is usually sufficient seating and it is BYOB. Suggestions include: Aloo Palak, Chicken Biryani (with ryta on the side), and chicken Korma.
author: Paul D.

description:
Been coming here since it opened in the 90's.  Defnitely one of the best Pakistani places for the price.  It's cheap and somewhat divey, and often noisy, but that's what's cool about it.  Certainly not fine dining.  

The food is always consistent and tasty, and spicy.  Hella big pieces of naan, one can feed two.  Usually get a couple of things, meat and veggie, using the naan to mop up the sauces.  Also, good for groups.
author: Ramon C.

description: I don't know, my fellow yelpers. I'm losing faith in you. Four stars. 509 reviews. I've had Pakwan bookmarked to try forever, and I finally ate there last weekend. It was some of the most mediocre Indian/Pakistani food I've had in a very long time or perhaps EVER. I guess nothing draws a crowd like a crowd. Yeah, Pakwan is cheap food in the City, but it's CHEAP in every sense of the word. Gamey lamb shank and dried out chicken biryani. They also had no lamb dishes (other than the lamb shank special) on a busy Saturday night. They also ran out of chai, and it took forever for them to make more. I was almost finished with my meal before a fresh container was brought out. Plus the tables were not clean and the floors were filthy. Pakwan is not even worth giving a second chance. I'm being generous with two stars. Simply overrated.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Love and marriage, love and marriage...goes together like a horseless carriage. You know the song. I feel the same way about this place and Zeitgeist. I love both places, and feel that they resonate together. Just to be me, I always ask for my favorite Naan-N-Curry item (aloo gobi) and then decide to have something else that tastes much better. I love Pakwan and hope they never change too much.
author: Cameron K.

description:
I love this place, I'm from England and it's the closest thing I've found to a proper ruby, plus it's cheap as chips. It's a bit chaotic and it feels more like a cafe than a restaurant but you can bring your own beer and make as much noise as you want. The tikka masala is great and the lamb chops if they still do them are out of this world. Plus the old geezer who sits around on a stool and must own the place is perfectly charming. It's like a bit of Main Bazar New Delhi dropped in the Mission. Plus they deliver and it's often lightening fast. They just put up that horrid TV screen that calls out the numbers but it only makes it more like India.

I changed my review of this from 5 stars to 3 because I went out the back once and saw they keep food out there where it's real dark and dirty. It may have improved since but until I get back there it's a 3 star jobbie, and I haven't wanted to go back since.
author: mefloquine x.

description: Awesome place and  got me hooked onto a curry fix. I got the Lamb curry with a tomato base. Awesome!!!
author: Helen V.

description: I try, I swear I try ... but Indian food is not my big craving. I went again and the tasty spicy flavors made my friends happy. 4 well earned stars. Let's see when my troops force to go again.
author: Javi V.

description:
Pakwan is a tremendous little divey restaurant.

Those looking for a gourmet experience, intent on criticizing the toughness of the chicken and the sophistication of the curries should look elsewhere.

Those looking to BYOB, and to nom on some refreshingly cheap and yummy naan and curry, head on down.

Also: the guy who generally takes orders here is fantastically friendly.
author: Keith C.

description: One of my favorite places in the city. Very inexpensive, yet extremely tasty. Portions are big. This isn't a place to go for a quiet and relaxed dining experience - it's high energy with a lot of hustle bustle and there isn't table service. Sometimes you have to fight to get a table, or ask if you can share one with strangers. If you're not in the mood for a lot of "frills", it's a great place to dine.
author: Kori M.

description: Nice selection of veg options.  The place can get pretty packed and it can be hard to find a table.  Their chana masala is one of the best I've had.  The aloo palak was ok, not something I would order again.  Veggie samosas were pretty tasty.
author: Dana P.

description:
Great place - such a high food rating for the $$ you'll spend.  Highlights include Achar Gosht (lamb) and the vegetable curries.

Pakwan is everyting you come to love about the Mission - good quality places that are affordable and authentic.
author: Jason H.

description:
Initially, I was skeptical about this restaurant and first impressions aren't that good - it's small, cramped, and smelly.
It's a self service concept - you order, pick up your own plates/silverware and seat yourself. They call your name and you pick up the food - simple.
The food itself was surprisingly good. I had the Chiken Achar, Chicken Tikka, and the Lamb Biryani. All three were excellent - my favorites being the Tikka (pefectly cooked in the tandoori oven - moist, flavorful) and the Biryani (perfectly cooked rice with masala and lamb).
Overall, the value for money is excellent and the food is exceptional so I highly recommend this place.

p.s. - I am Indian and have had many opportunities to have bad indian food.
author: Harsh X.

description:
Holy Crap!  I've lived next door to this place for 41 days and I just eat there for the first time last night.  How sad for me, all that time lost...  I can only rejoice in the fact that now I have found you Pakwan, I will never let you go.  Really, I'll never let go.

Tikka Masala anything is good but the cheese was great, loved the fluffy well constructed Naan, and the Tandori Chicken was moist and juicy... a real treat from the jerky like version you get most places.

Only criticism... those yummy cheese balls covered in syrup.  They should be warm and fluffy.  Not self serve from the refrigerator.  That was sad.  I have to find somewhere else to get those.  Galob Jamon?! I think that's what it's called.
author: Alicia W.

description:
YES, YES, OH YES YESSSSSSSSS.

I'm half way round my night out with me mate - we've sinned, we've drunk stuff and now in the time honoured British night out we must eat CURRY.

Having a man sandpapering the toilet whilst I am in there? No way Jose - (probably Akbar more like).

Why not 5* - it's the Naan.  Nip round to Mehfil, get fresh Naan there and leg it back here.

We were transported back several years to nights out in Bradford.
La recherche du temps perdu - let HIM eat cake, I will go for a curry every time.  Oh Lord it was good.
The pakoras, the onion bhaji, the curry, the fact that there was no alcohol - giving my liver a let up.
Oh yes I WILL RETURN.
author: Berty B.

description:
As long as you're cool with sitting on a chair that's never been cleaned on a floor that's never been mopped and being scowled at by the guy at the counter who's perpetually underwhelmed by you and everyone else, the place is great.

The food, the real draw, is most excellent however and if you're going for the atmosphere try somewhere else 'cause there's no there there.
author: Roger G.

description:
Quality Naan and a great to-go menu. Much different from the Hayward location, this one is all hipster and no authentic Pakistanis. 

Still really good though and definitely recommended for this area.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Things I LOVE about Pakwan:

1. They let you bring your own beverage. No corkage.

2. The tandori fish = to die for.

3. Super cheap.

4. Actually tastes the way Indian food tastes in India. Most Indian restaurants I've been to in the states are somehow "off" - I think they americanize their recipes or something. But not Pakwan. It's the real deal. (It's possible some people don't like this, but... I guess, don't go to India then.)

5. Naan = yum.
author: Jen B.

description:
A neighborhood favorite - Pakwan is not a fancy eatery, but the food is awesome.
