It's a bit of a self-service restaurant - order up front, get your own cutlery and water. Your number is called for you to pick up.  Our favorite dishes are chicken tikka masala, any of the tandoori meats, the GARLIC naan, and the vegetarian dishes.

Take out is a good option since it can get pretty busy.
author: Spoon G.

description:
I like it. A lot.

A friendly upbeat staff makes all the difference in the world.

A cozy and warm restaurant makes for a delightful alternative compared to the sometimes bitter San Francisco weather.

The portions were large and well priced.

The paneer tikka masala was extremely spicey and goddamn delicious.

Send them my love when you visit.
author: Veronica B.

description:
I'm going to go with four stars bc the guys there are great.  The service is awesome and it's fast.  The food is tasty too.  I am not a fan of Indian food, but I do like the chicken biyrani.. i totally murdered the spelling.  It's a little pricey for to-go fstyle ood, but it's manageable. 

Bring your own wine is wonderful.  My friends and I chill there and drink our wine and chat.  It's so low key and I can go there anytime of day.
author: Ann M.

description: Not quite as good as some places in the Tenderloin (or Tandoorloin), but still delicious and affordable. Mango Lassi is delicious, as are the curries. They also freshly grind their spices. How do I know? Because I bit into something that they had forgotten to grind and got qutie the burst of flavor. I like how the order at the counter model keeps things cheaper....
author: Mark A.

description: Haven't had much experience with Indian food, but this place was amazing. They have generous portions that have great quality and amazing flavors inside. Nahari was amazing - was a bit spicy but had an awesome flavor. The Nann was awesome. The other cool fact is that you can walk across the street, but a beer and bring it into the restaurant and drink it there. They have a limited beverage selection on site. The seating was a bit cramped and on certain nights very difficult to find a table. Parking can be hell if you don't arrive early as you park along the street. All-in-all this place was an amazing start to a passion that builds for Indian cuisine.
author: Pierce B.

description: Food coma... nuff said....  My favorite was the chicken tikka masala.
author: Mark F.

description:
+ saag dahl
+ chicken tikka masala
+ garlic naan
+ chai tea
+ friendly service
+ the right mix of spice, fresh ingredients, and a hint of grease!

Hits the spot.
author: Tulip F.

description:
to love is to love again.

i did what i said i would never do again. i did the unthinkable... i ate here.

yes, again. figured if i saw this creature crawling in and out with my own two eyes at this place. then im sure this is not the only restaurant in the world with cockroaches. and plus i didnt see any this time. or maybe i just chose not to look anywhere but at the brown table waiting for my number to be called. 

i had what my heart was desiring for a long time. the infamous tandoori chicken breast...oh sigh! and plain naan...i love the onion naan but i thought i was already gonna be eating the raw onions slices they generously put over the large breast of a chicken, that comes out so crisp and blackened from the tandoor that i wouldnt need onions in my naan...so plain it is or was. i ordered the veggie samosa, it tasted a little bit off balance today...and decided to also try the veggie pakora...um and that was just okay. i have tried better pakora and this place isnt where it was.
author: SammyWammy S.

description:
yummy and delicious. can't try enough of everything. bring cash and a friend to help you look for parking on the street. If you're there at night you might want a friend to help you get to your car safely. Um the place is kinda out by itself, but it's worth it if you're looking for ethnic food. 
A friend took us once but it's been hard to find again.
author: Jason C.

description:
Pakwan is simply fantastic Indian food. The tikka masala- both chicken and paneer - are fabulous and the samosas might be the best I've ever had. It's fast and very affordable. You must order the naan with whatever you get- so light and fluffy it makes the meal.

If you're new to Pakwan the system is a bit confusing- you get a number but you probably won't hear that number called, even though you have to pick it up yourself at the counter. It's okay, you'll get your food somehow. That's just part of the Pakwan charm. Also remember that it's BYOB so don't forget to pick up a beverage at the liquor store across the street. It's also one of the few dinner places open until 1am.
author: Allison S.

description: Best authentic Pakistani food, hands down !!! No ifs or buts !
author: M M.

description: Love the BYOB, especially since the beer selection across the street is so good.  A solid meal for 1+ for less than $10 incl tip.
author: jaf D.

description:
The best Indian in The Mish.

Good, fast, cheap and yummy.  And it's just down the street from me.  Gott alove it!

Ambiance is OK.  BYOB is a nice option.  Parking is not so good.

Probably the 3rd best Indian restaurant in SF behind Shalimar and Naan & Curry.
author: DJ N.

description:
I cant believe I havent written a review for Pakwan yet! I have been a regular here for 3 years and know the guys there by name - Ali, the manager is almost a friend.

Food at Pakwan really is yummy - feels like home cooked punjabi/ pakistani food. I mostly get take out from there on my way back from the gym and its cheap enough to do this a lot. Its the only replacement I have found in SF for my mom's cooking.

The best dishes there are the chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, palak paneer (when they have it) and their absolutely delicious kheer (rice pudding.) Just writing this review is making my mouth water :)
author: Mitali P.

description:
I had not been to Pakwan in years. It has changed. It's still awesome and cheap, it just looks nicer than it once did. It;s sort of amazing - the back door used to lead to a garden - now it's a long hallway with bathrooms. 
Anyhow... the food is great. I like Pakwan's way more than Naan'N'Curry or Shalimar, and I like its location more too...
author: Fred A.

description: Very nice indian food restaurant! We went for lunch, looking for a cheap place in the castro-mission area. We followed the Yelp reviews and stopped by Pakwan. When we sat, we looked around and I was surprised by the number of people in this place at 2 pm. The naan looked mouthwatering so we order 2, along with two meals. And it was delicious. For the price, it's a 5 star place! recommended by a Frenchman ! (meaning someone quite picky with good food :) )
author: Yann M.

description:
if it were socially acceptable, i would drink the cilantro chutney straight from the squirt bottle.

when i get food to go, i snag more than my fair share of the convenient little to-go containers located near the cash register. they probably hate me. i do not care.

the naan is tasty but usually, like, 30% is burnt. good thing it's the size of a parachute, so you still get a ridiculous amount of un-burnt naan.

the vegetable sabzi & the chana daal are my favorites. washed down with a healthy sip of cilantro chutney, of course.
author: Paula T.

description: We ordered the chicken tikka masala. It was quite tasty, until we found a huge fly in it. Beware.
author: Kristine A.

description: I really like this place because you can always count on cheap Indian food in a pinch.  The chicken tikka masala is really spicy, just the way I like it.  The rice and naan are fantastic.  The place gets crowded and finding a table can be a challenge but once you've ordered at the counter, a table usually opens up by the time your order comes on the counter.....usually.
author: Eddie L.

description: I WILL COME BACK. this place is sO GOOD. chill. clean. great location with bars around. cant wait to go back
author: Cindy L.

description:
Best indian/pakistani food I have had, at an amazing price.  

Great for vegetarians, meat eaters, and vegans alike.  The Bengan Bartha Pakwan Style is my go-to dish.
author: Garrett S.

description: good food cheap, super nasty men's room :-(
author: Zack A.

description: I've eatin at Pakwan before and it was decent. After my experience last weekend I will NEVER go back. The waiter took full advantage of our tipsiness and charged us well over the amount we ordered. We were pretty pissed off after reviewing the bill the next day, but not as upset as our stomachs. All my friends had terrible digestion; which meant hitting the toilet all morning long. With plenty of choices to eat around Valencia, I'm definitely not going to miss that place!
author: Pascal G.

description: Better than shalamar.  Yes, I said it.  Roommate and I had, garlic naan, lamb biryani, chicken tiki., sheesh ka.,  It was all good.  Comfort food, rich and filling- you don't need to order a lot here to get filled.  Also, the place is byob, which for alchies like me is clutch.  However, they need to either clean the place up respectable-like OR make a concerted effort for shabba-licous.  It's okay if you draw a line in the rice and say, 'you come for the food and the wall isn't a plate...'  The half assed attempt actually makes it look worse.  This isn't a first date place...but it's still sexy.  Pakwan is where you come to get your hands dirty in comfort food.
author: Jake H.

description: You Can not beat the price for this good of Indian food, mostly Northern Indian.  So good we used it to cater a party.  Efficient staff and really very well priced and good quality food! Got a needed face lift about I think 3 years ago and even before then the food was good
author: Joseph F.

description: Im a indo/pak  food fanatic. And for a long time I have dined at the same indo pak restaurants in the city, i.e Shalimar and Chutney in which I had a non verbal, food porn allegiance too.  However one day,  I ran into a worker at pakwan, who invited me to come eat at the restaurant.  I was quite reserve, but said what the hell. I ordered the seekh beef kebab, aloo palak methi, CTM, and lamb biryani.  My order was strategic for everyone judges an indo pak restaurant on basically these 4 dishes(tandoori, CTM, Biryani, Veggie dish.  In all honesty, the kebab was succulent and juicy, and CTM was flavorful, not full of cream.  The aloo palak was awesome bc it was served with jalapeno's which gave it a hint of crunch and heat.  The biryani was perfectly cooked home style.  Over all I think what gives Pakwan a lil advantange over other indo pak restaurants is they serve halal, hand slaughter,non antiobic/steroid raised poultry, which you can taste in the quality of the meat.   Thank You Pakwan for an awesome experience.
author: Yah A.

description: I heart Pakwan for many reasons. Cheap, convenient, close by, outdoor seating (great on a hot summer night), and BYOB factor. Their tikka masala is pretty tasty, naan is fluffy, seekh kabab is also great appetizer. Great place to go if you're on a budget, cheap date too. Bad things: cash only, parking is terrible,  and it can be loud/crowded inside too.
author: Kristy H.

description: Awesome Indian for the money, not too expensive, big portions, and BYOB. Achar is solid since I prefer spicy stuff and there isn't vindaloo on the menu. CTM is definitely above average too. Protip, if you're not drinking get the chai as it's $1 and has free refills. Honestly I'll eat here about once a week.
author: David H.

description:
the best lamb tandoori chops ever.  ever.

went here with a long lost friend from sg.  amazing food + amazing long lost friend = mind orgasm.
author: Francis G.

description: I love Indian food, and to me, this is the best in SF. Nothing fancy, but yummy and being in the 16th Valencia corridor adds a cool factor that is a great combo. Good date spot; good place to just meet up with some friends for cheap eats and chill.
author: Dan B.

description: Really excellent Indian food.  No frills kind of place (but much nicer inside than Shalimar), and it's all about the food.  Chicken tikka masala was creamy, rich, and not greasy/oily at all.  We also had the fish (sole, I think it was?), which was really outstanding.  Served with cilantro, onions, and lime- just very, very tasty.  The rice and naan was also very good.  Chai tea is $1.  Cash only.  Great prices.
author: Sarah F.

description: It was my first time going to Pakwan and I really liked the food and the atmosphere. We ordered Chicken Tikka Masala and some kind of cheese curry that was surprisingly good. But I really liked the Chicken dish; we almost licked the plate clean. It was absolutely flavorful and went very well with the rice. I'd definitely go back and I highly recommend this place to everyone.
author: Dillan H.

description: Everytime I step into Pakwan, it smells absolutely delicious.  But I've only had the naan here because I'm typically in between meals when I stop by.  The naan is heavenly hot, soft, and puffy.  It totally hits the spot for a mid-afternoon snack.  Service is friendly and the food is reasonably priced (naan is only $1).
author: Sirinda S.

description: Super tasty and cheap to boot.  Chicken tikka masala was great, and I loved the fluffiness of the naan.  And BYOB - a definitely plus.
author: Melinda C.

description:
i think that i've been spoiled by the quality and deliciousness of Indian Oven, but for the prices i can't expect too much. i guess because everybody else has raved about this place i expected more. 

-Pakwan wasn't very flavorful
-some parts of the naan were thick and too fluffy and other parts were flattened to a crisp. i like a consistency to my naan.
-the chai was horribly bland and hadn't been steeped long enough.
author: Regina C.

description: This place is rough.  Fend for yourself seating, utensils, and making sure you actually get your food.  The key here is that the food is excellent and reasonably priced.  I think the problem some people have is that this place has such a big reputation that they come thinking it is going to be nicer that they realized and then expectation hits them in the face and they miss the real secret to this place which is the price and the food.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Crazy spices.
Muy caliente.
Saucy!
BYOB.
Cheap.
Equals Pakwan. Oh yeah, satisfaction guaranteed. Recently came back and while I haven't had a single bad meal here yet, man my last visit was just perfect--long bike ride, cold wet weather, and not well fed at lunch, I was ready to dig in to some serious grub as a reward for all the hard physical labor I'd pulling during the day. The chicken curries always use very coarse dry chicken but the sauces are insanely good and actually go really well with the dry white meat. The lamb curries are just naughty, and man do they pack a punch; I think a crowd pleaser has been a lamb curry, the Saag Gosht.
And, even if you're not a vegetarian, it's easy to still love the chickpea extravaganza, Chana Masala. Pleasant surprise was the Paneer Tikka Masala; their Tikka Masala sauce is already brilliant on it's own, but combined with Paneer cheese... wow.
Finish it off with a Biryani (recommend the Chicken) and a pile of hot garlic Nan and we are in business. For a table of six, we split a:
* Chana Masala; dude, you just can't go wrong with this dish
* Paneer Tikka Masala, creamy goodness
* Chicken Achar, pretty spicy, beware of fire
* some other Chicken curry... I'll call you
* Saag Gosht, not the prettiest but possibly the tastiest
* Bhuna, oh baby bring it
* Chicken Biryani; a little buttery, some potato and plenty of tasty rice
* a crap load of naan
* our own mixed bag of Heinekens and Coronas (thanks Andrew H.!)
The bill? Between us all, it all came to about $12 per person including tax and tip. And trust me--we were busting at the seams. So much for working out! Can't wait to do that again.
Pakwan, my intense food coma thanks you.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Freakin' Pakwan, I love you.  Gets crowded (but in a good way) and is cash only, so bring cash and good company!

Daal is spicy and flavorful, naan is freshly made.  Rice=amazing.  My bf and I go there almost weekly.
author: Lolee B.

description:
late night, cheap, tasty, spicy, chicken tikki masala

cash only, no service, just take a number and pick it up.

simple, cheap, good.
author: Dora F.

description: The food here is absolutely delicious! Try the chicken tikka masala, the sag paneer, the eggplant, and the naan. Minus one star for not accepting credit cards, but I'm giving that star back because this place is BYOB with no corkage fee! (And there is a spirits store directly across the street.)
author: P U.

description:
Adjectives that come to mind: noisy, smelly, slow, tasteless, greasy.
Verbs that come to mind: waiting, standing, waiting, aching, sicking.
author: Caitlin A.

description:
A tad greasy, sometimes.  Loud, often.  The rice can be clumpy too.

But it's fast, cheap, and good.  You can feel comfortable eating alone here, or when you bring a group, try their pretty large assortment of dishes. 

Simply, a great non-burrito place in the Burrito District.
author: Philip H.

description: Service is non -existence but the compensates for everything it lacks. The nans are to die for. The curries are mouth watering.
author: Chandrashekar V.

description: very nice casual spot for indian grub!  You order at the counter.  But everything is soooo tasty!  Tikka masala, goooood!
author: Peter M.

description: Ok, I relent. It's not *always* bad. I had a good meal there recently. But inconsistency doesn't help their rating.
author: Albie L.

description:
I used to say I couldn't understand why someone would write a review for a place that already has 520 reviews.  Now, I know.  

I just had to say, this place has changed.
The food is hit or miss.  I used to think it was consistantly good, not great, but good.  Now, one time good, next not so much.
They seem to be hard hit by either the downturn in the economy or the myriad freeks of the mission, with the new charges for tea.  It's no longer free with your meal, now $1 a cup.  and such.
Still good naan nearly ever time, light and fluffy, and yet filling.  Yum.

Like others have said, the staff leaves something to be desired in the area of customer service and friendliness.  I just don't have time for cranky attitude from the counter boy! 

 :(

and yet, with all the options for Indian/Pakistani in the city and even in the neighborhood, I'll either skip the nightmarish parking, or go to one of the others in the area from now on.
author: Mom Of Three L.

description: Pakwan is a hole in the wall kind of place. This is what I have heard about it since I've  never visited it. We normally get the food delivered. Their Goat Biryaani is to die for, it's very authentic. I personally don't like any of their curries except Chicken Karahi, the reason is the amount of oil I see in their curries. It's too greasy. I would highly recommend this place for Biryaani.
author: Xen X.

description: I love this place so much. I came here all the time when I was unemployed, but these days I only make it over there about once a month. The food is consistently awesome, it's really inexpensive and I love that they let you bring in booze. Once you got there two or three times, the manager (owner? I'm not sure) will remember you and go out of his way to thank you for coming in.
author: Aero F.

description: The vegetarian samosas are delicious and the naan is fluffy and hot.  You need to get your own plates, cups, utensils, and water, so it's not a place to go and get pampered.  Great place for some tasty food at a reasonable price in a low key environment.
author: Amber T.

description:
Nice little hole in the wall place.

Decent food, have definitely had worse, but for the price it was totally worth it.

Not the friendliest of places, but I guess they are there to sell you cheap food and not smoke and mirror you with a wait staff.

This place is awesome if you are pressed for time, they always seem to push orders fast.
author: Joaquin S.

description: One of my favorite Indian places in the city. If you factor in cost, this is THE best Indian restaurant in the city. I really don't know what anything other than the Chicken Achar, Chicken Chole, or Baingan Bharta tastes like; these are so good, I can never get myself to try anything else. I always order these with Nan. Sometimes, if I'm feeling really crazy, I'll get the Garlic Nan instead of the plain. Saucy dishes like these must be eaten with Nan.
author: Bib G.

description:
i have had almost everything on the menu and it is mostly good. i did have chicken tikka masala the other day and it had what tasted like way too much lemon. i'm not sure if lemon is part of the recipe but that is what it tasted like. but other times i had the same dish and it was fine. so they can be inconsistent at worst. it is cheap eating and it wasn't that bad. 

chicken achar, achar gosht are rocking good. lamb seekh kabab might have a bit too much salt for me to love it to pieces but i order it time and time again. it's only $1.99. 

the guys here can be hit or miss on the friendly scale. mostly on the miss side. whatever. when i go with my wife though they always seem to be nice. whatever. okay looking at the takeout menu in front of me i see a few items i haven't had so i haven't tried most of the menu. but close.
author: roger b.

description: Ya' good food, decent portions for the price. BUT the RUDE people it t'aint the savings of a buck or two for a dish of food. It is not just the clientele that is rude, but the staff is too. Just down the street is a relatively like restaurant where service is that much more tolerable. The patrons tend not to be the nouveau cheap 'trendy' San Franciscan gentrification types...
author: cs g.

description: The best hole in the wall Indian restaurant in the mission. My only complaint is, I my clothes need to be washed immediately after leaving there because I end up reeking like Pakwan. Aside from that, the chicken tikka masala is fantastic and it's BOYB!
author: Ben E.

description: Chicken Tiki masala, rice & naan - you can't beat it for the price, always consistent & friendly service.  Yum
author: stephanie ..

description:
take into consideration:

1. the food was tasty, scumptious nan (perfectly crispy but still moist), the saag goshst was incredibly tender, the tikka masala was wonderfully spiced and aromatic with firm chunks of paneer and the lassi was thick and sweet. 

2. no waiters/waitresses, cafeteria style. beneficial because it saves them money and in turn your delicious MEAL FOR TWO IS UNDER $20. 

3. BYOB, but thats easy in the mission.

ah but that last empty star! and alas, it is the menu. while everything on it is wonderful, you will not expand your pakistani food repertoire and your tongue will not entirely revel in newly found tastes.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
ah what greater bliss than rubbing elbows with the best of friends as you sink your fingers into greasy curried heaven?

pakwan is cheap, consistently good, and it's BYOB (yay for blue moon from k&h across the street!).  i'm a big fan of their chicken tikka masala and the garlic naan.  i had some beef curry once that i disliked (spicy but flavorless).

last night, my friends and i worked on smoothening indo-paki relations (arbitrated by an irishwoman), also sampled the bengan bhartha (eggplant) and the chicken biryani. i was so enamored of my chicken tikka that i forgot to sample the eggplant but the biryani was excellent.

oh, i had the gulab jamun from the hallway fridge once and that was rather grainy and not very good, but hell, gulab jamun is gulab jamun!!

all in all a gritty but fulfilling dining experience that probably deserves four stars but gets the extra 5th for being just a couple blocks away!
author: Roshni R.

description: You know I really didn't care much for the food at Pakwan, but it's so damn conveniently located, and the fact that it's BYOB pretty much necessitates at least 3 stars.  Which is exactly how many I'll give it.
author: Oliver N.

description: I am struggling with my review on this place as I have been here a couple of times in the past when they were better, but here goes: The restaurant atmosphere overall is ok for simple Indian food. Awhile back, their food seemed alright as it was flavorful and full of spice but nowadays, that's all gone. When I once went in my mom and dad had intially ordered 3 dishes for lunch but the waiter repeated what we ordered and turns out he wrote 2 extra dishes we didn't want and so he gave us attitude and we took the food togo as we refused to give them tip and also refused to eat a poorly serviced establishment. When you go to Pakwan, make sure you take extra time and clearly know what you want before ordering and not leave it to the staff.
author: Alex C.

description:
Where solid cuisine and low prices perfectly intersect.

One in a dozen visits you might get a shred of courtesy from the staff.  One in twenty visits they might actually make a comment or gesture that qualifies as friendly.  Even though the notion of service is absolutely absent the food is very good, every time.

As I am one to critique, this definitely isn't health food.  It is definitely some of the heavier indian/pakistani food that I have had.  The greasiness floats to the top, BUT, even though the food has this quality it doesn't detract at all from the experience.  There are definitely those places where the fattiness of the food can ruin it (I remember an Indian place in Berkeley I ate at years ago), but not Pakwan.

I have eaten almost everything on the menu and each has its own delicious quality.  I suppose if I had to pick a favorite it would be Chicken Saag, but most often I eat the Keema Naan (naan stuffed with spiced ground beef) as a snack.  Oh, the rice pudding and Mango Lassi are the best I have had in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Christopher W.

description: Mmm, cheap, greasy, tasty Indian/Pakistani food in the Mission, just a block away from BART.  They don't have the widest selection of entrees or the highest promise of cleanliness, but their stuff tastes good and is served in generous portions, usually pretty quickly.
author: Leena K.

description:
Perfect for take out.  I showed just after Noon and ordered veg. samosas, naan (bread), chana masala (chickpeas in spices), saag daal (lentils with spinach), and chawal (rice) for me, my boyfriend, and my unborn baby.  All that food for under $20!  It was perfect...

The cashier was very nice... smiled a lot, and I could see the containers of fresh spices right near the griddle.  The food smelled great cooking.  I could see that those who ate in had to bus their own tables, and there was a big refrigerator for customers to grab their manga lassi, as well as any additional sauces they might want ...but they seemed to rotate them regularly, so as not to spoil them.  I appreciated that.

My food was ready very quickly, neatly in one to-go back.  It made my mouth water all the way home.

We had to eat it slowly because of how spicy it was - but spicy's what it's about! (I can't eat as much spicy these days because of the pregnancy).  We both had tummy aches later - but it was from the spiceness rather than staleness.  In other words, the food was FRESH and not stale at all, plus it was still piping hot.

Both the chana masala and the saag daal were delicious.  You could pop the cumin seeds between your teeth when you ate the saag daal.  I'd been worried that something with spinach would be bland - hah, it was rich and yummy!!  I'd get both of them again.  The RICE was FABULOUS!!!  Perfectly and flavorfully seasoned, with occasional orange grains.  The naan was perfect for dipping - light and fluffy and absorbed all the flavors.

The samosas were NUMMY.  Too bad I had to share. :-(

The only drawback was the thick layer of ghee that accumulated on the top of the chana masala - but as far as I'm concerned, it made it taste even better!

And the whole thing made a perfect leftovers meal later. :-)


Why one star short of five?  Probably because for some reason, I wish I'd gotten something with more veggies.  The samosas had yummy peas and potatoes, but I always crave lots of veggies with a meal... Definitely would go back.
author: Yvea E.

description:
they get one star for having food that is fast and tastes alright. another star for letting us bring in our own beers. even though that should lose a star for them not having any of their own beer.

but seriously...when our food is ready is it easier to bring the food to the table? or is it easier to walk over to our table to tell us our food is ready and then expect us to go and pick it up and carry it to our table? UBER FAIL.

and the dude behind the counter acts as if he hates all the customers. seriously? oh, i'm sorry.. i thought i was giving you my hard-earned money.. oh wait, I AM! you should at least act as if you'd give me the time of day and look at me when you talk to me.

the samosas tasted like grease. the chicken korma looked like it was picked up off the street (good thing we also ordered two other dishes). and the service blew, but i mentioned that already.

here's the only thing going for this joint: it's cheap and fast. but if you want good food, don't come here. yeah, it's popular, but that doesn't make it good.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: It's true, Pakwan is not exactly a good place to take a date. But you can't beat the food there. Great no frills, inexpensive Indian/Pakistani food served in a café style environment. It isn't a total hole in the wall, I've been to worse places in that respect. But it is loud, not the best acoustics. It's a combo of the IKEA cafeteria and a coffee shop. They take your order, give you a number, you sit down and grab your own utensils, napkins, glass and water. Then they call your number. Efficient and yummy.
author: Chy L.

description:
I tried this place a couple of times before writing a review only because I didn't want to be unduly swayed by my good first experience.

I will definitely go back.  Pakwan serves good, solid Indian-Pakistani food at very reasonable prices.  No, this isn't the place for a date or a quiet business lunch or to impress someone, but Pakwan does feed you well.

The first time I visited I tried a tandoori chicken breast with naan.  The chicken was better than most tandoori chicken, and the naan is served freshly made, very nice.  

The second time I tried a lamb skewer with naan.  This was also excellent--different meats, different flavors, but excellent both times.

They also have in the self-service refrigerator two sauces: a green and a red.  The red is sweet and reminded me of barbecue sauce without the smokiness.  The green is pleasant and piquant.

If the place were a little bit nicer and quieter, I'd probably give it five stars.
author: Richard C.

description: You definitely want to try Pakwan if you're in the Mission. Location is key --- close to BART and Roxie theatre. Parking is a problem. Food was much better than your usual "Naan and Curry" outfit. In case you're new to the experience, Pakwan operates in much the same manner as Naan and Curry in the city --- a hybrid of take-out & eat-in restaurant.  You place your order and setup your own table (plates, utensils, napkins etc) from a central storage area.  You also serve your own drinks. There are pitchers of water in the fridge. Your food arrives based on your order #, you pickup the food and take to your own table to eat.  You eat the delicious food stopping every now and then to say, "fuck, this is spicy" (or not spicy enough) as you gulp cold water and continue enjoying your food.
author: ITesh J.

description: Pakwan is really affordable and delicious. a great indian restaurant for a casual dinner, you order and pick up your food at the counter and its byob which is really nice to save a dime. the chicken tikka masala with plain nan was awesome and i enjoyed nibbling on my friends chicken cholay garbanzo beans. every dish i saw go by looked and smelt very good.
author: Barbara C.

description:
My god.  I avoided this place for YEARS.  I've never been one to crave Pakistani Indian food so I never bothered to check this place out.
Even when I was dating a dude who swore that this was the best food in the Mission, I still never went.
Until this morning. 
The same dude and I were wandering the Mission trying to decide on what we were going to have for breakfast/lunch/our first meal of the day.  First we were going to go to the Phoenix, but it was really crowded and we were ignored for a good 10 minutes.  Then we were going to go to Red Balloon, and then Frijtz, until he decided that we should finally try Pakwan.
I was down.  And I am now a fan.
For $32, we seriously got a TON of food.  Since I'm not skilled in the art of ordering Pakistani/Indian food, I let homeboy order and regrettably, I have no idea what the delicious dishes we had were called.  All I know is that shit was delicious, shit was cheap, and that I'll DEFINITELY be back and hopefully with someone that knows what they're ordering.
author: Meh M.

description:
tasty indian dive.

fyi it's cash only.
author: Greg D.

description: We eat here at least once a week. Rarely eat Indian elsewhere anymore. Bengan Bharta, and all chicken dishes are best. Lamb dishes are too oily, but still great. CHEAP- most dishes are $4.5-6.5. Rice and Naan are $1.5 each, but free chai, water, tamarind & mint chutney. Why can't the rest of Mission be this cheap?
author: Stephen H.

description: I don't understand this place. Aside from being really, really good and super cheap...it was a massive amount of food. I was forcing myself to finish it...and I failed. Will keep going here.
author: Alex R.

description: I come here for affordable, tasty food.  I usually go for the chicken tikka masala with garlic naan and a mango lassi.  If you don't eat meat, the samosas are really good.  *drool drool*  mmm...  It's usually more crowded at night and on the weekends.  If you want easier seating with less of a wait, I would recommend going during a weekday.
author: Pirate M.

description: This place isn't at the apex of Indian/Pakistani food and doesn't pretend to be.  Mostly it seems like it's good for takeout on a lazy weeknight or a repspite from the 16th Street drunk experience (you can BYOB from the liquor store across the street).   A lot of the entrees are hit and miss...I've been unlucky whenever I've strayed from the chicken tikka/tandor staples, but those are at least always consistent and quick.
author: Brandon B.

description:
cheap indian/pakistani food... tasty and satisfying if that's what you're craving while you're in the neighborhood...
it's self service.  grab a menu.  order at the cashier, pay.  get silverware, beverage and sit down until they call out your number.  go and pick up your order and enjoy...
or of course you can take it to go as well...
author: charlotte s.

description:
This place gets a ho-hum rating.

My coworker reacted with shock when I told her I'd never been to Pakwan, so I decided to give it a try.  I'm not sure what the fuss was about.  The food was pretty good but nothing special, with a high grease-to-flavor ratio.  

Inexpensive, yes, but certainly not the only place in the neighborhood to get a cheap bite.  I might stop in again for a takeout-on-the-way-home-from-BART dinner, but won't go out of the way for it.
author: Caroline O.

description: Good, cheap, cafeteria style food.  Sometimes I miss the pasta joint that was here before, but this is a good go-to place if you're in the 'hood.
author: Andi T.

description: Ugh. Are you people kidding me? This was the worst Indian food I've ever had. The samosas tasted like chicken gravy. The mango lassi made me gag. Never ever going back to this place again. Even if someone else is paying. That says a lot because I'm cheap.
author: Paul W.

description: I LOOOOVEE Pakwan! I have never dined in, but I always order to-go. Once I mention my name, they practically have my order memorized, (I vary it sometimes). They have a menu that accommodates all diets (Vegetarians included), which is perfect for me! They have my order ready within 15 minutes and they always provide service with a smile. I have never waited more than 5 minutes in line even on their busiest nights. I recommend everything on their Vegetarian Menu (their Saag Daal and Daal Chana is to die for!) They're Tandoori Fish is perfectly seasoned and tender, DELICIOUS! My friend (who eats meat) highly recommends the Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Korma, Seekh Kabab, and Bihari Kabab. Their prices are EXCELLENT and can't be beat. Always top off your meal with their smooth, thick Mango Lassi, you won't regret it.
author: Emjay D.

description: Food is very good and the location is great since it's in the heart of the Mission.  The saag paneer was thick and creamy which is just how I like it.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
I am actually on my way out the door for lunch at Pakwan, and just happened to read the latest Yelp reviews disparaging the place because of the sheep carcass parade. I sort of want to tell these people to get a life, grow up, etc. Actually, I am telling them to. If you are going to be a meat-eater, you need to get over the fact that something has to do die in a probobly gruesome manner to put that meat on your plate for a price that you are willing to pay. I realize that as Americans we are sheltered and for most of us the rarest meat we ever have to encounter comes saran-wrapped in nicely portioned colorful containers at our local grocer. Meat comes from a living thing, and it is not pretty when it is butchered for your consumption. If you have a problem with that, become a vegetarian, don't tarnish the reputation of an enthnic resteraunt whose owners come from countriers where these carcasses would usually be sold on the side of the street. I highly doubt it was unsanitary to carry it through the front door. I love Pakwan because it has none of the annoying hipster fake ethnic/I'm so cool qualities that permeate most places in the Mission. It is just a really awesome place with solid food.

That said, I love this place for the prices, (dinner for two for less than $15!), speedy service, super-nice owner (we are constantly forgetting cash, and he always lets us pay next time), BYOB, fluffy n'aan, and the kick-ass chicken tikki masala. I went to the hallowed DOSA the other day and couldn't believe that I paid 4 times as much for bland food in a stuck-up atmosphere instead of going to my beloved Pak. But don't go there if you are a sheltered stupid American, I will take your table.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
been wanting to try this place forevah--and finally did. it was just a little disappointing. but if you want cheap indian/pakistani food you can't really go wrong if you know what to order. 

i didn't really mind that it was not so clean, or that you have to get your own water & silverware and go up to the counter to order. so let's just be clear that i'm docking stars for dry ass chicken in both chicken dishes we ordered--both the tikka masala and the chicken biryani. i'm sorry guys, there's just no excuse for dried out bird. 

however, i really liked the two veggies--the saag paneer had chunky spinach that had great texture and flavor, and the eggplant was delish, tho pureed, wasn't expecting that but it was perfect for scooping with the naan. also the lamb curry was a hit. everything coulda had a li more kick, but maybe you have to ask for it that way. i'll try that next time. 

it's byob, so have at it. just stay away from the chicken.
author: rachel p.

description: One of the worst Indian restaurants I have been to. It's surprising how one can go wrong in spite of using so much oil/butter/cream.
author: Divya R.

description: I have to try really hard not to come in here multiple times a week with a 40 from across the street
author: Alexandra G.

description:
the naan was hard and dried.  worst naan ever.
the lamb biryani was pretty much tasteless, except for the few lamb pieces.
the chicken tikka masala had terribly dried chicken, but tasted okay.
the guy at the counter was also very rude and yelled at me for taking so long to pick up my food.  give me a break.  why does it matter to you?
author: H. L.

description: toasty, roasty, thick 'n' moist nan....loose platters of rice....flavorful chunks of sauced chicken....tasting great 'n' sauce great for dippin'....light spicy curry kick to each meal....lambs tender 'n' fabulous....pakwan salting more than norm, but great dishes to balance out with nan 'n' wrappin'....counter order 'n' pick up or at time delivered...meal under $ten per person...fillin' and fulfillin' for patrons....but, thinking tenderloin location best...
author: Hen A.

description: I enjoyed Pakwan thoroughly. The food is flavorful, when I asked for really spicy, they gave me pretty spicy (which is more than most places), and everything tasted rather fresh. The amount of ghee in their dishes is astounding. I found myself draining out the oil, it was so oily. Leftovers still taste great reheated in the oven, and for the price, it's hard to beat. The variety wasn't as bountiful as I had hoped, but I must say that the Tikka Masala, Sabzi, and Bengan Bhartha with an order of Jasmine rice were all a satisfying meal with tons of leftovers, split between two people (the bill was something like $22, and it served 6+ filling meals). I have a ways to go in my hunt for best Indian in San Francisco, but Pakwan is a great place to stop for a bite along the journey.
author: Shannon F.

description: A little grungy on the inside, but it's all part of it's charm. Really excellent chicken saag and great garlic naan makes this one of my favorites in the city. Alcoholic like me? Run across the street and grab some beer and bring it in. Leaves you feeling all warm and spicy.
author: Michael E.

description: Undeniably one of the best reasons to live in the Mission.  Consistently good, cheap Pakistani, and last time I went their only flaw was absent -- the weird cashier.
author: Katherine W.

description: I'm not a big fan of Indian food but after trying there Chicken Tikka Masala... and the Naan bread WOW.. yummy its so good descent portions, and inexpensive... definitely coming back!
author: Shirl C.

description: Yum, yum, yum!  Headed over here with a big crowd (12 deep), as our out of towner family members wanted Indian.  Recommended by my cousin in-law, we all met in the Mission, and had a whole row of tables smacked together.  This place was awesome, like most Naan-n-Curry type restaurants.  You place your order at the counter, take a number, and they announce over the PA system and flatscreen tv that your order is up.  Pick up your order from the open kitchen counter, and enjoy hot fluffy pieces of garlic or potato naan, hot samosas, lamb biryani (my fave), chicken tikka masala (a group fave), raita, and squeeze the yummy sweet (tamarind?) and green spicy (cilantro?) dips.  umm umm umm!  All the yumminess in that order was $30, and fed 4-5 of us.  Everyone ordered for themselves, paid they're own way, but our whole order was ready at the same time.  Genius.  Definitely the place to go, before or after hanging out club/bar hopping in the hood....  Oh, and the BIGGEST PLUS?  BYOB!  SCORE!  Cousin in-law got a case of red stripes for the table  So why 4 stars though?  I didn't go in myself, but my husband told me to "hold it and wait till we got home" when I said I had to use the bathroom...
author: Jennifer V.

description: Pakwan is a Mission staple. Bring in a forty of OE to wash down the Pakistani spices and a mango lassi to finish the job. The great curries here are inexpensive and delicious and oh so filling. Get ready for some serious belt loosening and an unproductive afternoon.
author: Phil M.

description: I could eat your Paneer Tikka Masala every single day until I died (probably from the grease), I really could.
author: Renee D.

description:
Having lived the majority of my life in South Asia, eating at Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the US is sometimes a traumatizing experience. My expectations have since stabilized to a reasonable level but Pakwan has totally screwed with my mind. My first visit to Pakwan left me pleasantly surprised, and is probably the reason why this isn't a 2 star review. They happen to have Nihari on the menu, which is a dish rarely served by other Indo-Paki restaurants and it happened to be delicious!

The second time I went in, I asked for Ghosht Daal (Daal w/ Lamb), and they said they couldn't make it with meat. I could either have Veg Daal or some kind of meat, not both. It really ticked me off. What I really wanted was the Nihari, but I decided to try something new since the food had been good so far. I ended up ordering the chicken korma instead. It sucked. I was really baked the first time around so now I can't even be sure if the Nihari really tasted that good. 

Verdict: Not going back, but if I need some Nihari, I'll make sure to wait for the munchies.
author: Miq V.

description: The food was good and cheap, but I couldn't get over the cleaniness of this place.  It was just so dirty.  There's this smell of tasty indian food with a combination of dirty dishes and unmoped floors.  Next time, it will be a to go order.
author: hello k.

description:
finally, finally, finally, i made it to pakwan last night.  i have only been meaning to eat here for at least 3 years, somehow though, it just never happens.  i have to say pakwan went way beyond my expectations.  the food was great and had the perfect amount of HEAT which i always appreciate.  we shared three dishes: aloo gobi, saag daal, and paneer tikka masala.  the aloo gobi was great but a little too oily (but I would get it again).  the saag dal was interesting and next time i make my own daal i will try adding spinach.  my favorite was the paneer tikka masala: creamy, yummy sauce, enough spice level to keep my mouth hot - but not overpowering, and enough pieces of paneer to share between three hungry people.  do you know what else i really liked?  you can basically use as much tamarind and green chutney as you want!  it's great (and cheap)!

ps. who cares about the ambiance?
author: Kristie P.

description: Ok atmosphere, but excellent food.  I was apprehensive before ordering, since I had read some mixed reviews on Yelp, but the fish, sag paneer, naan, and rice that we ordered was great!  Usually Indian food leaves my stomach feeling like it fought a war in a fire pit and lost (too spicy), but I felt just fine afterward.
author: Liza W.

description: not much else can be said of this place, but seriously I can't help it! I love the daal saag, and whatever the minty green spicy goodness in the plastic bottle is-it's the best anywhere! I love to cover it in my tasty garlic naan. my friends & i come here pretty much whenever we have a craving for cheap indian food (often!) in the mission. and it's nice that it's bring your own booze :o)
author: Ashleigh S.

description: I crave this place. Nothing says comfort like Pakwan.  Good for takeout, travels well, be sure to grab the green sauce and tamarind sauce to go with everything.  Specials are always good, can be a little rich, but never had poor execution on anything.  BYOB is never bad either.
author: stephen g.

description: Over all, pretty good flavor.  The food looked like a bowel movement and we had to retrieve it from the front counter, instead of having them bring it to us.   I smelled like the restaurant hours after I left, but they were nice and the place was clean.
author: regina k.

description: I eat here every week.  When I die, I want to be buried in a vat of chicken tika masala.  With maybe some chicken boti kebab thrown on top...
author: Scott L.

description:
"i've hit the point where i've found my indian food staple (chicken tikka masala) and can't bring myself to get anything else. ctm+rice+naan = perfect meal for two friends catching up. you know how sometimes places are unpredictable with their sauce? or you get those pieces of chicken that you don't wanna think about because they're hard or chewy or just plain old WRONG? the ctm here is so good, and reliable, and just awesome. also the chai and the naan and the speed and the prices.

the only thing that has always bugged me (and is why they lose a star) is that in the sfweekly or guardian or one of those, the review of pakwan says "and there's a secret garden you can eat in out back!" that's bullshit. there are bathrooms and that's it. is it through the kitchen or something? if anyone knows about this garden, you HAVE to tell me."
author: lauren a.

description:
I consider Pakwan to be the best Pakistani food around. Although I do not know the difference between Indian and Pakistani food, I find this satisfies my need for both. I love the Chicken Makanwala, Saag Paneer, and Reita. Their naan is scrumptious. Prices are cheap! 

The do not serve alcohol, but do support a BYOB option. Conveniently, there is a liquor store across the street. So brown bag your beer, and enjoy the most delicious food.

yum!
author: Alexis K.

description: Good food at a good price.  Great chai, a nice variety of dishes available, and good lamb dishes.
author: Adam Z.

description: I love this place!  Living near many indian restaurants in the haight I don't go to Pakwan as often as I would like.  This week we made the bus ride and man was it worth it!  The best chicken tikka masala and naan bread in the city... hands down!
author: Cynthia B.

description: Heard from my dear friends that this place is bomb! Not only is it in a great location. It's also big, spacious, good prices, and clean. Also i love their BYOB policy. And I definitely love, love the food!
author: Rae R.

description: I love, love, love the chicken tikka masala. I miss it. I dream about it. I almost rented an apartment above Pakwan, and I thought, "How great! I can eat chicken tikka masala all the time!" Then I realized that there are a lot of pigeons around Pakwan, and you don't necessarily want your home to smell like an Indian food restaurant.
author: Liz W.

description: It really is dirty but SLIGHTLY improved . I know too much about their prep practices to go there anymore. SOME of the food is O.K., but just O.K. I agree that some dishes are sweetened up. Shalimar blows this place away even though it is a dirty little nasthole in the loin. One star because the rice was always perfect and one star because the naan is pretty good too. I may be a bitter fuck and all, but most people that work here are dicks or retarded or both. Because of this I don't care to waste time describing anything I may have liked about the place. 2 stars. That's all. Fuck you.
author: Boxxxman J.

description: My buddy insisted we get some Indian food & Pakwan was great! Just a hole-in-the-wall kinda joint but the food was good & the service was fast. I highly recommend the Chicken Korma & the Keema Nan. My friend got garlic nan which was equally good. If you're looking for spicy, they'll have it. If you're like me & just like enough spice to flavor a dish, then you're in luck too!
author: Tom T.

description: Pakwan is crazy wonderful. Especially because all of my old indian favorites have either changed hands and recipes or have begun to serve their portions smaller and on smaller plates with a brand new higher price(although I have not tried Shalymar yet ). I'm a sucker for a nice hot dish of relatively spicy chicken tikka masala, and Pakwan made it happen. Not to mention this place is SUPER inexpensive and is tastier than any other indian place in the neighborhood). Really yummy  basmati rice and double yummy pakora. I really couldn't believe how cheap me and my friend's whole spread came out to be. Woah. Def coming back often. Totally legit. So happy I finally checked this place out.
author: Ruby T.

description: I love this place!  My friend and I go here a few times a month usually.  The food is tasty and cheap.  Nice and spacious.  Unlimited amounts of chai tea that my friend is very happy about.  The best part is that the people running the place are super friendly and good to us.  We tend to just sit around for ages even after we've finished and we never feel rushed.  Kinda like a second delicious home.  :)
author: Kelly L.

description:
ok so my lady friend was trying to impress me with the vittles in her neighborhood so we went to tartine.  after standing in line for five minutes (which i have come to realize is a short line for this place) we were informed that the lunch menu sandwiches would not be available until 11:30.  it was 11:17.  F that very much, we went to pakwan instead.

yelp said it was open at 11am.  it was unlocked and people were working, but they said they did not serve until 11:30.  it was 11:23.  F that but no way was i going back to stand in the tartine line and let those sandwich nazis win.  

we took a seat.  the place was freezing - the front window was wide open.  we waited until 11:32 and were still ignored.  we got up to leave and they pulled out menus and asked us what we wanted.  so we ordered chicken tikka masala, chicken saag, garlic paratha, to go back to her place. 

then we had about 15 minutes to kill before it got made.  first order of the day and all...  we stood outside (since it was the same temperature as the inside) and got to hear a lame sob story from a 40-something super skinny guy in an "alabama state" sweatshirt claiming he was a college student who needed $6 to take the bart to see his dad.  

food is finally ready, hand us the bag, thanks very much.  we get home and realize we were never charged.  ok, not all the way home, but far enough out the door that we were too hungry and annoyed at the wait and then the other wait to go out of our way to return.

food was ok but the leftovers much better the next night.

favorite new restaurant.
author: Will R.

description: Delicious and BYOB - I wish more places would let you (or, rather, expect you) to bring in your favorite beer/wine.
author: J M.

description: The first time my boyfriend took me to this place I thought it was some type of test.  The place looks like a dive, the dishes I'm sure they are clean but they are all scratched and well worn.  I was a little scared for my health, but then there was this fantastic smell in the air.  And when the food came, it was delicious (and cheap).  My two favorite combinations.  Who wants to pay for expensive table settings and eat crap.  If you do, don't come here.  My boyfriend is now my husband and I'm the one suggesting we eat at Pakwan.  Maybe it was a test afterall.
author: Little B.

description: It's edible and cheap but that's about it.  I once ordered a Chicken Tandoori here once and it was raw inside.  They didn't apologize or do anything about it, just gave me a new one.  Pretty gross.  The atmosphere is strange and they don't clean the tables too often.  With all the great other Pakistani/Indian places in the city, why would you go here?  Also, with all the people talking about how the food inspectors found rats here , really scares me.  Go to Rotee in the lower haight, it's awesome.
author: Mitch A.

description: This place is literally as good as it gets.  Where else can you stuff four faces full of food for like $25???  We always order the Chicken Tikka Masala, Chaana Masala, and Saag Paneer (and of course some Naan) and sometimes Samosas.  The food is soooooo good I just don't even know how to put it in words.  If I'm in San Francisco, no matter what, this is the only indian food place I will eat at.  Unless you order 10 different things and have leftovers, this place is an incredible deal!  I just don't even know what else to say - but this place definitely tops my list (next to Oxenrose Salon of course)!!!
author: Candace N.

description: My date was raving and raving about Pakwan, so we went, and it was OK.. nothing special, nothing WOW, and dirty looking.  He had no cash so I paid.  Needless to say, we have different tastes.  I like a guy who pays sometimes, and he likes ok Indian food.
author: Moi S.

description: I was visiting a friend in SF and was on our way to Zuni Cafe when we bumped into my sister-in-law and her friend.  They were going to Pakwan; her friend couldn't say enough nice things about it, and it was only a block away.  That was worrisome for me because we were in the Mission district, and most of the restaurants I walked by were a little too hipsterish for my taste.  But was I glad we picked this place to eat instead of Zuni (which I went the following night and was disappointed).  Though they were busy, the scene was much more laid-back.  The prices were very reasonable, and the portions sensible.  We ordered mostly vegetarian dishes, except the fish.  The fish was very tasty and cooked just right!  Definitely would come back next time I'm in SF again.
author: Eric W.

description:
One of mine and my wife's fav's! Very busy at dinner and very good food. Parking can be a challenge as it is in the Mission however; we usually get pretty lucky within 5-15 minutes of driving in circles (same as any place in the city). Simple inside but we go for the food (and prices too!) Addicted to the Lamb Biryiani (probably spelled wrong) and the Aloo Palak. We are stuffed every time we leave and $20 does the job every time. They have several locations. We have only tried two of them. Both had the same food but we prefer the one in the Mission.
Two words.........YUM EEE!
author: Jonathon T.

description: Tikki Tikki tikki.....Love it here. Tasty food and Cheap. The atmosphere is chill. Best part is you can bring your own beverage. I take a wine, sit with a mate and off to the chatter and yummy food.
author: Patricia N.

description:
my friend told me that pakwan was his favorite indian restaurant in the whole city and i *had* to try it. as we walked towards the place, i realized... "oh no, pakwan is the shady looking establishment i walk by on the way to work when i miss the 41 and am forced to tough it out on the 45..."

turns out i was wrong. fast, cheap, aaand delicious?? who knew a restaurant with a "75" score from the environmental health division (reference rick h.) could be so good.
author: Jessica W.

description: Ok, so my review is based on the one dish that I have ordered here for the last three years - the paneer tikka masala. It's creamy and amazing and no matter how busy they are, your food is ready in 10 minutes. The counter dude is always friendly and the prices are completely affordable.
author: Geryon R.

description:
love this place.

i only wish three things:
1. the nan wasn't $2 each.
2. that they would accept credit/debit.
3. that i had a bigger stomach.

(i won't hold the third item against pakwan, though.)

yay pakwan!

and yay that they also have outdoor seating, further allowing the smell of delicious indian to cover the normative aroma of piss and booze that usually characterizes 16th and mission.
author: Tara T.

description: Always good, tasty food at very good prices.  Crazy atmosphere and parking hell, but it always satisfies once I make it there!
author: John R.

description: I love this place. Very good food at great prices. You order at a counter but they bus the tables. It's also BYOB. It gets pretty busy at night, but the food comes out quick. I'm a big fan of the fountain drink machine too.
author: Cassidy K.

description: "Cheap eats hole in the wall" is what describes this place.  Good Indian and Pakistani food for the price.  You can bring alcohol from the liquor store accross the street as many of the customers do (i.e. one time we saw someone come in with a 12-pack). Eating-in is a little loud bec. the cashier yells over the loudspeaker "NUMBER #19, NUMBER #19. Wher z #19"????". Bottom line: good food for the price, takeout please.
author: Kat F.

description: Two blocks from BART, five different Nan's, quick, cheap and tasty.  What's there not to love about this place.  I have lunch here maybe 10 times a year.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: I love it!  My roommates and I go here probably once a week... bring in a bottle of wine... and have a lovely dinner for cheap.
author: Natasha P.

description: Yummy food, I also love how you can bring your own beer! The place is kinda dirty but, I guess you kinda have to look past that.
author: Reed M.

description: Quite simple really. My favorite place in SF so far. Cash only. Get the samosas, paneer tiki masala, garlic naan and bring your own alcohol. There is nothing bad about this place. This place is like, "f*** you, set your own table if you can find one." Sometimes you need to be slapped around a bit. I go home stuffed like a 4-H pig with leftovers for lunch tomorrow. Pakwan, marry me?
author: Liztastic C.

description: OK for the price: service is less than friendly, food was overly oily, and they don't have mango chutney.  Not 4 star quality!
author: Sarah H.

description: While Pakwan never quite reaches a Naan'n'Curry-level deconstruction of the budget Indian dinner mythos, it has a fun time offering up all the joy of a big-budget dinner at Amber India without taking things too seriously. Drinkers will enjoy BYOB.
author: Jacob S.

description:
Vegetarians& non-vegatarians alike can eat together at this authentic Indian Restaurant. Cafeteria style ordering and pickup saves time & money. I have been to Pakistan 4 times and India 7 times and spent considerable time in each country. Pakwan is the real thing. This place does not nickle & dime you. The Chicken Tikka Masala is fresh and delicious. The vegetarian alternative is PANEER Tikka Masala made with tasty cheese cubes instead of Chicken. I'm not vegetarian but this is 
my favorite dish. I get Tadoori chicken breast and dip it in the masala sauce. Their Keema Naan is tops for meat-eaters, The Samosas are delicious served with a small scoop of Garbanza beans (Chana) & w/chutney sauce they are out of this world.
Fresh Rice pudding in a tiny cup really tops off the meal without over-filling. It's aromatic and the best in San Francisco..Only the Vindaloo is too spicy for most of us...The Mango Lassis are soooooo delicious and also unparalleled anywhere west of Delhi and east of Fiji. Women-Alert! This is the place you have been looking for. It's spacious with 2 CLEAN bathrooms and a few sidewalk tables-Always a place to sit even in the busiest of times...Free Milk-Tea served with meals...Just go there and enjoy...a few doors down 16th street from Guerrerro towards Valencia. Say hi to Ali....a great guy with an interesting history....Interesting people congregate here. This is a travelers haven.
Enjoy
author: Tom D.

description: Really good indian food for really cheap, but you can find much better for same price.  Their chicken curry was great but missing something and my fiance's meal was a little dry.  BUT, the servings are huge and it is good.  Mango lasse here was GREAT!  The naan was good, but not the best by any means.  I am MUCH more impressed by an indian/pakistani restaurant I went to the dinner the night before (on an indian food kick right now!)  I will update this posting with the name of that restaurant when I remember it.  But overall, this place has decent indian food in the mission for cheap, which is always a plus.
author: Christina C.

description: I went to Pakwan for lunch the other day.  It was quite yummy and very reasonably priced.  It is a no frills kinda' place, self service, but the food was tasty and as I said, the price was right.  I had the Tandoori Chicken with rice.  I've definitely added Pakwan to my list of lunch places in the Mission.  Yum-Yum!
author: Steph P.

description: I go here for lunch with friends on weekdays.  Cheap, good vegi choices, could never finish the food, end up bring a doggy bag back.   I like the fact that there is a smoke shop next door, it's awesome to grab some smokes after a meal.  I always find great parking! but for some negative folks it's a bitch..  so be ready to drive in circles.
author: Abraham E.

description: This place was one of my first finds when I started using Yelp and it definitely delivered. I'm a big fan of the chicken tikka masala -- my primary test of an Indian/Pakistani restaurant. I also like their dal and samosas. My favorite thing to do is call my order in and pick it up for a cheap, yummy dinner at home.
author: Aaron V.

description: Love this place - great food.  Everything I've had here has been top notch, and at a reasonable price.  The only reason why this didn't get 5 stars in my book is because finding a table can be a major hassle - but the crowds are the price you pay for such good food.  I recommend coming here off hours or on rainy winter nights - in my experience you'll have more breathing room then.
author: Martin S.

description: Tasty and cheap. The reason I give it 3 stars rather than 4 is because of the bizarre experience when we entered. It looked as though you ordered at the counter, so we started to order. I wasn't sure, though, so my companion asked whether we should sit. "Yes!" said the man behind the counter. So we sat. After hanging out for awhile, it became apparent that although we could sit, no food would be forthcoming. So we went back up and ordered. Except that I ordered rice pudding, and when I went to pick it up, there was none. He tried to sell me on gulab jamun (sp?). I said no. He tried again. I said no again. Finally I got my two dollars back. I'd still return the next time I'm in sf, but it was odd.
author: Kimberley D.

description:
I want to die because I am sure this is what heaven would be like. Who cares about the ambiance of the restaurant? When the synapses in your brain are on rapid fire for pleasure you won't remember the color of the walls and the service of the staff. 

So delicious--the only thing to watch out for is over eating. Enjoy!
author: Celeste T.

description: This is hands down the best Indian food in the city. It's not oily, it's cheap as hell, and they let you bring in your own booze.  The Chicken tikka masala is the best I've tasted in any restraunt I've ever been to. In fact the cook gave me the recipe for it once, although mine didnt' turn out quite like his.
author: Srinivas R.

description: Everyone seems to be crazy about Pakwan.  I am not sure what everyone finds to be so meteoric about this place.  After eating the best in London it is hard to not make a comparison and I have to compare Pakwan.  I have tried a wide-array of food there and I don't think it has the flavour that I expect and that I have enjoyed in London or New York restaurants.  I don't go back and I don't like the environment.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: There's better Indian/Pakistani food out there, especially in San Jose and Fremont. Not very flavorful compared to what I have had.
author: Cat D.

description: I really liked this place. It was pretty good in comparison to the Indian food that I have tried in the city and they were really inexpensive. Three of us ate for less than 30 dollars with is unheard of in the city. The only draw back is the self service and the hole in the wall feel of the place, but what can you expect for prices like these. However there is a pretty cool bonus, they let you bring in your own alcoholic beverages to drink with your meal! If you are in the area and want some decent Indian food. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Tyler D.

description: Pakwan pumps their delightful scents into the air so when you walk by you HAVE to go inside. There's no escape, but you will not be disappointed. Always nice and spicey. The only downfall is that the cashier guys are consistantly trying to get into my pants, it's very weird. If you're a single lady, this is a good spot to nab yourself an Indian cashier I guess.
author: Colleen B.

description: The time that I went here, was when I was first introduced to the Pakwan chain.  Since then, I've tried the other Pakwan locations in Fremont and Hayward.  Each one's food taste slightly differently.  Having been to this Pakwan only once, my impression that we were able to find seating easily, and the food was inexpensive for what you're getting in return.  I think I tried the Bengan Bartha and it was tasty.
author: Lloyd C.

description: Staff is not so friendly, and maybe it does look a tad dirty inside, but the food is damn tasty.  As far as price and taste, they're definately a 4 star worthy restaurant.
author: Mary R.

description: Delicious! The only thing I didn't like were the plastic chairs outside. I'm a big fan of patio seating, and their patio seating was looking pretty dismal. Then again, their food was good enough to make me forget the patio seating situation.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Great option in the mission for wholesome food at prices that don't break one's back.

Big plus: bring your own beer or wine.
author: Nena G.

description: I am Pakistani and this is pretty good Pakistani food. The bihari kabob and seekh kabob is really good. I have yet to find good Nihari and this place was no better. The naan was a little soft, but overall I really liked the food for the price. The chicken tikka masala was also good. I will be back. Although, I thought the guys who manage the place were mean to the cute little Mexican bus boy and when I go back I'm going to tip him individually.
author: mazzy s.

description: Yummy pakistani food on a budget.  Cafe style, great food, good prices.  The eggplant is delish.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Maybe it was just a combination of the friends, the delicious aroma, and the alcohol, but I am convinced that I've never put a better tasting samosa into my mouth.
Served with a bit of garbanzo paste (i added some mint & tamarind sauce too!) these things are warm and delicous.
My friend exclaimed "it's like a doughnut!"
which i don't necessarily agree with, aside from the fact that i enjoy the taste of doughnuts, and I also enjoyed the taste of these samosas.

I also had the paneer tikka masala with onion naan and rice as well as a peach cider which I purchased at the liquor store conveniently located across the street (you're allowed to bring your own alcohol.)

everything was a bit spicier than I am used to but SO scrumptious that I didn't mind a bit.
author: Sean R.

description: everything was just OK.  nothing special.  Not really worth the hype unless you are comparing it to all the other places where the food is $5.99.  Sure it's cheap, and it's o.k..  I'd rather have better food for slightly more.
author: Dana C.

description: In my opinion probably one the few decent Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the mission  (Spicy Bite is also good but its too far to walk to). The meat curry dishes are very good. The daal masala I had left a bit to be desired. However, in a pinch Pakwan hits the spot.
author: Ish H.

description: This used to be my favorite Indian place in the city but I have been incredibly disappointed with my last two visits.  I can't help feeling that they've become complacent - my tandori lamb was charred beyond recognition, the curry chicken was dry (and since when are they only using white meat anyway?), and the eggplant was runny.  I'm on the fence about Pakwan, a four+ star place is now dangerously close to two-star territory.
author: Yan G.

description: The staff here is friendly and amiable.  The tandoori fish is out of this world and I highly recommend it, even if you're deathly allergic to seafood.  Some dishes are a little greasy (my only complaint).
author: Laura A.

description: Pakwan is like sex. You might regret it in the morning, but while you're having it, it's the best thing in the world.
author: Mark B.

description: So I heard from my friends, that it BYB, love it!!! I went with a few of my friends and their son, Adam. We just had soda and water this time, but the food was goood. Both of the lamb dishes were yummy.  We were famished and so appreciated it that our foods was ready in less than 5 minutes. Everything was cool, casual vibe, quick quick to order and to get seating. The only thing to watch out is how they charge you. He doesn't really pay much attention. Oh well, we just gave them a bigger tip.
author: karina x.

description: I'm a huge fan of their saag and tikka masala.  Their samosas are also delicious.  It's BYOB so bring it and enjoy.  It's a great way to start your night in the mission.  The prices are unbeatable, so order more than enough and take your time... I mean, wasn't it hard enough to finagle that table anyway?
author: Alex P.

description:
Fantastic food, and the prices make it a steal. There's a reason it's always packed.

Bring your own beer, and order the chicken korma.
author: V C.

description:
excellent indian food that is so cheap because you don't get table service

love the naan and the desserts

watch out for dirty silverware & crowds
author: Eva S.

description:
love me some palak paneer and garlic naan.
it's tasty, cheap, and the kind of place you can sit around chatting over the bottle(s) of wine you brought for as long as you like.
not the best for a hot date, but great for some spicy eats and an evening with a group of friends.
author: b g.

description:
as kathleen w. mentioned, the walls are the same color as the tikka masala.  it's interesting.  in general, i don't eat indian food because it makes me sick.  i think it's the combination of spices that are delicious in my mouth but once in my stomach cause a whole lot of churning.  i give it a try every few months to see if i've developed a tolerance because i like the taste.  last night was one such occasion.  

i had the chicken tikka masala, pretty much the only thing i ever get at indian restaurants, and a veggie samosa.  i tried the veggie samosa after taking a bite of my main course so it didn't really taste like anything.  i don't know if the samosa itself was bland or my taste buds were overwhelmed by the chicken.  i tried a bite of naan and it was dry.  

my stomach was a little weird on the bart ride home but i did not get sick.
author: Seong P.

description:
Ok, as my friend stated, "I'm the real deal" when it comes to Indian food. so listen up!
I luv this place! It was a weekly place for us! I must admit I didn't veer away from a whole lot ... stuck to what was great.. so there could be a lot more to this joint. Wish I still lived there to venture a bit more.
1- chicken boti-- boneless tandoori chicken.. this would be one of my last meals on earth.. give a squeeze of the lime and eat it hot! They must put crack in this because I'm itching just at the idea of eating this..
2- chicken makhanwala... great dish with fresh naan or rice
3- saag ghost-- lamb w/ spinach. Delicious w/ naan or rice!
Appreciate this place! It's great food and dirt cheap!  I wouldn't recc the veggie dishes too much. Go to Indian restaurants for that... Pakistani restaurants thrive on their meat dishes.. lets keep it that way :)  I haven't had better Indian food anywhere in the States.. well, if I had, it cost me 3-4 times more.. 

I wouldn't recc this place for  take home.. it's always better in the store, but freakin yuppies have made this place crowded! Why are you in the mission? Is nothing sacred in SF anymore???
author: H B.

description: I really don't understand all the hype about this place. Sure it's cheap, and it's got that crazy, um, perhaps I'm in a crazy third world country restaurant ambiance thing going on (i.e. dirty silverware, loud Indian pop music and multiplicitous odors and scents), but the food is simply not good.  I'm not an expert on Pakistani food by any stretch of the imagination, but my college roommate was from Karachi, so I'd like to think she taught me a thing or two about her native cuisine. We ordered 4 different dishes and it all tasted the same. No, thanks, next time I'll pass.
author: Suepattra M.

description: Decent northern Indian/Pakistani food (read: they serve lamb, beef, and chicken here). The achar gosht (extra spicy lamb curry) and the bhuna (lamb curry) are pretty good here, but find the naan and the lamb chops lacking. Also, the saag curries don't quite taste right (Naan & Curry's saag dishes are MUCH better). I don't like the fact the the chicken curries are chopped up with the bones in them :(.
author: Sunny Y.

description: Went here tonight for dinner, it was good , super cheap, and quick.  It's cafeteria style, so you order get your own plates, and drinks. It can be quite crowded but they seem to have plenty of tables, or you can always take it to go. They do have a very limited menu, but all the basics are there.
author: JIll H.

description: The owner I think, or older gentleman at the counter is kind of sleazy. I think at one point he asked me to live with him so I can get free food. I contemplated this for a while, hey free rent and free food, but remembered i had awesome roomates in an awesome apartment. sexual advances are nothing compared to their chicken tikka masala and Bengan Bhartha. Sometimes their Naan is burnt though....no good.
author: Christie D.

description:
this is REAL indian food.  the restaurant smells of tandoori smoke and spices- i knew i would enjoy the experience immediately.  sir rathole had already picked his dish(es) days in advance: chicken biryani and chana masala.  i on the other hand was going to give the entire menu a fair look-see before i made my decision.  i decided to go for the lamb curry, and sticking with idea of "you can tell the quality of a taco shop by it's carne asada", so goes for tandoori chicken at an indian restaurant.  i shit you not, the best tandoori chicken i've had at any point in my life.  it may have been the best chicken i've had, period!  it seriously pisses me off to know i won't find anything as comparable down south in san diego.  top that off with a side of saffron rice and two naan, and you call that dinner.

...go next door to andalu for fried mac 'n cheese and tartare tacos, and you call it dinner #1 followed by dinner #2.
author: Sean L.

description:
People already have written so much and I tried this place tonight for the first time.  So let me write about the dishes I had tonight. 

Vegetable Samosa: 3.5 - it's pretty good but not too special either.  

Bhuna Gosht (Lamb Curry) - 4 way better than the same named curry in Shalimar (but Bhuna Gosht at Shalimar is not their best curry), incredible portion of food considering the price.  It's HUGE, I thought only to pay for this chunk of lamb would cost more than the price of the curry...  
But still the flavor with mixture of spices does not beat the Chicken Curry at Shalimar in Tenderloin.  It's a bit less greasier than lamb curries served at Naan'n'Curry and better than N'n'C as well.

Sheekh Kebab - hm, very cheap but nothing really special, I would give 3.5 stars but still I have not found a restaurant that makes this Pakistani/Indian kebab really well in the city.  It's not that hard to make ones.  (I am not talking about Arabic/Greek Kebab here...) 

Naan: 2.5 - it's not bad, but it does not taste like how naan is supposed to taste.  Still naan or Onion Kulcha at Shalimar in Tenderloin is way better.  Their naan tastes like "whatever flat bread", like pita from Safeway or something.  

But overall, it's a great restaurant and I will definitely come back.  Do you know how much I paid for these dishes tonight?  $14.11!
