I went there again and again after that and I found their Saag was pretty good too (but for me still Shalimar is better at making this Spinach Curry dish...)
author: T T.

description: Best Chicken Tika Masala I've ever had. Awesome flavor in all the dishes.  Hand made Naan (oven baked).  Free Tea or bring  your own alcohol!  The parking in the neighborhood is difficult and once in the restaraunt you have to seat yourself.  The bathroom condition is mentionable due to it's sheer scariness/dirtiness.  Pakwan is great for family style eating.  The neighborhood is lively and riddled with bars, Mission Street hipsters and homeless vagabonds.
author: Darkie L.

description: The kitchen can look a little dodgy but the food is super good and the service is fast. Just wish it was closer to my place.
author: James B.

description: 'Cheap eats' is really what this place has going for it.  If you just want good ol' fashioned Indian food with questionable digestive happiness afterwards, this is your place.  Food is hit or miss, sometimes it's da bomb...exactly what you need; and other times...it creates a bomb...if ya know what I mean.
author: Aeon G.

description:
This place is fucking great! As a newbie to SF, I must say that San Franciscans must be very spoiled when it comes to Indian food. These cheap quick Indian places DO NOT exist in LA. If you want good Indian food there, you're paying at least &20 a plate. That said, I have gone on a frenzy of eating at these order-at-the-counter Indian places and this is the tastiest one I've come across. 
For whatever that's worth.
author: AssHa T.

description: Cheap. Good. Spicy. This is as close as you are going to get without going to Pakistan. I really enjoy eating here, never had anything bad, and its very filling. 5 stars for inexpensive this great tasting food is.
author: Mick R.

description: YUM.  I am a huge fan.  Chicken Tikka Masala.  Saag Paneer.  Chick peas.  Holy goodness - and all for $10.  You CANNOT get more flavorful food in SF for these prices.  I am so grateful for Pakwan.
author: Dann H.

description: Best Indian Food I ever ate in my entire life. Every time i roll to this joint i make sure to cop a 40oz to go along with some Chicken Tikamarsala, garlic nan and some rice ummmm shit's the business.! Prices are cheap and food comes out pretty quick if you never ate indian food in your life you should try this place first.
author: jeremy d.

description: Get the lamb biryani.  'Nuff said.  And if you don't like the service or the crowding or the noise or the funky bathroom - go back to Walnut Creek.
author: David S.

description: I was procrastinating on trying this place but i finally went and i am happy! I finally found an Indian restaurant close to my condo and so glad that its around. I love their Lamb Curry and Chicken tikka Marsala. So flavorful, so yummy, and the lamb was cooked perfectly! It reminds me of naan n curry but a lot closer to my hood. I've actually been craving some lamb curry from Pakwan but again i am procrastinating.
author: Lucky M.

description: I had the chicken special, a plate of rice, and a big piece of nan plus a root beer which I refilled all for $12. One of the few places left where two people can sit and eat for less than $20. Plus it's bring your own booze and you can sit outside on a hot night.
author: Julian M.

description: I don't write a lot of reviews, but today I found a earwig in my biryani. It was a shame, because it was really tasty, reasonably priced, and BYOB. Still, I think finding a dead bug in your food is generally a 1-star occurrence. Needless to say, I won't be back.
author: Dan R.

description: This is a great place for curry in the mission. Inexpensive, authentic and also American friendly with lighter options for those who don't like too much spice (which is not me). Good place for groups.
author: Sara W.

description: i come here when i'm craving for some naan and chicken tikki masala. it's sooo good. and so much cleaner than so many places i've been before. naan n curry on irving got nothing on this place. and they open late. my top favs is the original and garlic naan, chicke tikki masala, and the chicken bryani (don't think i spelled that right lol) and they have the milk tea too!
author: Lisa M.

description: I don't even like Indian food but damn! This place is good. I don't usually eat lamb because I'm not fond of anything even remotely gamey, but their Lamb Biryani was amazing. I also loved the Tandoori Chicken. Washed it all down with sweet and yummy chai tea. I will definitely be back!
author: Sushi S.

description: Doesn't have the drizzle and grease separation that you see in your Naan & Curry food. But the oily tastes good. And it's clean enough now to have new born babies hanging out. Late night dive for sure for more local flavor.
author: Tanya P.

description: This restaurant doesn't spend much energy on the decor or service, but focuses on the food.  You order at the counter as you walk in the door and then pick up your dishes at the kitchen.  Everything I've gotten so far has been great.  We tried the turnip curry special recently which was tasty, but I think the turnips were either very large or slightly old because they had some fibers in them I hadn't noticed before in other turnip dishes.  Nevertheless the spices were great.  We also ordered an eggplant/tomato/cream dish and ate everything with onion and garlic naan, which was great.  My personal indulgence is the mango lassi which (I tell myself) isn't so bad for you even though it tastes like it's made with heavy cream.  The food is very moderately priced and as long as you don't mind grabbing your own dishes and silverware this is a great find.
author: Megan L.

description: this place could stand to be a little cleaner, there are always flies, and the water glasses never seem to be that clean, the food is really good if a little inconsistent. The veg biryani is really great, but better when they include paneer and kinda of plain when they don't. Avoid the vegetable pakoras.
author: Jared Z.

description: Pakwan rocks.  Their Chicken Tikka Masala is better than the others.  Their naan is bigger and less laden with butter (usually that's a good thing - but with naan you draw a fine line).   you order at the counter and get your number.  the food is cheap, fast and very delicious.    the best part?  bring your own 6 pack or bottle of wine and just chit chat the night away.
author: Kate F.

description: The food is good, the prices are right, and you can bring your own booze! This seems like a really great place for a birthday party. It is casual, affordable, and you can bring your own drinks--you could bring a 12 pack of PBR if you wanted, and that just rules!
author: Jamie J.

description: I was introduced recently. I like it. Busy little place but cheap and decent selection of food. Great naan.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Very cheap, quick and tasty. Instead of one of those crazy enormous menus with 30 shrimp dishes they have a limited selection and do it all very well. Have tried most of the menu and have been consistently satisfied.
author: Stuart J.

description: Shalimar used to be my favorite but Pakwan is right up there.  Wish they took credit though since I often don't have cash on me.
author: Gene X.

description: Cheap and yummy = sexy.  The coma to follow is spectacular, therefore I only go on Sundays.
author: Claire C.

description:
Wanting Indian food, Michael and I decided to have dinner at Pakwan last night, a divey Indian/Pakistani joint in the Mission. The prospect of cheap Na'an and a loose BYOB policy attracted us, and after spending 6 hours looking for parking, we grabbed a liquor store bottle of screw top Chardonnay and got in line. At Pakwan, one's forced to fight for a menu, pushing your way though a line of hipsters and finally ordering at a counter as a impatient moustached gentleman in food stained clothing angrily asks, "You like spicy?!?!"
"Uh, yeah. Do we like spicy? I don't know. Do you want spicy? Me? I like spicy. You? Okay, okay, we want spicy. Jeez."
We found a table covered in filth, grabbed two opaque glasses from the shelf, unscrewed our wine and settled in. The place was hopping, as it usually is, filled with a mix of dreadlocked hippies, Mission hipsters and the dreaded Free-Tibet yuppies. You know these people. They're the kind of people that drive new Volkswagons and pat themselves on the back every time they recycle. These are the people that think they're doing the world a favor by going to Peet's instead of Starbucks. These are the kind of people who go to artsy political movies just so they can mention it at cocktail parties and make the rest of us that went to The Breakup feel like assholes. I hate these people and I assure you, they do not belong in Pakwan.
We sat there, forcing down our wine/brake fluid, anticipating our dollar na'an and fried lentils. All of a sudden, what can only be described as What About Bob comes over to our table. Spotting no empty spots in the tiny restaurant, he asks if we'll be using the "whole table."
"Oh, uh, no. Oh, uh, god. No, sure. Yeah. Sit with us. Uh, yeah. No problem. Really."
Mikey and I look at each other across the table as Bob Wiley settles in, slamming down a carafe of water and arranging his 47 napkins in some sort of scientific order. Over a microphone, stained shirt man calls our number. 
Pakwan is actually great, because for surprisingly little money, you get a ton of food and help yourself to plates and forks and spoons and mysterious sauces in ketchup squeeze bottles. It's kind of like Camp Calcutta.
Forced to fit all 11 plates onto our now tiny table space, we ate in virtual silence, as every word we spoke was clearly and openly providing entertainment for the literature-less Bob. It became so awkward and uncomfortable, we were no longer able to stifle giggles. Bob was oblivious, forcing cauliflower down his gullet with forkfuls of rice. Picking at our food and waiting for some privacy, we watched Bob finish and sit, proudly looking over his plates, breathing heavily. Suddenly, he began to cough. Now, when I say he was coughing, I don't mean he was clearing his throat. I mean, he spent a good 10 minutes sitting there staring into space hacking up a lung like a scene from Outbreak. Michael actually leaned back and uttered, "Oh my god..."
Bob was able to pass whatever object blocked his windpipe and moved on, babystepping out of Pakiwan and onto the streets of San Francisco to no doubt infringe on someone else's space and disperse bacteria onto their Tikka Masala. We exhaled and leaned back into our chairs as he departed, marveling at the perfectly empty and available table behind ours. 
We spoke freely for the rest of our meal and marveled at Bob's brazen behavior. But, it's not like we could hassle him. Because, you know, he's local...
author: Beth S.

description: Granted, the folks at my office will pretty much eat anything, but they've got  good appetites and they know what they like.  Pakwan, they liked.  There were 8 of us at four tables we'd moved together, elbow to elbow, fighting over naan.  Ah, good lunch, especially when the bosses are paying.
author: M. H.

description: Great Indian/Pakistani food for not much cash. Try the chicken tikka masala, garlic nan, and papadum. Don't expect to go out anywhere else after though unless you really want other people to know where you've been by the smell (that sweet, sweet spicy smell...MMMmmm...).
author: Raffy E.

description: Lately one of the only places I feel like eating out is Pakwan.  Nothing feels more like comfort food than a bowl of their saag paneer, a saucer of raita, and a fresh hot nan.  Yum!
author: Tara M.

description: I tried Pakwan because I was craving affordable, Indian takeout one night that wasn't too far from my apartment. After scavenging yelp, I found Pakwan. We ordered two chicken tikka masalas with rice... hard to go wrong with that! It was good... a little oily, and not the best I've had... just ok. It is priced pretty well though, and it's close to my apartment, so I know I'll be back. When I want to eat really great Indian food though, I'll go elsewhere.
author: Bridgette A.

description: Despite much hype and fanfare, I found Pakwan to be fairly mediocre. The chicken saag had a lot of bone and gristle in it, and the chicken wasn't terribly tender. The spinach wasn't creamy enough. The rice was pretty bad too - it was actually kind of cold. I wasn't impressed by the chana masala either. Sure the food was cheap, but so is most of the indian in San Francisco. I vastly prefer Indian Oven.
author: Dana L.

description: Pakwan reminds me of Naan n' Curry, except slightly more chaotic and maybe even cheaper?
author: Richie K.

description:
They Cashier was a Jerk. I asked him some simple questions and he was being really curt. They don't take credit cards which I learned after the cashier told me quite rudely after completely dismissing me. Jerk. 

Okay so after I got cash I came back well...I wanted indian food. Their naan was really good and thier food was well priced. 

This place got busy really quickly at 7 and the line for ordering food was huge. After awhile, we started noticing that everyone had thier own different beers and some table had six packs. So the perks of this place are that you can brink you own beverages...
author: Simran K.

description: The Bengan Bhartha with their hot naan always hits the spot. Mmmm...
author: Evelyn G.

description: Pakwan is my favorite cheap Indian/Pakistani food in San Francisco.  Fast, reliable, and delicious.
author: Susannah R.

description:
pakwan, i love thee as the fish loves water. to live without you is impossible, and unthinkable without tears. oh, the sun appears to shine such the warmer, and the days last as though the grains of time have stopped altogether. 

your beautiful plates of channa masala freeze me in awe. the plentiful flavors of your curry make me weak in the knees. if i could bottle the essence of your naan and rice, heaven would appear nothing less than your very presence. 

oh pakwan...i love you so!
author: Darrell L.

description: I thought this was the most authentic Pakistani food I had in California. The curries are the way they're supposed to be, the tandoori chicken is grilled to perfection and above all the prices were very reasonable. Two thumbs up!
author: Khalid S.

description: This is the best kind of restaurant: plentiful and delicious cheap food in a chill atmosphere. And easy for vegetarians to find options. I especially love that you set up your own table and get your own pitcher of water so that you never go thirsty.
author: Theresa P.

description: I was pretty impressed with the food.  And what's not to love about BYOB?  On par with my standard cheap Indian fair at Naan 'n Chutney in Lower Haight.  However, when I asked for a side of mango chutney, the guy at the counter looked at me like I had three heads.  And not in the way of like "We don't have that", but in the way of  "I have never heard of mango chutney, what the hell is that?".  I don' t know if I have ever been to an Indian/Pakistani place that doesn't have some sort of fruit based chutney.   But perhaps I missed some memo.....
author: Katie M.

description: This place is cheap and delicious.  Nothing pretentious about Pakwan -- just good eats.  Highly recommended!
author: Mike M.

description: I like this place, Food was not that spicy and was full of flavor. One star off for service. The Service was not the best.
author: steve a.

description:
this was my first foray into indian food. and OMG this place got me HOOKED. 

chicken tikka masala. and a piece of naan. and you're set for such a cheap price. omg so good.

you can also go across the street to the liquor store to get some beer....needless to say, i was quite happy and fulfilled. 

one extra +, it didn't make my clothes smell. for all those who swear by naan and curry, i say: try pakwan.
author: Angela H.

description: 3.5 stars.  First time I had Pakistani food.  Got the Saag Gosht and it was pretty good.  Lamb was tender and had good heat, but not too spicy.  Cheap eats and good portions.
author: Derk C.

description: I really like this place.  I'm a big fan of chicken tikka masala (I know, boring!) but they do other dishes well here too.  And it's really cheap.  I recommend the garlic naan if you're a naan person, I myself am more of a rice person (chalk it up to being Asian).  I like this place better than Naan 'n Curry.. feels less fast food-y.  I can't wait until the weather warms up so I can walk here more often!
author: Christie C.

description: I first had a meal at the Mission location in November 2004 and it was cheap and good. It is less hectic than Naan 'n' Curry and the food is  as good, or better, than the best of N'n'C (best N'n'C is the Irving location). The garlic naan was perfectly cooked. We've had the Bangan bharta (eggplant) Pakwan style which was really yummy and the Chicken Masala which isn't my fave dish anyway, but this one was good. The Saag Paneer and Chicken Saag are really great. The mango lassi was thick and delish.
author: Dana B.

description: This place has excellent nann and chicken tikka masala. The price is also very good. It's so cheap. The best part is that you can bring your own beer or wine!
author: Helen L.

description: After a Friday happy hour of heavy drinking, my friend and I crawled into here.  The place has great spicy food... but expect  to wait in line and they only take cash.  A fun date place too!
author: Annabel G.

description: By just strolling by its storefront, you would not expect Pakwan to offer such remarkable Pakistan-Indian food. I was addicted to their food during my entire school library internship and had to come in at least once a week. If you like spicy and affordable.... PAkwan is the place for you. Clean and simple, Pakwan is roomy and is nice for people watching too!
author: Patricia M.

description:
hulamom ate the spiciest vindaloo every day of her pregnancy with me so i feel like i might be genetically disposed to adore indian food.
that said, pakwan is a little slice of heaven.  hulaboy loves the tikka masala but i'm a fan of anything lentil or chickpea.  raita is solid and the naan is tremendous.  to say we go twice a week might be a lie:  sometimes it's three.
(i just wish their palak paneer was better.  sigh.)
author: nic f.

description: THE BEST Indian food in san francisco, HANDS DOWN!!!  This place is the bomb!!  It's so cheap and filling that you cant go wrong.  My all time favorite indian food place in san francisco.  If you wanna try the best tikka masala this is the place to do it.  And this place is open late too, so after you've had a few drinks you can stop by and get your drunk fill!! Great place and I would recommend this to anyone!!
author: christopher h.

description: I love this place! I can't get enough of the green Coriander Sauce and Mango Chutney! I like how they make their own Naan, and makes the whole place smell smoky! Careful though, after 30 minutes in there and you'll start to smell like curry! It's best to eat outside, and people watch!
author: Clarice A.

description: Dive-y,Spicy, Cheap Pakistani and Indian, BYOB: Parking is always an Olympic event in the Mission, but Pakwan is worth it.  You can buy beer across the street at the liquor store and bring it in.  The restaurant is packed with people at all times.  You go in, order at the counter while keeping an eye on tables that are about to open.  You have to grab them yourself.  I personally like to hover above people who are almost done so that they will leave.  :P  The place is great for take-out as well.  The Roxy is half a block away and I have gone there for a foreign film and have brought Pakwan with me.  Eating Chicken Masala, Lamb Biryiani, and Aloo Gobi in the dark while watching the magic of Wong Kar Wat is really a thumbs up in my book.  Especially for under $25.  Loud, flavorful, colorful, spicy, quick, filling and always a good time.
author: Diana L.

description: City-wise, what a bargain. The aloo palak and potato naan were pretty good, but not as spectacular as the Seekh Kabab--wow!
author: Maximillian M.

description: This is one of my favorite Indian food places around in the city beside Chutney's in the Tenderloin.  The food was awesome... very good and cheap.  I am surprised to find such a great gem in this area where there are tons of bars and expensive restaurants around... Perfect place to fill your stomach up before hitting the bars :D  Keep in mind that you need to go up to the counter and order your food.  Then grab napkins, plates, and utensils yourself.  They prepared food, then called out at the counter, you will need to come and pick them up yourself...  But I don't mind doing all that, all I care is good food and I got them from this place.
author: Lily K.

description: I don't even know what I had because a friend ordered but it was chicken something (not tikka masala) and amazing.  Best Indian food I've had in a while and not over priced like most Indian food is.  Cheap naan and great service.  Rice was meh though.
author: Isamarie P.

description: Yes my friend, I have tried all the Indian places in San Francisco and this is the only one that is truly special. The ambience and decor aren't the reason to come here. If you want the best, most authentic North Indian/Pakistani food that you can buy in a restaurant in America, Pakwan on 16th (f*$% the tenderloin location) could very well be it! I can't think of any off the top of my head that I consider much better. Very unique and fun experience unless you can't handle hot food, in which case I feel sad for you and you should go to Applebee's tonight. Actually, no, just go to Pakwan anyway but order your food mild. I always order the same thing here: Garlic Naan, Basmati Rice, Chicken Makhwanwalla (aka butter chicken), Chicken Tikka Masala, and Tandoori Lamb Chops. The lamb chops are still delicious and meaty, but have gotten a bit scrawnier and definitely more expensive in recent years. Anyway, the Saag (spinach)-based dishes are also muy delicioso. Don't forget to grab a bottle from the shop across the street either.
author: Amar M.

description:
One of the best casual Indian places in the city, if not the best.  This is a complete hole in the wall and serves good comfort food at extremely reasonable prices.  The people are nice, especially if you bring an Indian with you.  The food is quick and delicious.  It's even a pretty safe bet for those who don't particularly like Indian food.  Specifically, love the Chicken Tikka Masala (of course), Saag Dal, Garlic Naan, and the specials are usually good too.  

You may have to fight for seating later on weekends, but usually it works out.  Open until 11pm, which is a plus.  BYOB, but you can order and run across the street and your food will be ready when you get back.
author: James L.

description: You stand in line, place your order, and pick up your own food and utensils.  The price is reasonable due to the lack of "restaurant" service.  It was a packed house for dinner.  Nan is good and cheap, $1.  Everything is somewhat spicy, so was not a good choice for children.  Seems like most tables bought their own alcohol as it is not served there.  Don't come here for the decor.
author: N B.

description:
It's been a while since I've been here, and I always remember it being great in the past, but today's experience was barely a 3-star experience.

First off, the dining room was quite smoky from the grill. Oh, well, they have great food, right.

Well, the onion naan wasn't ready until several minutes after the food was, so by the time I got the naan (which they were nice enough to bring to my table) the two dishes I was going to be eating them with were noticeably cooling down. Then it was soft on the inside, as if the cooking had been rushed (because of it not being synched with the rest of the food). So it loses the rest of the points there.

As for the dishes, the Saag Daal (lentils and spinach) it was very tasty but I didn't notice any spinach, only lentils. Still it was, as I said, tasty. So I good my taste needs met but not my balanced meal needs.

The mirch salan (whole chili peppers in a thick red sauce) was probably authentic but not to my liking. My scalp sweats even as I think of it. The pepper was way too hot for me. Even cutting the pepper into pieces and having small pieces with the sauce barely helped. I'm not faulting their rating on this, as I got what was advertised, and it is a pepper's destiny to be spicy, but I was unable to finish it and would not order this dish again. The sauce was very good and went well with the naan.

And it wasn't even burn-the-mouth spicy, it was that flavor note that some hot peppers had which rendered it unpleasant for me.

All in all, I would not be inclined to come back until they (1) get better ventilation and (2) it is not a busy time, so the synchronization problem is less likely to occur.

This review applies only to this specific location.

Edit: As of the next day, my jacket smells of smoke.
author: Charles B.

description: Great, cheap curries. BYOB.  It's packed on a weekend night so know to either call your order in ahead of time or expect to wait for your food and a table. I've only been here one time when it was a hectic night and the food was actually bad (that time, the curries were oversalted and tasted like they hadn't had the right amount of time to simmer). Most of the time it's consistent food that is cheap and delicious.
author: J L.

description: Smells just as good after a week in the kitchen sink as it did the night we brought it home! Seriously mouth watering! And really, I'm the biggest wuss with smells...
author: Tres S.

description: I LOVE this place!! It's uber cheap, BYOB, and there's something to say about a man calling your order over a mic. The food is great, it's a little cramped at  times but fun with large groups of people because you can try one of everything and the meal ends up being like 7 bucks a person. Don't let the man at the counter try to talk you into getting more than you need...and make sure you get the tikka kabob, it is phenomenal.
author: Nicole S.

description: I thought that this restaurant was great.  The indian food was not incredibly spicy, but still good quality.  I had the nan, which was not incredibly flavorful, but still good garlic flavoring and very fresh bread.  The chickpeas were tender and the samosas were also nice.
author: Joanna S.

description: Cheap/fun place to go with friends/and an assorted mix of dishes to choose from. BIG PLUS run across the street to grab a 6 pack to bring in. How can you really complain. This place was open on Xmas day when nothing else was so an extra nod for that. I'm sure with SF there are even better spots than this...(hello we live in the mecca of the most restaurants per square mile)...but Pakwan is worth the try.
author: flo t.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said already... some of the best naan in town, the chicken tikka kabob is *superbulous*, and I can never visit without ordering the chana masala. all that and a beer from the market across the street make for a damn fine meal. Busy busy busy... just take charge and plow in, grab a table as soon as you can. CASH ONLY PEOPLE!
author: Jeremy H.

description: This is what you would get when you go to someone's grandmother's house. Warm and hearty. The atmosphere is ok - self service at the counter and get your own plates. But the food, just fantastic. The nan is out of this world as is the Tandori Chicken. I recently went with 5 friends, ordered like we were hungry and we all walked out of there for $10/person. Someone ran across the street to pick up some beer (its BYOB). Recommendations: Chana Masala, any Nan, Daal, Chicken Tandori, Lamb Kabob (spicy!). I tend to stay away from a lot of the meats...but the Tandori I will vouch for...enjoy!
author: Hilary H.

description: Hard to beat the bang for buck Indian food here (except maybe at Naan and Curry in Inner Sunset).  $10/person gets you chicken tikka masala, chicken saag, raita, mango lassi, and naan (all GREAT!).  It's very casual, order at the cashier, so you can schlep in in everything from your PJs to hooch wear.  And it's right next to all the other bars/restaurants around 16th and Valencia.  Bring your own booze (liquor store is conveniently located directly across the street).
author: Chris P.

description: Pakwan is cheap and awesome.   I had lunch there today - i think the new magament has really improved it.  Great Indian/Pakistani food.  Excellent Naan!
author: Marc B.

description: Cheap and tasty.  Two of my favorite words related to restaurants.  The food is very yummy, and you will leave full for less than $20.00.  I definitely wouldn't recommend use of the bathroom, before, during or after eating though.  Just don't.  A culinary experience if there ever was one, your tummy won't be disappointed.  Your taste buds may be a bit seared from the spicy dishes, but you'll live to talk about it, and come back for more.
author: brenda b.

description:
i hate to talk mess about this place because the staff was amazingly nice but:

i got super sick from the food here and i am hoping i will get up the nerves to try it again someday and figure out it was a fluke.

but the burning pains in my stomach and vomit can't be erased yet.

like i said though, the staff was sincerely amazing and efficient
author: Lauren V.

description: Great chicken tika masala. The vegetarian dishes taste different from each other! Only ok naan. One of the better cheap indian joints
author: J. R.

description:
fast friendly and pretty tasty.

also nice to not drop a dime on a quick and easy meal.

lentils.

don't go if you need to be waited on hand and foot.
go if you like tasty food from the sub continent and naan
author: Chris G.

description:
tasty and cheap. 

plus free chai, as much as you can drink.

what more is there to say?
author: Elle B.

description:
a few months ago, had i been told i'd be reviewing an indian restaurant AND giving it four starts, i would have laughed in your face.  my latest discovery (and if you don't believe me, check my "about me" page...) is that i like SOME indian food.  and pakwan is the reason behind this.

while i like some indian food, i can't imagine spending a lot of money on it.  that is why pakwan is so excellent - it's cheap.  the bill for two of us (and my usual partner in crime eats.  a LOT.  unlike me) is usually less than $20 at pakwan.  and while they don't serve alcohol, you can bring your own with NO corkage fee!  yay.

sadly, they don't take credit cards, so i always have to remember to go to the bank beforehand.  the ATM machine at the liquor store across the street scares me. ;)
author: Karen R.

description: Ok, I eat here about once a week.  I always order the Chicken Tikka Masala with an order of Garlic Naan.  My order is always less than $10 and is ready in less than 10 minutes.  Sure, the ambience leaves something to be desired.  Yes, the portion sizes keep getting smaller and smaller, especially if you have been to their other location.  That said, there's a reason why I come here once a week.  The sauces are so delicious, and the meal can meet any budget.  Sometimes I will grab it to go and either eat it at home, or next door at Double Dutch.
author: Julie B.

description:
i live in the south bay and this place is so good i get random cravings for it and want to drive up to eat.

delicious food, totally reasonable prices, and byob--genius!   it gets a little crowded and loud with a sometimes large mission hipster scene, but for some reason the cafe style of the restaurant and the byob part kind of make me enjoy the noise and overall boisterousness of the scene.  

definitely not a date place or anything like that.  hit it up with a bunch of your friends and a 6-pack after work or after happy hour.   it's can't miss for good indian/pakistani food and there are definitely some misses in san francisco in this area.
author: Lindsey A.

description: Yes, it's greasy. Yes, I've found a rubber band in my food before. But damn, is it good. While I've had much higher quality Indian food, this is my favorite place in the city. My ex and I used to buy several items and split them up, but I started getting an order of chicken tikka masala all for myself - it's just so rich and creamy and I've never found any as good elsewhere. Get yourself some Pakwan take-out, a movie rental and a six-pack, and you'll have the perfect lazy evening.
author: Lorelei D.

description: Had Pakwan for takeout.  The main dishes were pretty good.  The garlic Naan was dry and flavorless.  My lamb dish did not come with rice, which is fine for the price but would have been good to know over the phone.  I'll eat here again, since it's close by and I like Indian food, but it won't be a destination spot.
author: Mike F.

description: Great, quick Indian/Pakistani food. I'm a huge fan of their lentils and nan. I also love that it is BYOB. It can get a little crowded, but I usually take-out, so not a big deal.
author: Carmen C.

description: Pakwan is a great and cheap eats for Indian and Pakastani food.  I have found it too be some of the best food in the city.  Parking is hard in the Mission, so walk if you can.  They only take cash and if you want to have a beer you have to go across the street to the Market to purchase your selection and bring it back...
author: octavia h.

description: The quality of the food here can vary tremendously (don't order the samosa or any of the boney chicken dishes), but you can't argue with the price. Pakwan is cheap, fast and delicious.
author: Glen M.

description:
i crave their chicken tikka masala almost every day. awesomely large portions (i love leftovers). the vindaloo really spicy and not oily, which is always a problem with decent priced indian food. 

the dude at the register is super nice. one time, i didn't have enough cash and he gave me my food for what i had on me ($2 discount) and he always remembers me! or at least is really good at pretending he does. 
whatever, it makes me feel special.
author: Pam Z.

description: Pakwan is a solid, good, cheap Indian restaurant w/pretty kick ass food. Pretty much no atmosphere but when youre payin pennies for great food, make your own damn atmosphere!
author: Inome C.

description:
Is everyone here nuts?
The food here sucks.  I was so excited to try it after hearing so many good things to about it but SO disappointed after trying it.

After ordering and obtaining our dirty dishes to eat off of, we tried: 1) Chicken achar (very bad meat quality, heavy aftertaste of OLD meat) 2) Dahl (mediocre, lacking flavor) 3) Channa (heavy spices, no taste) and naan (decent).  The food at shalimar is much much better.  I'm indian and very picky about my indian food and this isn't even good peoples!!!!

also, whats up with the dollar for chai? it's complimentary at shalimar~
author: Michele Y.

description: Great restaurant -- chill and laid back atmosphere with delicious inexpensive food. The spices were right on the mark with the chicken tikka masala and my friend really enjoyed the aloo palak and chicken tandoori.
author: Melanie T.

description: Best tikka masala in the city.  not to be confused with the nepalese version at Little Nepal that is the best in the state.
author: Simi J.

description: I come here almost every weekend and the food is terrific and fairly cheap.  Get the potatoe naan with chicken tikka masala and palak paneer! Yummm!!  Try the chai tea also.  However, I must admit its kind of dirty in there...The cashier was picking his toe nails out front when I walked up.  He proceeded to go behind the counter and take my order and then sneeze 3 times into his hand.  I dont think he washed his hands and proceeded to cook.  Nasty!!!  :P
author: Steven L.

description: Generous portions, cheap and delicious, particularly the saag paneer.  The chicken tikka masala gravy is consistently yummy, however they tend to overcook the chicken.  This is why I didn't rate them 5 stars.  (Once I bought the orange gravy and took it home to my own chicken.)  Good dal, naan and lamb and rice dish.  Pakwan being located one block from my home makes my loyalty extra easy.
author: Leslie B.

description: Not good. Well, the basmati was fluffy and had good texture but everything else sucked except the BYOB.  The vindaloo was oily and the lamb smelled extra gamy. The naan looked like indian naan but tasted like wonderbread. There were also huge chunks of bone and gristle which totally not cool. Much better alternatives in the mission when the indian hankering comes such Alhamra or the Valencia triumvirate of Dosa, Udupi and Aslams.
author: Andy L.

description: This is hands-down the best Pakistani/Indian food in the city paired with the best price in the city. Plus, the guy who usually is at the register (and might be the owner) always greets me with a smile and remembers what I usually order -- nothing beats friendly customer service. Oh, and by the way, my favorite dishes are the dal and the saag paneer, with some raita and naan on the side. BYOB!
author: Daniela P.

description: For the price, the speedy service, the location, and the quality, I'm a fan.  If I want to order take-out, I always think Pakwan is a good option.
author: joolia f.

description:
I dont eat Indian food all that often, but this place was great.  LOVE the BYOB policy.  Food is great, ordering is simple, and its good for groups.

We went for a bday party and were able to get everyone there with no problem.
author: Richard C.

description: Pretty authentic food, BYOB which saves money, and fast service.  Serving sizes are large, and the lamb is really good.
author: Eric W.

description: I love love the food here.  My favorite dish is the tikka massala but everything else on the menu is yummy too.  The spices are flavorful and not too spicy, I hate when I can't enjoy my meal because it feels like there is a fire in my mouth.  A big plus about this place is that you can bring your own booze, super cool.  Only bad thing is during lunch and dinner time you practically have to fight for a table so be prepared for that.
author: P D.

description: By far the yummiest Indian food I've had in San Francisco. It's not fancy and you won't get served (is cafeteria style ordering), but who gives a shit because the food is delicious, cheap, and you can bring in your own beer from the liquor store across the street. Chicken tikka masala is my favorite here.
author: Rachel B.

description: My favorite Indian/Pakastani in the City.  Yeah, its dirty, and the guys can be a little rude -- but how can I mark them down for such "minor" details when the naan is so stellar, I can drink my 32oz High Life with no shame and dine with my wife for under $20?  Chicken Tikka Mmmmmmmmmasala.
author: Val U.

description: Yeah, it's dirty and kind of a hole in the wall, but the food was great! The naan was one of the best and the prices are low.
author: Vanessa W.

description: Pakwan has spoiled me for other Indian/Pakistani places in the city, especially those that charge 2x more.  Best experienced as takeout.  Highlights include paneer tikka masala, saag dal, samosas, and that incredible fluffy/crispy nan.  However, my absolute favorite item is the mouth-watering, moist and flaky tandoori fish, with cilantro and lemon.  Delicious!  Muttar paneer is also good when it's on the specials board.
author: Esther K.

description: This is one of my favorite Indian restaurants in the City. The chicken masala is some of the best. Gigantic portions at dirt cheap prices.  You have to grab your own tableware and wait for them to call out your order, but if you like good Indian food at reasonable prices, this is the place to try!
author: Eric G.

description: You have to put in some effort to eat here - If you don't mind busing your own table, pulling silverware from an old dresser drawer, and giving dirty looks to the masses as you fight for a dinner table then I'd recommend Pakwan. The food is inexpensive and you can brown bag your favorite alcoholic beverage from the liquor store across the street or from grandpa's secret stash. Go for the food and BYOB - dont mind the decor!
author: BrYan W.

description: Went here to lunch today.  The naan was really yummy.  Light and crisp and not overly chewy.  We had two chicken dishes and the chicken was really dry.  The veggie dishes were yummy but being I'm not a connosieur of Middle Eastern food, I'm reserving judgement until I have eaten a few other places.
author: Chris I.

description:
Great place in general, and the quality of individual dishes is very consistent over time. Their best dishes has ruined my palate for most other Indian places in the US, because they're so tasty. And actually, for average places to eat in India, too--while there are definitely places in India that outshine Pakwan, this place is certainly better than the average eatery in north India.

Unfortunately, some of their dishes verge on mediocre (why doesn't Yelp let you rate individual dishes??). I've found the chicken tikka masala and saag gosht to be quite good, and much better than some other dishes, like the paneer tikka masala, which is inexplicably less flavorful than the chicken version. The biryani isn't as flavorful as I'd like to be either, but maybe that's because I just came back from a trip to India where I had super-fantastic, incredibly tasty biryani. On the other hand, I like their tandoori.

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone within a reasonable distance who wanted Indian take-out--in my experience there is no competition on quality and reliability on their best dishes. I just wish their menu was a little deeper...
author: Jared B.

description: Solid.  For subcontinental grub that runs under $7 an entree, it's unbeatable.  Not only is it cheap, but it's not oily.  and it's clean (note:  this may or may not apply to the bathroom).  I tend to like all of the saag dishes and the tandoori chicken breasts here.  consider this place brown guy approved.
author: Sunil A.

description:
LOvE, LOVE, LOVE Pakwan...

the best place to go for Indian 'fast-food' - the staff is so quck and awesome, the food is just the best for the price...nothing more satisfying than a 10:30pm run to Pakwan...
author: Rollio R.

description: SOOO GOOOOOOD. And it wasn't even expensive. I've only eaten here once but it won't be the last. Can't wait to go again.
author: Pearl M.

description:
It is hard having to go to the south bay or Berkeley everytime I want to get some Indian food! Glad to have found somewhere good and local that tastes like actual Indian food!  

Nan was great as was the palak paneer, some of the chicken dishes, lots of other things, I think the only dish I did not enjoy quite as much was the chana, largely cause it wasnt cooked the way I (or my mom) normally cook it.

BYO is always key as well. I don't particularly recommend dinnertime on Fridays and Saturdays becasue it gets pretty packed - and a larger group would be hard to accomodate.
author: Nors P.

description: Good curries and the such, but don't plan on running any marathons afterward......
author: Ben E.

description:
I love this place! Of course, if you're looking for the best indian, this is not the place to go. This is just one of these place where I go when I fell like eating out after work.
I go there quite a bit, I often take to go, but eating inside is always great. You can feel the life in there! 
For the quality, the price is unbeatable. Service is reliable and quite cool.
Just one of my favorite regular restaurant where I live. So 5 stars, babe! They really deserve it.
author: nick s.

description: Completely overrated mediocre food, go down the street to Al Hamra where it's cheaper, spicier, and where you don't have to pick out the bones fromm the chicken in your curries.
author: michael R.

description: I like shalimar better. This is not bad either.
author: Hash K.

description: Don't expect classy decor, and don't get the food take-out... the trip home gives the half a cup of grease in each dish time to rise to the top. That said, what a great place. Consistently really tasty, really cheap meal. Lamb chops are to die for. Anything on the day's specials menu is bound to be really good. And the channa tastes, well, perfect. And every time I go, the meal, one way or another, seems to cost exactly $9 per person. As long as you have lots of naan to sop up that greasy-delicious sauce, what could be bad?
author: David K.

description:
Okay, okay, okay.  Now I like a little extra something in my food as much as the next person, but a burnt match?  That's just gross.

I was a big fan of Pakwan until a few months ago I was munching on some palak paneer and came across a little stick of some sort in my food.  The food in my mouth, that is.  I thought maybe it was a twig from the spinach so I kind of used my teeth and lips to get all the spinach off.  As I pulled the twig out of my mouth I crunched down on something gritty and gross.  I held the little stick up and a co-worker said, "Is that a used match?" Yes my friends, it was.

Understandably a little weary I didn't go back for a few months, but my co-workers are drawn to Pakwan like moths to a, well, match I guess.  The very next time I ate there I had a big hair in my food.

Sorry folks this ain't baseball - two strikes and you're out in my book. I'll never go back, especially when I can still get good, cheap Indian food less than a block away at Alhamra.
author: Nick H.

description: I love going to this place, it's really good food, outdoor seating, and its BYOB...
author: Stephen B.

description:
You might want to check out their health board score on the Department of Public Health website: the last one was 62. One of the violations: 'adulterated' and 'unwholesome' food.  That, my friends, means they're using food that is rancid and/or adulterated with nasty, illegal, dangerous chemicals.

The last time I ate here, I got sick.  The previous time, I ate here a friend and I both got sick.

At least the 'interesting' places in the Tenderloin have higher health board scores and will actually make the food spicy.
author: Matthew H.

description: Best Indian food I've ever had in Cali. Every dish is consistently good. Like, wow.
author: Miriam S.

description: simple, easy, good, spicy and inexpensive - great food, thanks to my buddies (Tim and Jay) for taking me here
author: Michael E.

description: Very tasty food.  A good variety, served quickly, at reasonable prices.  BYOB (easily purchased across the street) and enjoy!
author: Julie F.

description: I love this place, this and Shalimar are my two fav. Pakistani restaurants  in the city. good puffy fresh nan, Chicken tikka Masala is nice and spicy, their kormas, and keemas are well good too. new to indian food? try their chicken wrap.
author: Isaac D.

description: This is the best place to eat Pakistani food in the San Francisco area.....The atmosphere is chill & it's BYOB....The place is as authentic as it get's with Pakistani food....and trust me with all my travels as a mgmt. consultant I have checked out many Pakistani restaurant all across the US....You will NOT be disappointed & for the quality of food the prices are just amazing! A must for everyone!
author: Mo A.

description:
Truth Revealed: CARDAMOM vs COCKROACH...

First off, Pakwan was/is one of my favorite Indian places. It's hearty, satisfying, and all for a great price. On a particular evening we wanted to introduce Pakwan goodness to our friend who was to join us for dinner, so we picked up some rice, chicken boti, tikka masala, and lentils.  all excellent by the way.  my ravenous bf couldn't wait for our friend to arrive and began shoveling food down his throat.  the next thing i saw, he was holding what looked to be an Indian spice (or so we thought). After a close inspection he was convinced this was a baby cockroach with its antennas, almond shaped body and small feet. Yuck! 

I called Pakwan's, as we had ordered out and explained that my bf found a freakin' roach in his rice!! The man who had taken my order originally over the phone went on about how this was a spice...HA, yeah right buddy! But he agreed to give me my money back, so I packed up the 'roach and headed back to Pakwans for the dreadful confrontation. 

I couldn't believe they did us like that, after all of our customer loyalty! I was so embarrassed to hype them up to my friend and now here I was:  at the scene of the crime giving the Pakwan guy back his cooked 'roach when he replies, "WAIT! I KNOW WHAT THIS IS!" and runs to get something in the back. On his return he opens his palm and states, "This is an Indian spice called CARDAMOM!" He continues to show me a few almond shaped pieces and compares these to the alleged cooked 'roach. YES, the Cardamom had two antenna looking strands coming out of the tip and when you break the spice in the middle it has seeds which resemble the inner body of a 'roach. After further inspection I thought, "Why the hell does a cooked cardamom look like a freakin' cockroach?!". I know... I wanted to believe it was a 'roach because I didn't want to feel stupid but here is the truth; we were wrong and Pakwan's is still a legit place to eat. 

Thank you Mr. Pakwan person for helping to educate me on what cardamom is and how it is used to flavor many indian dishes! 

LESSON LEARNED! (note: I confirmed with my Indian friend that cardamom is a real spice  as I wanted to make sure that Pakwan's wasn't pulling a fast one on us. They weren't of course :)

Eat at Pakwans!
author: Denise C.

description: how the mighty have fallen.  what once was a must have every few weeks for me and my wife has become a joke of an establishment.  the food has clearly veered away from being authentic due to the lack of seasoning and flavor and the increase in spice for the sake of spiciness.  their CTM sauce was held up on a pedestal as a standard to be compared against now tastes like spiced up tomato paste.  service has never been a big thing here but when they fail to mention a dish in not available when you pay for it and forget to tell you, there's something wrong...  the naan from time to time can still be OK but i think pakwan's time is over for me.
author: Swarup B.

description: Worst indian I have had in a while, even the naan was burnt, really don't understand what all the hype is about.
author: Bronwyn B.

description: I was served turkey???? Is this a way of cutting cost and tricking customer? The chicken masala we ordered does not look like chicken the strands of meat are bigger?  Too bad I used to like their food and enjoyed it so much....what happen???
author: freewill m.

description: Yeah! Great food, unpretentious atmosphere, lively - surely some would say too noisy - and I love the BYOB. Great place for a fast, delicious Indian. Get your Baingan Bhartha Pakwan Style!
author: Bob M.

description: I love this place! The food is always excellent and well priced and they have a generous habit of giving away food if there is an ordering snafu and rounding off prices to the nearest dollar.
author: steve g.

description:
Always good! Always satisfies!

I love the butter chicken and beef kebabs! Whenever I have out-of-town guests, I take them here. Casual, relaxed and delicious!
author: Maggie S.

description: this place has delicious food & amazing prices. and it's BYOB! i particularly like all their extra spicy dishes. pakwan is almost a weekly destination.
author: Raja H.

description: Mmmm, just writing about Pakwan makes me crave their delicious Tandoori chicken legs. I have to say they have mastered that dish - it is consistently crisp on the outside, tender on the inside and well flavored throughout. This is not an easy task (I know this from experience) so props to Pakwan for their mastery of tandoori chicken. I love the hubbub inside Pakwan every time I go there, and it's a great place for groups so we often end up here on birthdays with a big bunch of friends. You can BYOB/W, eat delicious biryani, kebabs and curries and sing the happy birthday song to the birthday boy/girl. And then you get to join in when the table next to you starts serenading their birthday boy/girl. It's a great place for the feeling of community, and of course delicious food. Only complaint is that it's HIGH time they started accepting credit cards as payment - c'mon guys, stop being cheap!
author: Abheek G.

description: Simple, affordable and delicious. Again nothing fancy here, if you are looking for great 'nan' and city's best 'chiken tikka masala' , this is your spot. Expect to be covered in curry smell for the rest of the day :-)
author: Resat T.

description: No frills, no decor, counter service only (boys this is not a first date place).  Good for a quick, cheap meal.  I must admit I was a little scared by how cheap the prices were (I think it was the Pac Heights in me).  $5 Chicken Tiki Masala is the equivalent of the 99 cent sushi in Chinatown.
author: AngelaS F.

description: food is really good and pretty cheap.  everything was tasty.  this is a very no-frills type of fare.  there is nothing fancy about it.  service is negligible, but then you never really go to indian restaurants for the service.  the naan is perfect in my opinion.   the chicken tandoori tikka boti is also excellent.  the chicken is nice and juicy and every bite is full of flavor.  the aloo palak is also quite tasty.  the real standout are the samosas, however.  they are big and puffy and crispy on the outside and nice and soft on the inside.  they are not too heavy in texture or in spice.  i feel like i can eat entire plate of them!  i actually knocked the fremont location an entire star simply because of the fact that they dont have samosas on their menu.  all in all, this place did not disappoint.  if you are looking for cheap and delicious pakistani/indian food, this is the place to go in the mission.  my only complaint is the ventilation system in the place.  the entire room is filled with smoke from the tandoori.  you leave their reeking of indian food!  oh well, such is life.
author: Christian C.

description: Very cheap place and the food is great. Usually, I eat indian food and it's very heavy, but this place is good. The place was packed and there were not much service.
author: David G.

description: damn them.  it's good food.  bring your own booze cuz they don't sell any and can care less if you bring some in.  don't expect great service.  well, it's all self serve really. you order, get your tools, serve your drink, they yell out your number, and you pick up. but it really is worth it cuz their food is damn good and cheap.  all your typical curries and breads.  cool vibe too.
author: Adrian N.

description: ooooh, pakwan...i like you!  if it weren't for the parking situation and all those emo kids flocking to you, i would go more often.  you TOTALLY kick naan 'n curry's arse!  i just have one beef....listen, emo kids....people need to navigate this busy restaurant, and it's NOT cool for you to leave your stoopid backpacks on the ground in obvious corridors of foot traffic.  i know you're all indie and emo-ish, and life is so unfair, blah, blah, blah....just have some courtesy for your fellow diners....sheeeesh!
author: Miss P.

description: Pakwan was one of the first restaurants at which I ate when I first moved to San Francisco and remains one of my favorite. I usually order the same thing everytime: paneer tiki masala, garlic naan, vegetable samosas, and a little plate of rice (usually doubled when I bring a friend). Always delish dish. The atmosphere is very San Francisco (I usually don't like to use cities as adjectives but in this case I will make an exception): laid back, hustle bustle voices, bring your own alcohol if you so choose, order and sit down until they call your number, and then feast. If I am with friends, it's all homestyle, just order ten plates and share and laugh. I associate Pakwan with a new city and new friends so I am biased of course but I'm okay with that. I take my friends from out of town here and they love it. Paneer tiki masala is the epitome of comfort food; the feeling of safety and relaxation travels right to my sinuses when I walk through the door.
author: David A.

description: really tasty and inexpensive pakistani place.  long lines make this place a little hectic, but its worth it
author: Steve S.

description: Yay for being open on Thanksgiving Day!!!!!!  We are ordering out for our two person Thanksgiving meal - chicken curry, keema naan, vegetable biriyani. Now THAT's a spread!
author: Nan L.

description: eh...good lamb shank dish, chewy, fluffier na'an (love the potato na'an), but overall sub-par. i know everyone loves this place, but much prefer Naan N' Curry over this (pretty much comparable- get your own dishes, plates, water, order first and sit down), but the curry at Naan N' Curry is much tastier, with more spices in my opinion. prices are decent. I think they renovated this place, altho the last time i was there was YEARS ago and it looked way different. i think its "cleaner" looking now.
author: Miss Lili F.

description: i have eaten here once, and found it disgusting. the actual restaurant doesn't  quite feel clean and the food wasn't that good, however, i went with someone that loves it. i wasn't going to yelp my dissatisfaction, but my roommate reheated her leftovers last night, stirred them in the pot and found a humongous COCKROACH in HER CURRY!
author: Michelle M.

description: Love this place. Lamb biryani, chicken tikka masala, tandoori fish and the best naan around. Cheap, fast, and very tasty.
author: Nithin R.

description: I love this place.  Clean, cheap, fast, and hot.  The Tikka Masala is among the best in the city, and the Naan is always hot and fresh.  Not to mention, the water is actually cold, unlike every Naan N' Curry I've been to.
author: Corey Y.

description: This place did not hit the spot to satisfy my Indian food craving.   We had chicken tikki masala, 2 kinds of naan bread (regular and garlic), beef skewers, and a chicken curry dish.  Nothing really stood out to me....actually I was disappointed in the food.  Everything was just meh.  I also ordered a mango lassi - was looking forward to one all day and again was disappointed.  It was a bit sour - too much yogurt.  Service was average - you walk up to the counter to order your food, pay and wait for your number to be called.  Food came out quick...5-7 minutes and we were eating.  Since the food didnt do it for me, I won't be coming back here.
author: Amy T.

description: the garlic naan here is excellent.  their cholays and daal's are also fantastic.  there's no atmosphere, it's a great place, but it's a quick, eat your food and then leave place.
author: Liz C.

description: if you're the kind of person that will add one star just because "the price is right," then Pakwan is for you.  i will almost always prefer cheap and fast to fancy indian food.  as long as it's spicy, full of flavor, and there's some delicious sauce to go with it, i'm a happy woman.
author: hillary h.

description: saag paneer, aloo palak, chicken tikka masala or kabab, rice, plain nan, and chai is all i ever need when i enter the doors of pakwan. i've had a lot of experience with indian food all over the city and in other large cities, and i must say, pakwan is my favorite indian/pakistani restaurant of all time! the quality of the food, the price of the food, and just the overall experience of the restaurant is enough to deem pakwan the best indian pakistani restaurant in san francisco.
author: Tina T.

description: the important thing about pakwan is that they consistently carry Nihari and Mirch Salan, two often overlooked or completely forgotten dishes at other indian/pakistanian restaurants.
author: christopher a.

description: the saag aloo and broiled fish are amazing.  the service, table fights, and post-meal gut-bombs are not.
author: schnarf-a-larf a.

description:
In response to a prior review, I don't know if everyone here is nuts, because I haven't tasted any nuts in the dishes at Pakwan. Bahahaha, I slay me...

In any case, personally I love this place. I come her regularly with a friend, and this is a wonderful place to catch an affordable meal and have some downtime/catch-up time. In general, I like eating Indian food because of all the vegetarian options, and Pakwan doesn't fail. The pakora makes for a hearty appetizer, and all the different kinds of naan are awesome, though with cheese naan and garlic naan available, I recommend holding off on plain naan for the places that only offer plain. There's an eggplant dish that I really like, but the posted specials are usually experiments that end in success for me. The atmosphere is also wonderful, too --- kind of like a cafeteria, but more animated and lively. I'm also very impressed with the restroom, which used to be a dump, according to my friend who's eaten there for years. I never saw the restroom in its prior incarnation, but currently it's very well maintained.

Self-service is the name of the game here. You place your order at the counter, take a number, and wait to pick up your food at the other end of the counter. Water and other beverages are accessible from a side refrigerator, as well as all your utensils. Service attitude varies, but they're generally quite friendly. One guy at the register took pity on me when I was short a few cents. I insisted on going back to my table and getting the required amount from my backpack, but he waved away my effort. That certainly earned him a well-deserved tip in all those carafe tip jars that you see lined up next to the register.
author: Joseph R.

description: Guaranteed to satisfy Indian/Pakistani cravings for cheap.  BYOB, too - load up at the liquor store across the street.
author: J R.

description: this place is really good. im a die hard shalimar person, but this place offers you more variety like achar chicken and lamb vindaloo etc. and the meat is halal
author: Naureen H.

description: This place is "holy shit" good.  Every time I go there, I am shocked how delicious it is.  The prices are crazy low.  You can bring your own beer, which I love.  Plenty of vegeratrian options.  Try the different nans.   If only they delivered...
author: Rainforest C.

description: my fav for cheap indian food.  chicken tikka masala...so good.
author: Julia H.

description: yes, everyone's been here, loves it, and has reviewed it...so what?  i will too because i love me some pakistani/indian food.  yes parking is a bitch, but as strange as it sounds, the food at this pakwan kicks all other pakwan's arses, so keep circling til you find a landing pad.
author: cat c.

description: generous portions of food...we looked at the pictures they had at the restaurant and thought the portions would be small.. then when it came, we were pleasantly surprised.. so we ordered way too much food.. prices are cheap.. food was a good level of spiciness.. would go back there - worth the money spent..
author: Linda Y.

description: one of the most underrated pakistani-indian restaurants in the bay area.  its cheap, quick, has free chai, and both tamarind and cilantro chutney.  really, what more could you ask for from a bare bones eatery from the subcontinent?  well maybe, something not swimming grease!  on the whole however, Pakwan is a formidable Shalimar challenger and certainly bitch-slaps some more expensive spots like Rotee, Naan and Curry, etc.
author: greg B.

description: Cheap and tasty. Can get crowded on the weekends. I think that the other Indian place on 16th is cheaper but more oily. The guy who works at the counter can be a little creepy...he always stares at women in line.
author: Jessie H.

description: this place rocks  try the pakoras,  chicken tiki masala and tandoori chicken go across the street and bring a beer in.  this place is dynamite!!!!
author: bruce r.

description: Pakwan is everything you can ask for in a late-night, post-bar food experience.  The spices are great and the tandoor gives an even smokier flavor to the meat as foot traffic increases.  Grab some drinks from the liquor store across the street if you want to BYOB.  My only suggestion is to avoid sitting in the back near the bathroom.  Doesn't smell too great.
author: Jose W.

description: ah, pakwan. back when i worked in potrero hill, pakwan was the destination lunch restaurant for me and my one cool coworker. we would sneak out and take the 22 up 16th street, jumping off at the corner of guerrero and running up to the (usually filthy) counter to order benghan bartha and chicken tikka masala from the (always disgustingly) lecherous staff. and hour and a half later, we would sneak back in to work, hoping beyond hope that no one would notice that we reeked of onions and spices... sadly, pakwan doesn't quite live up to my fond memories. i ate here recently and was soooorely disappointed. but still, for obscenely cheap and edible indian food, this is the place.
author: oona m.

description: By far one of the better Indian/Pakistani food in SF! The food is def cheap.  If you want a classier place/good food...go to Amber.
author: Jag B.

description: I've had most of the veggie dishes here. They all kind of taste similar and a little bland, there's not any one that stands out. The rice is always cold, I feel rushed and it can be loud.
author: Sarah J.

description: this place is a worthy spot, do not mistake that. the naan is the weakest link though, a distant shame and downer. but any of the gosht (when i consumed meat) were phenomenal. exactly what i want in a curry, incredibly thick and teaming over with spices and heat. mirch salon. do it.
author: Christopher J.

description: Cheap and delicious, especially the tandoor chicken and melt-in-your-mouth nihari -- not sure how to reconcile this with the sketchy DPH food inspection rating scores. Seating is a pain in the arse: first you place your order; when a table vacates you trade elbows with all of the other people trying to get the same table; and then the kitchen starts preparing your food. Very annoying, and I'll probably just stick to Naan'n'Curry because of it.
author: A. T.

description: That's right--this is a five star joint. My roommates and I go here at LEAST once a week--and that's a sad, empty week when we only make it once. The food is cheap and extremely delicious. The eggplant and the lentils are INCREDIBLE. I am not exaggerating.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Hands down my favorite Pakistani/Indian place in the Bay Area.  The Chicken Tika Masala is to die for.  Come here for the food, not for the service or the decor.  But it begs the question... why would you want to eat this type of food in a nice place?  It would ruin the down home, comfort food feeling.
author: Tuyen V.

description: I live right across the street from this place.  Although, I was never a huge fan--I do find many of the dishes too oily--I would eat here regularly.  The most recent time I was there, I order the Saag Gosht (spinach and lamb) and got very sick.  I've noticed before that they often have a pile of raw chicken on their back counter.  I often have a craving for spicy food, but am reluctant to go back here.  As someone else mentioned they have a poor score from the department of health.  Eat there at your own risk.
author: duggy e.

description: my friend took me there about two weeks ago and i've already been back twice. they have good prices, i'm in love with their nan, rice, lamb chops, and the chicken tikka masala and i enjoy the hole in the wall atmosphere
author: Star C.

description: I have been to this place several times and found that the food is ok if the place is not very busy but if it is busy, the food can be hit or miss and I often wonder how fresh it is. The tandoori items are safe and the price is definitely reasonable.
author: Nadeem R.

description: Pakwan rocks!  Really authentic "dhaba" style Indo-Pakistani eats. Very inexpensive. Definitely take a look at the daily specials as those end up being the best thing available. My picks: achari gosht, the okra special,  mirch salan...
author: Charlie P.

description: good Pakistani food. the nihari, seekh kabobs are done well.
author: dha A.

description: LOVE this place.  The spices are amazing, the meat is tender and perfectly marinated.  The prices are absolutely reasonable.  The people are also very hospitable.  I am not one of those yuppies who puts a great deal of stock on ambience...as at the end of the day...I just want good food, fair portions at an affordable price.  Pakwan meets all of these requirements.  They're accommodating if there are many in a party and we just want to put tables and chairs together.  Give it a try, not to mention it's on a street full of cool shops that you can check out if you are waiting for a table or your take out to be ready.
author: Charisse L.

description: Better than most Indian/ Pakistani joints in the city.  Note, this location is a lot better than the other two.
author: Phi N.

description: The food and prices are as good as it gets.  Flavorful food, fun/casual ambiance.  I especially love their samosas.  Parking can be a bit annoying, but sometimes you luck out with a spot in front (weeknights).
author: Sarah K.

description: love their naan! potato stuffed naan, garlic naan, and plain naan! it's so big and cheap too. fresh and delicious with their meat or veggie dishes. I love how you don't have to tip at this place since it's self service but it's clean. I always get their refreshing mango lassi too! Very authentic!
author: WK H.

description: the tandoori bbq is outstanding! prices are great, atmosphere is casual and bustling.
author: Ben H.

description: what an overrated dump. oily, low-quality ingredients. the naan even goes stale before it cools off. eat here if you want to get sick.
author: steven w.

description: the benghan barhta is so filling . there's nothing like it.
author: michelle b.
